webTitle: Merson to quit in two years

fields.headline: Merson to quit in two years
fields.trailText: Aston Villa midfielder Paul Merson will retire when his current contract runs out in two years' time.
fields.body:
Aston Villa midfielder Paul Merson will retire when his current contract runs out in two years' time.

And the former England, Arsenal and Middlesbrough player, who is keen to move into management, will quit earlier if he can win a trophy with Villa during that period.

Merson said: "I want to win things. I've got two years left at Villa and then probably that will be it. I'll finish playing football.

"I am 33 now and a lot of people say I am playing better than I ever have and I probably am.

"But two years ago at 31 I was playing the worst football I've ever played. I am not silly. I know how football changes around and how quickly you can lose form.

"I want to win one more medal. I think if I did that I'd finish there are then. If Villa got to the cup final next season and we won it I'd finish then".

Meanwhile, Merson, is urging Villa manager John Gregory to bring in quality young players before the current team becomes too old to play in the Premiership.

But he is asking the club and fans to be patient with the Villa chief and give him time to rebuild the side.

Merson warned: "A full strength Villa team in two years will see seven players not here. That won't be because they've left the club. They will be too old to play and I am one of them. That's just me being honest.

"What you have to do is buy good quality young players, let them train with quality players and by the time we all finish they'll be ready to jump in and they'll be a quality team.

"But everyone has to be patient. The fans have to understand that you just can't go crash, bang wallop and find you have a championship-winning team. It takes time."

webTitle: How psychometric testing became big business

fields.headline: The truth will out
fields.standfirst:
Carl Filer was a star salesman for B&Q. He hit the headlines last week when the results of his personality test came through - and he got the sack. Adrian Furnham and Anita Chaudhuri on how psychometric testing became big business

Guardian Unlimited Work
fields.trailText: Carl Filer was a star salesman for B&Q. He hit the headlines last week when the results of his personality test came through - and he got the sack. Adrian Furnham and Anita Chaudhuri on how psychometric testing became big business.
fields.body:
It was, perhaps, the circumstances rather than the fact of Carl Filer's dismissal from what was shaping up to be a promising career at B&Q that stung the most. One might argue that anyone who responds to a computerised personality interview by saying that you "strongly disagree" that you are an overachiever had it coming to them in any case, but Filer had already demonstrated himself to be a star salesman at the DIY chain's Bournemouth branch when the results of the 50-question psychometric test came through last week. His bosses were unhappy with the results and escorted him from the premises.

He was by no means the only employee to take issue with a computerised measure of his character. Some years ago, a group of cleaners were upset to have their future employment decided on the basis of a test with multiple-choice questions including the following: "Would you rather be a) an archbishop or b) a general?" Another group went to court when a language-based personality test proved an excellent discriminator between first-generation immigrants, none of whom ended up with jobs, and those who were rather more practised in speaking English, who did.

Nevertheless, personality testing is big business. A handful of major players - such as SHL, Oxford Psychological Press and the Gallup Organisation - dominate the industry, with the support of the human-resources professionals who are their heaviest users. According to which data you believe, between 10% and 40% of big British companies use personality tests to select new recruits - with a similar number employing intelligence testing.

According to the Industrial Society, 5,000 different tests are currently being used to select more than half the managers in Britain, and even in high-technology posts, where technical knowledge is arguably rather more crucial than a sunny disposition, psychometric testing is used in 37% of recruitment. Enthusiasts argue there is plenty of predictive validity in such tests - they really do predict absenteeism, morale and productivity over time. Cynics would say it is a case of dissonance reduction - of employers wanting passionately to believe in tests for which they have parted with a large amount of money.

The man who must bear at least some of the responsibility for all this is Sir Frances Galton who, in the 1880s persuaded over 9,000 people to be personality-tested in his "anthropometric laboratory" at the Science Museum in South Kensington. But the first personality test, as a beleaguered interview candidate might recognise it today, was developed by the American army in 1917. They wanted to weed out recruits who couldn't stand the stress of battle.

Wars proved fruitful times for the testers. Faced with millions of conscripts, military chiefs yearned for a simple method to select one person for fighter-pilot training, another for the pay corps or another for the military police. Psychologists hurried to meet the demand, and two world wars later, the test as lucrative business was sweeping America. In Britain the key factor was the mass layoffs of the 1980s, and the subsequent inundation of firms with applicants. Testing seemed a cheap, reliable and sensible alternative to the expensive, time-consuming interview.

As the practice has become more refined, the ambitions of the testers have developed from merely detecting the "positive" personalities to probing the "dark side": pathology and personality disorders. Increasingly, tests are used to try to detect high-flyers who may subsequently derail, or to stop psychopaths getting recruited. But their ambitions go further still. "We are heading for the era of genetic screening," warns Carolyn Jones, of the Institute for Employment Rights, referring to the suggestion that one day interviewees could be given a mouth swab which could reveal the genetic and biological markers of personality.

There are, of course, all sorts of problems. Critics argue that people can easily lie - though testers have developed tricks to combat this in return - or that anxiety, headaches or period pains might lead to different answers on different occasions. But the big one is the argument that the tests are invalid: they simply do not measure what they say they measure. The current state of the science suggests some variables - neuroticism and conscientiousness, for example - can be predicted with some certainty, but the jury is still out. Measuring the validity of the tests is expensive; few recruiters treat it as a priority.

"Personally, I think these tests are very flawed," says Carolyn Jones, who calls them "just another mechanism to allow employers to filter out workers who do not fit. You do have to wonder exactly what they're looking for."

Ben Williams, a psychologist who scores psychometric tests for a living, acknowledges their limitations. "Testing can accurately predict behaviour to within certain parameters, and it can suss out whether the person giving super-flannel in an interview will actually be capable of doing the job required," he says. "Problems tend to occur if a company doesn't understand what profile it needs in its employers, or standardises the profile in order to save time and money." He confesses to sometimes sounding harsh in his test reports. "When we hand in our reports, employers probably believe about 75% of it, whereas the candidate's partner will believe 98% because they're more likely to already know the person's weaknesses."

The test publishers, wary of controversy, point out that the tool has to be used wisely. "We certainly wouldn't recommend running the test on someone who was already working there," says Jill Garrett, managing director of Gallup, of Mr Filer's case. Surely if an employee was seen to be good at their job but failed the test, the test might be at fault? "Not necessarily," she says. "But any psychometrician will be the first to admit that no test can be 100% accurate."

The sacking of Carl Filer will bring the critics out of the woodwork again, rehearsing the same familiar arguments. But most people agree that ability, personality and motivation are the most important predictors of work success and failure. At the heart of the issue lies the unresolved, perhaps unresolvable question: how can you actually measure a quantity as shifting and vague as personality in the first place?

The answer, ultimately, is that you do your homework: there are thousands of tests on the market, and only a few with enough data to give much credit to their claims of validity. Are they backed up by how people go on to perform in their jobs? This, perhaps, is the question that needs to be asked both by the selection professionals who fund the industry - and by the lawyers acting on behalf of those who don't quite fit the profile.

 Adrian Furnham is professor of Psychology at University College London and the author of various books on personality theory and testing.

What are you like?

Excerpts adapted from a personality test currently in use by recruiters:

1 Do you have a small, but "close knit" circle of friends?

2 Do you prefer to take your time over a task?

3 Do you enjoy meeting new people?

4 Are you usually punctual for meetings?

5 Do you find it easy to make friends with new people?

6 Do you enjoy solving practical problems?

7 Do you like taking the lead in group discussions?

8 Do you prefer to do a routine job?

9 When upset, do you prefer to be left alone?

10 Do you like looking at intricately designed buildings?

11 Would you say you are strongly opinionated?

12 Do you tend to act impulsively on your desires at the time?

13 Are you happy with the way you look?

14 Do you normally notice things which others ignore?

15 Do you feel good about yourself?

16 Do your friends think of you as quite a dependable person?

17 Would you say that you know people from a variety of backgrounds?

18 Are you a good time-keeper?

19 Would you help a friend out even though it was inconvenient?

20 Would you prefer a quiet night in or to go to a bar with some friends?

How did you do?

Sociability: questions 1, 5, 9, 17, 20.

Attention to detail: 2, 6, 8, 10, 14.

Self confidence: 3, 7, 11, 13,15.

Reliability: 4, 12, 16, 18, 19.

If you answered yes to 3 or more questions in each section, an employer would be likely to assess you as showing the positive personality characteristic being measured. (A greater number of questions would be included in a valid test). "Test results should be one part of the selection process and an interview is essential to discuss findings and give feedback to the candidate," says Siobhan Hamilton-Phillips of the Career Psychology consultancy.

 Test provided by Career Psychology.

webTitle: Bernard Arnault's escape from the net

fields.headline: Escape of the cybercaesar
fields.standfirst:
The dot.com strategy of France's richest man has fallen apart but Bernard Arnault still looks likely to come out on top

More internet news
fields.trailText: The dot.com strategy of France's richest man has fallen apart but Bernard Arnault still looks likely to come out on top. By Randeep Ramesh.
fields.body:
You cannot walk directly into Bernard Arnault's personal office in the fashionable eighth arrondissement of Paris. A camera bears down on any visitor to the French billionaire's room and a bullet-proof glass door only silently withdraws once you have been inspected by his bodyguards.

Getting in to see the owner of Louis Vuitton, Christian Dior and Givenchy once meant you probably could afford one of his company's £40,000 Ebel watches or a bottle of £150 Dom Perignon champagne, another Arnault brand.

Then France's richest man discovered the internet. Besuited executives at haute couture house LVMH, where Arnault is chief executive and largest shareholder, watched bright young things bowl into their offices attired in jeans and worn sweatshirts. "They aren't concerned with fashion," Arnault told reporters. "They wear the Gap."

What these cyber-entrepreneurs were concerned with was making money fast - something the LVMH boss appreciated. He had quietly built an impressive US portfolio of net stocks - with £60m invested in music site MP3.com and £6m in eBay. These were minority stakes in the pre-flotation rounds of financing and, according to market watchers, were then worth "a couple of billion dollars".

Emboldened by his American experience, Arnault prepared to grab a large chunk of European cyberspace. He set up an investment fund, Europ@web, with 80m euros (£50m) of his own cash to put into an array of net ventures.

The focus, initially, was Europe. A little more than 31m euros went into eLuxury, a retail site that would do for LVMH's brands what Amazon was doing for books. Arnault also owned Phillips auctioneers and considered online marketplaces a good bet. QXL and iCollector of Britain received nearly 38m euros between them, while Aucland.com in France was pumped up with 16m euros.

Arnault was not just interested in moving his brands to the net. Europ@web squirted 80m euros into Zebank, which was to be the continent's premier online bank, and bought 35% of internet service provider LibertySurf for 54m euros. By the end of 1999 Arnault had holdings in 19 companies.

The pope of fashion, as Arnault had been labelled, appeared intent on being the caesar of cyberspace. Europ@web sprawled over the globe. More than 17m euros went into Submarino - an online retailer in Brazil. Another 10m euros was poured into liquidation.com, a business-to-business marketplace based in Washington.

Europ@web opened nine offices in Europe and the US, hired 100 investment professionals and administered a fund of 500m euros. By summer 2000, Arnault's sortie into cyberspace had netted him stakes in 42 companies.

Then the campaign faltered. Just as Arnault was readying to float Europ@web for 3bn euros, fashion website Boo.com burned out. More than $135m (£94m) went up in flames - $12m belonging to Arnault. Worse the Nasdaq fell, at first slowly and then inexorably into freefall.

"Bernard Arnault can be extremely charming but he is ruthless," said one source, who refused to be named. "He has an almost photographic memory and can recall the smallest details of bids put to him. But if he decides that he must get out of a deal, he seems to forget that he was once enthusiastic about it, too."

Plans to float were first delayed and now appear indefinitely postponed. Executives in Europ@web used to a meeting a week with Arnault found that they were cancelled.

"We were on our own," said one former Europ@web staffer on the continent. "One of the guys from Paris said when the markets recover Bernard will call us again. In July the float was pulled. In August there were rumours of a broadband push and then by September just silence. It was more regal than arrogant. After all, he was Caesar."

The air is now being let out of Europ@web's bubble - so slowly no one will notice the hiss. Earlier this month, dot.com newsletter Industry Standard closed its European office, which was backed by Arnault, with the loss of 60 jobs. Moonfruit, a website tool company, into which Europ@web ploughed 8m euros for a 30% stake, is up for sale - minus its 50 staff. Sources say Moonfruit managed only £100,000 revenue for 2000. AKA Technology, a joint venture between Europ@web, Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and Accel, which made headlines when announced last autumn, has been quietly sidelined.

The sale of assets began with LibertySurf in January. The ISP was sold in a cash-and-shares deal to Italian rival Tiscali, netting Arnault more than 280m euros. Another looming sale is that of Zebank, which started operations in France last month after a much-delayed launch. City sources confirm it is in talks with Egg, Prudential's online bank.

"Europ@web have realised they cannot launch an online bank in every major European capital in the current environment and are looking for a possible partner," said a source in the Square Mile.

Peoplesound, a music dot.com, received 6m euros from Europ@web two summers ago and impressed record companies with software that tracks who listens, downloads and pays for music on the web. Asked about possible offers for the company, Martin Turner, a co-founder, said: "It is an interesting perspective. Consolidation is very much the driving force of survival at this point of time. It would be negligent for anybody to neglect the opportunities provided by consolidation."

In some cases Europ@web asked executives to hand back a chunk of their remaining cash. "They want their money back," said a source at one Arnault-funded dot.com. "Even if you could reach profitability by, say, cutting back on staff and offices, Europ@web are not interested because the valuations of internet companies are so low they would not recoup their investment."

Much of the strategy has fallen apart in the tech market turmoil. Europ@web paid 30m euros for a chunk of online auctioneer QXL in June 1999. Today the stake is worth less than 3m euros. Another online marketplace, iCollector, received 8m euros. Europ@web's 1.5m shares in iCollector are priced at 50p, but the stock trades on Ofex in London at 8.5p.

There are many in the Arnault fold who remain bullish. One darling is flutter.com. The betting site secured more than 45m euros in funding - 20m euros coming from Europ@web for 36% of the company. According to the chief executive, Josh Hannah, it has "$28m in the bank" and generated more than £500,000 last year by taking a cut on each bet placed.

The question is whether it can become profitable before needing extra cash. "We don't have any competition and are growing at 35% a month so I am pretty confident of success," says Hannah.

There are few willing to discount the possibility that Arnault's exit route from the internet will work. In February, Europ@web closed seven of its nine offices and let go of most of its investment staff. Phillip Jaffre, the former boss of Elf, the oil company, was brought in as chief executive - replacing the 33-year-old brash but brilliant Chachram Becharat. Age and experience was in, youthful exuberance out.

By now Arnault was entranced by the possibilities of third-generation mobile phones. "Arnault became infatuated with 3G," said another source. "All of a sudden it was internet bad, 3G good."

Europ@web had a 300m euro cash boost in November when French industrial conglomerate Suez Lyonnaise des Eaux took a 33% stake. As part of the deal Arnault took 6% in a Suez-backed consortium, along with Telefonica of Spain, to bid for a 3G licence in France. The theory was that not only would Suez get the use of Arnault's financial muscle, but also also turn Europ@web into a "3G powerhouse".

Then Suez pulled out of bidding for licences in France and Belgium, leaving it with a large stake in Europ@web and Arnault with hundreds of millions of euros. The deal did not include any stake in Zebank, cash and shares from the LibertySurf deal, eLuxury or AKA Technologies.

"Bernard Arnault definitely got the better end of the deal," says Matt Lewis, an analyst at research house ARCchart. "Without a 3G licence why would Suez want a bunch of at best medium-performing internet investments?"

According to bankers familiar with the deal, Europ@web and the four other ventures are worth more than 1.2bn euros - leaving Arnault ahead on paper by 500m euros. As becomes one of Europe's most remarkable dealmakers, Arnault appears to be escaping from the web as quickly as he became entwined by it.

Where the euros went

Europ@web's biggest investments (euros) and stake (%)

Zebank | 82m | 70%

LibertySurf | 54m | 35%

Eluxury | 31m | 40%

QXL | 30m | 10%

ProXchange | 28m | 25%

Sportal | 20m | 10%

LeisurePlanet | 20m | 20%

Source: Guardian research

Moonfruit, a website tool company, into which Europ@web ploughed 8m euros for a 30% stake, is up for sale - minus its 50 staff. Sources say Moonfruit managed only £100,000 revenue for 2000. AKA Technology, a joint venture between Europ@web, Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and Accel, which made headlines when announced last autumn, has been quietly sidelined. The sale of assets began with LibertySurf in January. The ISP was sold in a cash-and-shares deal to Italian rival Tiscali, netting Arnault more than 280m euros. Another looming sale is that of Zebank, which started operations in France last month after a much-delayed launch. City sources confirm it is in talks with Egg, Prudential's online bank. "Europ@web have realised they cannot launch an online bank in every major European capital in the current environment and are looking for a possible partner," said a source in the Square Mile. Peoplesound, a music dot.com, received 6m euros from Europ@web two summers ago and impressed record companies with software that tracks who listens, downloads and pays for music on the web. Asked about possible offers for the company, Martin Turner, a co-founder, said: "It is an interesting perspective. Consolidation is very much the driving force of survival at this point of time. It would be negligent for anybody to neglect the opportunities provided by consolidation." In some cases Europ@web asked executives to hand back a chunk of their remaining cash. "They want their money back," said a source at one Arnault-funded dot.com. "Even if you could reach profitability by, say, cutting back on staff and offices, Europ@web are not interested because the valuations of internet companies are so low they would not recoup their investment." Much of the strategy has fallen apart in the tech market turmoil. Europ@web paid 30m euros for a chunk of online auctioneer QXL in June 1999. Today the stake is worth less than 3m euros. Another online marketplace, iCollector, received 8m euros. Europ@web's 1.5m shares in iCollector are priced at 50p, but the stock trades on Ofex in London at 8.5p. There are many in the Arnault fold who remain bullish. One darling is flutter.com. The betting site secured more than 45m euros in funding - 20m euros coming from Europ@web for 36% of the company. According to the chief executive, Josh Hannah, it has "$28m in the bank" and generated more than £500,000 last year by taking a cut on each bet placed. The question is whether it can become profitable before needing extra cash. "We don't have any competition and are growing at 35% a month so I am pretty confident of success," says Hannah. There are few willing to discount the possibility that Arnault's exit route from the internet will work. In February, Europ@web closed seven of its nine offices and let go of most of its investment staff. Phillip Jaffre, the former boss of Elf, the oil company, was brought in as chief executive - replacing the 33-year-old brash but brilliant Chachram Becharat. Age and experience was in, youthful exuberance out. By now Arnault was entranced by the possibilities of third-generation mobile phones. "Arnault became infatuated with 3G," said another source. "All of a sudden it was internet bad, 3G good." Europ@web had a 300m euro cash boost in November when French industrial conglomerate Suez Lyonnaise des Eaux took a 33% stake. As part of the deal Arnault took 6% in a Suez-backed consortium, along with Telefonica of Spain, to bid for a 3G licence in France. The theory was that not only would Suez get the use of Arnault's financial muscle, but also also turn Europ@web into a "3G powerhouse". Then Suez pulled out of bidding for licences in France and Belgium, leaving it with a large stake in Europ@web and Arnault with hundreds of millions of euros. The deal did not include any stake in Zebank, cash and shares from the LibertySurf deal, eLuxury or AKA Technologies. "Bernard Arnault definitely got the better end of the deal," says Matt Lewis, an analyst at research house ARCchart. "Without a 3G licence why would Suez want a bunch of at best medium-performing internet investments?" According to bankers familiar with the deal, Europ@web and the four other ventures are worth more than 1.2bn euros - leaving Arnault ahead on paper by 500m euros. As becomes one of Europe's most remarkable dealmakers, Arnault appears to be escaping from the web as quickly as he became entwined by it. fields.headline: Arditti Quartet
fields.standfirst:
Queen Elizabeth Hall, London
*****
fields.trailText:
Queen Elizabeth Hall, London
*****
fields.body:
The Arditti are a national treasure, the best in the world at what they do, and in a more enlightened musical culture than ours they would be venerated as much as the Amadeus Quartet were in their heyday. But because they have chosen to play almost exclusively 20th-century and new music, their pre-eminence is not honoured here as it should be. In continental Europe it is different: there the group is in constant demand. As a result, their London appearances have become rarer and rarer.

This recital, given as part of the South Bank's international chamber music season, was a welcome exception. The Arditti had chosen a programme of five quartets from the past 40 years that showed just how wide their musical sympathies are, and how they meet the challenges of everything they play with the same unstinting commitment and instinctive musicality. It was a long musical journey, from Thomas Adès's 1994 Arcadiana, with its evocations of lost Edens through quotation and impressionism, to Iannis Xenakis's ferocious Tetras, which he wrote for the Arditti in 1983, and which remains the quartet's most startling tour de force.

But the playful, intricate canons of Conlon Nancarrow's 1989 Third Quartet, the splintered effects of Jonathan Harvey's 1995 Third, and the impacted fierceness of Giacinto Scelsi's Fourth (1964) offered challenges of equal intensity. Nancarrow's work is perfectly balanced, but Harvey's is not; for all the carefully worked detail of the string writing and the textural imagination behind it, the ideas never really cohere into something more, and it seems much longer than its 18 minutes. But for once a work by Scelsi did not outstay its welcome: the Arditti managed to sustain its arching curve of minutely inflected lines in a single concentrated statement.

A wonderfully executed recital then, let down only by the inadequate programme booklet, for which the audience was charged £2. Among other inaccuracies it indicated that Nancarrow, Scelsi and Xenakis are still with us; all, alas, are now dead.

webTitle: World music: Gutsy gospel from Alabama

fields.headline: Gutsy gospel from Alabama
fields.standfirst:
Blind Boys of Alabama
Mean Fiddler, London
****
fields.trailText:
Blind Boys of Alabama
Mean Fiddler, London
****
fields.body:
It was a brave decision to invite a group of elderly blind singers to perform gospel songs at the Mean Fiddler, a some-time disco next to a sex shop. It was an even braver decision for those singers to kick off with that cringe-making tear-jerker, I Believe, and to choose Danny Boy for their encore. But the result was a show that was poignant and exhilarating, even though there were moments when one feared for the health of the performers.

The Blind Boys of Alabama are an extraordinary institution. Founded in 1939 by Clarence Fountain, who still leads the group today, they first got together as students at the Talladega Institute for the Blind in Alabama. They were taught pop songs by their white teachers, and they studied the black gospel styles of classic groups such as the Golden Gate Quartet.

From this they developed their own eclectic approach, and the ability to match their four-part harmonies to anything from hymns to R&B, pop or funk. It's a process that still continues, as Fountain and long-term colleagues Jimmy Carter and George Scott prove on the Blind Boys' fine new album, Spirit of the Century, in which they mix gospel standards with songs by Tom Waits or Ben Harper.

Their vocal power is still immense. They came onstage (or were helped on) wearing grey collarless suits, gold shirts and dark glasses, looking like frail retired gangsters, and they often sat motionless when they were not singing. Then they would burst into life, sometimes shaking with enthusiasm as they swapped lead vocals and added rousing harmonies. Much of the set consisted of traditional gospel favourites, from Nobody's Fault But Mine through to Run on for a Long Time, with the songs revived and updated both through the passion of the performers and their often modern new arrangements.

Amazing Grace was treated as a gutsy rewrite of House of the Rising Sun, and What a Friend We Have in Jesus was tackled with fervour and some almost screamed vocal embellishments worthy of the young James Brown. By the end, they had transformed the Mean Fiddler into an unlikely revivalist meeting. They told touching, funny stories of how they had been saved by their faith, and ended with a frantic gospel workout, while Jimmy Carter was led out into the crowd, dancing and shaking hands.

fields.headline: UK net user numbers grow despite dot.coms crash
fields.standfirst: More internet news
fields.trailText: As many as 9m homes in Britain are connected to the net, underlining its growing popularity, figures revealed yesterday, writes Julia Snoddy.
fields.body:
As many as 9m homes in Britain are connected to the net, underlining its growing popularity, figures revealed yesterday.

According to data from net monitoring firm Netvalue, more than a third of British homes are online - which means Britain is ahead of France and Germany in terms of penetration but lags behind Denmark and the US.

The company also claims 12.7m people were using the net at home in March - the first time the number of home users has reached more than 12m, Netvalue says - and 1.4m households have been connected in the last six months.

"The population of the internet is growing across the age groups and backgrounds. More people are going online and spending more time online. Users' confidence has developed and more people are doing things like shopping or banking on the web. The internet has become much more mass market," a Netvalue spokesperson said.

The company, which surveys a panel of 3,000 people every month, also found that the number of women on the web has continued to grow and "silver surfers" - people aged over 65 - have adopted the internet most rapidly.

Almost 5m women used the net in March, compared to 3.9m in October. More than 2m of those women went on to make a secure connection and give their credit card details. Use of the internet by the 65-plus age group increased by 34% over the six months between October last year and March 2001.

"The internet is still growing in popularity despite the dot.com companies going under and the collapse of share prices in the techsector. It is not affecting usage at all," the Netvalue spokesperson said.

The survey also had some good news for beleaguered BT. Yell.com, BT's online directory service, was the most visited directory website with nearly 1m users. Yell.com was also the 10th most active advertiser, reaching over a fifth of all home internet users.

Dell.com was the biggest online advertiser according to Netvalue.

Net researcher Jupiter MMXI said its figures for March show that 8.4m households in Britain are connected and 13.7m people are online at home.

fields.headline: Colin Matthews and the horn at twilight
fields.standfirst:
Colin Matthews premiere
Royal Festival Hall, London
****
fields.trailText:
Colin Matthews premiere
Royal Festival Hall, London
****
fields.body:
Writing for the horn carries so many implied associations. No other orchestral instrument, save perhaps the trumpet, brings as much specific baggage with it. What the horn can do, it does consummately, and it always conjures up very precise musical worlds. Composers embarking on a horn concerto ignore that indelible character at their peril.

In his new work Colin Matthews has been happy to go along with those intrinsic elements. His Horn Concerto was given its first performance by the soloist Richard Watkins, with the Philharmonia (which commissioned it) under Esa-Pekka Salonen. It is a 20-minute single movement that inhabits an enchanted nocturnal world of mysterious rustlings, dappled shading and subterranean movements, shot through with the haunting calls and singing, expressive melodic lines that define the instrument's essence.

The orchestration reflects that twilight world: the strings are often muted and frequently subdivided; flugel horns rather than trumpets line up in the brass. The horn section is positioned offstage; their bracing, hunting mottos open the concerto from the wings, answered by their soloist colleague. As he migrates across the platform during the course of the work they punctuate the dialogue with varied versions of their original calls.

The work follows a clear arch, with a darting, fugitive scherzo at its centre, which eventually dissolves into the most luminous music in the whole score, as the solo horn's high-lying lines are clothed in the glitter of tuned percussion and usher in the long, lingering coda. It is a totally lucid and satisfying scheme.

Matthews was moved to write a horn concerto by Watkins's artistry, and the wonderful legato and supple phrasing that his soloist produced must have delighted him. Salonen made sure the beguiling orchestral textures were evoked with total precision.

The work was framed with Bartok's Divertimento for Strings and Sibelius's Fifth Symphony, but there was also some unannounced Sibelius to begin the concert, for the saddest of reasons. Giuseppe Sinopoli, the Philharmonia's musical director from 1983 to 1994, died suddenly in Berlin on Friday at the age of 54. Salonen conducted the Death of Melisande from the Pelleas and Melisande Suite in touching, eloquent tribute.

webTitle: Charlotte Raven on the May-Day protests

fields.headline: Why the anti-capitalists are fools
fields.trailText: Every year around this time, I am vaguely troubled by my reaction to a movement which I feel I should support: the May Day protests.
fields.body:
Every year around this time, I am vaguely troubled by my reaction to a movement which I feel I should support. The forthcoming May Day protests have caused me a lot of soul searching and, even as I'm writing this, I'm not sure whether my suspicion of the "new left", as veteran journalist John Lloyd called them this week, is petty or intellectually sound.

On the petty side, I've never been one for street parties as a form of political protest. They're too much fun for the participants, who approach the day with the misconceived notion that they are its primary focus. According to their websites, May Day is about releasing the "imagination and creativity" of the people taking part. No one knows quite what will happen because the shape of things is dictated by the individual's whim - rather than the will of the collective which deferred, in former times, to the demands of clarity and coherence.

In those days, the frustrated performance artists who latched on to political protests for their own egotistical ends were rightly consigned to the margins. Jugglers and fire-eaters knew their place. Now, thanks to the peculiar character of the global anti-capitalist movement, they're the people calling the shots. The unicycle brigade are now in charge of everything - from thinking up funny ha-ha acronyms for their activist cells, to mobilising fellow protesters to star in street theatre events.

It's the ordinary people - those whose contempt for the system is neither a source of creative inspiration nor an excuse for wearing silly outfits - who are now on the periphery. None of the lefties or trade unionists I know are planning to take part in May Day. While broadly supporting its aims they, like me, are irritated by the movement's propensity to forget that opposition to the market didn't begin in the 90s.

I guess this is petty as well, but the curious historical ignorance of the anti-capitalist activists really gets up my nose. Making no reference whatever to any ideological antecedents, they talk for all the world as if they were the first ones to notice that the market's drive to profit is achieved through exploitation. All the way through Naomi Klein's No Logo, I wanted to shout, "I KNOW", as you would if you were sitting in a sauna with someone who tried to warn you that the room was usually hot. Her contention, that the connection between products and the sweated labour that produced them was first made in 1995, makes amusing reading for anyone whose conviction that these links existed predated the Nike swoosh.

Whatever the reasons for these omissions, the key to understanding the modern anti-capitalist movement is its belief in its own uniqueness. We are told again and again that it is not a movement so much as a global network of like-minded individuals and groups whose activities are coordinated through the internet. Unlike any previous anti-capitalist organisations, it has no platform or programme beyond the humiliation of "big business" - yet what is this if not a statement of aims?

The movement is disingenuous when it pretends that its failure to fully flesh out its ideas is an unavoidable consequence of not having a postal address. In fact, it has a number of shared presumptions which together could be said to comprise a programme if only they would admit it. They don't want to, of course, because to do so would be to accept that a "line" does exist that has not been arrived at democratically.

One of these assumptions is the belief that multinational corporations are the root cause of human suffering. For an old style anti-capitalist, this would be a bit like blaming the girl in the call centre for the phone's queuing system. She is an administrator - a symptom of the system rather than the cause of the problem. It's the same with multinationals - they may be bigger than they ever have been, but their function within the system is the same, and that is to generate profit. They can't do anything else. Morality doesn't come into it.

To describe them as "wicked", as the modern anti-capitalists do, is to act as if they have any choice. Corporations generate profit through exploitation - this is not contestable ground. If they didn't exploit, they wouldn't exist. It is therefore fanciful to base a campaigning strategy on holding them "accountable" for their actions. It's like holding a cow accountable for shitting - you could make her do it somewhere else but you'd have to kill her before you could make her stop.

Far from being a threat to the system, the self-styled anti-capitalist movement has a paltry reformist agenda. Naomi Klein believes that multinationals should be "subject to the same accountability, controls and transparency that we demand of our public institutions". Perhaps they should - but it wouldn't make a blind bit of difference. People would still be charged more for a pair of trainers than it cost to produce them, workers would still be paid less than a living wage to make them. No liberal democratic checks and balances can alter the intrinsic nature of these relationships.

If Nike moved out of Asia and shifted its production to the US, as all the campaigners want, how would that be a victory? The sweatshop workers who used to produce Air Jordans would be employed by another trainer manufacturer and the shoes would be made in the US by immigrant labour on the minimum wage. All those years of campaigning for that. Somebody should have pointed out that, really, there is no way that multinationals can operate ethically. One might be less awful than the next, but even the "responsive" one is still a machine for extracting value from the sweat of our collective brow.

Klein and others avoid these issues. As campaigners in a global arena, they are never in one place long enough to subject themselves to too much debate and their followers are too busy doing flashy new things with their websites to wonder what the whole thing really means. It's easy to take it all at face value - it seems so glamorous from a distance what with all those aliases and nuggets of misinformation - so that it's hard not to get drawn in. If you do this May Day, I'd advise you to treat it as harmless but pointless fun.

News I can use

I didn't watch the last season of Have I Got News For You because I thought it was smug and annoying. This wasn't based on anything - I just somehow thought that the fact that it had been going so long meant that it must have sacrificed the things that made it good in the first place. How can a satirical programme still be relevant after 10 years? And how can something so close to becoming a national institution not end up as part of the furniture?

I still don't know the answer to these questions but the first programme in the present series showed that I'd been wrong on all counts. If you didn't know, you'd think you were watching something in its second season. No one is trying too hard but, amazingly, neither Deayton nor the regular panelists seems to be complacent either. That said, they don't feel the need to reinvent the wheel every time it comes on. There's a confidence here that is so seldom found now on TV, which expresses itself as faith in the original formula. They never changed the set, because it worked perfectly well as it was. Comic conventions were left in place - Angus is still mocked for his vanity.

To manage to hold on to all this and somehow stop the thing from going stale is a feat that is achieved in no small part by the choice of guests. The Tracey Emin/John Humphrys stand-off this week was vintage stuff. Watching Paul Merton follow Emin's trains of thought to their bizarre and illogical conclusion, while behaving like a perfect gentleman towards her, made me feel, as all good UK TV does, peculiarly patriotic.

It's the same with multinationals - they may be bigger than they ever have been, but their function within the system is the same, and that is to generate profit. They can't do anything else. Morality doesn't come into it. To describe them as "wicked", as the modern anti-capitalists do, is to act as if they have any choice. Corporations generate profit through exploitation - this is not contestable ground. If they didn't exploit, they wouldn't exist. It is therefore fanciful to base a campaigning strategy on holding them "accountable" for their actions. It's like holding a cow accountable for shitting - you could make her do it somewhere else but you'd have to kill her before you could make her stop. Far from being a threat to the system, the self-styled anti-capitalist movement has a paltry reformist agenda. Naomi Klein believes that multinationals should be "subject to the same accountability, controls and transparency that we demand of our public institutions". Perhaps they should - but it wouldn't make a blind bit of difference. People would still be charged more for a pair of trainers than it cost to produce them, workers would still be paid less than a living wage to make them. No liberal democratic checks and balances can alter the intrinsic nature of these relationships. If Nike moved out of Asia and shifted its production to the US, as all the campaigners want, how would that be a victory? The sweatshop workers who used to produce Air Jordans would be employed by another trainer manufacturer and the shoes would be made in the US by immigrant labour on the minimum wage. All those years of campaigning for that. Somebody should have pointed out that, really, there is no way that multinationals can operate ethically. One might be less awful than the next, but even the "responsive" one is still a machine for extracting value from the sweat of our collective brow. Klein and others avoid these issues. As campaigners in a global arena, they are never in one place long enough to subject themselves to too much debate and their followers are too busy doing flashy new things with their websites to wonder what the whole thing really means. It's easy to take it all at face value - it seems so glamorous from a distance what with all those aliases and nuggets of misinformation - so that it's hard not to get drawn in. If you do this May Day, I'd advise you to treat it as harmless but pointless fun. News I can use I didn't watch the last season of Have I Got News For You because I thought it was smug and annoying. This wasn't based on anything - I just somehow thought that the fact that it had been going so long meant that it must have sacrificed the things that made it good in the first place. How can a satirical programme still be relevant after 10 years? And how can something so close to becoming a national institution not end up as part of the furniture? I still don't know the answer to these questions but the first programme in the present series showed that I'd been wrong on all counts. If you didn't know, you'd think you were watching something in its second season. No one is trying too hard but, amazingly, neither Deayton nor the regular panelists seems to be complacent either. That said, they don't feel the need to reinvent the wheel every time it comes on. There's a confidence here that is so seldom found now on TV, which expresses itself as faith in the original formula. They never changed the set, because it worked perfectly well as it was. Comic conventions were left in place - Angus is still mocked for his vanity. To manage to hold on to all this and somehow stop the thing from going stale is a feat that is achieved in no small part by the choice of guests. The Tracey Emin/John Humphrys stand-off this week was vintage stuff. Watching Paul Merton follow Emin's trains of thought to their bizarre and illogical conclusion, while behaving like a perfect gentleman towards her, made me feel, as all good UK TV does, peculiarly patriotic.

fields.headline: State of the Nation
fields.standfirst:
South Bank Centre, London
***
fields.trailText:
South Bank Centre, London
***
fields.body:
As a showcase of the newest music by the latest generation of composers, the London Sinfonietta's State of the Nation weekend is unique in the British music calendar. This year, the programme of world and UK premieres was as ambitious as ever: with conductors Pierre-André Valade and Garry Walker, the ensemble performed over a dozen new pieces in five concerts over two days.

Yet for State of the Nation to be more significant than a celebration of statistics and the superhuman stamina of performers and listeners, the new works have to live up to the hype of representing the best of new classical music. The range of styles, approaches and genres was typically wide: from Peter Batchelor's three-minute tape piece based on steam engines, Steamin', to Jonathan Powell's A Rebours, an ambitious 25-minute piano concerto. Taken as a whole, the weekend presented a blend of the worthy, the well-crafted and the genuinely innovative.

The pieces that stood out were those whose imagination broke the frame of convention. Fraser Trainer's The Colour of Scars, for soprano saxophone and 14 players, developed a vivid drama from its Mark-Anthony Turnage-inspired language. But neither of the most memorable ensemble works were world premieres. Richard Ayres's No 24: Noncerto for Alto Trombone was written in 1995; this "uncertain concerto" - Ayres's explanation of his title - was a moving study of musical dislocation.

With David Purser, the soloist, battling with a bag full of mutes, from a tin can to a paper plate, and attempting to articulate a coherent musical line, the piece was poised delicately between comedy and tragedy. Ian Vine's espinas, composed in 1999 and inspired by the mobiles of Alexander Calder, suspended Roger Benedict's impassioned viola solo between static extremes of high and low registers, as if the viola were a heavy object caught in weightless limbo.

There was another image of a viola in space in Tansy Davies's Small Black Stone for viola and piano. This taut, seven-minute movement, with its ferocious dynamism and luminous coda, expressed the compressed energy of cosmic forces. Rolf Hind's Cloud Shadow/Solgata for piano, played by the composer, was a similarly elemental investigation of light and reflection. Where Cloud Shadow was a scintillating rhythmic ripple at either end of the piano's range, Solgata focused on the half-light of piano strings muffled by Blu-Tack. With another ingenious device, Hind conjured sustained notes from the piano, creating a shimmering texture.

But the real heroes of the weekend were the players of the Sinfonietta and especially Valade, who conducted the bulk of the concerts with understated brilliance. With videos of each composer discussing their works cleverly masking the breaks between pieces, State of the Nation was as successful in its presentation as it was impressive in conception.

fields.headline: Erik Truffaz
fields.standfirst:
Jazz Cafe, London
****
fields.body:
This was the final night of French music week, and initially the signs were not great. Weary after a long tour, Erik Truffaz's band faced a noisy crowd, who acted as though a DJ was toasting over 1960s jazz albums. The mural behind thestage features a life-size approximation of the famous silhouette that graces albums such as Sketches of Spain: Truffaz, a trumpeter with an attractively fragile sound, was playing in the shadow of Miles Davis.

Things slowly warmed up as Italian bassist Marcello Giuliani (doubling on five-string acoustic bass guitar and a regular electric model) locked more securely into drummer Marc Erbetta's breakbeats. One challenge Truffaz's band tackles is that of integrating improvised rap into live jazz. The rapper Nya (leather hat, Swiss passport) came across as a bit of a spare part at first, jiggling around with clenched fists. Yet by the second half of the night, on numbers such as Bending New Corners and Yuri's Choice, he was flying with the rest of the players and the crowd paid attention.

The processed Rhodes piano of Patrick Muller and the live sound engineering of Salvatore Dardano are crucial to the band's sound. Muller has that funky Echoplex thing down to a Z and Dardano dropped in the Teo-style effects in all the right places, maintaining a razor-sharp sound on Erbetta's kit and resisting the temptation to dumb down by pumping up. Muller's sensitivity to timbre continued on acoustic: for the ballad Siegfried, he damped the piano strings with his left hand while soloing with his right. Truffaz played eloquent modal runs, unfinished melodic sentences, heartbroken single notes. You couldn't ignore the Miles factor, but so what? This is a jazz group that relishes entertaining and connecting with a club audience with little compromise.

For The Mask, their vociferously demanded encore, Julien Lourau guested to blow some pungent sax. Muller extracted wild sounds from his Rhodes while Giuliani and Erbetta cooked like crazy. Truffaz shrugged with pleasure.

fields.headline: Hallé/Brown
fields.standfirst:
Bridgewater Hall, Manchester
***
fields.trailText:
Bridgewater Hall, Manchester
***
fields.body:
A guest conductor needs a way to make an orchestra feel it is doing something different; one way of doing this is to change the seating arrangements. So Iona Brown ranged the Hallé's double basses along the back of the podium. It means that their impact is doubled, but it does not work equally well for all music. The one thing that the various orchestra seatings of the classical era shared is that the cellos and basses were close to one another. By leaving the cellos in their traditional place to her right, Brown risked ensemble and balance problems.

Those risks can help make a concert exciting, but not in the opening performance of Mozart's "Paris" symphony. The nervousness was palpable, the textures were soggy, and the playing lacked space to flower. It was easy to wish that Brown was in her old role of leading from the violin.

Things were much better in Beethoven's Fourth Symphony. The strings settled down to produce a marvellous range of colours; with Brown's brisk tempos they played with delicacy, precision and verve. Beethoven's fuller scoring (albeit with a smaller wind section) gave more scope for the different seating of the basses to yield thrilling textures. The woodwind also rose impressively to the occasion, led by Graham Salvage's gloriously musical playing of the bassoon solos.

Benjamin Britten's Serenade may be one of his most perfect works, but it is far too seldom heard. Paul Nilon may not quite have the cutting edge for some of the vocal lines, but his interpretation grew as it proceeded, with a marvellously spirited reading of the Hymn to Diana and a superbly controlled concluding Sonnet. The Hallé's own principal horn, Laurence Rogers, played with glowing confidence in the most challenging of the horn solos, the Elegy.

It was in this movement that we heard perhaps the real reason for putting all those double basses along the back of the orchestra: their spine-chilling pizzicato line is so important to the music's effect, but it is so often muffled in the more traditional seating.

webTitle: Object of the week: Play Euros

fields.headline: Silly money
fields.standfirst: Object of the week: Play Euros
fields.trailText: Object of the week: Play Euros.
fields.body:
It's enough to turn the heart of any Europhobe to stone. Right here in an ordinary British corner shop, dangling amongst the plastic machine guns and knockoff Barbies on a listing revolving rack, one finds propaganda of the basest sort. Can you believe it? They're selling play Euro-money to our children!

On first inspection this would appear to a rather ordinary play money set, albeit one designed to indoctrinate four year olds into the New World Order. There is the usual over-the-top effort to demonstrate that it ain't real money, with "COPY" stamped directly into each coin, as if someone might actually try passing off a grey plastic wafer as legal tender. The notes are half size (I'm guessing; I have no idea how big a real Euro note is meant to be) and they say PLAY MONEY right on them. The packaging insists that "notes, coins and all accessories are just for kids only". Even anti-European conspiracy theorists might venture a little joke about it being proof that the single currency is only make-believe.

Fortunately for the paranoid, all is not what it seems. The little cartoon character on the package is a pig, clearly a US capitalist pig, with a dollar sign on his porkpie hat. He is raising two fingers (he only has four) to Europe while standing before a globe not-so-subtly positioned so America is dead centre. The cash till drawer in which the Euro money nestles has dollar signs embossed on it. There are only four partitions for coins - the classic penny, nickel, dime and quarter layout. With 1, 2, 5, 10, 20 and 50 Euro cent and 1 and two Euro coins included in the set, the plastic change is rather awkwardly distributed in a way young Europeans will only find confusing. Up one side of the package runs the grammatically-challenged slogan, "Over thousand dollars in value with million times of fun!" Dollars? Who makes this toy? The CIA?

I'm not sure how to calculate whether or not this toy is actually a million times of fun, but all counted up the set totals Euro12,757.76, well over a thousand dollars in value. In fact at this week's rate it's about $11,354.41. This is due to a mystifying decision to include only the highest paper money denominations, not bothering with any lowly 5, 10 and 20 Euro banknotes.

The set boasts no less than 15 crisp new 500 Euro bills, each roughly the equivalent of a £300 note. How children are supposed to learn to make change with such a profound shortage of in-between money is unclear. It's fine for playing at buying a yacht with your drug-dealing profits, or pretending to bribe your Euro MP, but is that really what we should be teaching our kids?

fields.headline: At this price?  Egg
fields.standfirst:
More internet news
Guardian Unlimited Money
fields.trailText: Scrambled, fried or poached, egg will inevitably end up on the faces of some of the best-paid analysts in the City over the prospects of the eponymous bank.
fields.body:
Scrambled, fried or poached, egg will inevitably end up on the faces of some of the best-paid analysts in the City over the prospects of the eponymous bank.

Two brokers' recommendations yesterday amply illustrated the problem: "buy," said the highly regarded analysts at HSBC; "sell," argued the team at Credit Lyonnais Securities. Both brokers used equally emotive language: Credit Lyonnais said egg was "fundamentally flawed", while HSBC insisted it "will silence the critics".

Who to believe? Since egg made its debut on the stock market last year when Prudential sold 20%, the company has worked hard to prove that its business can work. All the headlines it grabbed in the early days after its flotation proclaimed the fact that the stock had fallen below the 160p issue price.

Yesterday, at 154.5p, that price was still elusive. Ever since flotation, the HSBC analysts had thought that egg's shares were worth 150p. Now they put the price closer to 180p, because they believe the fundamental value of egg must be rising.

"At the time of the IPO, the business had an 18-month track record, an untested strategy and was losing over £150m per annum," the HSBC analysts said. Last week, egg announced that its losses had narrowed to £37m and insisted it would break even by the year's end. This has done nothing to change the minds of the Credit Lyonnais analysts, who see the fair value for the shares at 130p.

Egg's business model is based on selling more than one product to each of its customers and on diversifying its customer base - an imminent possibility if rumours of the acquistion of Bernard Arnault's Zebank are to be believed.

But the sharply divergent views in the City reflect the fact that egg is as close as the financial services industry has a new economy stock. Even the best-paid analysts cannot agree whether this is one egg best left out or included in a basket.

webTitle: How David Edwards won a million pounds

fields.headline: How I made a million
fields.standfirst:
David Edwards is a Mensa Superbrain and past Mastermind winner who planned his appearance on Who Wants to be a Millionaire? down to the last detail. No wonder he walked away with the top prize, writes Brian Logan

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: David Edwards is a Mensa Superbrain and past Mastermind winner who planned his appearance on Who Wants to be a Millionaire? down to the last detail. No wonder he walked away with the top prize, writes Brian Logan.
fields.body:
It's been an extraordinary fortnight for David Edwards. First, on April 10, came his top-prize victory - only the second ever - on ITV's Who Wants to be a Millionaire? Champagne corks popped; silver banknotes cascaded from the studio sky. Then came the celebratory party - "Nice but wearying", says the 53 year old - then, inevitably, the tabloid frenzy. "My wife and I were whisked back to a hotel, of the sort which is so posh, they don't provide you with a kettle. We were about to sit down and take stock, when the phone rang. It was our son, saying, 'Dad, there's a Sun reporter hammering at the door.'" The secret was out: two weeks later, producers Celador are still hunting the mole who leaked details of Edwards' win to the press.

Since that triumph, which was broadcast on Saturday, "we haven't had any time to let what's happened sink in", says Edwards' wife, Vivian. Their Staffordshire village has been invaded by prying journalists. "I'm glad to say," Vivian adds, "that the pub, the garage and the shop did very well out of them." As the hacks raked muck, Edwards felt less fortunate. "You think to yourself: there are things I've done in my life which I don't feel particularly proud of, but is there anything that might titillate the average tabloid reader?"

He wouldn't know - he's a lifelong Guardian man, and is giving one of his only two interviews to this paper (the other is with the Stoke Sentinel). A genial and thoughtful man, he bears none of the scars of a week in the eye of a tabloid storm, and seems happy and incredulous: "It's all very strange." At least for now, he's back teaching physics at Denstone College (the kids now say "Give us a tenner, sir"). He and Vivian, also a teacher, have two college-age children: "I don't think anybody who knows us will see any ostentatious change in the way we live," he says.

Edwards is no ordinary Who Wants to be a Millionaire? contestant - he's a previous winner of Mastermind and one-time Mensa Superbrain who meticulously plotted his Millionaire win for a specific purpose. "This was pretty cold-blooded," he says. "I wanted to win a lot of money, ideally enough to retire on." To ensure the success of his scheme, Edwards calculated the number of phone calls he'd need to make to gain a place on the show, then set aside £1,000 to cover the cost. He also rehearsed the coordination required for the programme's Fastest Finger round, at which he'd been beaten on an earlier appearance. This obsessive behaviour having reaped rewards, however, Edwards maintained an admirable self-irony throughout his winning performance. He now insists: "If I had gone away - again - with just a travel expenses cheque, it would still have been an enjoyable experience."

This is a man, after all, who is quiz mad. His Mensa title was awarded, in 1985, after he won a newspaper competition. "Until then," he explains, "I hadn't realised there was anything about my general knowledge that was more than just better than average." So what does he put that knowledge down to? "I can remember, when I was about seven, my mum buying me a little Manila-covered booklet for ninepence in Woolworths which contained lists of facts. I went through it and memorised all the capital cities, everything."

He grew up in Barry in south Wales in the 60s: "Education was considered very important. It was a way out of the automatic progression to the mines." But his secret isn't just in 60s schooling. "Television was much more informative then. I accumulated a lot of knowledge, probably mostly useless, from watching television."

As teacher and quiz show veteran, Edwards is perfectly positioned to see how things have changed over 30 years in both areas. On TV, as in schools, the concept of public service has had to defer to the market. Out with Ask the Family, in with Who Wants to be a Millionaire. "Since the 80s," Edwards agrees, "money has become more important, as has the feeling of every man for himself."

So is Edwards at ease with the signals that Who Wants to be a Millionaire sends out? "I think sometimes money is seen to be the be-all and end-all," he says, circumspectly. "I'm not in a very strong position to be saying this, because I've deliberately gone into a competition with the intention of winning as much money as I could. But it is a shame that sometimes the pursuit of money is seen as more important than the achievement of coming through a rigorous competition." He pauses, for a long time. "If I think too hard about this, I feel in danger of being hypocritical."

Are the standards against which he is measuring himself sustainable in an age when Edwards is paid about three times as much for 30 minutes as he has been paid in 30 years teaching? There is, he adds, "Something that's not quite right there. The puritan in me can't come to terms with that.

"But I'm doing my best to," he laughs

Although he admits they have never been desperately hard-up ("We've had the occasional month of struggling to get to pay day without drifting into the red."). He enjoys teaching enough to continue for a while, and is looking forward to the time when some pupil brushes him up the wrong way and he can say, "I don't care, I'm a millionaire".

"The money will buy freedom to do all the things I'm interested in and don't have time to do properly, and wouldn't expect to have time to do until I retire, when I may not be fit enough to make the most of it. Now I can retire fairly soon, and carry on playing squash, and sword-dancing - that's traditional Northumbrian sword-dancing - and getting better at the concertina, and following up my family history research," says Edwards.

fields.bodyText: It's been an extraordinary fortnight for David Edwards. First, on April 10, came his top-prize victory - only the second ever - on ITV's Who Wants to be a Millionaire? Champagne corks popped; silver banknotes cascaded from the studio sky. Then came the celebratory party - "Nice but wearying", says the 53 year old - then, inevitably, the tabloid frenzy. "My wife and I were whisked back to a hotel, of the sort which is so posh, they don't provide you with a kettle. We were about to sit down and take stock, when the phone rang. It was our son, saying, 'Dad, there's a Sun reporter hammering at the door.'" The secret was out: two weeks later, producers Celador are still hunting the mole who leaked details of Edwards' win to the press. Since that triumph, which was broadcast on Saturday, "we haven't had any time to let what's happened sink in", says Edwards' wife, Vivian. Their Staffordshire village has been invaded by prying journalists. "I'm glad to say," Vivian adds, "that the pub, the garage and the shop did very well out of them." As the hacks raked muck, Edwards felt less fortunate. "You think to yourself: there are things I've done in my life which I don't feel particularly proud of, but is there anything that might titillate the average tabloid reader?" He wouldn't know - he's a lifelong Guardian man, and is giving one of his only two interviews to this paper (the other is with the Stoke Sentinel). A genial and thoughtful man, he bears none of the scars of a week in the eye of a tabloid storm, and seems happy and incredulous: "It's all very strange." At least for now, he's back teaching physics at Denstone College (the kids now say "Give us a tenner, sir"). He and Vivian, also a teacher, have two college-age children: "I don't think anybody who knows us will see any ostentatious change in the way we live," he says. Edwards is no ordinary Who Wants to be a Millionaire? contestant - he's a previous winner of Mastermind and one-time Mensa Superbrain who meticulously plotted his Millionaire win for a specific purpose. "This was pretty cold-blooded," he says. "I wanted to win a lot of money, ideally enough to retire on." To ensure the success of his scheme, Edwards calculated the number of phone calls he'd need to make to gain a place on the show, then set aside £1,000 to cover the cost. He also rehearsed the coordination required for the programme's Fastest Finger round, at which he'd been beaten on an earlier appearance. This obsessive behaviour having reaped rewards, however, Edwards maintained an admirable self-irony throughout his winning performance. He now insists: "If I had gone away - again - with just a travel expenses cheque, it would still have been an enjoyable experience." This is a man, after all, who is quiz mad. His Mensa title was awarded, in 1985, after he won a newspaper competition. "Until then," he explains, "I hadn't realised there was anything about my general knowledge that was more than just better than average." So what does he put that knowledge down to? "I can remember, when I was about seven, my mum buying me a little Manila-covered booklet for ninepence in Woolworths which contained lists of facts. I went through it and memorised all the capital cities, everything." He grew up in Barry in south Wales in the 60s: "Education was considered very important. It was a way out of the automatic progression to the mines." But his secret isn't just in 60s schooling. "Television was much more informative then. I accumulated a lot of knowledge, probably mostly useless, from watching television." As teacher and quiz show veteran, Edwards is perfectly positioned to see how things have changed over 30 years in both areas. On TV, as in schools, the concept of public service has had to defer to the market. Out with Ask the Family, in with Who Wants to be a Millionaire. "Since the 80s," Edwards agrees, "money has become more important, as has the feeling of every man for himself." So is Edwards at ease with the signals that Who Wants to be a Millionaire sends out? "I think sometimes money is seen to be the be-all and end-all," he says, circumspectly. "I'm not in a very strong position to be saying this, because I've deliberately gone into a competition with the intention of winning as much money as I could. But it is a shame that sometimes the pursuit of money is seen as more important than the achievement of coming through a rigorous competition." He pauses, for a long time. "If I think too hard about this, I feel in danger of being hypocritical." Are the standards against which he is measuring himself sustainable in an age when Edwards is paid about three times as much for 30 minutes as he has been paid in 30 years teaching? There is, he adds, "Something that's not quite right there. The puritan in me can't come to terms with that. "But I'm doing my best to," he laughs Although he admits they have never been desperately hard-up ("We've had the occasional month of struggling to get to pay day without drifting into the red."). He enjoys teaching enough to continue for a while, and is looking forward to the time when some pupil brushes him up the wrong way and he can say, "I don't care, I'm a millionaire". "The money will buy freedom to do all the things I'm interested in and don't have time to do properly, and wouldn't expect to have time to do until I retire, when I may not be fit enough to make the most of it. Now I can retire fairly soon, and carry on playing squash, and sword-dancing - that's traditional Northumbrian sword-dancing - and getting better at the concertina, and following up my family history research," says Edwards. fields.headline: Richard Reeves
fields.standfirst:
Will coffee shops be the next to go in the new economy shakedown?

Guardian Unlimited Work
fields.trailText: Will coffee shops be the next to go in the new economy shakedown?
fields.body:
With the Nasdaq nosedive, the death of dozens of dot.coms and now job slaughter in the telecoms sector, you might have expected all the activities intertwined with the new economy to cease, too. And chief among them is the coffee house, doling out lattes to the labourers of the digital age. When even Cisco is straining, surely Starbucks will feel the heat? According to one recent report in the Silicon Valley bible, the Industry Standard, coffee vendors are starting to get worried.

In fact, the rash of new espresso emporia dotting our cities may end up being the only surviving remnant once the excitement of the cyber-economy has worn off. Caffeine, it turns out, is going to remain king.

Of course, we've long enjoyed a dose of the stuff in our coffee or tea - in 1732 Bach composed the Coffee Cantata with a libretto declaring "Ah! How sweet coffee tastes! Lovelier than a thousand kisses, sweeter far than muscatel wine!" But while plenty of high-brow workers - Samuel Johnson and Voltaire among them - have sworn by the productivity-enhancing powers of a cuppa, the caffeinisation of the white-collar workplace in recent years has been unprecedented.

Work has become more intense, with more people reporting deadline pressure and more people reporting that they work continuously, with few if any fallow periods. We need the coffee because the afternoon doze has been cancelled. Contrast the work of people in the City today - fast, IT-driven, global - with the sedate world of banking just a few decades ago, when an afternoon sherry might not have seemed a bad idea.

Caffeine - despite numerous claims to the contrary - is a proven brain kickstarter. In their book The World of Caffeine, Bennett Weinberg and Bonnie Bealer pull together a range of studies showing that it makes us think faster, keeps us alert and improves memory. In a 1960s advertising blitz, coffee was dubbed the "Think Drink". You can do one of the tests yourself: get someone to read out a string of numbers and try to repeat them. Then have a cup of coffee and do it again - you'll be faster. Whatever happens to the dot.com and telecommunications sector - and we shouldn't forget how many early electricity companies went bust at the start of that previous revolution - the value of mental input to the economic process can only keep growing.

But the benefits of caffeine aren't restricted to the workplace. People who drink coffee are less likely to commit suicide, controlling for other risk factors, than those who do not, according to at least two large-scale studies. Increased well-being and motivation for work were two of the positive results, according to Dr Ichiro Kawachi, from the Harvard Medical School, who tracked 85,000 nurses in his research.

Of course, there are health concerns raised by overuse of caffeine, and the inevitable backlash: Caffeine Anonymous is doing good business, and Caffeine Prevention Plus lobbies in the US to outlaw caffeine. But, on balance, caffeine taken in moderate quantities is close to the perfect drug for the modern worker. In the long run, the ever-proliferating purveyors of expensive espressos would seem to have little to fear.

 A curious contribution to the debate on the impact of women in the military comes from the 1930s, when the Foreign and Commonwealth Office was considering the employment of women as diplomatic staff, following the dropping of the ban against women in the Whitehall in 1920.

"I imagine that the emotional balance of many Government Departments has on occasion been disturbed since 1920," wrote FCO mandarin Claud Schuster. But he ends on an optimistic note: "We have to face the fact that men and women who are thrown together will on occasion make love to one another, and if they do it in any great number they will on occasion make love successfully." MoD of the 21st century take notice - the only danger, of course, being the introduction of a new government target for "successful" lovemaking.

 Richard Reeves (rreeves@indsoc.co.uk) is director of futures at the Industrial Society.

fields.headline: Murdoch raises Hughes stakes
fields.standfirst:
General Motors hears last-ditch offer for US satellite operation

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Rupert Murdoch made a last-ditch effort to win control of Hughes Electronics yesterday in a meeting with General Motors, writes Jane Martinson.
fields.body:
Rupert Murdoch made a last-ditch effort to win control of Hughes Electronics yesterday in a meeting with General Motors, the US satellite group's controlling shareholder.

The News Corporation head, whose businesses include satellite company Sky Global as well as newspapers around the world, was expected to sweeten marginally the terms of his bid.

Under the terms of the original deal, Sky Global's assets would be merged into Hughes, with News Corp owning about 35% of the total and shareholders in Hughes 51%. Any new deal is more likely to involve a re-evaluation of Sky's assets rather than more cash, according to sources close to the talks.

Shares in News Corp rose 5.5% in Sydney yesterday as prospects for a deal improved.

Yesterday's meeting at the Detroit headquarters of GM took the form of a pitching battle between Mr Murdoch's team and the Hughes management, which wants to buy the business outright.

Michael Smith, the chairman of Hughes, was also called to Detroit to make a presentation to senior GM executives. Mr Smith was expected to present his case, alongside a financial backer, to Richard Wagoner, GM's chief executive, and Harry Pearce, its vice-chairman.

At Mr Murdoch's side was Steve Ballmer, the chief executive of Microsoft, the software firm which is expected to contribute $3bn (£2.08bn) for a stake in the proposed company.

Takeover talks broke down last month amid a disagreement over valuation and management issues.

The Hughes management and some shareholders argued that Mr Murdoch's original offer, made at the end of last year, undervalued the group.

Since talks broke down both sides have indicated that they have other fish to fry. Mr Murdoch has said that Sky Global does not need a US business, while GM has considered a full spin-off of Hughes with the backing of a financial buyer such as GE Capital.

Mr Murdoch has benefited from the absence of a rival bidder and the falling markets.

One Wall Street analyst said: "I think there's a better than 50% chance that he [Murdoch] will win it. It just makes sense."

However, sources close to the talks urged caution in trying to second guess the outcome of a merger that was first mooted five months ago.

"This is very, very hard to forecast. Hughes seem vitriolically opposed to doing a deal with Murdoch ... but GM needs the money."

With falling production and sales, GM has long indicated its desire to realise some value from its stake in Hughes. It owns all of the group's assets and 30% of its tracking stock.

A large part of the cash offered by News Corp would come from Microsoft and the cable investment company owned by John Malone.

The rest of the deal will be based on a valuation of Sky Global's assets as well as those of DirecTV, Hughes' main satellite business.

The company's negotiations to sell Stream, the Italian pay-TV concern, might allow it to increase its terms marginally.

Neither GM nor News Corp would comment on the state of play or even confirm that the talks taking place yesterday. Mr Murdoch was understood to have instigated the meeting through a letter to the GM board but the car group's executives called the meeting, alongside that with the internal team.

In meetings with analysts earlier this month, Hughes executives said they had been given several week by the GM boards to come up with an alternative plan.

The decision over whether to go ahead with Mr Murdoch's plan could come as early as next week's scheduled board meeting.
