fields.headline: Debt alarm stirs Brown
fields.standfirst:
World Bank and IMF admit poorest nations will struggle for years despite relief

Special report: debt relief
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown last night gave strong backing to campaigners for more generous help for the world's most impoverished countries.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown last night gave strong backing to campaigners for more generous help for the world's most impoverished countries.

The chancellor's move came after the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund warned that the assistance offered so far would be insufficient to save some nations from further years of grappling with unpayable debts.

The Treasury said Mr Brown was alarmed by the findings of a World Bank and IMF working party on debt sustainabil ity for the 22 nations already granted debt relief under the international community's HIPC (heavily indebted poor country) initiative.

This showed that assumptions previously made by the Bank and the IMF for likely export growth from impoverished nations in Africa and Latin America were too high, with many countries also adversely affected by the HIV/Aids epidemic.

"We are very concerned about the debt sustainability report," a Treasury spokesman said. "We are very grateful to the Fund and the Bank for highlighting the issue of ongoing sustainability. The chancellor will be asking tough questions at the spring meetings this weekend about the impact of debt relief on the resources for poverty reduction in these countries."

Campaign groups such as Drop the Debt - the successor to Jubilee 2000 - and Oxfam have been arguing in recent months that the HIPC terms were not generous enough to ease the burden on poor countries. In particular, they said, the World Bank and the IMF set their threshold for debt sustainablity too high, at 150%, of exports.

"We are aware of the Drop the Debt and Oxfam reports on the need for 100% debt relief," the Treasury said.

"The issue is about whether the World Bank could release additional resources and, if it could, on how they should be allocated between HIPC and non-HIPC countries. But these are legitimate questions that Drop the Debt and Oxfam have raised."

According to the Bank's report, predictions that poor country exports would grow by more than 6% a year were too optimistic, and that if they grow in line with the 4.2% average during the 1990s, debt levels will rise to 160% of ex ports by 2005 and 180% by 2015. In addition, three of the countries which have qualified for HIPC relief - Bolivia, Malawi and Niger - will not reach the 150% threshold in the first place because of the volatility in their export growth rates, while a further three - Burkina Faso, Rwanda and Tanzania - will not reach the 150% level until the medium term.

Even for countries that do reach the 150% level, the World Bank and IMF acknowledge that the HIV/Aids emergency in many African HIPCs will mean that debt levels will soon rise: "Longer term growth prospects can be undermined by natural disasters, war, or health threats such as the Aids epidemic. In such cases, in the absence of adequate grant financing, external indebtedness may need to rise to accommodate the financing of reconstruction and rehabilitation."

Adrian Lovett, director of Drop the Debt, said: "The bad news is that the HIPC initiative is yet again failing to meet its stated objectives. The good news is that the IMF, World Bank and their shareholders have the resources to save the day by cancelling 100% of the debts these institutions are owed by the poorest countries."

webTitle: Theatre: murder and minimalism in Glasgow

fields.headline: Murder and minimalism in Glasgow
fields.standfirst:
'Tis Pity She's a Whore
Citizens' Theatre, Glasgow
***
fields.trailText:
'Tis Pity She's a Whore
Citizens' Theatre, Glasgow
***
fields.body:
Theatre Babel are to classical theatre what minimalism consultants are to the modern home - they strip away all the maddening, deadening stuff, leaving something reinvigorated and new. Recent productions have included Liz Lochhead's Medea and Iain Heggie's savage The King of Scotland; now they turn their intensely modern gaze to John Ford's early-17th-century tale of incestuous love and murder.

The play's weak and sometimes baffling subplots have been stripped away, along with several peripheral characters whose loss nobody will mourn, leaving less than two hours of an essentially private tragedy unfolding behind closed doors. The set is equally stark and bold: just two chairs before a vast projection screen, lit in serene blue and then bloody red, featuring only a cross or dagger. Quee MacArthur's score pumps life into the proceedings, with thumping heartbeats, galloping rhythms and divisions between scenes marked by an electrical fizz. It's hard to imagine a more atmospheric interpretation of the play, or a better-looking staging, for all its simplicity.

Less successful is Babel's treatment of the text itself: a move away from the star-crossed lovers approach to Giovanni and Annabella's incest (Ford reworked Romeo and Juliet to include this religious and social taboo) towards an exploration of the psychology within that relationship. What this means is a recasting of Giovanni as a power-crazed madman, a sexual obsessive bent on holding power over his sister. Compared in the programme to serial killer Jeffrey Dahmer and cult leader David Koresh, he is transformed into a calculating, monstrous presence, Annabella into his mesmerised prey.

If this were a better-known play, or incest was something we now had ways of dealing with and talking about, maybe such a new emphasis would feel timely. Instead, the tragedy of the drama gets lost (the audience often reacts with laughter), despite an engaging performance by Frances Thorburn as Annabella, and the issue becomes one of manipulation within relationships. That's a rich source of dramatic interest, but the incest is rendered secondary to Giovanni's dangerous personality; he just happens to be his lover's brother. We avoid the questions Ford was asking about forbidden desire in 1630; questions to which we still have no real answers.

 Ends Saturday. Box office: 0141-429 0022. Then tours. Details: 0141-226 8806.

fields.headline: Visiting world war memorials
fields.standfirst:
What is the cheapest way my 14-year-old daughter and I can visit a concentration camp (perhaps Bergen-Belsen as we have been to Anne Frank's house), a second world war site, trenches from the first world war and a war cemetery?
Joanna Nicholson
fields.trailText: What is the cheapest way my 14-year-old daughter and I can visit a concentration camp, a second world war site, trenches from the first world war and a war cemetery?
fields.body:
 I worked in Poland as a teacher for three years and can think of no better country for the type of trip you describe. No other country suffered more during the second world war. Warsaw is really one huge war site, with a vast, Soviet-built war cemetery in the suburbs (in Pole Mokotowskie). There are also two of the most notorious concentration camps - Auschwitz and Treblinka - and Hitler's 'wolf lair' bunker, where he spent most of the war, is also located in the north of Poland in remote and hauntingly beautiful country. It is also much cheaper than Germany. If you want to see a place that was really at the coalface of recent history, you can't overlook Poland.
Craig Armstrong

fields.headline: Disability rights: the issue explained
fields.standfirst: Government initiatives on disability rights have come thick and fast over the past 12 months. But awareness of the issue among the general public remains seriously lacking.
fields.trailText: Government initiatives on disability rights have come thick and fast over the past 12 months. But awareness of the issue among the general public remains seriously lacking.
fields.body:
The past 12 months have witnessed a flurry of activity on the disability rights front.

First and foremost was the establishment of the disability rights commission. This came into existence in April 2000 with an annual budget of £11m and a mandate to provide information and advice to businesses and disabled people, and take employers to court where necessary. The commission is seen as the equivalent of the commission for racial equality.

Next was the announcement that the Disability Discrimination Act would be extended to cover an estimated seven million jobs previously excluded from the act. Small businesses (those with fewer than 15 staff) and professions such as the police, prison service and fire brigade, will have to comply with the act.

The move was welcomed as the most significant reform to take place since the introduction of anti-discrimination legislation 30 years ago.

Other government initiatives deserve a mention as well. A special education needs and disability rights in education bill will work towards providing a level playing field in education, putting a stop to the current state of play that sees disabled people twice as likely to be without qualifications as able-bodied people.

Meanwhile, a new white paper, Valuing people: a new strategy for learning disability in the 21st century, will look at issues surrounding community care, improved day services and social inclusion for the country's 1.5m people with learning difficulties.

Unfortunately, government activity in the area of disability rights doesn't seem to be filtering down into a greater understanding of the issues by the general public.

There are more than 6.6m disabled people of working age in the UK, but a recent survey found that only half of the people questioned had heard of the 1995 Disability Discrimation Act.

They also thought nearly half of all disabled people used wheelchairs, when in reality the figure is 5%, and didn't know that diseases such as HIV and heart disease were included in the act.

webTitle: First human case of foot and mouth suspected

fields.headline: First human case of foot and mouth suspected
fields.standfirst: Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: The first human case of foot and mouth was feared tonight as it was reported that a slaughterman was suspected of having contracted the disease.
fields.body:
The first human case of foot and mouth was feared tonight as it was reported that a slaughterman was suspected of having contracted the disease.

The unnamed man from an undisclosed location in Cumbria was undergoing tests to establish if he has the disease, the Department of Health said.

Dr Angus Nichol, director of the communicable disease surveillance at the Public Health Laboratory Service, has disclosed that there had been other suspected cases of humans catching foot and mouth, but all had proved to be negative.

There has been only one recorded case of a human contracting foot and mouth in Great Britain, during the last outbreak in 1966. According to Maff's website, "the general effects of the disease in that case were similar to influenza with some blisters. It is a mild short lived, self-limiting disease."

Foot and mouth should not be confused with hand, foot and mouth disease, which is unrelated and does not affect animals.

Meanwhile a leading environmental group today accused the government of "incompetence" for ignoring warnings that an outbreak of a foot and mouth was all but inevitable, given current farming practices in the UK.

Friends of the Earth (FOE) claims that the government failed to take action after three scientific reports since 1998 had warned that intensive farming and large-scale animal movements would seriously increase the risk of foot and mouth disease.

The group points to reports from the UN food and agriculture organisation, the EU scientific committee on animal health and animal welfare and the Italian public health ministry, all of which discussed the possibility of a foot and mouth outbreak in Europe.

The UN report warned in 1998: "Europe faces a growing threat of devastating animal disease epidemic. This is mainly the result of long-distance transport of animals and increasingly dense livestock populations within certain areas in the region."

FOE is calling on Tony Blair to launch an investigation into the causes of the current outbreak and the effectiveness of the government's response.

Charles Secrett, the executive director of FOE, said: "Spin doctors and news managers have offered us many scapegoats for the foot and mouth crisis, from individual farmers to Chinese restaurants. But its is now becoming clear that the government itself must face criticism. Small farmers, the tourism industry and tax payers are now paying a very heavy price for Maff's incompetence and the government's love affair with intensive farming."

Martin Howarth, the director of policy at the National Farmers Union, agreed that the foot and mouth outbreak had exposed problems in the UK's farming methods, but he disagreed that intensive farming was to blame.

He said: "Perhaps some of our farming practices need to be looked at. Live markets need to be looked at. This disease has shown that some sheep have gone through three or four markets, with new groups of animals being remixed and rematched. But that is not a modern practice.

"There are more stingent movement controls for pigs, and maybe it should have been done for sheep. That's a fair point, but it is not related to intensive farming," Mr Howarth said.

webTitle: Death online: don't shoot the medium

fields.headline: Death online: don't shoot the medium
fields.trailText: How would you like to watch someone die? Simon Rogers on a Florida website's death show.
fields.body:
How would you like to watch someone die? And this isn't just anyone. This is the infamous Timothy McVeigh, the man who blew up the federal building in Oklahoma in 1995, murdering 168 men, women and children with a home-made fertiliser-bomb.

The offer comes from the Florida web-hosting company Entertainment Network, which wants to place a webcam in the execution chamber to film McVeigh's death by lethal injection next month at his Indiana jail. The company would charge users $1.95 (£1.35) for the show, a proposal promptly turned down by the US government: "The constitution does not require that those who wish to record courts or executions be allowed to do so," the assistant US attorney, Gerald Coraz, said. "Executions should not be public spectacles." District court judge John Tinder agreed, refusing the request on Friday. Entertainment network has vowed to appeal.

It sounds like the classic internet horror story, with the webcast as a moral-free zone serving up horror for titillation (and dollars). Cue earnest debates about the evil in our midst.

But whether or not it goes ahead, the webcast actually has a cold logic to it. It's a position stated by Entertainment Network's chief executive, David Marshlack: "The government is sponsoring the killing of the human being who was responsible for this horrendous act, and we believe the people have an absolute right to witness this action." And it cites a poll (on the Entertainment Network site, naturally) that shows 61% in favour of broadcast.

On one level, why not? Executions are legal in the US, and the death penalty is widely supported. Shouldn't Americans know what goes on in their name, in the name of law and order? These are deep questions: what happens when someone receives a lethal injection? Is it painless? How are they treated beforehand? What are their last words? Has the reality of dying struck home? The reality is, by all accounts, messy, inconclusive and possibly mundane. But surely it has a place in a national - and international - debate.

As for McVeigh himself, he has waived all his rights of appeal and will almost certainly die in May - in a procedure he has said he wants shown live on the web, call ing it "state-assisted suicide". Entertainment Network says the money would be donated to charities for the 168 people killed in the bombing - although families of the victims say they want no part in it.

The event itself promises to be a media merry-go-round. More than 1,400 reporters will be covering McVeigh's death - 10 of whose news organisations will fork out the $1,146.50 fee for the closest possible view (plus transport by golf carts around the prison complex, padded chairs, phone lines and "chilled bottled water"). And there will be a broadcast of sorts anyway: this month, the US attorney general, John Ashcroft, agreed to allow McVeigh's execution to be shown on closed-circuit television to families of his victims in Oklahoma.

The webcast undoubtedly is voyeurism of a sort. Entertainment Network is hardly CNN - the company operates VoyeurDorm.com, a website on which 55 cameras are trained on female students, and DudeDorm.com, which features the same treatment for 14 gay and straight male college students. But there are other questions. Isn't all news voyeurism? While journalists get to witness events and report back, the web offers readers the opportunity to bypass editors and go straight to the source.

A nd this was always the promise of the net. It was going to provide unlimited and unrivalled access to information. In secretive countries such as Britain, hidden papers would be revealed and governments would fear their impact on the waiting world. In the US, where freedom of information is a constitutional right, it would provide global access to the huge amount of data available. Of course, court action may be irrelevant anyway - things have a habit of leaking on to the web and this video may too.

However, the net does not entitle anyone to unlimited access to anything they want - child pornography, for instance. But the fact that it exists is not the fault of the internet, just as the case of the two "internet babies" (adopted using a company with a website) that turned into an international incident wasn't the fault of the net.

That this has become an issue at all says a lot more about the nature of the execution debate than it does about what is essentially just a communications medium. Can you support the death penalty but want it to be hidden away? The other interesting feature of this case is that while state executions are common, this will be the first federal execution since the US supreme court reinstated the death penalty in 1963. The state is taking McVeigh's life - and whether you agree with it or not, that is surely significant.

Maybe the problem is with the death penalty itself, rather than the net.

fields.headline: Trade fears hinder vaccination plan
fields.standfirst: Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: Vaccination against foot and mouth disease looks less likely today after the government signalled that industry opposition to the scheme means it cannot go forward.
fields.body:
Vaccination against foot and mouth disease looks less likely today after the government signalled that industry opposition to the scheme means it cannot go forward.

The agriculture minister, Nick Brown, told the House of Commons agriculture select committee that vaccination was not a possibility while farmers unions continue to oppose the policy.

He said: "The leaders of all the farming unions without exception oppose vaccination. They believe the vaccination strategy compromises trade, not just international trade but also domestic consumption. And they worry that the vaccination strategy will enable the virus to live on in the animals, that it might perpetuate the disease."

Mr Brown said that the culling policy has contained the virus, and despite health concerns over the disposal of carcasses, vaccination may never be brought in.

"The case for vaccination recedes as the number of daily cases declines," he said. He added that the average number of daily cases is now 16 compared with 43 just over two weeks ago

Mr Brown did hold out a possible third way, suggesting that cattle in heavily infected areas such as Cumbria and Devon could be given an initial vaccination that would wear off within a year.

At the moment, all discussions of vaccination have assumed that the animals would be killed once the disease is brought under control. Farmers are concerned that vaccinated animals -which carry the disease - could later infect healthy, unvaccinated animals.

Mr Brown's testimony will be welcomed by the farmers unions, but animal rights activists and some organic farmers are likely to take an opposing view. Animal rights activists this weekend demonstrated in opposition to the government's policy of culling healthy animals rather than administering a vaccine.

Mr Brown said that the culling policy has contained the virus, and despite health concerns over the disposal of carcasses, vaccination may never be brought in. "The case for vaccination recedes as the number of daily cases declines," he said. He added that the average number of daily cases is now 16 compared with 43 just over two weeks ago Mr Brown did hold out a possible third way, suggesting that cattle in heavily infected areas such as Cumbria and Devon could be given an initial vaccination that would wear off within a year. At the moment, all discussions of vaccination have assumed that the animals would be killed once the disease is brought under control. Farmers are concerned that vaccinated animals -which carry the disease - could later infect healthy, unvaccinated animals. Mr Brown's testimony will be welcomed by the farmers unions, but animal rights activists and some organic farmers are likely to take an opposing view. Animal rights activists this weekend demonstrated in opposition to the government's policy of culling healthy animals rather than administering a vaccine. webTitle: On whose behalf is the BMA really acting?

fields.headline: On whose behalf is the BMA really acting?
fields.standfirst: The British Medical Association is calling on 'overworked' GPs to participate in unofficial action, but compared with nurses and teachers GPs have got it easy, writes Patrick Butler
fields.trailText: The spirit of 1970s-style trade union militancy is alive and well in the health service and it resides in the traditionally conservative, male dominated, tweed-jacket wearing group of highly-paid professionals who run the British Medical Association (BMA).
fields.body:
The spirit of 1970s-style trade union militancy is alive and well in the health service and it resides in the traditionally conservative, male dominated, tweed-jacket wearing group of highly-paid professionals who run the British Medical Association (BMA).

Barely a week goes by without the association launching another tirade against the iniquities of the government's NHS plan, the traumatic implementation of which is apparently driving doctors en masse to depression, stress, exhaustion and early retirement.

Last week, it warned it is to ballot its GP members on whether they are prepared to "resign from the national health service" next year if a new contract is not agreed - supposedly because the existing terms have foisted "intolerable workloads" upon GPs.

It issued guidance to its family doctor members advising them how to "curtail their workload". This effectively tells GPs how to work to rule and includes measures such as refusing to register new patients and limiting list sizes.

Industrial-style sabre-rattling can be heard elsewhere. In the north-east, 70% of GPs, according to a BMA survey, say they are willing to take "some form of concerted action" to protest against heavy workloads, lack of resources and too much bureaucracy.

On May 1 "hundreds" of GPs around the country are said to be ready to participate in unofficial actions - "wildcat" strikes if you like - to mark National Doctor Day, a stunt organised by Doctor magazine, a weekly trade journal.

These include a series of measures including attending marches in London, shutting down surgeries, just doing paperwork and not seeing patients, or, bizarrely, just seeing patients and refusing to do paperwork.

So why is it so difficult to sympathise with the GPs? Is it the BMA's outrageous insistence that its highly partial interests are synonymous with those of patients? (Less work for GPs, the BMA says, is "in the best interests of patients' health and safety."

Much has been made of the decline in respect for GPs as a result of the Harold Shipman murders, but trust has probably been battered much more by the antiquated, patient-unfriendly opening hours held by most GPs, and the difficulty of getting out-of-hours service.

Ironically, on National Doctor Day many patients would not be able to see a GP anyway, either because there were no slots available as they had not booked a fortnight previously, or because the surgery is only open when they are at work.

Such sustained whingeing from one of the most secure, respected, well-paid and protected professions is guaranteed to stick in the throat. Working life is undoubtedly tough for GPs, but so is it for teachers and nurses, who earn a fraction of the salary.

The average GP earns £55,000, according to the BMA, although others put the average at nearer £70,000. Some GPs on paid-by-results personal medical services contracts earn more than £100,000, and even up to £140,000.

Their holiday entitlement is generous - a survey by GP magazine last year found that 70% of GPs get six weeks holiday a year; 14% get seven weeks off and 5% take off eight weeks or more. Nearly half of GPs go on holiday at least three times a year.

The incessant complaining of the BMA brings to mind the former Tory health secretary Kenneth Clarke's infamous line: "I do wish the more suspicious of our GPs would stop feeling nervously for their wallets every time I mention the word 'reform'."

Mr Clarke also called the association "a very powerful Imperial Guard type organisation" and "one of the nastiest (trade unions) I had dealt with".

That might be overstating it a little, but helps remind us that when the BMA defends the NHS is it also defending a very lucrative contractual arrangement for GPs, and when it speaks up for patients, it does so only to defend the interests of the BMA.

webTitle: Mini-generator that gives green light to the Robocop warrior of tomorrow

fields.headline: Mini-generator that gives green light to the Robocop warrior of tomorrow
fields.standfirst: Invention paves way to making laser-wielding hi-tech soldiers a reality
fields.trailText: The soldiers of the future - able to see in the dark, around corners and over the horizon - will look like Robocop and stalk their target like the Terminator.
fields.body:
The soldiers of the future - able to see in the dark, around corners and over the horizon - will look like Robocop and stalk their target like the Terminator.

Computer displays on their visor-screens will keep them in touch with comrades and give warning of where landmines lie. They will have miniature camera-carrying spyplanes in their backpacks, which they will be able to steer over barricades, under bridges or through windows.

And when they say the word, tiny rocket launchers mounted on their wrists will fire projectiles which will lock on to a target visible only on their eye-level screens.

Personal body armour will automatically sense the landscape and change colour accordingly to camouflage the soldier. It will react to temperature and adjust the climate inside to keep the soldier cool or warm. It will be wired with tiny sensors to detect chemical and biological attack, and swiftly seal them from the ambient air.

If they get hit by a high calibre bullet, it will tell the medical teams how much blood they are losing. Even in the dark or the smoke of battle, the medics will find them, because they will be on their screens too - linked to a global positioning system that can pinpoint them to a metre or two.

For five years, that has been the dream. But there has been a catch: it would take a 20lb battery to power tomorrow's hi-tech infantry soldier for even a few days in the field. A US team of engineers may be about to change that.

Researchers at the Pacific Northwest National Laboratory in Washington state have just unveiled a space age generator that weighs less than 2lb, measures little more than a fat paperback novel, can generate 25 watts and keep going for a week.

Fuel cells powered by hydrogen are the power packs of tomorrow. Although invented by a Victorian barrister called William Grove, they were first used to get Apollo astronauts to the moon. Smaller scale fuel cells are already on trial in buses in Chicago.

The latest design from the Washington labs will contain a store for aviation spirit or diesel to make the hydrogen, a cell in which the hydrogen reacts with oxygen to yield energy, and a little lithium battery, all in tubes about eight inches long. The complete system could be ready for testing by 2003.

"By then we expect infantry soldiers to use a variety of electronic gear, such as heads-up displays, global positioning systems, laser range finders and thermal weapons sights," said James Stephens, who led the research. "It all takes power, but we can't ask these soldiers to carry any more weight."

But the future warrior will go into battle so highly trained, so technologically equipped, that they will be too costly to be regarded as mere cannon-fodder. So microsensors in their underwear will measure their heart rate and stress levels, and incorporate the kind of climate controls used in astronauts' space suits. A drinking straw inside their helmet will supply water.

A patch on their arm will feed nutrients and vitamins through the skin and into their bloodstream to keep them going in the combat zone.

The visor will incorporate a night-vision light intensifier to turn night into day.

The helmet will be fitted with target and communications computer systems linked by wireless to their field command - to save the soldier from "friendly" fire - and it will say when to dive for cover when the beam of a sniper's laser sight touches them.

It will contain tiny microphones to give them sounds from every direction. It may even have a tiny video camera to relay what they see back to the battle commanders.

And if the visionaries at the US Army Soldier Systems Centre in Natick, Massachusetts, have got it right, their own weaponry will be mounted Batman-style in a pod on their wrist.

This will house bullets with a range of 300 yards and six inch exploding projectiles with a range of 1,000 yards, all fired by voice command. It may even hold a thermal imager that could detect concealed mines in the user's path. Some of this hardware is ready now. Some is in the workshops. Some still waits for the defence laboratories to deliver the ultra-light "wear able" computer systems of 2025. The US army is already testing a palmtop based military system called Jedi - short for joint expeditionary digital information system - and the UK Ministry of Defence is pumping millions into nanotechnology to devise sensors and "smart" armour on a scale of a billionth of a metre.

By 2003, the Americans will have spent $2bn on Land Warrior, which will provide soldiers with their own digitised map display on a monitor fitted to the helmet, and a laser rangefinder that can calculate the distance to the target and display the spot on the map.

It will weigh more than 80lb and cost a fortune to replace - which is why scientists are also working hard on tiny, expendable robots, programmed to go into the field of fire ahead of tomorrow's warrior.

Things to come

Other new hi-tech inventions in the pipeline include:

 Nasa is soon to test a "scramjet" aircraft (above) that could in theory fly at up to 7,000 miles an hour and cross the Atlantic in 30 minutes, scooping up oxygen from the air and combining it with hydrogen for propulsion.

 Sandia National Laboratories in Albequerque has developed a magnetic accelerator that can fire projectiles up to 20 times the speed of a rifle bullet. It is at the moment being used for lab tests - but a weapon based on it would destroy targets purely by kinetic energy.

 The US Marine Corps and the Naval Research Lab are soon to award contracts for a miniature plane called Dragon Eye that runs on a battery, carries a camera in its nose, can fly at 500ft, stay in the air for an hour, and can be carried in a soldier's backpack.

 Naval scientists are experimenting with "supercavitation" bubbles to reduce hydrodynamic drag. The Russians already have a supercavitation torpedo that travels underwater at 230 mph. The next step: long-range underwater missiles.

fields.headline: EU warns Montenegro against secession
fields.standfirst: Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: The European Union today cautioned Montenegro's pro-independence movement against taking unilateral action to break away from Yugoslavia following its narrow election victory.
fields.body:
The European Union today cautioned Montenegro's pro-independence movement against taking unilateral action to break away from Yugoslavia following its narrow election victory.

The EU's foreign policy chief, Javier Solana, said the EU fully supports a democratic Montenegro within a democratic Yugoslavia. "The EU opposes any unilateral steps which could run contrary to the stability of the region," he said.

With most votes counted in Sunday's election, secessionists led by Montenegrin president Milo Djukanovic had 42% of the vote, compared to 40.6% for the party wanting their republic to remain with Serbia in the Yugoslav federation.

The narrow victory margin was a signal for Mr Djukanovic not to act hastily to break up the federation, said Sweden, which currently holds the EU presidency.

"The election results in Montenegro give no clear mandate for continuing with a referendum on independence," said Sweden's foreign minister, Anna Lindh. "Montenegrin society is obviously divided on the issue of Montenegro's future status."

Meanwhile, the European commission today warned that any attempt by Montenegro to break away without negotiations with the Serbs could jeopardise continued EU aid payments.

"If the constructive dialogue is continued... then political, economic and financial aid will be continued," commission spokesman Gunnar Wiegand said. "It is essential that there be stability in the region."

Elections have left Montenegro's main pro and anti-independence movements in a virtual stalemate, dampening government hopes of broad backing for a peaceful split from Yugoslavia.

Spokesman Miodrag Vukovic said Mr Djukanovic plans to form a new governing coalition with the separatist-minded Liberal party, which won 9% of the vote, and that together they would push for a referendum on independence as early as June.

But pro-Yugoslavia voters have said they would boycott any referendum - which would probably doom it from the start, judging from Sunday's election results.

Even before the election, the United States and its European allies were opposed to Montenegrin independence, viewing it as a potential source of new instability in the Balkans.

fields.headline: John the Scot's Periphyseon
fields.trailText: David Luscombe, Professor of Medieval History at the University of Sheffield
fields.body:
David Luscombe, Professor of Medieval History at the University of Sheffield

Currently, the study of medieval thought is vibrant, with the 14th century in particular providing the excitement of new approaches and discoveries.

However, the biggest single step since the millenium celebrations seems to me to relate to a much earlier period, and this is the most recent progress made by Edouard Jeauneau on his monumental edition of John the Scot's Periphyseon. The fourth volume arrived on my desk just a few weeks ago.

John the Scot (or Eriugena) was an Irish thinker at the court of the Carolingian Emperor Charles the Bald in the mid-ninth century. The Periphyseon was his master work, an immense philosophical epic.

The work was inspired by a profound knowledge of the traditions of Platonist and Judaeo-Christian writing about nature, about the procession of beings from their source and their return, about creation and salvation.

John explored the division of nature and its reunification. There is nature which creates and is not created (God); nature which is created and creates (Platonic Ideas; primordial causes); nature which is created and does not create (the created universe in Genesis); and finally nature which does not create and is not created.

John's work is encyclopaedic in its presentation of late antique and early medieval learning, taken from Greek and Latin sources, and covering such subjects as physics, astronomy and anthropology.

Previous attempts to edit the work have been hampered by the instability of the manuscript texts. For over a hundred years, scholars have desired a genetic-critical edition which copes with all the revisions made by two contemporary Irish scribes and yet presents the text intended by the author. Jeauneau has compared his task to working with molten metal.

As well as establishing a critical edition and identifying John's sources fully, he has displayed four versions of the work in parallel columns, using different typefaces to indicate the scribes and the nature of their changes. The result is brilliant.

fields.headline: Bringing poetry to schools
fields.trailText:
Andrew Motion, Poet Laureate and professor of creative writing, University of East Anglia
One of the things I've become very involved with recently is a project called Poetry Class, and one of the most valuable parts of the project is a conference called "Working Together" . The idea is to try to bring together teachers to create more emphasis on writing poetry within the curriculum. Thanks to very generous DfEE and Arts Council support, it's getting off the ground. We can all think of universities that have a commitment to creative writing, including UEA, but it's not necessarily easy to think of schools that do the same.
fields.body:
Andrew Motion, Poet Laureate and professor of creative writing, University of East Anglia
One of the things I've become very involved with recently is a project called Poetry Class, and one of the most valuable parts of the project is a conference called "Working Together" . The idea is to try to bring together teachers to create more emphasis on writing poetry within the curriculum. Thanks to very generous DfEE and Arts Council support, it's getting off the ground. We can all think of universities that have a commitment to creative writing, including UEA, but it's not necessarily easy to think of schools that do the same.

Regular visits from writers mean we can prove the value of creativity in education. And, of course, that raises all sorts of other questions - such as how you evaluate creative writing in schools.

The Poetry Society has a programme of school visitors, but they need more financial help. It doesn't actually cost very much to send a poet into a school. Simon Armitage, Hugo Williams, Carol Anne Duffy and myself are already involved. The visits should be on a regular and unremarkable basis - it's a very practical intervention. Poetry should come along with the school milk each morning - if the school milk still came, of course.

Poetry should come along with the school milk each morning - if the school milk still came, of course. Link Poetry Class Compiled by Ros Taylor

fields.headline: In love and war
fields.standfirst: The author of Birdsong is a marketing man's dream - a bloke who writes about the trenches, DIY and technology, but with plenty of heart-felt romance and corset-ripping sex thrown in
fields.trailText: The author of Birdsong is a marketing man's dream - a bloke who writes about the trenches, DIY and technology, but with plenty of heart-felt romance and corset-ripping sex thrown in.
fields.body:
Go on, say it. Sebastian Faulks. Close your eyes, say it again, nice and slow. Sebastian Faulks. You get a picture in your head, right? Very English, very blond, broad shoulders, public school posh, effortlessly confident, cracking sportsman, all-round decent cove, Brideshead Revisited. At first glance, Sebastian Faulks, pronounced folks, couldn't be more Sebastian Faulks-ish.

The author is standing outside the club he was so keen to meet at, mobile phone in one hand, big cheery wave in another. Everything is going to plan, as you'd expect. Only one problem, he says with an apologetic shuffle: the club is shut. Never crossed his mind that it might not be open for lunch. Sorry. Perhaps we should go for a drink. So we set off for a bar, and we walk and walk and walk, and when he sees I'm tiring he hails a cab. Ah, this is it, here at last, he says happily. He walks in and walks out again, bemused. "It's changed. Used to have an upstairs. This place doesn't have an upstairs." Eventually, he realises his bar is next door. Beneath the urbane facade, there's something nicely shambolic about Faulks.

He sits down with a Bloody Mary, and tells me how much he hates conflict; will do anything to avoid it. "I never find losing your temper helps. If you lose your temper you risk losing faith, because you become incoherent and slobber," he says, like a man who knows his Kipling.

Faulks's novels, of course, are all about conflict. Conflict of the heart, and conflict of the battlefield. He is best known for his first-world-war trilogy: The Girl at the Lion D'Or, Birdsong and Charlotte Gray. The last two sold phenomenally. Birdsong, with its magnificent evocation of the hellishness of the great war - all those men trapped in tunnels and trenches, maimed, maddened and ultimately destroyed by a war with no purpose - is regarded as his best book.

But the books are about more than war. For many readers they are primarily love stories. Man eyes woman, woman eyes man, and we know that despite the fact that one is married, it will all end in a corset-ripping, faint-inducing, conscience-searching affair.

The jacket of his new book heralds On Green Dolphin Street as a "departure for Faulks". And in a way, it is. The setting is more modern - America in the wake of McCarthyism and on the eve of Kennedy's election. But in the end Faulks gives us more of the same. On page five, married Mary meets Frank, and we anticipate. By page 90, "his face was buried in her breasts", and his tongue was "searching for a withheld core of her". (In 1998, Faulks won the Bad Sex Award for Charlotte Gray.) Even more familiar is the fact that this is a love triangle in which all three sides have been broken by war.

Why is Faulks fixated on war? He says he is not - well, no more than many men of his age and upbringing. "It's just what the 20th century did. I'm just a reporter. That's the simple answer," he says rather modestly, rather grandly.

He takes me back to 1959, when six-year-old Sebastian was taught by a man "who had an arm tucked in here, and a gammy leg, and he'd been ripped apart by bullets". Wherever he looked there were men scarred by war. "And my father was wounded three times," he says, vaguely. His dad, a trainee lawyer, joined the army as an officer, like so many university boys did. It is only when I ask that he gives more details. "Yes, once in the head and twice in the arm." How badly was he shot? "Well, it went through the tin helmet and it went through the skull, but there was no damage to the brain. When they took his helmet off the last words he remembers hearing were the sergeant's: 'The major's a goner.'" Faulks says he thinks the war made his father relaxed, unambitious - having survived the horror, he was content with family and friends, peace and a nice garden. His idea of "unambitious" is interesting; his father was a judge.

His dad didn't talk to him about his war. Was that because he wanted to protect him? "No," he says. "I think the idea was that if you talked about what you'd done, you risked your friends thinking you were shooting a line, showing off. The only people who really talked about what they'd done were people who ran pubs and hadn't been anywhere near a bullet." The attitude seems to have been passed down from father to son. Faulks sounds so fogeyish at times.

He tells a story about his young, rebellious days at school. Wellington College in Berkshire was founded as a charitable foundation for sons of army officers who had been killed in action. By the time he joined as a boarder, it was a public school. Faulks couldn't stand it. "The ethos was cold showers, cross-country runs and not standing out from the crowd. The more you blended in with the rest of the unit, the better the man you were." He often talks in army jargon. "The idea was that the child came to you and badly needed to be disciplined and reshaped and corrected." He ran away, but only got as far as home and then returned. After O levels, he took on the authoritarian regime like never before. "I went down with two friends of mine to demand more drugs and more women and more freedom. I think I would have been expelled, but they thought I'd get into Oxford or Cambridge and that would be good for them." They suggested he live in the local village with a retired teacher. Faulks not only agreed but ended up staying on at school a year longer than he had to to do even more A levels. Poor, hopeless rebel.

He says he couldn't understand his parents. They loved him, yet they felt duty-bound to send him away for all those years. They were such a funny lot, he says - so stifled, wooden, emotionally repressed. "My parents' generation didn't have any understanding of psychology or emotion or individual temperament. In fact, they were slightly embarrassed by all those words." Thankfully, he says, he is very different. " I don't find it at all difficult to talk about sex, love, emotion. You know, girly things."

I ask him what kind of schools his children go to. "They go to very old-fashioned ... quite old-fashioned ... they'd hate me to say that, can I correct that, forward-looking independent day schools. They make friends, they play football, they have a good time."

So different from his own childhood. Faulks says he was a strange, friendless little boy. "I didn't really want to play with other kids. I made my first friend when I was 11. Unfortunately, he was Indian and he had to bugger off to India. Bastard! Then, when I was about 15, I suddenly cracked the friendship thing and became rather manically social." He says his 20s were a blur of parties and people.

You seem so different from your male characters, I say. Charlie, Mary's husband in On Green Dolphin Street, is a typical Faulks man - a hard-drinking loner mired in existential despair. He gives me a funny look and orders a glass of wine. "There's a lot of me in Charlie," he says. "That fear of boredom, that fear of emptiness, that fear that it's just completely pointless. I have a tremendous battle with melancholy and depression." Does he take pills? "I've had pills, yes, but everyone's had pills, haven't they? But I have learned how to deal with it." He remembers his stiff upper lip, decides he has overplayed it. "Yes, it's mild depression, I suppose."

Faulks often seems to be at war with himself: the radical free spirit stifled by his conservatism; the hedonist and the ascetic; the artist and businessman. You can also see it in the novels. He has a very obvious masculine side to his writing (war, technology, DIY) and a very obvious feminine side (love, landscape, romance). They don't merge, they exist side by side.

I ask him whether he considers himself a romantic. "Yes, I suppose so, by my definition of it." What is his definition? "A romantic is someone who believes that something is valuable even if it doesn't last. And a non-romantic is someone who says that if something doesn't endure, or can't be logically proved and pinned down, it's worthless," he says rather stiffly.

Does he consider himself a romantic novelist? Faulks recoils. "No. That's a sort of, oh no, to me that says Barbara Cartland or something." But they are love stories? "Yep. Among other things, they are, yep. There is always a love story in there. There is always romantic or sexual love. Both actually. Romantic stroke sexual. Plus a life affected by the public world."

I tell him that's why I think he's a marketing man's dream - the middle-class chatterati, who wouldn't normally touch romantic bonkbusters, love Faulks because they can tell their friends they are reading profound books about the trenches or Kennedy. "I hadn't thought of that, but I can see that. I can see that. I can see that. I can see that. If that were true it would be fine by me."

He agrees that he has a niche market, and says that, without wishing to sound immodest, he can't think of anyone else who writes quite like he does. "I'm very surprised that they don't, because it seems to me that what makes my novels different, perhaps, is that I'm interested equally in men and women characters and that I'm very interested in the way the public world impacts on private lives. But in a way you'd think both of those would be a given to any novelist. They seem to me so absolutely elementary, but nobody else seems to do it. I suppose Captain Corelli's Mandolin is the book I've most liked and has those elements."

After university, Faulks went into journalism - he was a features writer for the Telegraph, literary editor at the Independent, a columnist for the Guardian, and deputy editor at the Independent on Sunday. Today he lives in London with his wife Veronica, who was his secretary at the Independent, and their three children. He was widely liked in journalism, though some regarded him as a dilettante. His time at the newly born Independent on Sunday was a nightmare. "It was very tense. We'd taken people away from steady jobs and they had one baby and a huge mortgage." He couldn't stand making people redundant. Despite the apparent insouciance, the stress gave him an ulcer.

Does he recognise himself when he is profiled? "No, not really. It's a sort of alter ego. But I've come to recognise it. The alter ego comes across as very large, lumbering, burly, languid, slightly posh, slow, gentlemanly, a rather old-fashioned sort of creature. Whereas inside I feel very nervy and nervous and quick and impatient." Most of his friends would recognise both sides.

Perhaps this inner battle is best seen in his attitude to war itself. In the books, the vileness of it all wins out; in life the romance does. He seems to have little respect for his journalistic days because it was second-hand experience. He feels that life has been too easy and, as a result, too empty. As a child, did he want to fight a war? "No, though I assumed that I would. They just seemed to come every 30 years, and I was ready for it."

Does he feel he has missed out by not fighting a war? "Not really, no. Of course, there is that intensity of experience for which I am hungry." What would the intensity be like? "I think closeness to death would be pretty exhilarating, in a way, and friendship, yeh, and selflessness, a kind of selflessness, a sense of your own worthlessness, I think, is pretty exhilarating." Isn't the sense of selflessness a bit Boy's Own? "I think selflessness is the wrong word. I think expendability. The feeling that you are just an atom in a very large mass. Pretty depressing in a way. I think it would also be oddly thrilling."

A couple of hours and a few glasses of wine later, Faulks returns to the word exhilarated. He has just said that his wife and children make him happier than anything, and mentioned a time he hugged his oldest son after a bath. "I was consumed by happiness. There was nothing I could imagine that could be more ecstatic than that moment." He stops, stares into the emptied glass. "But apart from that you don't get so excited when you're older, you just don't get that turned on, you don't get exhilarated in the same way. In my 20s you could have skiing, or football, or dancing, or partying, you know. Feel absolutely on fire. And I haven't felt on fire for years."

webTitle: Ed Douglas talks to the Sherpa of a 1924 Everest expedition

fields.headline: The face of Everest
fields.standfirst: George Mallory and Andrew Irvine's attempt on Everest is shrouded in mystery. As a search for the remains of Irvine's body begins,  Ed Douglas  talks to Sherpa Ang Tsering, the last living link to that famous 1924 expedition
fields.trailText: George Mallory and Andrew Irvine's attempt on Everest is shrouded in mystery. As a search for the remains of Irvine's body begins, Ed Douglas talks to Sherpa Ang Tsering, the last living link to that famous 1924 expedition.
fields.body:
This month on Everest's bleak north face, an American expedition will be searching for the dessicated remains of Andrew Irvine, the 22-year-old Oxford student who disappeared in 1924 with George Mallory - whose marble-like broken form was discovered in 1999.

The romantic story of these explorers dressed in their tweeds and puttees is not just about whether they reached the summit before they perished, 29 years before Sir Edmund Hillary and Tenzing Norgay climbed the mountain. It has become a myth from an age of innocence, before modernity's consumerism and egocentricity overwhelmed Everest in an avalanche of sponsors' badges and empty oxygen bottles.

But while the Americans hope to bask in the reflected glory of Irvine's courage, there is a more direct link to this era. Because while all the sahibs who watched Mallory and Irvine disappear forever in the spring of 1924 are long since dead, one of the Sherpas who climbed with them is still alive, now aged 97, and living in the Indian hill station of Darjeeling, under the huge massif of Kangchenjunga.

Ang Tsering was born in Nepal in 1904 in the remote village of Thame close to the border with Tibet. One of five brothers, he tended the family yak herd, but left the Everest region in October 1920, looking for work in Darjeeling. Through a combination of chance and courage, he ended up being one of the best-known Sherpas of the pre-war period, going to Everest with the British in 1924 and 1933 and to the huge peak of Nanga Parbat, now in Pakistan, with a German team in 1934. As he turns the pages of his photo album, revealing team photographs from the 1920s and 1930s, his hand brushes each page and he utters one word in Nepali: "Chaina." They are gone.

How the old Sherpa came to be in Darjeeling is mixed up in the economic and political revolution that the British brought to the Himalayan foothills of northern West Bengal and Sikkim. Where before there was no one and nothing but forest, the British made tea plantations and offered work to thousands of migrant workers from the Himalayan region. There were Rais, Limbus, Bhutanese, Lepchas, full-blown Tibetans and their cousins from the Khumbu region of Nepal in the shadow of Everest itself - the Sherpas.

When the British first started mountaineering in the Himalayas they cast around for the best porters to carry supplies in the thin air and extreme cold of high altitude. The Tibetans had the genetic advantage of having lived for generations at altitude, but they were high-spirited and unruly. The Gurungs, who had earned fame in the Gurkha regiments of the Indian Army, were willing and cheerful but couldn't climb at high altitude. The Sherpas, on the other hand, were ethnic Tibetans used to fitting into a Hindu world and found themselves quickly favoured by the Everest climbers who started each attempt from Darjeeling.

Ang Tsering sits by an open window looking across the hills of Sikkim from his house in the Darjeeling district of Toong Soong Busti, where Sherpas have lived for more than a century now. Frail and wheezing, he still has strong memories of those faraway days. On the first Everest expeditions in the 1920s, he recalls, Sherpas were there for one reason: "We went on expeditions to earn money. No one had any ambition to climb Everest." But while the sahibs had them carry tinned quail and champagne to base camp, working conditions for Sherpas were hard. In 1922, seven Sherpas were killed in an avalanche at 22,000ft and in 1924, during Ang Tsering's first expedition, two Gurkhas died of pneumonia and a stroke at base camp. Ang Tsering can still remember the biting cold. "Our clothes were too thin," he says simply.

Along with the dangers of frostbite and avalanche, the Sherpas were worried about the spiritual dangers of climbing Everest. Ang Tsering went to the head lama at the Rongbuk monastery at the base of the mountain, to ask for his blessing: "The rinpoche said that we should not climb Everest because things would get worse, not just in our lives, but in the world. He said I must help the chilling-na - the foreigners - because they would pay us." The monastery was destroyed during the Cultural Revolution following the Chinese occupation of Tibet.

I asked him how much he earned on that trip in 1924. "Twelve annas, that's three-quarters of a rupee." (In 1924, a rupee could buy 32lbs of rice.) Ang Tsering had also worked as a woodcutter: "I made 10 rupees a week as a woodcutter." "So why did you go to Everest for less money?" I ask him. There is a wheezy chuckle. "Because the work was easier."

Ang Tsering carried loads to above 26,000ft. While the graft and danger were shared by the Sherpas, they didn't grasp the foreigners' philosophical love of climbing mountains. Many held the view of the monks at Rongbuk that there was a lion made of pure gold on the summit, and that is what the British were after. In a way, they were right.

Mallory and Irvine became household names in their home country, but the Sherpas remained obscure, disappearing back into their homes in Toong Soong Busti. Ang Tsering at least has no complaints. "The British were very fair," he says. "They looked after us. If someone was killed in the mountains then the families would get compensation. The Sherpas couldn't do the paperwork and the Himalayan Club looked after that." The Himalayan Club, based in Darjeeling, became an employment agency for expeditions, regulating working conditions for Sherpas like Ang Tsering. Their secretaries became closely involved with the Sherpa community, perhaps the most famous being Jill Henderson after the war. "Mrs Henderson was a very good lady. Once a week she would come and see everybody - every Sherpa house - and ask how everyone was. And if anyone was sick, she would arrange for a doctor. For a long time, every Sherpa house would have a picture of her in their houses."

There is another picture in Ang Tsering's home of a square-shouldered Sherpani dressed in her best clothers smiling at the camera. His wife, Pasang Diki, died in Darjeeling in 1960, the same year as Ang Tsering's mother died in his home village. Ang Tsering was on yet another expedition to Everest but he turned his back on the mountain the Sherpas call Chomolungma. "I said to the mountain: 'I promise I'll never go to you to climb again.'"

He and his wife had 12 children, eight of whom are still alive. Three of them worked in the mountains, like their father, but there are few Sherpas left in Darjeeling who still climb. "They want jobs in government departments now," says Ang Tsering. "If they work for the government then they'll get pensions." It isn't a matter of regret for him.

There are still plenty of Sherpas working on Everest and other mountains, and wages are now comparatively good; a top Sherpa can earn $3,000 in a season in a country with an annual per capita income of only $200. The romantic story of these explorers dressed in their tweeds and puttees is not just about whether they reached the summit before they perished, 29 years before Sir Edmund Hillary and Tenzing Norgay climbed the mountain. It has become a myth from an age of innocence, before modernity's consumerism and egocentricity overwhelmed Everest in an avalanche of sponsors' badges and empty oxygen bottles. But while the Americans hope to bask in the reflected glory of Irvine's courage, there is a more direct link to this era. Because while all the sahibs who watched Mallory and Irvine disappear forever in the spring of 1924 are long since dead, one of the Sherpas who climbed with them is still alive, now aged 97, and living in the Indian hill station of Darjeeling, under the huge massif of Kangchenjunga. Ang Tsering was born in Nepal in 1904 in the remote village of Thame close to the border with Tibet. One of five brothers, he tended the family yak herd, but left the Everest region in October 1920, looking for work in Darjeeling. Through a combination of chance and courage, he ended up being one of the best-known Sherpas of the pre-war period, going to Everest with the British in 1924 and 1933 and to the huge peak of Nanga Parbat, now in Pakistan, with a German team in 1934. As he turns the pages of his photo album, revealing team photographs from the 1920s and 1930s, his hand brushes each page and he utters one word in Nepali: "Chaina." They are gone. How the old Sherpa came to be in Darjeeling is mixed up in the economic and political revolution that the British brought to the Himalayan foothills of northern West Bengal and Sikkim. Where before there was no one and nothing but forest, the British made tea plantations and offered work to thousands of migrant workers from the Himalayan region. There were Rais, Limbus, Bhutanese, Lepchas, full-blown Tibetans and their cousins from the Khumbu region of Nepal in the shadow of Everest itself - the Sherpas. When the British first started mountaineering in the Himalayas they cast around for the best porters to carry supplies in the thin air and extreme cold of high altitude. The Tibetans had the genetic advantage of having lived for generations at altitude, but they were high-spirited and unruly. The Gurungs, who had earned fame in the Gurkha regiments of the Indian Army, were willing and cheerful but couldn't climb at high altitude. The Sherpas, on the other hand, were ethnic Tibetans used to fitting into a Hindu world and found themselves quickly favoured by the Everest climbers who started each attempt from Darjeeling. Ang Tsering sits by an open window looking across the hills of Sikkim from his house in the Darjeeling district of Toong Soong Busti, where Sherpas have lived for more than a century now. Frail and wheezing, he still has strong memories of those faraway days. On the first Everest expeditions in the 1920s, he recalls, Sherpas were there for one reason: "We went on expeditions to earn money. No one had any ambition to climb Everest." But while the sahibs had them carry tinned quail and champagne to base camp, working conditions for Sherpas were hard. In 1922, seven Sherpas were killed in an avalanche at 22,000ft and in 1924, during Ang Tsering's first expedition, two Gurkhas died of pneumonia and a stroke at base camp. Ang Tsering can still remember the biting cold. "Our clothes were too thin," he says simply. Along with the dangers of frostbite and avalanche, the Sherpas were worried about the spiritual dangers of climbing Everest. Ang Tsering went to the head lama at the Rongbuk monastery at the base of the mountain, to ask for his blessing: "The rinpoche said that we should not climb Everest because things would get worse, not just in our lives, but in the world. He said I must help the chilling-na - the foreigners - because they would pay us." The monastery was destroyed during the Cultural Revolution following the Chinese occupation of Tibet. I asked him how much he earned on that trip in 1924. "Twelve annas, that's three-quarters of a rupee." (In 1924, a rupee could buy 32lbs of rice.) Ang Tsering had also worked as a woodcutter: "I made 10 rupees a week as a woodcutter." "So why did you go to Everest for less money?" I ask him. There is a wheezy chuckle. "Because the work was easier." Ang Tsering carried loads to above 26,000ft. While the graft and danger were shared by the Sherpas, they didn't grasp the foreigners' philosophical love of climbing mountains. Many held the view of the monks at Rongbuk that there was a lion made of pure gold on the summit, and that is what the British were after. In a way, they were right. Mallory and Irvine became household names in their home country, but the Sherpas remained obscure, disappearing back into their homes in Toong Soong Busti. Ang Tsering at least has no complaints. "The British were very fair," he says. "They looked after us. If someone was killed in the mountains then the families would get compensation. The Sherpas couldn't do the paperwork and the Himalayan Club looked after that." The Himalayan Club, based in Darjeeling, became an employment agency for expeditions, regulating working conditions for Sherpas like Ang Tsering. Their secretaries became closely involved with the Sherpa community, perhaps the most famous being Jill Henderson after the war. "Mrs Henderson was a very good lady. Once a week she would come and see everybody - every Sherpa house - and ask how everyone was. And if anyone was sick, she would arrange for a doctor. For a long time, every Sherpa house would have a picture of her in their houses." There is another picture in Ang Tsering's home of a square-shouldered Sherpani dressed in her best clothers smiling at the camera. His wife, Pasang Diki, died in Darjeeling in 1960, the same year as Ang Tsering's mother died in his home village. Ang Tsering was on yet another expedition to Everest but he turned his back on the mountain the Sherpas call Chomolungma. "I said to the mountain: 'I promise I'll never go to you to climb again.'" He and his wife had 12 children, eight of whom are still alive. Three of them worked in the mountains, like their father, but there are few Sherpas left in Darjeeling who still climb. "They want jobs in government departments now," says Ang Tsering. "If they work for the government then they'll get pensions." It isn't a matter of regret for him. There are still plenty of Sherpas working on Everest and other mountains, and wages are now comparatively good; a top Sherpa can earn $3,000 in a season in a country with an annual per capita income of only $200. fields.headline: Dumbing up
fields.standfirst:
We may be cleverer than we think we are

Special report: are we dumbing down?
fields.trailText: We may not know who won the battle of 1066 - but we can tell you that if Gina is faster than Jane, and Jo is slower than Gina, then Jo is not necessarily faster than Jane.
fields.body:
We may not know who won the battle of 1066 - but we can tell you that if Gina is faster than Jane, and Jo is slower than Gina, then Jo is not necessarily faster than Jane. So what if we struggle to link Romeo with Juliet? We know something far more valuable: that it is possible to use three colours to paint the sides of a cube in such a way that two sides of the same colour never touch - so there.

In other words, we may know nothing about anything but our IQ is rising. That, at least, is the finding of a new study which suggests we are smarter now than ever before. Britons' average IQ has risen by 27 points since 1942, while Americans' have seen their collective brainpower surge ahead by 24 points since 1918. The authors of the new research, published in America's Psychological Review, attribute the advance to the more stimulating environment that exists now compared to a century ago. TV programmes, the internet, even kitchen-table conversation, are all bubbling away with more information than was ever available in the olden days. Whether it is Chris Tarrant stretching our brain cells on ITV, pub quizzes giving us a mental workout or the infernally difficult timer system on the home video, 21st-century life is a veritable gymnasium for the grey matter.

Yet how do we square this optimistic news with the anecdotal evidence of "dumbing down" all around us? Are we really so smart when the Guardian's recent survey found hardly any Britons can name four pre-war prime ministers and only a few can quote a single line of poetry? There are three possible explanations for this contradiction: 1) the anecdotal evidence of dumbing down could be wrong; 2) we could simultaneously be getting sharper and forgetting what used to be regarded as the foundations of western culture; 3) or perhaps IQ is simply a useless indicator, measuring neither knowledge nor wisdom but rather a knack for doing silly puzzles. Remember: you can only choose one answer.

fields.headline: Giuseppe Sinopoli
fields.standfirst: Italian composer and conductor whose analytical approach to masterpieces led to a love-hate relationship with the British public and critics.
fields.trailText: Italian composer and conductor whose analytical approach to masterpieces led to a love-hate relationship with the British public and critics.
fields.body:
One of the most interestingly controversial musical figures of his generation, the Italian conductor and composer Giuseppe Sinopoli has died, aged 54, of a heart attack while conducting a Berlin performance of Verdi's Aida - the work with which he made his operatic debut in his native Venice in 1978.

The symmetry might suggest a straight career trajectory for a man destined to conduct the great operas and symphonies of the Italian and German repertoires. In fact, the development of the young Sinopoli was altogether more interesting, and makes more sense of the studied, analytic light in which he revealed - or, for some listeners, destroyed - familiar masterpieces. Until 1981, Sinopoli's reputation might have stood as a composer, following, to a certain extent, the examples of his fellow Venetian Bruno Maderna and the Veronese Franco Donatoni. Like Maderna, he studied for a while at Venice's Benedetto Marcello Conservatoire, but found greater fulfilment when he followed the senior composer to the more challenging musical environment of Darmstadt.

Parallel to this rigorous schooling, he followed the wishes of his Sicilian father and worked for a doctor's degree in medicine as a surgeon and psychiatrist at the University of Padua. In 1972, both of his disciplines came to fruition: he was appointed professor of contemporary and electronic music at the Venice Conservatoire, graduating meanwhile in Padua with a doctoral dissertation on criminal anthropology and, in the psychiatric field, a study on the physiology of the acoustic mental area. He also took his first steps in conducting with Hans Swarowsky in Vienna, founding Venice's Bruno Maderna Ensemble three years later; his first major recording, in 1981, was of Maderna's music, though few such daring choices of repertoire ensued.

His compositions, like his later conducting, combined structural rigour with sensuous textures. Yet few of them have been heard in this country; and after the 1981 Munich premiere of his opera Lou Salome, taking as its protagonist the far-from-bluestocking colleague and muse of Nietzsche and Freud, composing took a back seat to conducting.

The 1980s was the decade in which Sinopoli the conductor came to power. His operatic supremacy was confirmed in 1985 with performances of Puccini's Tosca at the Metropolitan Opera, New York, and Wagner's Tannhauser at the festival shrine of Bayreuth, where he was due to return to conduct the Ring cycle this summer. He injected new life into Rome's Accademia di Santa Cecilia Orchestra during a four-year tenure. He also began his love-hate relationship with the British public and critics, conducting Puccini's Manon Lescaut at the Royal Opera House, before taking up his post as principal conductor of the Philharmonia - with, as he admitted, little experience of large-scale symphonic concerts - in 1984. It is easy to see where the critical hostility came from: Sinopoli's preference for slow speeds and mannered, sometimes lifeless phrasing, brought back a juggernaut approach to Brahms and Schumann at a time when authentic liveliness was the order of the day, and could result in some leaden evenings in the concert hall.

Yet there was always the phenomenal ear for layering of textures, however eccentric - the brass perspectives in his Bruckner interpretations were impressive, and recognisably Sinopolian, whatever the doubts about the pacing of the perfor mance - and the capacity to surprise. The Mahler symphonies which he performed with the orchestra and subsequently recorded for his loyal company, Deutsche Grammophon, flashed only occasional theatrical fire until an astonishing interpretation of the maverick Seventh, the hardest of the series to balance and articulate. Taking place in the Royal Festival Hall within days of a performance by the reigning Mahler conductor, Klaus Tennstedt, it bore the results of endless preparation; though in the cold light of the recording, the usual eccentricities of tempo and emphasis can easily pall.

The players, of course, remained baffled by Sinopoli's peculiarly Italian brand of intellectualism; London musicians never like too much talk, let alone an analytic seminar on the work in question. The Philharmonia relationship, buckling under the weight of the critical opprobrium, nearly came to an end in early 1990; but Sinopoli stayed on in his ennobled capacity as music director until 1994. There was too much at stake - the ever-fruitful contract with Deutsche Grammophon and tours to countries such as Japan and Germany, which idolised the maestro as Britain never did. The Italian opera recordings, to which the Philharmonia lent an unprecedented degree of tonal beauty, were generally better received than Sinopoli's symphonic repertoire. Here, too, there were sometimes justified charges of excessive mannerism; and the conductor's habit of laying everything on the dissecting table resulted in conspicuous recording edits, sometimes in the middle of a singer's phrase or note. Yet Sinopoli's surprising affinity with the natural flow of the bel canto line usually triumphed, even at some dangerously slow speeds; his Madame Butterfly, with Mirella Freni in the title role, exposes the tough psychological study embedded in a lush musical idiom.

A new and significant post at the head of Berlin's Deutsche Oper, which he briefly took up in 1990, came to an end over details in the contract, though it did at least result in a shimmering, microscopically detailed recording of Strauss's Salome (the sequel, Elektra, made in Vienna, confirmed Sinopoli as an exacting master of Strauss's most complex scores). He moved instead to the Staatskapelle Dresden, where the marriage of this subtle, soft-grained institution with an altogether tougher and more aggressively intellectual master succeeded against all odds; earlier this year they undertook a punishing American tour. Sinopoli's long-term ambition to benefit from the fruits of his archaeological studies at Rome University, and to indulge them with a swift retirement from the world of music, was not to be fulfilled; though his schedule for the near future shows no suggestion that he was near to attaining his dream. There is, inevitably, a frustrating sense of incompleteness; but at least half of his recorded legacy makes an impressive testament.

Sinopoli leaves behind a wife, Silvia, whom he married in 1979, and two sons.

 Giuseppe Sinopoli, conductor and composer, born November 2 1946; died April 20 2001
