fields.headline: Clinic to challenge embryo rule
fields.standfirst: Fertility expert goes to court in fight against government limit on IVF treatment
fields.trailText: The head of Britain's most successful IVF clinic and a 46-year-old patient who has made eight unsuccessful attempts to have a baby will go to court in London tomorrow to challenge a rule which says doctors should not implant more than three embryos at a time in a would-be mother's womb.
fields.body:
The head of Britain's most successful IVF clinic and a 46-year-old patient who has made eight unsuccessful attempts to have a baby will go to court in London tomorrow to challenge a rule which says doctors should not implant more than three embryos at a time in a would-be mother's womb.

In a case with powerful implications for the increasingly tense relationship between regulators and fertility doctors, the woman, who is not being named, and Mohammed Taranissi, head of the private Assisted Reproduction and Gynaecology Unit, are seeking a judicial review of guidelines laid down by the government's IVF watchdog, the human fertilisation and embryology authority (HFEA).

The HFEA maintains that implanting more than three embryos gives an unacceptable risk of the mother becoming pregnant with triplets, putting the babies in danger.

Mr Taranissi accuses the HFEA of restricting the freedom of doctors to use their own judgment and to help patients on a case-by-case basis.

He and his patient want to use five embryos. He said it was ridiculous to suggest that a 46-year-old woman who had endured eight IVF cycles of three embryos each without a single pregnancy would miraculously become pregnant with triplets if an extra two embryos were put back.

"Some of those who argue against this say that my pa tient's chances of getting pregnant are very small. How can she have a very small chance of becoming pregnant and at the same time have a high risk of multiple births?" Mr Taranissi said.

During IVF, a woman's eggs are removed, fertilised with the father's sperm, and the embryos reimplanted.

The unnamed patient requires IVF treatment because of blocked fallopian tubes. She has been trying to have a baby for five years, and is thought to have already spent about £24,000.

"There shouldn't be one rule for everybody," Mr Taranissi said. "It's wrong in principle. Even if the three-embryo rule is right for 95% of people, they have to acknowledge that a small percentage will be com promised by this blanket approach.

"It shouldn't be up to the HFEA to make this kind of decision. It's not on medical grounds, it's on political grounds, and they shouldn't be in the position of nannying clinics, telling them what they should and shouldn't do. There should be some flexibility."

Mr Taranissi's clinic has the highest success rate in the UK, with about 40% of treatment cycles resulting in a live birth: the national average is just under 20%.

The HFEA's guidelines are not binding on IVF clinics, but the authority has the right to remove the licence from any clinic which breaches them.

His lawyers believe that Mr Taranissi's patient would have a case against the HFEA under the European Convention on Human Rights if the authority blocked her wishes.

The authority is under pressure on a number of fronts from IVF patients and clinics as it struggles to weigh the pros and cons of a flood of new techniques for screening embryos before implantation.

It has already provoked anger for its refusal to allow patients to choose the sex of their child, or to allow clinics to screen embryos for chromosomal abnormalities. It is also under surveillance by religious groups, rightwing newspapers and elements of the eco-warrior movement, eager to pounce on any sign that it is becoming more laissez-faire.

Mr Taranissi said: "The HFEA is worried [the trial] will open the doors for all the clinics to do all sorts of things they don't like. This is unrealistic. The authority can always go back to a clinic and tell them something is unsuitable. But why should we have to assume everybody is irresponsible?"

Mr Taranissi is also opposed by much of the medical establishment. The Royal College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists and the British Fertility Association would like to see the maximum number of embryos put back reduced to two. Women who are pregnant with triplets often give birth prematurely. The babies are far less likely to survive and have a much greater risk of cerebral palsy.

An HFEA spokesman was not available for comment yesterday.

webTitle: Blunkett and Brown in battle of the books

fields.headline: Blunkett and Brown in battle of the books
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown and David Blunkett will go head-to-head after the election by publishing books outlining their visions of the future of the Labour party.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown and David Blunkett will go head-to-head after the election by publishing books outlining their visions of the future of the Labour party.

Barely-concealed ambitions to lead the Labour party will surface as the two cabinet heavyweights publish their thoughts on the future of socialism.

Both books will be seen as bids to stake out the respective authors' claims to lead the party if and when Tony Blair relinquishes the reigns of power.

The chancellor's book, which he has been writing for the past three years, was finally finished and a manuscript delivered to the Treasury last month. Its 360 pages spell out Gordon Brown's vision of the future of social democracy.

Mr Brown is now deciding whether to go ahead with publication after weighing up what one Westminster insider described as "the perils of how publication would be perceived."

The book is said by publishing sources to be "an exploration of ideas, rather than his minute by minute negotiations on the London tube."

The chancellor has written the majority of the book himself, with the remainder penned by Raymond Plant, professor of European thought at Southampton University.

Today Prof Plant refused to comment on the book, which has already had one putative title rejected by the chancellor. It is not expected to be published ahead of a general election.

webTitle: Davids done for drugs as Roma roll on

fields.headline: Davids done for drugs as Roma roll on
fields.trailText: Serie A returned to normal this weekend, with the leaders Roma back to winning ways, leading scorers Andriy Shevchenko and Hernan Crespo getting a goal each, concerns about racist abuse at Lazio and, oh yes, a drugs scandal overshadowing everything.
fields.body:
Serie A returned to normal this weekend, with the leaders Roma back to winning ways, leading scorers Andriy Shevchenko and Hernan Crespo getting a goal each, concerns about racist abuse at Lazio and, oh yes, a drugs scandal overshadowing everything.

According to La Gazzetta dello Sport, Juventus midfielder Edgar Davids has tested positive for nandrolone. He denies the charges, but he faces a suspension of up to two years if found guilty.

Davids is the eighth Serie A player to fail a drugs test this season and the seventh to test positive for nandrolone. He was tested after Juve's game against Udinese on March 4, and apparently aome up "non-negative".

Davids nevertheless played for Juventus on Sunday afternoon - and played well in a 0-0 draw against fourth-placed Parma.

The Parma fans greeted him with whistles, but he ended the game as man of the match.

"Edgar did not have a great match but a superb one," the Juventus coach Carlo Ancelotti said. "If he needed to he gave a great answer with such a game."

It did Juve little good. The Old Lady huffed and puffed but failed to crack the Parma defence. The French international striker David Trezeguet had two good chances to win the game inside the final 10 minutes but he first shot weakly at Gianluigi Buffon and then opted to pass in the final seconds with a clear sight of goal.

"We showed we are still alive," Ancelotti said. But the gap between his team and Roma is back up to six points with seven games to go after the leaders won 3-1 at Udinese.

Damiano Tommasi helped to scale down the doubts after two disappointing results by helping Roma into a 2-0 half-time lead. His 39th-minute shot was too hot for Luigi Turci to handle and Vincenzo Montella knocked in the rebound for his 15th goal in 19 appearances. Then Tommasi got one himself in injury-time.

Hidetoshi Nakata put Roma three up in the 66th minute, when he clipped a running volley from a Cafu cross into the top corner.

"We were resolute and focused and relaxed a little only in the last 15 minutes," said the Roma coach Fabio Capello. "Results have gone against us, but we have always played great football."

Roma's next two games are against their only remaining rivals for the scudetto, with the Rome derby against Lazio next Sunday and Juventus at the Stadio delle Alpi the following week.

Lazio may find themselves with an even trickier run-in if fears that they may be temporarily exiled from the Stadio Olimpico are realised. They picked up their fifth fine of the season after their fans abused Parma's black players recently. "If it happens again," said the Lazio president Sergio Cragnotti, "they will pull us out of the Stadio Olimpico."

Lazio remain seven points off the pace after their 2-1 win in Vicenza on Sunday. Diego Simeone gave them the lead 10 minutes before half-time before Crespo scored his 19th league goal of the season.

Their three closest pursuers, Parma, Atalanta and Milan, all drew on Sunday. Milan needed a last-minute goal from their Georgian international Kakha Kaladze at Lecce to gain a 3-3 draw. And Atalanta conceded a last-minute equaliser at Perugia when the Korean international Ahn Jung-Hwan struck from 20 yards.

At the bottom of Serie A, Bari lie five points adrift after going down 4-2 at Bologna, for whom Giuseppe Signori scored twice. And Reggina won 3-0 at Verona in a game in which they were reduced to 10 men at the end of the first half. Francesco Cozza received a red card almost immediately after putting Reggina 2-0 up, but the visitors kept their nerve and their clean sheet while Verona had two players sent off in the second half.

Napoli missed a chance to climb out of the relegation zone when they conceded an equaliser to a Roberto Baggio free-kick deep into injury-time of their game against Brescia at the Stadio San Paolo on Saturday.

webTitle: Van Nistelrooy signs £19m deal with United

fields.headline: Van Nistelrooy signs £19m deal with United
fields.trailText: Ruud van Nistelrooy has completed a British-record £19m transfer to Manchester United. In a statement to the Stock Exchange, United confirmed that the PSV Eindhoven striker has signed a five-year contract starting July 1.
fields.body:
Ruud van Nistelrooy has completed a British-record £19m transfer to Manchester United. In a statement to the Stock Exchange, United confirmed that the PSV Eindhoven striker has signed a five-year contract starting July 1.

Van Nistelrooy's fee, £500,000 more than had been originally agreed last year, eclipses the £18m that took Rio Ferdinand from West Ham to Leeds this season.

"I am very pleased to have finally signed for Manchester United," said Van Nistelrooy. "In spite of what has happened in the past year, my feelings for the club have never diminished.

"It has always been a dream of mine to play for United at Old Trafford, so this move has been a very easy choice for me to make and I look forward to playing for the club next season.

"Even when I was convalescing, they spoke to me, which tells me a lot about the club," Van Nistelrooy told the official PSV website. "I had a fantastic time at PSV and no matter where I am, I will always look out for them. But Manchester United are a club I always wanted to play for."

Over the weekend, Van Nistelrooy flew to Manchester for a medical, which confirmed there was no permanent problem from the serious cruciate knee ligament injury he suffered a year ago. And today, after agreeing personal terms, the Dutch striker finally completed the move.

Sir Alex Ferguson admitted: "I am delighted that we have signed Ruud, a player we have admired for some time. The deal underlines our determination to improve the squad at United.

"We've been monitoring his progress throughout the recuperation period and I'm very happy with the way things have gone.

"Strikers are always going to cost a lot these days but if you can get one who is not only top class but still only 24, it's even better," he added. "It means the position is covered, barring accidents, for four or five years down the line."

Van Nistelrooy's arrival at Old Trafford will further intensify the battle for places up front - or force one of the four strikers already there out of the club.

Teddy Sheringham is out of contract at the end of the season, but has been offered a new one-year deal worth an estimated £35,000 a week - and Sheringham insisted at the weekend that the Dutch striker's signing would have no bearing on his decision.

He said: "It's no different from any other year. There are always big signings coming in and we have to compete with big players at this club.

"It's good for the club but it's no different from my point of view."

webTitle: Lib Dems call for reform of the CRE

fields.headline: Lib Dems call for reform of the CRE
fields.standfirst: The document in full
fields.trailText: The Liberal Democrats today joined the furore over the politicisation of race by choosing St George's Day to publish an ethnic minority manifesto.
fields.body:
The Liberal Democrats today joined the furore over the politicisation of race by choosing St George's Day to publish an ethnic minority manifesto.

The document - which comes in the middle of an ongoing row over candidates signing up to the commission for racial equality's race pledge - would see the foundation of an equality commission to replace the CRE.

It would establish an independent police complaints authority and an end the crime of blasphemy, which only relates to the Christian religion. Another proposal is to keep the right to jury trial, in a bid to help ethnic minority defendants facing an all white magistrates panel.

All Lib Dem MPs have now signed the anti-racism pledge and Mr Kennedy has already called on William Hague, the Conservative leader, to remove the whip from the three Tory MPs whom have already vowed not to sign up to the pledge.

Lib Dem leader Charles Kennedy warned that any prospective MPs planning to play the race card could suffer. He said: "If there is an attempt by candidates to play on people's fears as opposed to addressing their hopes I think it will backfire badly."

Mr Kennedy, who was flanked by Lib Dem prospective parliamentary candidates from ethnic minorities at the launch, said the media as well as politicians had a duty to act responsibly over race. "Loose talk, irresponsible talks and easy media headlines can lead to genuine social problems down the line for a lot of people," he added.

The Lib Dems have more ethnic candidates standing in the UK's 659 constituencies than any other party. However, a spokesman for the party was today unable to specify how many of those candidates were in winnable seats.

He said: "We don't categorise seats as winnable after our success in Romsey."

fields.headline: Tory advert inflames race row
fields.standfirst:
Party accused of playing on asylum fears

Special report: race issues in the UK Politics: Election 2001
fields.trailText: Conservatives have been accused of playing on asylum fears after Tories in Kent placed an advert seeking to tap into local fears about 'bogus' asylum seekers. By Vikram Dodd, Lucy Ward and Tania Branigan.
fields.byline: Vikram Dodd, Lucy Ward and Tania Branigan
fields.body:
William Hague's efforts to neutralise the race row enveloping his party were dealt a blow last night after it emerged that Tories in Kent had placed a newspaper advertisement seeking to tap into local fears about "bogus" asylum seekers.

Former home secretary Michael Howard's constituency party in Folkestone and Hythe placed the advertisement, which a leading refugee charity said played blatantly on fears of racism.

But the Conservative leader yesterday insisted that his party would not be diverted by allegations of racism from making asylum a key campaign issue in the coming election, as the fallout from three Tory MPs' refusal to sign a pledge not to pander to racial prejudice continued.

Mr Hague's chief adviser on ethnic minority issues raised the stakes further by suggesting that the role of the commission for racial equality, which drew up the pledge, should be reviewed, suggesting it was addressing an agenda which had "outlived its usefulness".

Mohammed Riaz, who exchanges ideas regularly with the Conservative leader on race issues, told the Guardian: "A review is necessary, not because of the recent problems that the CRE has faced but because, as a body that has lasted many years, it is never ever clear what type of agenda they are working towards or what are their ultimate aims."

Defending his local party's advertisement, Mr Howard said the rise in asylum claims was "one of the most important issues" in his constituency. Tension has been high in Kent over the issue, with groups helping asylum seekers reporting violence against those who say they are fleeing persecution.

Under the heading Common Sense, the advert asks voters: "What matters most to you?", then says in bold text: "Bogus asylum seekers?", before promising that the Conservatives "reduced the number before. We will do so again. Conservatives will get it right."

Helen Bamber, director of the medical foundation for the care of victims of torture, said: "In the context of previous violence towards asylum seekers in Kent it's inviting hatred. It's so desperately untrue to suggest that most asylum seekers are bogus. It gives no recognition that large numbers of those who come to Britain are fleeing persecution and torture.

"Home office statistics show that of those applications that receive full consideration at least half get a positive decision."

The Liberal Democrats, aiming to overturn Mr Howard's 6,300 majority, condemned the advertisement. A party spokesperson said: "Michael Howard knows that his days are numbered and desperate times equals desperate measures.

"This is just the type of nasty sentiment that William Hague should be stamping on. It's no surprise that Mr Howard hasn't signed up to the CRE compact."

Mr Howard defended the advert and rubbished claims of pandering to prejudice: "People in my constituency are deeply concerned at the number of asylum seekers coming into this country illegally.

"Very large numbers are being picked up on the Eurotunnel terminal which is in my constituency. The government has completely failed to deal with this problem and its an entirely legitimate matter of public debate as is accepted in terms by the CRE document."

The Conservatives last night declined to comment directly on the advertisement or whether the national party endorsed it. A Central Office spokesman said: "William Hague made a statement on Saturday reiterating that racism has no place in the Conservative party."

For Labour, home office minister Barbara Roche said: "Given the Conservatives' record on asylum policy, it can be no surprise to the Tory party that they are accused of exploiting the issue rather than dealing with it."

The race row, which last week saw the Tory party divided over the CRE pledge, which Mr Hague signed but shadow chancellor Michael Portillo rejected, grew more bitter yesterday.

Mr Hague, writing in the Sunday Telegraph, accused Labour of a "shabby and contemptible" attempt to gag his party over asylum, and shadow home secretary Ann Widdecombe dismissed the race pledge as "silly", suggesting Labour had accused the Tories of racism to hide its asylum policy failings.

Liberal Democrat leader Charles Kennedy urged Mr Hague to expel from his party all MPs who refuse to sign the pledge not to play the race card in the election campaign. The broadcaster and Labour chairman of the Greater London Assembly Trevor Phillips described racism as "the canker at the heart of the Tories" and accused Mr Hague of failing to deal with it.

Meanwhile, the CRE faced accusations from former Conservative chairman Sir Brian Mawhinney and others of behaving irresponsibly and of being seen as partisan, with some Tories privately claiming the body had worked in league with Labour to embarrass the Conservatives over the compact.

CRE chairman Gurbux Singh said the row over which MPs had signed its pledge had overshadowed the fact that all parties had failed on the race issue. He said: "I want to see a positive, healthy discussion as opposed to political parties throwing mud at each other. That, I think, is deeply saddening.

"I believe that all political parties are failing."

But there will be pressure among some Conservatives for revenge against the CRE, though the party has no policy to reform the body. One Tory source said: "If the CRE continue to behave in cahoots with and act as the mouthpiece of the Labour party, we may think of radical reform."

A senior CRE source said claims that the watchdog had set out to embarrass the Tories were nonsense: "It's not the commission scoring points, it's the Tories scoring own goals. Their stance on race is in complete disarray, they don't know if they're coming or going."

Mr Hague, writing in the Sunday Telegraph, accused Labour of a "shabby and contemptible" attempt to gag his party over asylum, and shadow home secretary Ann Widdecombe dismissed the race pledge as "silly", suggesting Labour had accused the Tories of racism to hide its asylum policy failings. Liberal Democrat leader Charles Kennedy urged Mr Hague to expel from his party all MPs who refuse to sign the pledge not to play the race card in the election campaign. The broadcaster and Labour chairman of the Greater London Assembly Trevor Phillips described racism as "the canker at the heart of the Tories" and accused Mr Hague of failing to deal with it. Meanwhile, the CRE faced accusations from former Conservative chairman Sir Brian Mawhinney and others of behaving irresponsibly and of being seen as partisan, with some Tories privately claiming the body had worked in league with Labour to embarrass the Conservatives over the compact. CRE chairman Gurbux Singh said the row over which MPs had signed its pledge had overshadowed the fact that all parties had failed on the race issue. He said: "I want to see a positive, healthy discussion as opposed to political parties throwing mud at each other. That, I think, is deeply saddening. "I believe that all political parties are failing." But there will be pressure among some Conservatives for revenge against the CRE, though the party has no policy to reform the body. One Tory source said: "If the CRE continue to behave in cahoots with and act as the mouthpiece of the Labour party, we may think of radical reform." A senior CRE source said claims that the watchdog had set out to embarrass the Tories were nonsense: "It's not the commission scoring points, it's the Tories scoring own goals. Their stance on race is in complete disarray, they don't know if they're coming or going."

webTitle: Comment: A race row swirls around doomed Conservatives

fields.headline: A race row swirls around doomed Conservatives
fields.standfirst:
The trimmer Portillo is a man without qualities, in a collapsing party

Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: The trimmer Portillo is a man without qualities, in a collapsing party.
fields.body:
Michael Portillo's refusal to put his signature to the all-party declaration against racism may come to be remembered as the moment when the Tories passed the point of no return. A move in a leadership struggle that is being waged only weeks before a general election, his action is testimony to the fact that the party has failed to reshape itself to match the values of the majority of voters. As a result, like the Liberals in the 1920s, it seems destined to remain stuck on the impotent margins of politics.

It has long been clear that Portillo's project is to bury the party's Thatcherite past and take it back on to the centre ground. He knows the Tories must reinvent themselves if they are ever to return to power. The difficulty he faces is that far from preparing the party for the large shift that is needed, William Hague has re- inforced its most atavistic traits.

This is not because the Tory leader shares them. Mr Hague is certainly not a racist, more a ventriloquist who voices what he believes to be the prejudices of others. Certainly, promising to "reclaim Britain" and prevent it from becoming a "foreign land" (as Hague did in his ill-judged speech in Harrogate) may raise a cheer from the ageing ranks of party stalwarts. For most voters, however, it merely confirms that the Tories no longer understand, or even much like, the country they seek to govern.

It is tempting to pin the blame for the party's plight on Hague and his advisers, but in fact they are wrestling with an almost insoluble dilemma. Hague's party is a casualty of Mrs Thatcher's deconstruction of Tory Britain. It no longer knows whom or what it represents. Until Margaret Thatcher launched her assault on the country's institutions, Conservatives could claim to embody a certain vision of what it is to be British.

Today, when they survive their wipe-out in Scotland and Wales only by virtue of devolution and proportional representation, such a claim is laughable. The constitutional ancien regime Baroness Thatcher revered and the traditional social order she sought to restore are barely memories. For the country, that is no bad thing. With all its conflicts and blemishes, Britain is a livelier and more interesting place than it has been for decades. For the Tories, however, the passing of the old Britain is a disaster, for it has stripped them of their identity as a party.

Michael Portillo has defended his refusal to sign the Commission for Racial Equality's declaration against racism as a libertarian stand against stereotyped, politically correct politics. More plausibly it is an attempt to shore up his support in a party in which the right has become too strong to be openly challenged. Faced with the passing of the old Britain, large numbers of Tories in the constituencies have retreated into an imagined and - if you scratch beneath the surface - ethnically charged Englishness. These are people whose support Portillo cannot do without if he is to win in the postal ballot of party members that will finally decide the leadership, in the event of a challenge to Mr Hague after the election.

It is no secret that for some time Mr Portillo has been courting what remains of the Tory left. It is equally well known that he has incurred the hostility of many of his former friends and allies. Though not all are of one mind, Mr Portillo's rhetorical gestures to social liberalism and the suspicion that he has softened his opposition to the single currency have evoked deep mistrust and a sense of betrayal among die-hard Thatcherites.

These sentiments will have been strengthened by reports of a telephone conversation between Kenneth Clarke and John Stevens, the leader of the small breakaway pro-European Conservative party, suggesting that Mr Clarke had come to believe that Mr Portillo had shifted his ground on a number of issues. Against this background, Mr Portillo's refusal to sign the anti-racism declaration can only be seen as a gesture designed to placate the right.

It is by no means clear that it will have the desired effect. The result of Mr Portillo's manoeuvrings may only be to boost the position of his rivals on the right. If Mr Portillo is selected by Tory MPs as one of the two candidates to go forward to the postal ballot of all party members, there is no certainty that he will win - particularly if the other candidate is Ann Widdecombe (who has hedged her bets interestingly by announcing that she will sign the declaration) or an unambiguously rightwing figure such as Iain Duncan Smith.

To be sure, it will not be considerations of ideology that weigh heaviest in the minds of MPs when they cast their votes. It will be securing their seats. If Labour is returned this June with another massive majority, Tory MPs may flock to Mr Portillo in sufficient numbers to sway the constituencies in his favour. He may be handed the crown in sheer desperation.

Whether it is worth having in such circumstances is a moot point. Even in the wake of another Labour landslide, I remain unconvinced that Labour will - or should - incur the fateful risk of holding a referendum on the euro. But if the government takes the plunge and wins narrowly (the best it can hope for), it can no longer be taken for granted that the Tories would unite in accepting the result. It is more than likely that the Tories would resume their civil war, with Mr Portillo trapped helplessly in the crossfire, or else finally split - an upshot that would vindicate John Stevens's courageous decision to quit the party.

The events of the past week carry a powerful message about a Portillo-led Tory party. Mr Portillo knows where real power lies in his ranks and he will be extremely cautious in challenging it.

At the same time, he plainly understands that a reactionary Tory party, held together chiefly by mistrust of Europe and dislike of the country Britain has become, has no future. Torn between these conflicting imperatives, he has already shown himself a trimmer. Should he become leader, he seems set to go the way of William Hague and John Major, men without qualities cast by history in the role of hapless accomplices in the self-destruction of their party.

John Gray is professor of European thought at the LSE.

fields.headline: £2,000 for ridiculed curry-eating cleaner
fields.standfirst: Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: A Bangladeshi-born cleaner has been awarded £2,000 by an employment tribunal after his former work colleagues mocked him for eating curries.
fields.body:
A Bangladeshi-born cleaner has been awarded £2,000 by an employment tribunal after his former work colleagues mocked him for eating curries.

Sai Chowdhury, 32, from Wallasey, Merseyside, was sacked from his job at the Mother Redcaps Nursing Home in Wallasey for the poor standard of his work and his sickness record.

He told the tribunal in Liverpool: "I brought all sorts of curries and spicy rice dishes to work for my dinner. But soon other staff started complaining about the smell of curry. I was the only person picked on for their choice of food, even though people cooked things like fish and chips ... I am convinced I was sacked because I was different."

The tribunal ruled he had suffered racial harassment at work due to comments made by staff about the smell of the curries and awarded him £2,000 for hurt feelings. But they rejected his claims he was sacked due to his race.

fields.headline: Game over?
fields.trailText: Comment: on the surface, it's not looking good for sports websites at the moment, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
On the surface, it's not looking good for sports websites at the moment, but then again, the same could be said of any dot.com that is entirely dependent on advertising revenues.

The problem with sports websites however, is that everyone has one and there are only so many sports fans to go round.

Even if a site does manage to pull in millions of regular users, today's depressed online advertising market is not a happy place for money men to be at present.

Even Rob Hersov, the high-profile founder and chief executive of Sportal, in which BSkyB has a 5% stake, has even gone on record saying the sector has to consolidate to two players because it is far too competitive.

Mr Hersov is hoping that Sportal will be one of the two players that survive, although Sportal has not been immune to market woes, despite having raised £56m at launch two years ago.

Earlier this month it was reported by the Sunday Times that Sportal was looking for £7m in new funding and was close to putting itself up for sale.

Sportal has since denied such speculation, although it has recently been forced into making a number of staff redundancies and has been trying to sell a number of its non-money making websites for some time.

Two other sports websites are up for sale at the moment and plenty more are desperately seeking funding.

Sportinglife.com, a joint venture by the Mirror and Press Association, and Soccernet are both on the block, as is (reportedly) Quokka sports, the webcasting sports site.

Who will buy them? The usual suspects are all pulling out of sports websites, and rival websites, those that have already had acquisition pitches, are far too cash-strapped at the moment to risk feeling sorry for a competitor going out of business.

According to sources close to Sportinglife, the site is currently being shopped around for about £10m.

It's all a different picture from that painted a few years ago when sports websites were jostling for market recognition by any means possible - the preferred way was to spend millions of pounds on a TV marketing campaign.

Anyone remember that awful Kevin Keegan advert for Sportal during Euro 2000?

And was it really only 12 months ago that BSkyB bought Sports Internet Group for a whopping £310m, an operation that is now valued by analysts at a meagre £10m?

Consolidation is said to be the word on everybody's lips, but some within the industry are not entirely convinced buying up the smaller players is the right strategy.

Paul Wright, vice president of sales and marketing at Sports.com, a European offshoot of CBS SportsLine, asked what was the point of buying a desperate sports website when really all you buy is the staff, and that only adds more costs to your own bottom line?

"Sometimes it's better to sit it out, plod along, and wait for the market to pick up."

"It's a hard market at the moment, every penny is that much harder to get and it's all about weathering the storm. Those purely supported by advertising have got a problem full stop," added Mr Wright.

The only way out of this current slump is clear - develop new revenue streams.

For sport, e-commerce and betting are the obvious strands, especially since the idea of sports webcasting pay-per-view is still only a pipe dream.

fields.headline: Naked Sophie is most offensive advert of 2000
fields.standfirst: Table: top 10 offending ads of 2000
fields.trailText:
5pm: Yves St Laurent's poster featuring a naked Sophie Dahl received a third of complaints about poster advertising last year. By Claire Cozens.
Top 10 offending ads of 2000
fields.body:
The controversial poster for Yves St Laurent perfume featuring a naked Sophie Dahl accounted for a third of all complaints about poster advertising last year.

Almost 1,000 people complained about the advert, according to figures published today in the Advertising Standards Authority's annual report.

The ASA received 12,262 complaints last year, of which 2,696 were about poster adverts.

National newspapers attracted 2,216 complaints while direct mail sparked 2,059 complaints.

The second most complained about advert was for gas supplier Npower, which featured a ginger-haired family accompanied by the words: "There are some things in life you can't choose".

The ASA received 219 complaints from people who believed the advert was offensive to redheads, but the authority ruled they were not justified because it was intended to be lighthearted.

Other controversial campaigns included a poster of a woman's naked bottom for Marks & Spencer, and one for Benetton featuring a prisoner on death row.

Objections to two posters for underwear firm Gossard were upheld for being sexually explicit, and they were ordered to be removed.

fields.headline: Dando suspect appears in court
fields.standfirst: Special report: Jill Dando trial
fields.trailText: The man accused of murdering TV presenter Jill Dando appeared at the Old Bailey today for a short preliminary hearing which was held without press and public being allowed into court.
fields.body:
The man accused of murdering TV presenter Jill Dando appeared at the Old Bailey today for a short preliminary hearing which was held without press and public being allowed into court.

After 40 minutes the case was adjourned until noon tomorrow.

Barry George, 41, from Fulham, west London, has denied murdering 37-year-old Ms Dando, who was shot dead on the doorstep of her home in Fulham on April 26 1999.

Prosecuting in the case is senior Treasury counsel Orlando Pownall. Michael Mansfield QC is defending Mr George.

Mr Justice Gage is the presiding judge. The trial is expected to last up to six weeks.

fields.headline: Dixons chairman to step down
fields.trailText: 4.45pm: Dixons has confirmed its founder and chairman, Sir Stanley Kalms, is to quit the board next year, reports Ashley Davies.
fields.body:
Dixons has confirmed its founder and chairman, Sir Stanley Kalms, is to step down from the board next year.

The man who led the first large-scale new media sell-off - the partial flotation of Dixons' internet service provider Freeserve - plans to retire from the group's board at the annual general meeting in September 2002.

But a statement from Dixons announced: "It is intended he will become president of the company."

Earlier this year, Mr Kalms sent "sell" signals to the City when he loaned 3m shares to a third party.

The deal meant he could sell them at a fixed price but would not be committed to selling them.

Speculation about Mr Kalms' imminent departure was sparked last week when Dixons briefed a City headhunter to seek a potential replacement.

Mr Kalms has run the company for 43 years.

The company, which began life as a photographic studio, is now valued at £5bn.

webTitle: Teddy on the spot but Ruud on the verge

fields.headline: Teddy on the spot but Ruud on the verge
fields.trailText: Manchester United find themselves suffering in the football equivalent of purgatory: too good for the Premiership, not good enough for Europe.
fields.body:
Manchester United find themselves suffering in the football equivalent of purgatory: too good for the Premiership, not good enough for Europe.

The enervating effect of this form of limbo seems to have drained their resolve. Statistics say this is the best side in England, yet on Saturday they looked anything but, misplacing passes, misreading openings, squandering possession.

Never mind half an eye on the beach, they wandered through the motions as if already mentally plopping down a towel to reserve the sun lounger. At least there will not be any competition there: the Germans will be elsewhere, playing football.

It was lucky for United, in their Lennox Lewis mode, that City did not come equipped to exploit their lethargy. Anticipating a pasting, Joe Royle had stuffed his side with mountainous centre-backs, a thick blue line to stifle red attacks.

But unlike Hasim Rahman, the City manager forgot to pack an upper cut to put the complacent champions on their backside. Desperate for three points, City seemed tactically incapable of working out how to take more than one.

Paulo Wanchope, who had previously enjoyed his visits to Old Trafford, had one of his days when his limbs seem connected in the wrong order. Paul Dickov's main contribution was to give away a penalty. And Shaun Goater, when he came on, was clearly under orders to play like a United forward, giving the ball away with gusto.

The extent of City's ambition was summed up by Andrei Kanchelskis. Once a flying winger down the Old Trafford flanks, but now slowed by the biggest tongues seen on a football boot flapping around his ankles, he was substituted no more than 20 minutes after himself coming on.

So fed up with this farrago of a local derby was Roy Keane that he opted out. After his assault on Alf-Inge Haaland, United's captain trundled off to the biggest cheer of the day from the home fans. Keane has done many things deserving of a standing ovation this season: a mad-eyed revenge attack on a fellow pro was not one of them.

At least Keane's impending suspension means he will not have to play with some of the team-mates he believes are not up to the job again this season. And next term there will be new and expensive faces for him to bawl at.

United expect to agree details of Ruud van Nistelrooy's move from PSV over the next few days, the Dutch striker having had a preliminary medical test in Manchester on Saturday.

If a cull of this squad is due, only Teddy Sheringham behaved as if time was against him. When Paul Scholes declined the offer to miss a second penalty Sheringham seized the ball and the chance to score what might be his last Old Trafford goal. How Royle would like to be able to imply players of that calibre are not up to the job.

 The Juventus and Holland midfielder Edgar Davids, linked with a possible close-season move to Old Trafford, has tested positive for the banned steroid nandrolone, according to Italian press reports.

Paul Dickov's main contribution was to give away a penalty. And Shaun Goater, when he came on, was clearly under orders to play like a United forward, giving the ball away with gusto. The extent of City's ambition was summed up by Andrei Kanchelskis. Once a flying winger down the Old Trafford flanks, but now slowed by the biggest tongues seen on a football boot flapping around his ankles, he was substituted no more than 20 minutes after himself coming on. So fed up with this farrago of a local derby was Roy Keane that he opted out. After his assault on Alf-Inge Haaland, United's captain trundled off to the biggest cheer of the day from the home fans. Keane has done many things deserving of a standing ovation this season: a mad-eyed revenge attack on a fellow pro was not one of them. At least Keane's impending suspension means he will not have to play with some of the team-mates he believes are not up to the job again this season. And next term there will be new and expensive faces for him to bawl at. United expect to agree details of Ruud van Nistelrooy's move from PSV over the next few days, the Dutch striker having had a preliminary medical test in Manchester on Saturday. If a cull of this squad is due, only Teddy Sheringham behaved as if time was against him. When Paul Scholes declined the offer to miss a second penalty Sheringham seized the ball and the chance to score what might be his last Old Trafford goal. How Royle would like to be able to imply players of that calibre are not up to the job.  The Juventus and Holland midfielder Edgar Davids, linked with a possible close-season move to Old Trafford, has tested positive for the banned steroid nandrolone, according to Italian press reports.

webTitle: Everton threaten disciplinary action after Nyarko goes AWOL

fields.headline: Everton threaten disciplinary action after Nyarko goes AWOL
fields.trailText: Everton have threatened Alex Nyarko with disciplinary action after he failed to turn up for training on Monday.
fields.body:
Everton have threatened Alex Nyarko with disciplinary action after he failed to turn up for training on Monday.

Nyarko, a £4.5m signing from Lens last summer, demanded to be substituted during Saturday's 4-1 defeat at Arsenal after being abused during an on-field confrontation with an Everton supporter who also tried to swap shirts with him.

The Ghanaian international midfielder claimed he was finished with football for good and failed to arrive at Everton's Bellefield training facility this morning.

"This is a situation we don't need," said Everton manager Walter Smith. "But we will have to await a meeting between myself and the player before we can further discuss what actions we, as a club, can take.

"We have to wait for Alex to come back or have some contact with him before we can find out the road we will travel down."

Commenting on Nyarko's reaction to Saturday's incident, Smith said: "At first I thought he was injured. It wasn't clear that he was the subject of a supporter's displeasure, but it quickly became clear he wanted to come off.

"That is the first time I have ever seen anything like that. I have never seen a player ask to come off and I don't think many managers have.

"It is not a good example to set and it raises a lot of questions, not only about his commitment to the club, but also the mentality of the player to handle it. He showed a lack of strength mentally.

"Not many footballers will go through their careers without receiving a bit of criticism and he's obviously not accepted it too well."

Ian Ross, Everton's head of corporate affairs and PR, confirmed that the club were investigating the whereabouts of the missing player.

"We are currently trying to make contact with Alex in order to arrange a meeting with him," he said. "If this cannot be achieved within the next two or three days the club would have to consider some form of disciplinary action."

Regarding the supporter who encroached on to the Highbury pitch, Ross added: "Whilst conceding that football is a game which will always inflame emotions and divide opinion, Everton Football Club will never tolerate the misbehaviour of any of its supporters.

"Because of the onset of legal proceedings involving one of our supporters in the aftermath of Saturday's game at Arsenal we can not comment further. However, once they have been completed, the club will consider taking action against the individual involved."

webTitle: Beaten by a tomato, but I still loved the world and it loved me

fields.headline: Beaten by a tomato, but I still loved the world and it loved me
fields.trailText: I was beaten by a tomato. Red and big and occupied - for all I know - by a real athlete. It puts it all into perspective now.
fields.body:
I was beaten by a tomato. Red and big and occupied - for all I know - by a real athlete. It puts it all into perspective now.

Real athletes can wear tomatoes and win. Journalists can wear expensive shoes and have the best training advice and stumble.

I guess you either have it or you don't.

In fact there were quite a few who had it yesterday. The pair of Tweenies, the clown with balloons on his head, the Scottish womble. All breezing by, chatting, exchanging DIY tips.

To be fair, it wasn't the best of beginnings. Seven minutes after the gun sounded Fran - my running flatmate - and I still hadn't crossed the starting line. Congestion was to blame, with plastic bags and unwanted clothing flying through the air, bottles and banana skins occupying the tarmac. It was lethal, but we had been warned to expect anything.

Somewhere, around three miles out, anything happened. It was turning out to be a pleasant jog when suddenly I was blessed. As we passed a church a priest appeared by the side of the road flicking water from a bowl with something which looked like a shaving brush.

Some of his holy water may have landed on my shoe - I can't be sure - but I had an extra spring in my step for a few brief seconds. This was soon disturbed by the first toilet stop of the day -a rather nice Victorian number with ornate wrought iron railings and high ceilings.

It was after this general relief that the real running began. Greenwich town came into view, and the crowds, which were already big, got bigger. People were shouting strange things at friends.

Anyone who had their name on the front of their vest was suddenly public property. Screams of encouragement mixed with brass bands, terrible Beatles tribute bands and the sedate encouragement of the Pearly Kings and Queens looking surreal and arrestable in their uniforms.

Past the Cutty Sark and on to Tower Bridge, which would mark the 12-mile point, I must have lived this part of the run at least a dozen times from the safety of my bed/armchair. I could hear David Coleman murmuring something about how plucky we all were, despite the fact that the real race was between the Rhino and the Tomato.

All seemed well. Water stations every mile ensured that we were all wet and hydrated - there were even shower corridors you could pass through - a bit like a car wash which gave you a gentle sprinkle of water down your back and front.

As the city neared, so the roads became thinner. We were all pressed together and at first we apologised for gashing each other's legs - then when we'd done it so many times we just grunted.

The halfway mark was within reach and things were getting tiring. Tower Bridge loomed, magnificent and old - candy blue, with thousands of people screeching encouragement on either side.

I knew what was coming next - and was prepared for it. Just on 13 miles out I saw a small union flag fluttering in the distance and annoying someone's ear and then the words: "there he is".

My parents had spotted me. We stopped for a brief chat, exchanged pleasantries and went on our way. So someone was watching after all. Indeed from nowhere then came calls and hoots and screams from various people who had levered themselves from their Sunday beds to cheer us on.

Our hearts lifted. But not for long.

Despite regularly ingesting isotonic fluid and strawberry and banana flavoured gels (350 calories a sachet), we were getting only fleeting benefits. Meanwhile, children were pressed to the barriers, offering up support and sometimes their sweets - I got a jelly baby with its head bitten off and something that tasted like a throat lozenge.

Through what was now a haze of discomfort, Canary Wharf appeared. It was too big, too long. It went on forever. Mile after mile of new concrete, glassy buildings and pubs - each one with a cheery red-cheeked crowd outside it.

Things were flagging. Knees were sore, ankles were pinching.

Every time we went through a tunnel it felt as if someone had turned off the oxygen supply and turned up the heating.

20 miles gone and it was now agony. I guess this was my wall coming. Tall and slippery, with broken glass on the top. How I got past that point without hiring a cab I'm yet to unravel.

At 23 miles I was ambushed by my mum, who had cunningly hidden herself in a crowd of 2000 - I could pick out her yelp of delight from 30 yards away. I guess things got progressively worse from there.

The closer to home, the harder it became. My feet were sticking to the floor. Fran was looking worried. But we didn't stop and walk but just ran at walking pace.

I thought I would welcome the embankment - 25 miles gone - but it was by then just pain. The last mile felt like the first 13. Nothing was very much fun anymore. I was gone. I was hungry.

Turning past Big Ben I spotted a man holding, not a sign of encouragement, but an advert for McDonald's bacon double cheese burger - £2.88 with chips and a drink. Unbelievable cruelty.

By then I would have eaten my hand if it was encased in a bun and covered in mayo with a couple of those little gherkin-type things for relish. And I'm a vegetarian. Imagine what others must have gone through.

But the finish was in sight now. Past Buckingham Palace and a couple of screeching friends and to the end.

The full-stop finish, no more, never again.

Around me people staggered, their faces covered in dry salt deposits form their sweat, lips trembling, a few crying.

All around strangers offered congratulations, touched our backs, smiled the prettiest, brightest smiles, spoke the most beautiful words. Truly a mind-bogglingly, dreamlike moment.

I loved the world and it loved me.

We all walked off like saddle-sore ranchers to collect our medals, the obligatory silver-foil blanket and our bag of goodies. They thrust into my hand a cheese sandwich. Cheese and tomato and a bag of crisps. Joy of joys.

After all that, I then wondered does life surely doesn't get any better?

 David finished the race in 4 hours 37 minutes.

fields.headline: 1.4m stay up late for Lewis fight
fields.trailText: 4pm TV overnights: Lennox Lewis's shock defeat attracted more than 1m viewers to BBC1 early on Sunday morning, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Lennox Lewis's shock world heavyweight boxing title defeat attracted more than 1m viewers to BBC1 in the early hours of Sunday morning.

World Heavyweight Championship Boxing, the BBC1's live coverage, began at 3.15am and ran until 5am.

The programme had 1.2m viewers - nearly three quarters of people watching TV at that time, according to unofficial overnights.

During the fight, the audience peaked at 1.4m viewers.

The BBC director of sport, Peter Salmon, would have been encouraged to learn more than 0.5m viewers watched the fight in multichannel homes.

But last night's repeat of the fight on BBC1 pulled in a disappointing 5m viewers.

The 60-minute highlights show was screened between 7pm and 8pm last night and had a 21% audience share.

It lost out to Lily Savage's Blankety Blank and Coronation Street on ITV.

The comedy gameshow gained 6.8m viewers while Coronation Street pulled in 13.8m.

BBC1's boxing highlights also failed to beat the 7pm-8pm slot average for the past month.

An average 5.9m viewers have tuned in between those times to watch programmes such as Last of the Summer Wine, the Antiques Roadshow and Ballykissangel.

ITV also won the battle of the revamped post-8pm peaktime line-ups thanks to a new Richard Wilson sitcom, High Stakes, and the returning feelgood drama, Where the Heart is.

High Stakes, which stars Wilson and Jack Shepherd as two investment bankers constantly at odds with each other, debuted between 10pm and 10.30pm.

It drew 5.9m viewers and a 29% audience share; beating BBC1's Ten o'Clock News, which had 4.9m.

Where the Heart is returned between 8pm and 9pm and won its slot with 9.5m and a 36% audience share.

Sunday is a problem night for the BBC but the new-look line-up performed better than previous Sunday fare.

Ground Force at 8pm was followed by Alistair McGowan's Big Impression at 8.30pm.

The new crime drama, Murder in Mind, was broadcast between 9pm and 10pm.

Ground Force managed a steady 8m viewers and a 31% share, while Alistair McGowan pulled in 7.2m and had a 27% share.

Last week's Son of God had just 4.2m between 7.50pm and 8.40pm.

Murder in Mind, the first of seven self-contained stories written from the perspective of the murderer, had 6.4m and a 26% share in the difficult 9pm BBC1 slot.

Overall, BBC1 raised its Sunday peaktime share by 3.5 percentage points to 26.2% compared with the previous week.

On Friday night, Dom Joly made a triumphant return to Channel 4 with Trigger Happy TV between 9.30pm and 10pm.

The second series, which has been backed by a big marketing push, opened with 3.4m viewers and a 15% audience share.

It was up against BBC2 opposition Forgotten Heroes: Korea Remembered, which went out between 9pm and 9.50pm.

The BBC2 documentary about the British army's heroic stand at the battle of the Imjin River had 2.8m viewers and a 12% share.

fields.headline: 'Which side will get tired first?'
fields.standfirst:
As the violence continues, Israeli and Palestinian press alike are brooding on the gruelling consequences of Sharon's hardline stance, says Derek Brown

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: As the violence continues, Israeli and Palestinian press alike are brooding on the gruelling consequences of Sharon's hardline stance, says Derek Brown.
fields.body:
In the wake of Sunday's suicide bombing in Israel and the continuing bloodshed in the occupied territories, the press commentators are in doom-mongering mode.

In a thoughtful analysis for the Tel Aviv daily, Ha'aretz, Danny Rubinstein notes defence minister Benjamin Ben-Eliezer's comment that, "The question is: Which side will get tired first? It won't be us." But, Rubinstein comments, it may not be the Palestinians either: "In fact, insofar as public stamina is reflected by events on the ground in the West Bank and the Gaza Strip, the Palestinians are not showing any signs of fatigue or collapse. The opposite is true. Despite all the obstacles, sacrifices and woes, it appears that the Palestinian population in the territories can forbear and continue the intifada uprising for some time."

The Jerusalem Post reveals the extent to which prime minister Ariel Sharon has taken control of military operations, to the exasperation of his cabinet colleagues. The hawkish prime minister has, however, now been brought to heel: "Security cabinet members will, from now on, be phoned before any military action or significant diplomatic decision, prime minister Ariel Sharon told his security cabinet yesterday, bowing to criticism following last week's large-scale raid into Gaza that security cabinet members say was ordered without their knowledge."

The Jordan Times has an arresting picture of tiny middle-class children in Beirut wearing headbands adorned with slogans of the Hamas militant group. The paper's leader writer laments the Israeli government's hardline policies: "In most of his public comments, Sharon has hardly made mention of principles of international legitimacy, has totally ignored all peace efforts of the past few years and months and has repeated that Israel would not budge in its position on the future of Jerusalem and Jewish settlements. All moderate Arab states who had been lobbying the region to give Sharon some time to prove himself as a leader of Israel other than just the leader of a hardline Likud Party have now come to the conclusion that old habits and beliefs die hard."

The Palestine National Authority's ministry of information has an editorial blasting the Israeli government not only for the damage it is inflicting in the occupied territories, but for the damage it is doing to Israel itself: "Over the years, Israel defended itself in the West by describing itself as having common values with the West... reiterating time after time that Israel is the only democracy in the Middle East.With the advent of the global village and information technologies allowing the people the world over to know almost instantaneously what is happening anywhere in the world, Israel is no longer capable of hiding its real self, being a theocracy not a democracy, and as one of the most cruel abuser of human values and human rights, particularly those of its Palestinian Israeli citizens in Israel proper and the Palestinian population in the occupied Palestinian territories in the West Bank, including Arab East Jerusalem and Gaza."

Veteran Palestinian commentator Daoud Kuttab, writing for the Arab Media Internet Network website, takes apart the belief, almost universally believed in Israel, that the conflict was started on the orders of Yasser Arafat: "The intifada was not initiated by Arafat but by a restless Palestinian public that was tired of negotiating about the right to live in freedom and liberty of occupation. True, the Palestinian leadership didn't physically stop the intifada but there is no evidence that it started it... Every time Israel uses excessive force against Palestinians, it kills, maims and destroys property. Every time it closes areas and prohibits movement, they are simply increasing the Palestinian anger and hate against the occupation and the settlers who get apartheid-like preferential treatment. These Israeli actions, not Arafat's lack of action, are the main reason for the continuation of the Palestinian resistance."

fields.headline: Fighting back
fields.standfirst: Piers Morgan, once Fleet Street's most outspoken editor, has been remarkably quiet since the City Slickers share-dealing debacle. In his first interview since the scandal, the Mirror chief seems a changed man - until he relaxes. By  Janine Gibson
fields.trailText: In his first interview since the share-broking scandal, Mirror chief Piers Morgan seems a changed man - until he relaxes. By Janine Gibson.
fields.body:
Two years ago the biggest problem Piers Morgan faced was what he would like to do next. At 34 he was presiding over a Mirror that had visibly turned a corner: it was confident and sharp and making more waves than a weakened and uncertain Sun. The circulation had stabilised even if it wasn't going up, and the paper was becoming a must-read. Possible solutions were floated: a bigger job within the Mirror Group - maybe an editorial director role across more of the titles; maybe on the board. His greatest worry was: where do you go from editor of the second biggest-selling daily newspaper at 34?

At least 18 of the intervening 24 months have not been kind to Morgan. And the worst of it is that he brought most of it upon himself. The share-dealing debacle which broke in February last year through a small story on page four of the Telegraph is still going on - the DTI has yet to report a conclusion to its lengthy investigation into the £20,000 worth of Viglen shares that Morgan bought the day before they were tipped in his newspaper. But he has been publicly vilified through the pages of rival newspapers - notably David Yelland's Sun, which has revelled in its rival's distress, laying into Morgan, Sir Victor Blank and Philip Graf, the chairman and chief executive of Trinity Mirror.

Morgan has remained largely silent on the subject - save for a couple of contrite company-issued expressions of regret - for nearly 18 months now, a shadow of his formerly boisterous self. But now it's time to emerge from behind the locked doors and give his first newspaper interview since the share-dealing scandal. "I feel like I've been under a cloud for too long. Regardless of what the DTI does, it's just gone on too long."

It's now because Trinity Mirror has made its most public declaration of faith in him yet. He has signed a new contract (a lucrative, five-year deal, according to the trade press) which makes him "effective" editor in chief of the Sunday Mirror as well as editor of the daily. It's not quite the seat on the board, but it's as close as a man still under investigation can probably get.

Morgan is suitably grateful. "I have regularly throughout this, particularly at the start, thought that a lot of lesser managements would have turfed me straight out the door. I thought that from the first week onwards when it really began to accelerate and the Sun really stuck the boot in. And I've been absolutely staggered by the support from the company led by Victor and Philip Graf and the rest of the board, who have all stuck their necks out for me and refused to alter their position.

"We all know the DTI are continuing their investigation and no one can say with 100% certainty how that will end because we're not them. I remain confident, like the company does, that I did nothing wrong. But until that position changes, they are perfectly entitled to carry on business as usual."

This bullishness despite the continuing rancour of some of the press. "We're down to a few diehards now: Richard Ingrams, David Yelland, Andrew Neil and the Sunday Busi ness and a couple of others who just keep saying the same thing. I've got the picture - I may be a cretinous greedy stupid little idiot but I'm still editing the Mirror and that's my day job. So they can keep saying it and I can keep just laughing because eventually you laugh."

He wasn't laughing last year. "Debilitating" is the word he uses to describe the mass of coverage, and there's no doubt that Fleet Street made the most of the opportunity to heap ordure on the head of one of its finest. The most stinging pieces were the ones addressed directly to the integrity of Blank and Graf: how can you, as men of honour, tolerate this behaviour in your company, as the Sun asked frequently. Did Morgan ever think that they would sack him? "Regularly. Oh yeah, regularly. Yeah. Because I think if you're getting the level of press coverage that I was getting then the pressure on management is ferocious. That's why I say I owe them a huge debt of loyalty."

Did you ever resign? "No. There's a big difference between thinking you might have to go and resigning. Never resign. There's no point."

Resignation is of course the reason why Morgan has this new job. It's the official explanation for Colin Myler's departure as editor of the Sunday Mirror two weeks ago after he published an article which caused the Leeds footballers' trial to be abandoned. Myler had fallen on his sword within the week. If you were him, you might feel somewhat aggrieved that the board of Trinity Mirror, which has seen fit to back one editor so enthusiastically, accepted his resignation with such alacrity.

Morgan sees a distinct difference. "It was a combination of things. In the end if the judge had come back on the Monday and said, 'That was a bit naughty but the trial continues,' it would have been a rap over the knuckles and we probably wouldn't be where we are. Unfortunately what happened was the £8m high-profile trial of the year collapsed and it was totally unprecedented. There's a big school of thought that the judge made the wrong decision, but that's a different issue.

"If you're the editor of a paper where a trial collapses because of a story you've published I think you have to carry the can. I think Colin accepted that and he's got great sympathy from his colleagues for doing it."

Yet as someone who's had quite a lot of second chances, Morgan must surely feel that Myler should have been given one. "People are trying to say, 'Well, what about the shares thing,' and they forget the company's position on the shares thing, which is that they did a massive internal investigation and they decided I'd done nothing wrong so there was no reason for me to leave."

It's almost a year since the press complaints commission issued its strongly worded rebuke to Morgan, Blank and Graf over their handling of the share-buying culture at Trinity Mirror. Morgan, it found, had breached the code of conduct on three counts and the company was warned that its rules on share dealing for its journalists were inadequate. The City Slickers, Anil Bhoyrul and James Hipwell, whose column exhorted readers to "fill your boots" by piling into new technology stocks, were fired for gross misconduct and came very badly out of the PCC ruling. In the madness surrounding rev elation after revelation of shares being ramped, hacks making thousands and readers being ripped off, the entire Mirror newsroom seemed to be implicated in what was termed a culture of greed. "There's no evidence of the culture," Morgan insists. "The culture's a great myth. Hardly anybody on the floor bought shares and hardly anybody had any connection with any Slickers tips at all. It was a countrywide culture of piling into new technology stocks. Clearly when you go back now and study the language [the Slickers] used it looks like everything's a share ramp. Everything was 'fill your boots'. I didn't see it as share ramping, more a bit of fun with the stock market. We learned a very salutary lesson: you can't have fun with the stock market without it ending in the way that it did."

Oddly, he still seems to feel that Bhoyrul and Hipwell (both fired and still also under investigation by the DTI) got off lightly. "I think the Slickers have avoided most of the criticism that they probably should get for what they've done. They know what they did and they're City journalists - they should've been much more au fait with how it works than anybody else."

But as their editor, wasn't he responsible for them? "Totally. I totally held my hands up and said the managerial responsibility failed completely. Completely. And made mugs of all of us. After the PCC adjudication what was clear to me afterwards was it was bloody stupid of me to ever think that I could actively trade in the stock market and not at some stage come into conflict with the paper."

The paper, the paper. Morgan loves the Mirror. Perhaps not since MacKenzie ruled the Sun has an editor been so attached to a paper. He thinks it's his and is genuinely still mystified that anyone could believe he would deliberately defraud Mirror readers. "Naive, stupid, yes - add any adjective you like. Was I in some way criminally minded about it or crooked or out to fleece the readers? It is so unlike the person I think people know I am to even consider . . . That's the thing that upset me most: that people would call into question that I would be like that with the paper, because I put my heart and soul into it and I just wouldn't do that."

He talks about the new supplements (the A List, the Look, M magazine) that have been added to the paper in recent months and lambasts the Sun (again) for not doing likewise. There can be no doubt that he remains as editor of the Mirror because the paper is deemed a success. If the board didn't like where it was going, he would have been fired last May. But no one wanted to sack Morgan, even though it was by no means the first time he had been seriously warned by the PCC. Let's not forget the Countess Spencer report for the News of the World in 1995, when Rupert Murdoch was forced to intervene, or even "Achtung Surrender!", the rabble-rousing Euro 96 headline.

Somehow he keeps managing to get back up. "Most of my cock-ups have been errors of judgment that have not led to catastrophe, financial meltdown or trials collapsing or whatever - and that's probably been my saving grace. 'Achtung Surrender!' was just my shockingly bad humour even though it caused mayhem, and I apologised for my humour. Most of it was calls like that.

"Generally, my legal record, for example, has been extremely good. Last year was the best year for the Mirror legally in about 25 years. I take libel and stuff like that very seriously because that's where you get hammered financially."

Money is the key to Morgan's assessment of damage done. The difference between himself and Colin Myler, he explains, is that Myler's mistake cost money. This, he seems to imply, was the unforgivable sin ("my mistakes never cost anyone any money"). Try to gently suggest that there are other things as important as the monetary cost, such as ethics and reputation, and he does briefly look puzzled before he recovers. "Of course. Of course. We've all got ethics." (But rather in a tone as if to say, "we all get spots").

And there's the fact that the paper's performance, though not outstanding in sales terms, has largely been unaffected by the back-of-house shenanigans. Morgan claims it as a 2% sales fall year-on-year - still negative but a big improvement on the 10% year-on-year drop the paper was experiencing when he arrived in November 1995.

Still, there's something deeply ironic in the fact that our most controversial editor - the one who has drunk in the regulator's last chance saloon more than any other - is, far from being sacked, now assuming editor in chief responsibility for another paper as well as his own, even if the strategy of forcing the two titles to work together makes perfect sense. With the new editor, Tina Weaver - who has been his deputy on the Mirror and launched the successful women's magazine M which has just been moved from Tuesday to Saturday - he intends to run a seven-day show. Not, he hastens to add, a seven-day operation in the sense of a merged staff, rather one brand and a joint-effort approach to stories in an attempt to lift the lacklustre performance of the Sunday title.

It's almost as if the rumbustious spaniel that was Piers Morgan has metamorphosed into older, wiser, corporate Piers. There's the new job, he looks a lot older (36, now) and he is answering questions in a measured, careful way. There is corporate-speak and regret tempering much of the old devil-may-care attitude.

No longer the youngest editor in Fleet Street, he's been in situ at the Mirror for six years. You might think that his years of outspoken profile-building, first at the Sun as the friend-to-the-stars editor of the Bizarre column and then, in 1994, for a year at the News of the World, are over. Perhaps it is now time for Morgan to adopt an elder statesman persona.

But he just can't keep it up for long. After an hour or so of "of course I don't underestimate the seriousness of this situation" and "I'm very grateful for the loyalty of the board", he's handing out grotesque cartoonish insults left, right and centre to those he feels have done him wrong and railing against the newspaper industry for being no fun. Though his greatest outrage has been reserved thus far for the "lawless" antics of the Sun and certain broadsheets (Sunday Business and the Times, though the Guardian does not escape his wrath) in covering his misfortunes, when he starts to relax he launches an extraordinary appeal for a return to the old days.

"Fleet Street's become very boring. There's too much attention to methodology and all this kind of stuff. When I first came into Fleet Street it was lawless. Totally lawless. Indiscriminate stories being published with no attention to law, the press complaints commission, anything else." This, I venture, is how he ended up at the centre of a DTI investigation. "I know it is. There's so many regulations, it's ridiculous. Unleash the dogs! Let us back in! I want my tabloids back! We want to cause mayhem again. It's what we're about. We're not the Economist; we should be upsetting and enraging and entertaining and all the rest of it."

The threats are still as excessive as ever (see above) and he's fond of using the word Sicilian when describing his planned revenge against Yelland as if he were the Godfather, but it's when he launches into a tirade about the staid nature of the British Press Awards and the lack of joie de vivre among today's journalists that he's vintage Morgan.

"If it falls to me to eradicate this cancer of boring tedious journalism with my trusty sword of juvenility and my shield of unruly behaviour, then so be it." Being Morgan, he later emails me a revised version of this epigram, which better apes the grammar of Jonathan Aitken's original. But as this is the boring old Guardian, we'll stick with the genuine article.

fields.headline: Dando trial begins
fields.trailText: The man accused of murdering Jill Dando appeared at the Old Bailey today. The case was adjourned until tomorrow.
fields.body:
The man accused of murdering TV presenter Jill Dando appeared at the Old Bailey today for a short preliminary hearing, which was held without press and public being allowed into court.

After 40 minutes the case was adjourned until noon tomorrow.

Barry George, 41, from Fulham, west London, has denied murdering 37-year-old Ms Dando, who was shot dead on the doorstep of her home in Fulham on April 26, 1999.

fields.headline: How the press is covering the race row
fields.standfirst: 23.04.2001: Tory advert inflames race row
fields.trailText:
A round-up of today's newspaper coverage of the CRE race dispute
23.04.2001: Tory advert inflames race row
fields.body:
The Guardian
Advert in which Folkstone and Hythe Tories promise to clamp down on bogus asylum seekers inflames race row. LSE professor of European thought John Gray writes that shadow chancellor Michael Portillo's refusal to sign the anti-racism declaration "may come to be remembered as the moment when the Tories passed the point of no return".

The Times
CRE chief Gurbux Singh accuses Labour and Tories of endangering race relations. MR Singh says he is 'deeply saddened' that an attempt to take race out of the election campaign had backfired so badly. Times leader says the past week has shown politics at its worst.

The Daily Telegraph
Labour strategists accuse foreign secretary Robin Cook of making a tactical blunder by intervening in race debate with his 'chicken tikka masala' remarks. Chancellor Gordon Brown, who is running the election campaign, was not asked for his opinion on the speech, it claims.

The Independent
Shadow home secretary Ann Widdicombe undermined Tory leader William Hague's attempts to draw a line under the race dispute when she described the CRE's race pledge as "silly".

Financial Times
Labour will this week cool its rhetoric in the political race row after CRE chairman Gurbux Singh accuses both parties of mud-slinging. FT's leader says the row between the government and the Conservatives has done neither side credit.

Daily Mail
Former CRE member Dr Raj Chandran accuses the organisation of fuelling racial hatred. Dr Chandran, who was ousted fter Labour came to power, says the race equality body is "packed with Labour activists and sympathisers" and is "intent on portraying the Conservative party as 'riddled with racists'".

Daily Express
Former CRE head Sir Herman Ouseley attacks the government's record on race, singling out Robin Cook for "raising the temperature". Sir Herman claims wealthy Asians enjoy greater influence than Afro-Caribbeans in politics.

The Sun
Labour's bid to smear the Tories on race has backfired after black leaders expose a "crude mud-slinging plot". The Sun says it does not wish to fan the flames of this row but outlines a St George's Day celebration of all that is good about England.

The Mirror
Asian Labour peer Lord Paul, an adviser to Tony Blair, advises everbody to "calm down" and dismisses CRE's anti-racism pledge as "meaningless". CRE chairman Gurbux Singh explains why we do need a race pledge. The Mirror leader says the good intentions of keeping race out of the election has become confused and that the Tory leadership has failed only in not expelling John Townsend from the party.

Daily Star
The paper's leader says that although it rarely agrees with William Hague, it stands by his argument that he should be able to discuss immigration problems without being branded a racist.
