fields.headline: Doctorin' the house
fields.standfirst: A collective of designers and film-makers who operate in the  grey area between club visuals and film, The Light Surgeons were established back in 1995, out of a "foolish dedication to car boot bargain super 8's and thrashed slide projectors" Sean Dodson talked to them.
fields.trailText: A collective of designers and film-makers who operate in the grey area between club visuals and film, The Light Surgeons were established back in 1995, out of a "foolish dedication to car boot bargain super 8's and thrashed slide projectors" Sean Dodson talked to them.
fields.body:
They may term their dedication to super 8s and slide projectors 'foolish', but The Light Surgeon's list of 'patients' has been far from foolish: they include FilmFour, Warner, onedotzero, Mo Wax, Skint, and Ninja Tune.

At last year's onedotzero retrospective, the collective premiered Electronic Manoeuvres - part road movie and part political essay on the state of the American nation and its obsessions with consumption, control and corruption Ü to great acclaim. Following the success of their first narrative-based work, the collective will be performing Electronic Manoevres 2 at this year's festival.

SD You've often been sited as part of a lo-tech revolution in film. How true is this?

LS Pretty true. We used to get our equipment from car boot sales and jumble sales. We didn't need brand new stuff, video wasn't accessible when we first started club visuals, and this was the place to get the 16mm projectors etc. It fitted in with our retro-sampling aesthetic, the cine thing. The main thing was we could get our hands on it for the right price at these places.

We used film in a lo-tech way, differently to the way it was being used. We approach film from the back door, playing with it creatively by putting it into a space, making up and appropriating material and film loops, approaching it as you would music. Sampling images, layering and creating references and juxtapositions.

SD You have worked with musicians such as the Propellerheads and Sneaker Pimps as well as corporate launches for the likes of Sony. Do you change your approach much or is corporate hospitality the new rock n' roll?

LS Doing a stage event for a independent label or a live show for UNKLE is totally different to corporate hospitality events. Live gigs like Propellerheads and Cornershop mean we have to make it more theatrical, you're performing as the band are performing, illustrating the music with visuals. We produce visuals for each track and then jazz it out. For UNKLE our visual set was very tightly laid down and orchestrated. A DJ or turntablist thing makes it more important to have visuals because there's no singer to dribble over. Corporate events pay the rent, and we give them credibility and transform a space for them. We're not anti-commercialism, we mix both. Luckily the commercial clients we work for are buying into what we do, so it's not like we're forced into doing something we wouldn't want to. If you can combine them that's perfect.

SD How long until you make your first feature film?

LS We've just got our first short film - Thumbnail Express - out the way. It makes up part of EM, which is a live exploded documentary. But Thumbnail Express will also become part of a larger series, Gilligan's Travels, that we've been developing with onedotzero. Once complete this should be consumed on TV, but the live event is a different experience. We've a plan to make a short sci-fi film next using the methods we've explored with our experimentation with projection and graphics. There's always a question of funding when you're doing something different and not through the usual routes, and all the time learning about a craft too.

SD . . . and why did you choose to make a documentary?

LS It seemed a logical extension of what we'd been doing. We worked on a design exhibition in 99 and collected material in the states, including audio. It was the first time we captured our own audio, started showing this with projections, and thought one of the interviews would work well as a short. This was commissioned for onedotzero4. Our background in listening to music and illustrating it visually, means it came together as 'inverse film-making', back to front. Don't do it at home. But the interview meant we had a ready made script so didn't have to make this bit up.

SD A lot of well known film-makers Ü Mike Figgis and Ken Russell come to mind - are experimenting with new forms of film and new ways of making them. How do you view this?

LS What holds film back from being really mad and experimental is where it's shown. Cinemas only show formula stuff. That's why forums like the onedotzero festival or organic film clubs like the Halloween Society, or hybrid club events are so important now. Ken Russell has always made pretty unconventional films, but nowadays what defines a film is getting it shown - the definition of what a film is is changing. The convergence of traditional film, graphic design, new media and internet means that people are exposed to and are more accepting of these new forms. But you'll always get the purists too. Technology shouldn't lead you into a film form, it should just open the creative possibilities, and give more access to do it. The tools are there now. It's easy for us to make film now because we've got [software video-editing package] Final Cut Pro and a G4.

SD. How soon will your work be online? How do you see yourselves fitting in with the whole cybercinema movement?

LS We want it to be online, beginning of next year - but we've got so many events and projects that it's hard to find the time. The 'me tv' idea is pretty crazy. I'll like to use the internet as an imagebank for us, so people could see the process and how we make up a visual show. We want to communicate to more people and this is an amazing way to do it. We don't see ourselves as part of a movement, we're not stuck on digital either, we've used analogue methods so long. But we see the possibilities and want to use them to get our messages and stuff out to more people.

 The LightSurgeons will be performing at onedotzero5 on Saturday May 5 at 9pm.

webTitle: Car bomb injures two in central Israel

fields.headline: Car bomb injures two in central Israel
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: A suspected car bomb has exploded in the central Israeli town of Or Yehuda, slightly injuring two people.
fields.body:
A suspected car bomb has exploded in the central Israeli town of Or Yehuda, slightly injuring two people.

Israeli police said that they did not know whether Palestinian militants were responsible.

The parked car exploded close to the market area of Or Yehuda, a town south of Tel Aviv.

The blast followed yesterday's suicide bombing in Tel Aviv, when a Palestinian blew himself up in a bus queue during the morning rush hour. The bomb also killed an Israeli doctor and sprayed dozens of commuters with shards of metal and glass.

Yesterday's attack, which was the second fatal suicide bombing in the central Israeli town in a month, came only hours after security officials from the two sides met for the first time since the latest escalation in the seven-month uprising.

On Saturday, Israel admitted that it was holding secret talks with senior Palestinians.

Previous bombings inside the borders of the Jewish state have overwhelmed attempts to restart negotiations, leading instead to Israeli reprisals.

However, the foreign minister, Shimon Peres, said he hoped to continue the talks that he has been conducting with the speaker of the Palestinian parliament, Ahmed Queria, or Abu Ala as he is usually known.

webTitle: Europe colludes in Israeli trade scams

fields.headline: Europe colludes in Israeli trade scams
fields.standfirst: The EU bans trading with 'illegal' Jewish settlements, but accepts their goods under Israeli guise, says Brian Whitaker
fields.trailText: The EU's disallows trading with 'illegal' Jewish settlements, but accepts their goods under Israeli guise Brian Whitaker.
fields.body:
Last Wednesday, a fax arrived at the Guardian - and no doubt, other British newspapers - from the foreign office. It was deemed so important that an official even phoned to check we had received it.

The fax was a statement from the foreign secretary, Robin Cook. "I have today spoken to Israeli and Palestinian leaders to urge both sides to do all they can to avoid confrontation," it began.

You can guess the rest: "negotiations... restraint... an end to violence... return to peace talks... restraint... negotiating table... restraint... peace talks" and so on. All very reasonable and British, but hopelessly ineffectual.

On the same day, the European Union joined in the chorus. Everyone agreed with the US secretary of state, Colin Powell, who in a rare outburst the previous day had condemned Israeli action against the Palestinians as "excessive and disproportionate".

The only difference between the Americans and the Europeans was that it took the Europeans an extra day to get around to saying it.

This helps to explain why the US has dominated the Middle East peace process for so long (with disastrous effects), while Europe, which might play an important and useful role, has been left dithering on the sidelines.

Europe, unlike the US, does not have a single foreign policy but its 15 member states try establish common ground where they can. That leads to the sort of vacuous statements issued by Britain and the rest of Europe last week, without any serious prospect of action to back them up.

In the recent UN security council vote on sending an international observer "force" (terrifyingly armed with notebooks and pencils) to the Middle East, the four European members - Britain, France, Ireland and Norway - abstained. Although the US vetoed the plan anyway, Europe's abstention, in the view of many people, encouraged the Israeli prime minister, Ariel Sharon, to believe he could escalate the violence with impunity.

Surprising as it may seem, Europe has as much economic muscle in the region as the United States. European money keeps the Palestinian Authority alive and Europe is Israel's most valuable trading partner. Israel earns around $14bn (£9.7bn) a year from Europe - one-third of its total exports. Europe could use this influence towards achieving a just peace - if only the member countries agreed on a course of action.

Last week, France hinted at economic measures to show European disapproval of Israel's policies and EU foreign ministers may discuss it further when they meet in Brussels on May 14.

One option would be to cancel or suspend the trade agreement which, since 1975, has allowed Israeli goods to enter Europe on preferential terms. Any decision to do that would have to be unanimous and, on past form, there is no chance of it happening.

There is, however, an interesting alternative which does not require a political decision, merely an administrative decision of the kind that no reasonable person can disagree with: to clamp down on fraud.

One of the great unpublicised scandals of the EU is that Israel has been cheating on the trade agreement for years and depriving the EU of revenue in the process. It is known, for example, that Israel has imported Brazilian orange juice, labelled it as Israeli and sent it on to Europe - thus allowing the Brazilians to evade European taxes.

The preferential terms under the agreement apply to goods produced wholly or substantially in "the territory of the state of Israel". Europe has a similar agreement with the Palestinians, but by controlling exports from the occupied territories, the Israelis bar the Palestinians from making use of it.

Jars of Palestinian pickle, for instance, are handed over to the Israelis who stick a "Made in Israel" label on them and export them to Europe. Flowers grown by Palestinians in Gaza, strawberries, oranges, lemons and aubergines are all sent to Israel, mixed with Israeli produce and exported to Europe with Israeli certificates of origin.

In 1998 a Palestinian grower told the European commission that he allowed his flowers to change their nationality in order to avoid the risk of damage and delay "as a result of Israeli treatment of Palestinian produce". This was a polite way of referring to the Israeli authorities' practice of thrusting metal spikes through boxes of Palestinian flowers, rendering them unsaleable. Ostensibly this is done for security reasons.

Israeli companies import leather from Europe and pass it to Palestinian companies, who turn it into shoes and jackets. The Palestinians pass the goods back to the Israelis, who then send them to Europe as Israeli products. The point of this is that Israeli importers and exporters cream off a percentage that would otherwise have gone to Palestinians.

Another - politically more serious - fraud arises because produce from Jewish settlements in the occupied territories is not covered by trade agreements with Europe and is therefore not entitled to preferential treatment.

Europe has made its view of the settlements extremely clear. "Settlements change the physical character and demographic composition of the occupied territories. All settlement activities are illegal and constitute a major obstacle to peace," a statement from EU presidency said recently.

But what Europe says and does are two different things. By allowing settlement products to be imported under an Israeli guise, Europe helps to keep the settlements in business.

The more farsighted Israelis recognise this as an obstacle to peace. The Gush Shalom organisation, for example, urges Israelis themselve to boycott settlement produce, under the slogan, "A penny to the settlements is a penny against peace."

In some cases there is no attempt to disguise the origin of these products. The Golan Heights Winery exports 38% of all "Israeli" wine - from vineyards on occupied Syrian land. It markets them under the labels "Yarden", "Gamla", and "Golan", and the company's website lists distributors in nine European countries, including House of Hallgarten in Luton.

Ahava produces bath salts and cosmetics from the Dead sea on the occupied West Bank. Its website lists outlets in Belgium, Germany, Italy and the United Kingdom (including Selfridges in London). Other products would not be difficult to track down: a long list is published on Gush Shalom's website.

The EU has known about this for a long time but it held off taking action on the grounds that there was no point in making a fuss while peace seemed imminent. But in the last few months that has changed and peace seems further away than ever. Action now could help to get it back on course.

fields.headline: Compact: the issue explained
fields.trailText: As the welfare state shrinks, so the role of the voluntary sector grows in importance. It was in recognition of this that the government launched the national and local compacts between its agencies and the voluntary organisations, which are increasingly carrying out the work of a welfare state.
fields.body:
As the welfare state shrinks, so the role of the voluntary sector grows in importance. It was in recognition of this that the government launched the national and local compacts between its agencies and the voluntary organisations, which are increasingly carrying out the work of a welfare state.

The compacts' aims are to improve working relationships between the government and voluntary sector, ensuring resources are allocated and needs met in the most efficient way possible.

An example is the compact funding code. Until recently, voluntary organisations complained they would burn the midnight oil getting funding proposals in on time but never hear back from the government. Others found themselves being awarded funding but waiting forever for the cheque.

The situation hampered the work of voluntary organisations, delying projects and making it difficult to make longer-term plans. The funding code, launched in November 2000, commits the government to giving notice of funding decisions within three months and issuing cheques on time.

Similarly, the consultation code, launched at the same time, explores ways of ensuring all interested parties are consulted about proposed legislation that might affect them. To date, these are the only two national codes to have been drawn up.

National codes on volunteering, black and ethnic minority organisations and community groups are expected shortly, but thereafter most of the compacts will focus on more localised issues. Some 70% of voluntary activity takes place at a local level and what works for a local statutory agency and voluntary organisation in Devon will not necessarily work in Northumberland. But if they prove successful, compacts can be expected for a whole wealth of activities.

Some people are suggesting, for example, that compacts be drawn up with local residents and community associations to ensure urban renewal schemes don't end up alienating the people already living there.

Overall, the compacts have been well received with a 1999 survey finding one in three voluntary organisations reporting an improved working relationship with the government. But if organisations are displeased they can raise the issue with the voluntary sector's working group on compact, request mediation or pay a visit to the ombudsman. And the annual parliamentary review should provide an additional platform for airing grievances.

And the annual parliamentary review should provide an additional platform for airing grievances.

webTitle: REM star out on bail after 'air rage' incident

fields.headline: REM star out on bail after 'air rage' incident
fields.trailText: "Embarrassed" REM guitarist Peter Buck was released on bail today after an appearance at Uxbridge magistrates court in London over an alleged air rage incident.
fields.body:
"Embarrassed" REM guitarist Peter Buck was released on bail today after an appearance at Uxbridge magistrates court in London over an alleged air rage incident.

Mr Buck, 44, was charged with criminal damage, being drunk on an aircraft, two counts of common assault on air crew and one public order offence following an incident on a British Airways flight. The married father of two was arrested at Heathrow airport on Saturday as he got off flight BA 048 from Seattle.

Crew on board the aircraft told police that a drunken Mr Buck had torn up a written warning from the captain of the flight, thrown yoghurt over a male member of staff, pulled tight an air steward's tie and wrenched the arm of a female cabin crew member.

The court scheduled Mr Buck to appear for a committal hearing on June 18. His band are due to play in front of Nelson Mandela and a 20,000-strong crowd at the South Africa Freedom Day Concert in Trafalgar Square, central London on Sunday. Fellow band members Michael Stipe and Mike Mills had flown in earlier.

The band's manager, Bob Gold, paid the £25,000 bail. Following the hearing, the band's attorney, Bertis Downs, read a statement on Mr Buck's behalf.

The statement read: "I am very grateful to the court for allowing me to undertake our promotional tour.

"The matter has been delayed until mid-June when I will of course be back here. I am very sorry for the incident and very embarrassed about the whole thing."

fields.headline: Chechnya
fields.standfirst:
About 20 gunmen have surrendered to the Turkish authorities after a brief hostage-taking drama in Istanbul. The gunmen said they wanted to draw attention to Russia's 'dirty war' in Chechnya. Mark Tran explains

Special report: Chechnya
fields.trailText: About 20 gunmen have surrendered to the Turkish authorities after a brief hostage-taking drama in Istanbul. The gunmen said they wanted to draw attention to Russia's 'dirty war' in Chechnya. Mark Tran explains.
fields.body:
Is there a dirty war? Conventional fighting between Russian and Chechen forces has for the most part ceased, but human rights organisations have reported a rise in the disappearance, torture and summary executions of detainees. Human Rights Watch describes the situation as a transition from an internal armed conflict to a classic dirty war.

How extensive is this dirty war? Human Rights Watch has documented more than 113 cases of "disappearances" in Chechnya since Russia launched its military campaign against the rebellious province in September 1999. A leading Russian human rights group, the Memorial Human Rights Centre, put the figure at 150, but the full number is believed to be much higher. The total number of dead from the military campaign is estimated at between 30,000 and 40,000.

Has there been any international response? Last week, the UN Commission on Human Rights condemned Russia for what it said was the "excessive and indiscriminate" use of force by its troops in Chechnya. But Russia is not paying much attention.

A similar UN resolution was approved last year, but Russia simply ignored calls to allow UN human rights monitors into Chechnya or to set up a national commission of inquiry. The discovery of a mass grave of 60 Chechen civilians in January has only heightened international concern.

Why are Russian troops in Chechnya? Russia launched a military campaign against Chechnya in September 1999 - the latest in a series - after a spate of massive explosions in Moscow that was blamed on Chechen extremists. Russian troops captured the capital Grozny after a fierce bombing campaign modelled on Nato's air war in Kosovo. The Chechnya campaign helped cement Vladimir Putin's position as Russia's new president.

Has Russia always had troubled relations with Chechnya? The rebellious Chechens have never accepted Russian rule ever since they were conquered in the 19th century. Stalin tried to pacify the northern Caucusus province by deporting the whole population, including women and children, to Siberia. But the survivors returned and Chechens to this day are a thorn in Russia's side.

Why is Russia worried about Chechnya? Chechnya's is Russia's wild west. Crime and lawlessness run rampant, but what particularly worries Moscow is attempts by various Islamic chieftain to create an Islamic state incorporating Chechnya and neighbouring Dagestan. Part of the reason Russia launched its 1999 campaign was the inability of Chechen leaders to control their more extreme elements as they had agreed to after the 1996 war.

Who is in charge in Chechnya now? A pro-Kremlin administration runs Chechnya led by Akhmad Kadyrov, but several of its members have been picked off by Chechen rebels. Earlier this month, Mr Kadyrov's deputy, Adam Deniyev, was assassinated in a bomb attack on a local television studio. Chechen rebels claim to have compiled a death list of all officials in Chechnya appointed by the Russian government. Any Chechen who agrees to work for the Russian-imposed local government is considered a traitor.

fields.headline: Compact: the basics
fields.trailText: • Compacts are agreements between government agencies and voluntary organisations on how they wish to work together.
fields.body:
 Compacts are agreements between government agencies and voluntary organisations on how they wish to work together.

 A national compact was launched in 1998 and was followed last summer by a local compact between local statutory bodies and local voulntary organisations.

 The guidelines are meant to be based on shared values and mutual respect. They are designed to reflect the needs of ongoing and developing relationships and are not laws set in stone.

 Compacts are monitored by a voluntary sector working group. Organisations also have recourse to mediation and the ombudsman. And there is an annual meeting with ministers that leads to an annual report to parliament and includes an annual action plan to ensure the work is taken forward.

 National codes of practice on funding and consultation have already been released and will be follwed by codes on volunteering, black and minority ethnic organisations and community groups. But most compacts will be between local statutory bodies and the local voluntary agencies that carry out 70% of the country's voluntary work.

fields.headline: Murdoch muscles in on Hughes talks
fields.trailText: 2pm: Rupert Murdoch is trying to rescue his takeover bid for the US satellite broadcaster by taking personal control of negotiations. By Ashley Davies.
fields.body:
Rupert Murdoch, the News Corp chairman, is today trying to rescue his flagging takeover bid for US satellite broadcaster Hughes Electronic Corp by taking personal control of the negotiations.

Mr Murdoch is scheduled to meet executives from General Motors, which owns Hughes, to discuss ways of kickstarting the stalled talks.

His intervention comes two months after GM - which, through its ownership of Hughes, owns the DirectTV satellite broadcasting unit - and Mr Murdoch reached a preliminary agreement over an alliance.

The plan was to create a new global media powerhouse worth more than $60bn by combining DirecTV with News Corp's satellite TV subsidiary, Sky Global Networks.

However, shareholder opposition prompted GM to pull back and find new ways of spinning off Hughes without any News Corp involvement.

Today's meeting in Detroit is expected to be attended by the News Corp president, Peter Chernin, and Microsoft's chief executive, Steve Ballmer. Microsoft has agreed to help finance the proposed deal.

Neither News Corp nor GM were commenting on the meeting and the session is not expected to result in an immediate decision. GM's board is not to address the issue formally until May.

Although Mr Murdoch's personal intervention in the now lengthy process will be seen as an attempt to move things along swiftly, he is not thought to be bringing any 'sweeteners' to the table.

The original deal is understood to have been worth a potential $8bn to GM.

Microsoft has discussed contributing at least $3bn plus technological assets to support Mr Murdoch's bid.

fields.headline: Signs of the times
fields.standfirst: Xan Brooks introduces the onedotzero festival - a vibrant hinterland where pop promos, web design, experimental film and computer games interact
fields.trailText: Xan Brooks introduces the onedotzero festival - a vibrant hinterland where pop promos, web design, experimental film and computer games interact
fields.body:
Cannes may have the stars, and the London Film Festival the bulging war chest of feature presentations. But when film historians look back in years to come they could well wind up ranking onedotzero as the most crucial, groundbreaking festival of the early 21st-century. A touring showcase for the best of digital film, it has seen its influence mushroom in the past five years. Onedotzero made its first appearance at the London's Institute of Contemporary Arts in 1996. Since then it has shuttled between 25 international cities (including Stockholm, Melbourne, Montreal, Barcelona, Taipei). In the meantime the rebel arts that it celebrates have increasingly broken through to the mainstream.

Conceived as a reaction to conventional cinema, onedotzero occupies a vibrant hinterland where pop promos, web design, experimental film and computer games interact. The festival was founded back in the mid 90s by Matt Hanson and Shane Walter, who have been dubbed the "Chemical Brothers of digital film". Hanson cut his teeth as a film critic for Dazed and Confused magazine, but became disillusioned with the formulaic produce he was forced to review. He found an antidote in the wilder stylings of those artists on the fringe. "These people weren't hung up on celluloid," he says. "They're more comfortable using digital tools."

"We feature work that is made by people you wouldn't expect to be making films," adds Walter. "Graphic designers, illustrators, photographers, theatre designers, even architects. People who thought about making films but couldn't afford it now find that they can invest a relatively small amount of money in a picture that is of broadcast quality."

Thus onedotzero has become a forum for the internet generation. Recent developments in technology have seen the arrival of inexpensive digital cameras and the availability of desktop editing software that allows you to sculpt your raw footage in the comfort of your own home. It is this democratisation of film-making that onedotzero champions, this blurring of the boundaries between film, art, advertisement and design. "Digital moving image has totally revolutionised our entertainment landscape," says Hanson. "When we started there weren't many people working in a cross-media sense." Even now he finds the work defies the usual pigeonholes. "The digital films that we promote fall in between the established categories. Are they commercial or are they art? It's an interesting question."

Onedotzero's impact can already be felt throughout the mainstream movie industry, where digital techniques have now become par from the course (George Lucas shot his next Star Wars movie entirely on digital). In the meantime, several of the artists championed in the festival's early years have now gone on to reach a wider audience. Sexy Beast director Jonathan Glazer is one notable onedotzero graduate, while the inaugural festival was the first event to showcase the work of Being John Malkovich creator Spike Jonze (at that time a humble pop-promo director).

But then onedotzero has always spotlighted what is new and exciting, and served as a vital early warning system for the pioneering artists and techniques just over the next horizon. Needless to say the stars of tomorrow are already gathered at this year's event.

 onedotzero5 runs from April 27 to May 6 at the ICA, London. Box office 020-7930 3647, or see ica.org.uk or onedotzero.co.uk for more details.

fields.headline: Doncaster leader steps down
fields.trailText: Doncaster councillor Colin Wedd has announced his resignation as leader of the troubled authority following his arrest last week in connection with allegations of expenses fraud.
fields.body:
Doncaster councillor Colin Wedd has announced his resignation as leader of the troubled authority following his arrest last week in connection with allegations of expenses fraud.

Mr Wedd is the third council leader at Doncaster to be arrested under Operation Danum, the long-running police investigation into corruption within the authority.

A statement issued by his Sheffield-based solicitors says Mr Wedd has "reluctantly decided to resign from his position as leader of Doncaster metropolitan borough council in order to concentrate on the investigation and clear his name".

Mr Wedd said: "After four years of being in the most senior positions within the council, I'm devastated by what has happened."

His solicitor said Mr Wedd had not been charged with any offence, and had been released on unconditional bail.

fields.headline: C4 in sitcom pledge
fields.trailText:
Programme promises: Channel 4 is to launch two new sitcoms as part of its 'contract with viewers', writes Jessica Hodgson.
23.04.2001: Promises, promises, promises
fields.body:
Channel 4 has made a commitment to launch two sitcoms over the next year as part of its new "contract with viewers".

The broadcaster also wants to launch a comedy drama made in Scotland to demonstrate a greater commitment to regional programming.

The commitments come as part of Channel 4's "statement of promises", a new programme contract that replaces the Independent Television Commission's annual performance reviews.

Under the new deregulated programming landscape, broadcasters will set out their programming stalls for the coming year.

If the system is felt to be inadequate by the new regulatory body, Ofcom, it can impose sanctions.

Channel 4 said in its statement of promises that it wants to "use [its] reputation for risk and non-conformism to engage a younger generation in the values of public service broadcasting".

As part of its commitment, Channel 4 said it wants to concentrate on "experimenting with programmes at the boundary of drama and documentary".

It is promising to screen a feature-length story of rail privatisation by Ken Loach called The Navigators, and Kenneth Branagh in Shackleton, a feature-length profile of the Artic explorer by Charles Sturridge, who directed Longitude.

Meanwhile, Channel 4 promises to introduce more international programming into the True Stories strand, with Russia, Iran and Africa chosen for particular attention.

The broadcaster is also committed to two "landmark authored" series, one by Darcus Howe on Britain and one on America by Jon Ronson.

fields.headline: Ethnic minority mini-manifesto
fields.trailText: The Liberal Democrats are the only political party whose primary mission is to protect, promote and proclaim freedom. The freedom we cherish does not, however, mean the freedom of the strong to oppress the weak, or the freedom of majorities to ignore the needs of minorities. The great Liberal philosopher L.T. Hobhouse wrote that 'the struggle for liberty  is the struggle for equality'. So justice in the struggle to secure liberty and equality is at the heart of our philosophy. Liberal Democrats recognise that minority ethnic groups in Britain look not for special favours, but for equality of opportunity. Liberal Democrats offer minority ethnic groups in Britain a real chance for real change.  Charles Kennedy, Leader of the Liberal Democrats  Equality and the Fight Against Racial Discrimination
fields.body:
The Liberal Democrats are the only political party whose primary mission is to protect, promote and proclaim freedom. The freedom we cherish does not, however, mean the freedom of the strong to oppress the weak, or the freedom of majorities to ignore the needs of minorities. The great Liberal philosopher L.T. Hobhouse wrote that 'the struggle for liberty  is the struggle for equality'. So justice in the struggle to secure liberty and equality is at the heart of our philosophy. Liberal Democrats recognise that minority ethnic groups in Britain look not for special favours, but for equality of opportunity. Liberal Democrats offer minority ethnic groups in Britain a real chance for real change. Charles Kennedy, Leader of the Liberal Democrats Equality and the Fight Against Racial Discrimination

Liberal Democrats will combat discrimination on the grounds of race and in all its other forms. We will:

Strengthen the fight against discrimination with an Equality Act. This will fight unfair discrimination on whatever grounds, including race and religion. A new Equality Commission will be able to investigate potential breaches of the Act and take action in its own name. We will also create a separate Human Rights Commission to safeguard human rights.

Support recent European anti-discrimination legislation. We will back measures under Article 13 of the Treaty of Amsterdam on anti-discrimination, including race and employment legislation and action. This will allow British Citizens from ethnic minorities travelling or working in Europe to be protected from discrimination.

Immigrants are too often labelled as a problem for British society. Britain has benefited hugely from immigration, in the same way that many Britons who have emigrated have benefited from their experience. There are practical as well as humanitarian reasons for having a fair immigration system. The shortage of skilled workers in many fields means immigrants have an important contribution to make to British society. We will:

Free immigration laws from discrimination. We will ensure that immigration policy is non-discriminatory in its application. We will reform current immigration laws so that families are not divided. We will also regularly review immigration policy, separate from our asylum obligations, including an assessment of skills needs of the country in an increasingly global economy. We will reverse the present Government's decision to charge fees for appealing family visit visa applications.

Protect people fleeing from persecution by dealing with asylum applications fairly and more quickly. We will introduce fair benefits for asylum seekers to replace the demeaning voucher system. We will review the failing dispersal system, end any unnecessary restrictions on asylum seekers undertaking voluntary work and review restrictions on paid work by asylum seekers in their first six months. Recognising pressures on host communities, we will ensure that local services are adequately compensated for the cost of supporting asylum seekers. We will work with other countries to ensure that responsibilities are sensibly shared, and to seek a system which discourages illegal trafficking in people.

"The history of immigration is one of success for our country. The integration of immigrants, refugees and asylum seekers has been truly remarkable. Their contribution is important and valued". Lord Dholakia, President of the Liberal Democrats.

Equality of Opportunity and the Public Services

Liberal Democrats believe that the top political priority for the people of Britain, regardless of their ethnic background, is to secure high levels of investment in the essential public services on which we all depend. Adequate funding of the public services are especially important for less advantaged communities, because this is the only way they will be able to secure fair access to a decent education and good quality healthcare. When public services are under-funded, it is the ethnic minorities who will lose out most of all. Only the Liberal Democrats have a clear and costed commitment to make significant increases in the major public services. We will:

Provide improvements in education costing more than £3 billion a year, funded by putting one penny on the basic rate of income tax.

Provide substantial immediate increases in pensions and raise investment in the NHS, funded by setting a new top tax rate of 50% on income over £100,000 a year and by closing loopholes in Capital Gains Tax.

Liberal Democrats also recognise that some ethnic or religious groups have special needs or sensitivities which must be taken into account in the delivery of public services, particularly healthcare and education. In particular, we will:

End the use of mixed sex wards so that patients have more dignity when they are in hospital.

Promote a wider availability of complementary medicines and healthcare through the NHS to take maximum advantage of different approaches to health.

Replace the National Curriculum with a less rigid Minimum Curriculum Entitlement which can be more sensitive to community preferences. We will provide for a broad and balanced curriculum including languages, science, maths, the humanities, physical development (including sports instruction and advice on healthy eating), religious education, parenting, citizenship and creative arts.

Improve access for under-represented groups in Higher Education by tripling the incentive payments for recruitment and retention of under-represented, mature and part-time students. We would pay colleges one-third on admission and two-thirds on completion of a course.

Liberal Democrats recognise the best way to ensure that the public services are sensitive to the needs of minority ethic groups is to enhance political participation by and representation of this section of the community. To promote wider representation in political office, we will:

Secure fair votes for all national and local elections. For Westminster, we support the system of AV+ as proposed by the Jenkins Commission as a first step. We will therefore put the Jenkins Commission's recommendations before the British people in a referendum at the earliest possible opportunity. Ultimately, we wish to see the Single Transferable Vote (STV) used for Westminster elections. We will introduce STV immediately for local government and European elections.

Include in our Equality Act provisions to permit political parties to employ proportionate positive measures in their selection processes to remedy under-representation of one sex or of minority groups in public office.

"Our vision is to provide the right infrastructure, the right environment, the right opportunities - the right playing field - and then to set people free to shape their communities, shape their lives, celebrate their success. Because we are honest about the cost, we know we can deliver that opportunity. Because we trust the people, we know they will make those opportunities work." Matthew Taylor, Liberal Democrat Shadow Chancellor of the Exchequer.

Equality and the Legal System

Good police relationships with the community are essential to effective policing. Relationships with ethnic minority communities have been particularly strained recently in the wake of the inquiry into the Stephen Lawrence murder investigation. Liberal Democrats support implementation of the positive recommendations of the Macpherson Report. We welcome the start that has been made, such as the Metropolitan Police's new race and ethnic task force, but recognise that much more needs to be done. We will:

Make the police more accountable. Public confidence in the police has declined. As well as seeking to improve the visibility of the police and improving police relations with the community, we will create a genuinely independent police complaints system to deal with complaints speedily, efficiently and impartially. We will encourage police forces to be more representative of the communities they serve, and ensure that 'stop and search' is based on intelligence and attaches no relevance to the race or colour of those stopped by the police.

Tackle hate crimes. We will establish police hate crime investigation units to coordinate information and action against racist and other hate crimes.

Liberal Democrats recognise that ethnic minorities also have concerns about the way in which the courts and the prison system treat ethnic minority citizens who come into contact with them. Ethnic minorities comprise a disproportionate share of the prison population. We will:

Retain jury trials for middle ranking cases currently threatened by Labour's Mode of Trial Bill, so that defendants can choose be tried by a jury representative of the community rather than a predominantly white magistracy, and restore the right to silence.

"For my constituents, and for those of many of us who represent multiracial communities, these are day-to-day issues. Twenty-five per cent. of my constituents are black or Asian. It is not just that many experience discrimination, and find that they have a greater chance of being excluded from school or doing less well there, or of being arrested or detained by the police, or of going to prison, or of being out of work. Nearly every week, people come to my surgery and tell me that they are being racially harassed, simply because of the colour of their skin." Simon Hughes, Liberal Democrat Shadow Home Secretary.

Equality of Opportunity in the Economy

Ethnic minority communities often live in economically disadvantaged areas, characterised by low pay, poor housing, high unemployment and poor access to financial services. To boost the prosperity of these communities, we will:

Review the minimum wage annually. The review will follow the recommendations of the Low Pay Commission. Equal work deserves equal pay, so we will also extend the full Minimum Wage to all those aged 16 and over, abolishing the lower rate paid to people under 21.

Remove taxation for the lowest paid. We believe that people start paying tax at too low a level and will work to reduce the burden of taxation on the low paid. Over time, we will cut the 10p tax rate to zero. At present, this would take 1.4 million people on low incomes out of tax altogether.

Regenerate deprived communities wherever they are through a one-stop Single Regeneration Grant system. This would streamline existing regeneration measures. We will ensure that all regeneration schemes are truly in line with the aspirations of the communities they are designed to help by strengthening local democratic input into decision-making.

Tackle financial exclusion by promoting community banking, Local Exchange and Trading Schemes (LETS), and credit unions. We will reform the regulations governing credit unions to make it easier to run non-interest schemes for Muslims.

Self-employment and small business are a particularly important route to economic advancement for ethnic minorities. To help small businesses create wealth and employment, we will:

Scrap unnecessary business regulations. We have published a list of 25 specific major regulations which we will scrap. We believe new regulations should where appropriate be subject to a "sunset clause", setting a deadline after which they would automatically lapse. We will also consult business before introducing any new measures.

Cut business rates on small businesses by introducing a Business Rates Allowance, similar to personal tax allowances. This tax free allowance would be set at £1500 and apply to all small businesses. With larger businesses paying a little more to cover the cost of the scheme, smaller businesses will pay less.

Promote diversity of ownership. We will initiate a review of policy governing mutual ownership of building societies, insurance companies and credit unions to encourage and develop them.

"In a fair society, business ownership must not be restricted to those with a particular background. The spirit of entrepreneurship should be nurtured in all sections of the community, everyone should be enabled to embark on their own enterprise regardless of age, ethnicity or gender." Brian Cotter, Liberal Democrat Small Business Spokesperson.

Equality and Religion

Liberal Democrats recognise that many cultural groups are defined by religious faith, rather than by ethnic group. The Runnymede Trust has produced a report on Islamaphobia, but discrimination on the grounds of religion is not limited to Muslims. Religion can be one of the most important factors in determining how a person is seen by his or her colleagues and acquaintances, and so there needs to be adequate legislation, along the same lines as existing race legislation. We will:

Include on census and other information-gathering questionnaires an optional question on religious faith or background. We would ensure that this information was used in the same way as information on ethnic background is currently used.

Introduce legislation protecting people from religious discrimination through our proposed Equality Act. This legislation should be equivalent to existing race discrimination legislation, subject to necessary exemptions and exceptions. It could also apply to those who claim they have been unfairly discriminated against on the basis of a lack of a particular religious belief.

Liberal Democrats believe that there should be legal parity between all religions and religious groups and that no one religion or denomination should receive preferential treatment. We will:

Abolish the existing Blasphemy Laws, which are discriminatory in their application.

Create a source of funding and support for those groups which feel unable to accept lottery funding due to their beliefs.

In the longer term, support the disestablishment of the Church of England.

"The purpose of our proposed Equality Act is to extend the life chances of people disadvantaged through belonging to groups discriminated against by British Society. To right this wrong, and to make meaningful the concept of citizenship, of living in a civilised society, we need the statutory remedy of true and enforceable equality before the law." Robert Maclennan, Liberal Democrat Shadow Cabinet Spokesperson on Constitutional Affairs.

Equality of Opportunity World Wide

Britain's membership of the UN Security Council, the Commonwealth, the EU, NATO, and other global bodies gives us a key role in world affairs. But with power comes responsibility. We must not turn a blind eye to poverty, nor support authoritarian regimes which oppress their people and threaten world stability. Britain's influence should be used to fight for human rights and equitable and peaceful relationships between nations.

The Liberal Democrat approach puts democratic values, human rights and good governance at the top of the foreign policy agenda. We advocate effective aid policies to address the greatest problems of developing countries and promote democracy and good governance. We will:

Honour the UK's commitment to meet the UN target of increasing overseas aid to 0.7% over the next ten years. We support the moves already made by the British Government to reduce the debts of the world's poorest countries. But Britain could take the lead in favour of more rapid action on debt relief by bodies such as the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank. Their Poverty Reduction Strategy Programmes should attach at least as much importance to governments taking action to tackle poverty as to liberalising their economies.

End links between aid and trade. Tied aid is a form of protectionism which inhibits development. We will subject all aid programmes to thorough assessment for their environmental, social and human rights consequences.

Promote genuine liberal trade. Trade underpins well-being throughout the world, but does not mean a right of the powerful to exploit the powerless, or make them more dependent. We want global trade to be based on rules and dispute settlement within the World Trade Organisation. But we also want WTO and EU rules to establish internationally recognised standards and labelling to allow consumers to exercise informed and ethical choice.

Press for a global competition authority within the WTO. This would co-ordinate the anti-monopoly activities of individual nations in order to tackle the growing concentration of corporate monopoly power more effectively.

Work with Britain's partners in the Commonwealth to make it more effective in promoting conflict resolution, good governance and democratic values.

"The fact is that the in our increasingly interdependent world, the assertion "No man is an island" is moving from the status of moral precept to a statement of hard political reality. We can now only prosper, have a context of stability in which to live our lives and assure a safe environment for our children if we are prepared, not just to recognise our global interdependence on each other, but also give it some political form in effective structures which provide an element of global governance." Sir Paddy Ashdown, former Leader of the Liberal Democrats.

fields.headline: Rapid rise in police recruitment
fields.standfirst: Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: Jack Straw today announced a dramatic increase in police recruitment, saying Home Office figures show a 77% jump in new recruits starting training this year.
fields.body:
Jack Straw today announced a dramatic increase in police recruitment, saying Home Office figures show a 77% jump in new recruits starting training this year.

The home secretary said the figures were a result of the first year's £40m investment from the government's crime fighting fund. Opposition critics said police numbers were still far lower than when Labour took office.

Every force in England and Wales saw an overall rise in the number of recruits, except Hertfordshire.

The Home Office statistics showed that 7,009 new recruits began residential training in 2000-2001, compared with 3,963 in the previous year, an increase of 76.9%.

The largest increase was in the Yorkshire and Humber region with a rise of 168%.

The home secretary announced the figures as he met the new intake at the Metropolitan police's training centre at Hendon, north London.

"Forces are to be congratulated on their efforts to recruit more officers," Mr Straw said.

"With nearly 40% of the total number of recruits coming through the crime fighting fund this is a sure sign that the government's increased funding for the police is delivering results."

The shadow home secretary, Ann Widdecombe, said of the figures: "Although they are saying a 75% increase, what they neglect to tell you is that that of course was the lowest level to which they themselves have allowed recruitment to fall. "If you compare the current numbers not with that but with those that they inherited there is precious little increase at all."

Mr Straw said: "The figures are very good - they show recruitment is rising very rapidly.

"Police numbers have been falling since 1993 because of the state of the public finances."

Mr Straw acknowledged that retaining police was also important and said fewer officers left the force through either resignations or retirements in 1999-2000.

Labour was obliged to stick with the Conservatives' public spending plans for the first two years in power, he added.

Simon Hughes, Liberal Democrat home affairs spokesman, said: "More police officers are, of course, welcome.

"But better figures in the last month before the general election can't make up for four years of inadequate funding, belated interest and broken promises by this Labour government."

fields.headline: Will leonine Frances be the pride of IPC?
fields.standfirst: Woman's Realm may be over but its editor, Mary Frances, has a new venture, Your Life. The magazine may not be launching at the best moment but, with Frances's bold Leo style, it should break new ground
fields.trailText: April 23: The former Woman's Realm editor has the strength to make a success of her new title, Your Life, writes Maggie Hyde.
fields.body:
The modern woman doesn't want a realm, she wants a life. That's the message from the magazine publisher, IPC, which is merging Woman's Realm with Woman's Weekly.

Mary Frances, the editor of Woman's Realm, will move on to edit Your Life, a new title for 40 to 50-year-olds. How will she fare in her new role?

As a Leo (August 14 1953), her horoscope shows the dilemma faced by many Leo Lions; whether to perform like the big cat or the cuddly, chocolate-box kitten.

Despite attempts to innovate, Woman's Realm got stuck with its knitting-pattern, nesting image and the female planets in Frances's horoscope must have responded in kind.

She has a charming and persuasive, nice-lady Libran Moon, linked to graceful Venus in the homey sign of Cancer.

The Libran Moon accommodates others - although it is notoriously indecisive - and her Venus is warm and womanly. When these planets combine, it brings out the side of her that really does know how to knit a scarf to keep teddy warm (Woman's Realm, first issue, February 22 1958).

Those days are over and Your Life is activating Frances's jungle instincts, with more scope for her bold and colourful Leo style. But can she use this to break new ground?

Despite her creative vision and organisational skills, she is coming up against an ill-chosen moment.

The horoscope for the launch of Your Life reveals it to be a lack-lustre Taurus (April 24 2001), with poor aspects to glossy, good-life Neptune.

Its horoscope does not look as if the magazine will do well with its target market of "empty nesters", who have time and money for luxury treats.

As a staunch Taurus, Your Life may hang on a while but this is a difficult time for the glossies in general and IPC in particular.

On May 6, Jupiter makes its final opposition to Pluto, crossing IPC's horizon, a problem period for the company bringing a probable downturn in advertising revenues as the year unfolds. Old formulae will cease to work and the winners will be the innovators.

Frances has her Sun placed next to the power planet Pluto, so she does have a real lion's roar in her.

People with this configuration have the ability to "regenerate and change themselves and the things around them by focusing their wills... but these natives can be dictatorial... they must realise they are not the only power in the universe". (Sakoian & Acker, the Astrologer's Handbook).

This side of her nature is coming into play much more now because in February, Uranus began making a series of oppositions to her Sun-Pluto power point, calling for a radical change of lifestyle and approach.

This time of life "awakens us to our own power... we may not be the most peaceful person to live with. We are excitable, 'wired', unpredictable and restless. We want to remove what we feel is stifling and break free of the restrictions of tradition or past conditioning." (Howard Sasportas, Gods of Change).

Uranus will continue to activate Frances's desire to create something unique until it has completed its transits in January 2002.

But she is coming in to bat on an unlevel playing field and it won't be until autumn 2003 that this lioness feels secure in her den again.

If, by then, Your Life is full of vitality, it will be largely down to Frances finding her roar and rising to meet the challenge of the winds of change.

Email the Media Medium at maggie@companyguide.co.uk

As a staunch Taurus, Your Life may hang on a while but this is a difficult time for the glossies in general and IPC in particular. On May 6, Jupiter makes its final opposition to Pluto, crossing IPC's horizon, a problem period for the company bringing a probable downturn in advertising revenues as the year unfolds. Old formulae will cease to work and the winners will be the innovators. Frances has her Sun placed next to the power planet Pluto, so she does have a real lion's roar in her. People with this configuration have the ability to "regenerate and change themselves and the things around them by focusing their wills... but these natives can be dictatorial... they must realise they are not the only power in the universe". (Sakoian & Acker, the Astrologer's Handbook). This side of her nature is coming into play much more now because in February, Uranus began making a series of oppositions to her Sun-Pluto power point, calling for a radical change of lifestyle and approach. This time of life "awakens us to our own power... we may not be the most peaceful person to live with. We are excitable, 'wired', unpredictable and restless. We want to remove what we feel is stifling and break free of the restrictions of tradition or past conditioning." (Howard Sasportas, Gods of Change). Uranus will continue to activate Frances's desire to create something unique until it has completed its transits in January 2002. But she is coming in to bat on an unlevel playing field and it won't be until autumn 2003 that this lioness feels secure in her den again. If, by then, Your Life is full of vitality, it will be largely down to Frances finding her roar and rising to meet the challenge of the winds of change. fields.headline: Children in poverty: the basics
fields.trailText: • The government hopes to eradicate child poverty over the next two decades.
fields.body:
 The government hopes to eradicate child poverty over the next two decades.

 Getting parents into work and targeting tax cuts and spending increases at those who need them most have formed the backbone of government moves towards cutting poverty.

 In recognition of the fact that money won't solve everything, the government has launched three schemes, Sure Start, the Children's Fund and Connexions, which will provide health, education and emotional support to children most at risk.

 Children are to be consulted about their needs. Paul Boateng, minister for young people has set up a group of a hundred 10- to 17-year-olds who will be asked their opinions.

 More than 1.2m children have been lifted out of poverty as a result of government policies introduced since the last election, according to the Child Poverty Action Group.

fields.headline: Promises, promises, promises
fields.standfirst: ITV, Channel 4 and Channel 5 unveil their 'contracts with viewers' this week ahead of the upcoming communications bill.  Maggie Brown  reveals exactly what they mean
fields.trailText: ITV, Channel 4 and Channel 5 unveil their 'contracts with viewers' this week ahead of the upcoming communications bill. Maggie Brown reveals exactly what they mean.
fields.body:
In a significant break with the past, ITV, Channel 4 and Channel 5 are publishing formal programme statements tomorrow, for the first time ever. These express their philosophy and what they expect to put on screen and achieve in the current year. They also look forward, in very general terms, to 2002 - without giving good ideas away to the opposition. The "contracts with viewers" (see above) matter because they are a dry run for the new deregulated system backed by the communications white paper, due to become a wide-reaching statute in 2003.

A government task force is putting the finishing touches to the bill, so it will be complete - apart from the controversial new rules allowing concentrated media ownership - by the time the new government is formed. The programme statements therefore represent the first concrete sign of how a so-called "light touch" regime will try to maintain the variety and quality that still distinguishes British television, by placing the onus on the broadcasters.

Too trusting for a system that rashly axed News at Ten? "The great benefit is that we get a dry run for a year, backed by what is in the current licences, and we will see how clear and how bankable it is," says Patricia Hodgson, chief executive of the Independent Television Commission, architect of the scheme.

Hodgson aims to "update the [programme] requirements to match audience needs". But can that be achieved in a highly competitive world suddenly facing a downturn? The communications white paper, remember, proposed three tiers of regulation. The first covers everyone including BSkyB, and requires compliance with basic codes and standards (requiring impartial news, for example). The second tier gives the new regulator - Ofcom - powers to set and enforce clear targets for the quantifiable things, regional news in peak time, investment in original programming. The programme statements under debate here mainly cover the third tier, all those qualitative public-service programme duties, including documentaries and arts expected of ITV, Channel 4 and, it seems certain, of Channel 5 too.

At the end of the year, channels and individual ITV franchisees will have to report on how they have measured up. With their licences simplified, the statements are seen as a means of "getting away from a group of us in a small room trying to make a contract with audiences", says Sarah Thane, ITC director of programmes. "They have to report back to their audiences on how well they have done. It's all public." In other words, the audiences will play a big part in keeping ITV honest.

Hodgson sketches out how Ofcom will enforce standards. In the first year, it will report on each licence holder's performance: "If it isn't wonderful, it will say so. In the second year, if there is a 'major and persistent' departure from an (agreed) remit, Ofcom can direct a franchise holder to make changes. If they still fail, it can use sanctions, fines, shortening licences, as happens now." So the "light touch" can still be followed by the stick if good intentions waver.

Thane says, however, that these new programme statements, the companies' own handiwork, have a greater commitment to detail than the regulator could have asked for. The prize of self-regulation and flexibility is clearly desirable and all have been on their best behaviour in this interim period. For ITV, the profile of regional programming is raised because if local people feel short- changed, they can make their views known at two public events a year (when companies unveil their statements and report back on how well they fulfilled them).

There are lots of active stockholders out there, a huge raft of people who have a significant int-erest in regional broadcasting. The interesting thing will be the extent to which they become engaged," says Thane. "The aim is to maintain diversity, not an identikit service." So, news and current affairs apart, regional slots can be spread over eight to 10 genres, providing sport does not dominate.

Channel 4's statement reflects culture secretary Chris Smith's desire to get away from the current negative clause defining it as catering for tastes and interests not readily served by channel three, and to ensure it does its duty as the most public service- oriented of the commercially funded channels, just below the BBC.

And Channel 5, Hodgson remarks, "is absolutely up for this, very much saying, 'We have something to bring to the party.' " In the run-up to the white paper it hardly participated in the political lobbying, but it subsequently mobilised as the changed ownership decreed more funds and a move towards the mainstream. As for ITV's statement: "We're impressed. Clarity and realism. What you want from them is a really high commitment to original production. Be realistic, they are popular entertainers; don't let's be snooty about popular drama. The public love it, it's very successful."

Are the programme statements legally binding? Thane replies: "That's a very interesting point. In essence, the streamlined licences and diversity commitments underpinning them are legally enforceable. The statements are a voluntary manifestation of that." So they need an element of goodwill on the broadcasters' side in order to deliver. The potential danger is that, somewhere down the line, clever lawyers might walk all over them.

The 'contracts with viewers'

CHANNEL 5

General: Will continue "to provide a point of difference in style and content from other broadcasters".

News: Promises a daily hour of news and talk from 5.30pm during the election campaign, with Matthew Wright hosting discussion on the day's developments.

Documentaries: Undertakes to remain energetic, specialising in reactive documentaries and current affairs.

Original drama: To stay at 12 hours per year excluding soaps, with Urban Gothic returning.

Entertainment: Commits to one-hour family entertainment formats: a third year of Night Fever and Fort Boyard, plus a new strand, Desert Forges. Greed - a team game show with large cash prizes, hosted by Jerry Springer - starts this summer.

Movies: Nightly 9pm film is seen as a dependable public service.

Children's: Pledges 11 hours, 40 minutes per week including the two "zones", Milk Shake and The Core. Weekly quota to include 90 minutes of drama and nine hours of information-based programming.

Plus: Ten per cent of production spend will be outside London for the first time.

ITV

General: ITV describes itself as "a high-quality, mainstream, mass-audience channel". It pledges an annual network programme budget for 2001 of £750m (up from £705m). It says "original production" is its key determinant.

ITV "has an inclusive appeal aimed at the widest possible audiences, across age, class, geographical and cultural boundaries". To be "innovative and distinctive", it says, "is not one of our defining characteristics".

Entertainment and drama: These genres are described as "the key to ITV's offer to the viewer". Besides the already screened Popstars and Nicholas Nickleby, promised offerings later in 2001 include Survivor, Othello, a drama-documentary about Bloody Sunday and Alan Bleasdale's Henry VIII.

News: Commits to current news programmes in peak time, including the terms for a reinstated News at Ten.

Documentaries: Renews commit-ment to popular social history, following the success of Time of Our Lives, but says opportunities for peak-time docs have been affected by the return of News at Ten.

Sport: In a dig at Sky, ITV says it can "make top sporting events available, live and free to the widest possible audience, regardless of their willingness to pay".

Arts: "The South Bank Show is the only arts strand regularly on a mainstream channel."

Religion: Will continue Sunday Morning, and promises a major documentary series on miracles.

Plus: No firm date yet given for digital broadcasts, as terms have not yet been agreed with BSkyB.

CHANNEL 4

General: "We will use our reputation for risk and nonconformism to engage a younger generation in the values of public service broadcasting."

Landmark programmes: "We will increasingly concentrate on a selected number of high-cost projects of ambition each year", which in 2002 include Ken Loach's The Navigators (on rail privatisation) and a film about Shackleton starring Kenneth Branagh.

Drama and documentaries: Aims to promote personal authorship and so attract writers, directors and performers seeking "creative freedom". Forthcoming factual series include a study of the criminal justice system.

News and current affairs: Commits for at least two years to peak-time news, plus improved business coverage.

Multicultural: Documentaries will explore marriage in a multicultural society, and contrast family life in the third world and Britain.

Arts: Will "reinforce our focus on architecture and design", and plans series on Picasso, classical music (by Howard Goodall) and men in dance (by Matthew Bourne).

Children's: The first 125 (of 250) episodes of The Hoobs, the puppet show for three-to-fives created by Jim Henson's Creature Workshop.

Sport: Will use the "fresh approach" used for cricket for the world rally championships from 2002.

Plus: Channel 4's "salience" in the new media landscape is to be maintained by increased provision of creative content across different platforms - as with the webcasting of Big Brother and Kumbh Mela.

fields.headline: B2B magazines face advertising slowdown
fields.trailText: 1pm: Business to business magazines will suffer from the advertising slowdown, according to new research. By Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
New research from the Advertising Association suggests that business to business magazines will not be able to buck the forthcoming advertising slowdown.

By the end of the next business year, according to the figures, the total advertising revenue for business to business magazines is likely to rise £48m to £1.38bn.

This represents a significant decline in the growth seen in 1999-2000 and 2000-2001, when advertising revenue increased 71m from 1.26bn to 1.33bn.

The growth predicted over the next year is 3.5%, compared with a rise of 5.3% over the course of the previous year.

The research has been compiled in response to predictions that advertising revenues will fall for media companies across the board.

The results echo research published in January by market research company AC Nielsen, which predicted advertising growth over the next year of 4%.

Since last autumn, the media industry has been seeing growing signs of an impending advertising slowdown.

ITV companies Granada and Carlton warned then that their advertising revenue would decline.

Since then there have been further warning signs of decline, with the country's biggest advertiser, Procter & Gamble, slashing spending by 25%.

fields.headline: BSkyB rethink threatens new media chief
fields.trailText: 12.15pm: BSkyB is poised to oust John Swingewood, its director of new media, after a company-wide budget review. By Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
BSkyB is poised to oust John Swingewood, its director of new media, as a company-wide budget review is expected to lead to cutbacks in its internet division.

Speculation surrounding Mr Swingewood's departure suggests a scaling back of BSkyB's 200-strong online ventures arm.

A BSkyB spokesman refused to confirm reports of Mr Swingewood's departure, despite speculation that he is to leave BSkyB in the next few days.

Mr Swingewood, who was appointed to the post in October 1999, has taken responsibility within the company for a string of disastrous internet investments.

Soon after joining BSkyB, Mr Swingewood announced a £250m internet war chest, which it overspent after buying Sports Internet Group last summer for £301m.

The value of Sports Internet is now said to be as low as £10m.

BSkyB's other internet investments included £10m in the recently rescued Letsbuyit.com; £11m in Gameplay, which is currently looking for a buyer; a 6% stake in Sportal, which is also said to be desperate for more funding; around £1.5 in the now defunct Toyzone.co.uk; and almost £1m in Mykindaplace.com.

In addition to managing BSkyB's internet investments, strategy and websites, Mr Swingewood was charged with negotiating an ADSL deal for BSkyB's next generation set-top box.

The favoured supplier is BT, although Kingston, a company in which BSkyB has a stake, is also said to be in the running for the contract amid rumours that negotiations with BT have dragged on too long.

Additionally, Mr Swingewood's role is said to have become largely superfluous, given BSkyB's new focus on "T-commerce" (shopping via interactive TV) and the appointments of Jim Rudder as director of interactive broadcasting and Jon Florsheim as managing director of Sky Interactive.

webTitle: Army defiant as Bangladesh election looms

fields.headline: Army defiant as Bangladesh election looms
fields.standfirst: Last week's killing of 16 Indian soldiers at the border shows the military is prepared to defy its political masters, says Luke Harding
fields.trailText: Last week's killing of 16 Indian soldiers at the border shows the military is prepared to defy its political masters, says Luke Harding.
fields.body:
India's vast border has always been a source of trouble. In the north of the country, the line of control between India and Pakistan in Kashmir has been at the centre of conflict for half a century. Down in the remote north-east, China still contests India's presence in the state of Arunachal Pradesh.

But until last week, nobody had paid much attention to India's border with Bangladesh. All this changed last Wednesday when 16 Indian soldiers appear to have ventured just inside Bangladeshi territory near the town of Manakchar in Assam.

They were responding to an incursion two days earlier by Bangladesh's border security force, the Bangladesh Rifles, into Pyrdiwah, a village in the neighbouring state of Meghalaya. What happened next is the subject of bitter controversy. Cut off from their unit, the Indian soldiers appear to have walked straight into a trap.

They were disarmed by hundreds of Bangladeshi villagers who appeared from nowhere and handed over to the Bangladeshi Rifles. They were then tortured. Finally they were shot.

"The jawans [Indian soldiers] were strangled and their bones broken. Some of the bodies were badly charred and scalded as boiling water was poured on them," General Gurbachan Jagat of India's border security force claimed. On Friday, the mutilated bodies of all 16 men were returned to the Indian side.

The weekend papers in India made grim reading. In particular, one image shocked: that of a dead Indian solder being carried on a pole by Bangladeshi villagers across a shallow river. His hands and feet were tied with rope.

On Saturday, the dead man's colleagues watched as all 16 soldiers were cremated on a series of wooden pyres. Nine of them were so badly mutilated they could not be identified.

The incident could have been expected to plunge relations between India and Bangladesh into turmoil. In fact, both Delhi and Dhaka have been remarkably restrained in their response - and have blamed the border skirmish on "local adventurism".

Last night, Sheikh Hasina, Bangladesh's prime minister, telephoned her Indian counterpart Atal Bihari Vajpayee to express her "regret" at the deaths.

What now seems clear is that Major-General Fazalur Rahman, the chief of the Bangladesh Rifles, deliberately orchestrated the skirmish.

Bangladesh's general election is only two or three months away. The country has been paralysed in recent months by a series of opposition-called "hartals" or strikes. It is little secret that General Rahman is no friend of Sheikh Hasina's.

Like most of the Bangladesh military, Rahman's allegiance appears to lie with the Bangladesh opposition leader Khaleda Zia, the widow of the former military ruler Ziaur Rahaman. Since Sheikh Hasina won office in 1996, the influence of Bangladesh's generals who enjoyed unbridled power during 16 years of martial rule has waned. They have privately opposed her policy of improving relations with India.

Were Sheikh Hasina now to sack Gen Rahman, the opposition could parade him as a patriot who had the guts to stand up to Bangladesh's overweening neighbour, sources in Delhi have suggested. As one Indian newspaper put it: "The military had been quietly preparing the ground for a major showdown using the classical route - India baiting.

"The BNP [Khaleda Zia's party], and its supporting cast of generals are clearly trying to cash in on the deep divide in the Bangladeshi consciousness over India's designs. The 2001 Bangladesh elections will decide if the ploy has worked."

The gruesome incident last week shows that Bangladesh's armed forces are prepared to act in defiance of their political masters in Dhaka, a worrying trend.

Back in 1975 the army assassinated Sheikh Hasina's father, Sheikh Mujib, the country's independence leader, together with most of his family. A long period of military rule followed.

As Bangladesh prepares to go to the polls, following an exceptionally acrimonious pre-election campaign, could another coup be on the cards?
