webTitle: Public inquiry into death of abused child

fields.headline: Public inquiry into death of abused child
fields.trailText: The government yesterday ordered public hearings of evidence about the death of Anna Climbié, the eight-year-old murdered in London last year, after months of sustained and horrific child abuse went unheeded by the child protection authorities.
fields.body:
The government yesterday ordered public hearings of evidence about the death of Anna Climbié, the eight-year-old murdered in London last year, after months of sustained and horrific child abuse went unheeded by the child protection authorities.

John Hutton, the health minister responsible for children's services, said an independent inquiry into failings by social workers, police and NHS staff would start work shortly to learn lessons from the tragedy and strengthen safeguards for vulnerable children.

He surprised the agencies under investigation by announcing terms of reference requiring details of their mistakes to be paraded in public. Senior managers had been expecting a private inquiry that would concentrate as much on general standards of child protection in England as the circumstances of Anna's murder.

The girl died at the hands of her aunt, Marie Thérèse Kouao, 44, and her lover, Carl Manning, 28, who were convicted of murder and cruelty at the Old Bailey in January and jailed for life.

She had been brought to the attention of social services three times and was discharged from hospital twice since coming to Britain from the Ivory Coast in 1999. After her death, the marks of 128 separate injuries were found on her body.

The judge said Anna had been repeatedly assaulted "by hand and implement", "covered from head to toe in injuries and open sores", "bound by ankle and wrist in packing tape" and "placed overnight naked in a bag in the bath, sometimes for 24 hours". He said: "What she endured was truly unimaginable."

Mr Hutton said the inquiry into her death would be the first "tripartite" investigation using powers under the Children Act, the NHS Act and Police Act. In effect there will be three parallel inquiries, conducted simultaneously, but producing a single report in spring next year to the health secretary and the home secretary.

Lord Laming, the inquiry chairman, will be assisted by a team of expert advisers, including specialists in paediatric medicine, nursing, child protection and the police.

He said: "The difficult issue of whether or not to hold the inquiry in public or private needed to be considered very carefully. I believe a public inquiry will be both more effective and fair, and will ensure that matters are dealt with in an open and honest manner."

The terms of reference instruct Lord Laming to:

 establish the circumstances surrounding the girl's death;

 identify which services were requested or required for her;

 examine the way local authorities, health bodies and police responded to those needs and how well they co-operated with each other and other services such as education and housing; and

 reach conclusions about the circumstances of her death and "make recommendations as to how such an event may, as far as possible, be avoided in the future".

Rob Hutchinson, of the Association of Directors of Social Services, welcomed the decision to take evidence in public.

The Department of Health said agencies involved in the case included the London boroughs of Ealing, Brent, Haringey and Enfield, Brent and Harrow health authority, Enfield and Haringey health authority, North West London Hospitals NHS trust (covering Central Middlesex hospital), North Middlesex hospital NHS trust, and the Metropolitan police.

webTitle: Harry Potter actors sign secrecy contracts

fields.headline: Harry Potter actors sign secrecy contracts
fields.standfirst: Plus: Penelope Cruz denies affairs; Mormon director plans film on church founder; Dances with Wolves sequel planned
fields.trailText: Plus: Penelope Cruz denies affairs; Mormon director plans film on church founder; Dances with Wolves sequel planned
fields.body:
Some of the young actors in Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone have been made to sign contracts promising not to talk about the contents of the film according to Ananova. A spokeswoman for the film's producer's Warner Bros admitted that it is having to take a firm line with it's child stars. "As a matter of routine, we asked the parents or legal guardians of the children who are working on the set to sign these agreements," she said. "The purpose of them is to stop people discussing various aspects of the film before it's released." However, despite the secrecy, a few details from the film have leaked out. Apparently, Harry is a football fan who supports Arsenal and loves fish fingers.

Penelope Cruz has dismissed talk that she and co-star Nicolas Cage are an item. "We are not together as a couple," she said in an interview published in Saturday's Daily Telegraph magazine. "Nicolas and I are very good friends." Cage, who very publicly left his actress wife Patricia Arquette while he was on the set of Captain Corelli's Mandolin, had a great sense of humour, Cruz said. "He really makes me laugh. I grew up watching all of his films." The 27-year-old star also dismissed rumours that she was romantically linked with Tom Cruise after pictures were shown in the tabloids of her and Cruise walking arm-in-arm in Central Park. "You thought those pictures were real?" Cruz said. "...they were taken on the set of my new film Vanilla Sky. The Spanish actress said she was looking forward to returning to her "real home" in Madrid this summer and revealed she was planning a new project with Spanish director Pedro Almodovar and Antonio Banderas.

Mormon film-maker Richard Dutcher, director and star of last year's God's Army has announced plans to make a movie biography of church founder Joseph Smith. Dutcher has already begun scouting New York and Midwest locations for the tentatively titled The Prophet: The Story of Joseph Smith Jr. "I want to bring this amazingly charismatic and strong individual to the screen,'' Dutcher told reporters. ''A figure like this is greater than Lawrence of Arabia. This is Gandhi... If I don't make this film, somebody else is going to. And I'm convinced that if they do it, I'm not going to like it.'' The founding father of Mormonism claimed a heavenly being appeared to him in 1823 and showed him a religious history of an ancient American civilisation, which Smith translated, into the Book of Mormon. He died in jail in 1844.

A sequel to Dances with Wolves has taken a step closer to the big screen after the film rights to the follow-up novel The Holy Road were bought by an American production company, according to Ananova. The original book about a tribal warrior who goes on a mission to rescue his wife when she is abducted by white invaders, was turned into an Oscar-winning film starring Kevin Costlier in 1990. The book which will take up the story ten years later, is set to be published in September. There is no word yet on whether Costner will be involved in the film.

webTitle: Hotel hostages freed as gunmen surrender

fields.headline: Hotel hostages freed as gunmen surrender
fields.standfirst:
Photo gallery

Special report: Chechnya
fields.trailText: Pro-Chechen gunmen in Istanbul have surrendered to police and released their captives, Turkish television reported today.
fields.body:
Pro-Chechen gunmen in Istanbul have surrendered to police and released their captives, Turkish television reported today.

The group, armed with automatic rifles and shotguns, stormed a luxury hotel overlooking the scenic Bosphorus 12 hours earlier, taking at least 30 people hostage.

The action ended after the interior minister, Sadettin Tantan, held talks with the gunmen. No one was injured, according to the police.

The gunmen had earlier issued a statement saying that their action was a protest against Russia's "bloody attacks" in the Caucasus.

They told the police that they had no intention to "spill blood" but warned that the action could "turn into a mess" if the Turkish authorities intervened.

However, it is reported that they had demanded to speak to Mr Tantan.

The group is believed to be led by Muhammed Tokcan, a Turkish citizen of Chechen origin, who hijacked a ferry and held more than 200 people hostage in 1996.

He was sent to jail after surrendering to police, but released late last year under an amnesty law.

Hundreds of police surrounded the hotel. Snipers wearing black ski masks took up positions outside the hotel and at least six ambulances were outside.

Witnesses said that the guests were screaming and running in panic when the gunmen entered the lobby, firing rounds into the area.

Hotel worker Alisan Ercan said that he heard shots and saw four or five gunmen in the lobby as he ran from the hotel.

Hotel guests hid between tables in the lobby, Mr Ercan said. About 60 guests and 40 workers escaped the hotel, many leaving through fire exits.

Police detained the 13 gunmen after they left the hotel.

The Chechen rebels' fight against Russia is popular in Turkey. Turks not only share the Islamic religion with Chechens, but more than 5m Turks trace their roots to the Caucasus.

About 25,000 Chechens live in Istanbul and western Turkey. There are about 80 Caucasus organisations in Turkey and many have been active in promoting the Chechen cause.

fields.headline: Ruud van Nistelrooy factfile
fields.trailText: 1976: Born July 1 in Oss, Holland.
fields.body:
1976: Born July 1 in Oss, Holland.

Plays for Nooit Gedacht and Margriet before joining FC Den Bosch, then in Dutch Second Division.

1997: Moves to First Division with Heerenveen. Scores 13 times in 30 appearances in 1997-98 season.

1998: Signs for PSV Eindhoven on his 22nd birthday for £4.2m (15m guilders) - a record between Dutch clubs.

August 29 - scores first League goal for PSV, against his former club.

October 31 - hits hat-trick for PSV against Sparta.

November 18 - makes international debut for Holland in 1-1 draw with Germany.

1999: May - ends season as top scorer in Dutch league with 31 goals, second in European Golden Boot Rankings.

Voted Dutch player of the year by fellow professionals.

Scores first and so far only international goal against Morocco.

2000: February 21 - wins 10th cap for Holland in 2-1 friendly victory over Germany.

March 6 - Picks up knee injury in friendly against Danish side Silkeborg with goals tally on 29 for season.

April 21 - PSV agree to sell him to Manchester United in £19m deal.

April 25 - United call a press conference for 4.30pm. Just before 6pm, United reveal that van Nistelrooy's transfer has been held up by his knee injury. Van Nistelrooy undergoes a medical but United director David Gill announces that United are "unable to complete all necessary tests to our satisfaction today."

2001: April 21 - PSV Eindhoven chairman Harry van Raay reveals Van Nistelrooy will join United for £18million over the weekend following talks with United officials.

April 23 - Passes medical and is expected to complete his move to Old Trafford soon.

webTitle: Crisis prompts increase in rural borrowing

fields.headline: Crisis prompts increase in rural borrowing
fields.standfirst: Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: Farms and other agricultural businesses borrowed two and half times more money from banks last month as the foot and mouth crisis took hold, figures revealed today.
fields.body:
Farms and other agricultural businesses borrowed two and half times more money from banks last month as the foot and mouth crisis took hold, figures revealed today.

The British Bankers' Association (BBA) said its members increased their lending to the farming sector by a net £47m in March. The figure is significantly higher than the same month a year earlier, when net lending was £18m, and it is the largest amount for five months.

As well as an increase in loans, the figure covers those banks which have allowed farmers to delay interest repayments because of the crisis, the BBA said.

Tim Sweeney, BBA director general, said: "The foot and mouth epidemic and lenders' willingness to help those affected probably accounted for increased lending to the farming sector."

The BBA added that significant increases were also seen in lending to transport and communication businesses, real estate companies, construction firms and retailers. Only food, beverages and tobacco companies made significant repayments on borrowed money.

webTitle: Foot and mouth in the media

fields.headline: Day 63: foot and mouth in the media
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk keeps you informed with a daily briefing on the press coverage of foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText:
Day 63: Two papers report on how the disease has led to farmers committing suicide.
Special report: foot and mouth in the media
fields.body:
The Guardian
The paper reports on the desperation of the British farmers. One farmer was found dead a week after his beef cattle were slaughtered. A bigger fear is taking hold, however. Potentially cancerous chemicals are being released into the atmosphere as a result of the pyres of dead animals.

Daily Mail
The Mail reports on how the cull is not only affecting sheep and cattle - horses are now under threat. A beautiful stallion had to be killed because its owner could not afford to keep him.

The Times
A piece on page 10 reveals an inquiry has been ordered into the effects on public health of the smoke and pollution from the pyres.

The Sun
William Hague has become the latest casualty of foot and mouth. He will escape slaughter but 370 animals that live practically on his doorstep will not be so lucky.

The Mirror
The paper, which still insists it is only day 61 of the crisis, reports on the second farmer suicide.

The Daily Telegraph
The paper reports from the front line and reprints the diary of a farmer's wife, who says all they "can do is pray and spray". One piece suggests Devon will be unable to dispose of rotting carcasses, which are set to contaminate the land for years.

fields.headline: Week 34: the expert's view
fields.standfirst: Blue Square expert The Camel tells it the way he sees it, and gives it to us straight
fields.trailText:
Current totals (from their initial £100 kitties):

Scott Murray = £148.04

The Prince of Punts (aka Paul MacInnes) = £50

The Guardian Unlimited Punters Collective = £28.46

Sean Ingle = £22.32
fields.body:
Current totals (from their initial £100 kitties):

Scott Murray = £148.04

The Prince of Punts (aka Paul MacInnes) = £50

The Guardian Unlimited Punters Collective = £28.46

Sean Ingle = £22.32

Scott Murray: Coventry to win at Ipswich £10 @ 7/2

Bet lost: Ipswich won 2-0

If you mention the word "Ipswich" in Blue Square Towers you better say it in hushed tones or you're liable to be beaten to a pulp. A seer (well, we assume he's a seer) staked £100 each way on the Tractor Boys at 2000/1 prior to the beginning of the season. So, if they manage a Champions League spot, our intrepid punter wins £50,000.

As for Mr Murray's selection, I can see the logic - as usual, this boy doesn't bet without thought, but I seem to be complementing him so often it might go to his head - but I didn't think it was particularly value. Let's face facts, Coventry are mediocre, in-form though they may be, and against a team with nothing to play for odds of 3/1 or better might tempt to put my betting boots on. But scintillating Ipswich, in the prime of form, are not such an outfit. They are winning games like it is going out of fashion, and to my way of thinking could not be opposed here.

For the sake of my bosses' health though, let their glorious season end with a Uefa Cup place, not a top three finish.

The Prince of Punts: Manchester City to be up at half-time against Manchester United £5 @ 6/1

Bet lost: it was 0-0 at half-time

I am not averse to using statistics to find a value wager. But to say because Manchester City have been leading at the break twice in the last three matches they are value at 6/1 to be leading in the local derby is plainly nonsense. It's like tossing a coin three times, and because it lands heads each time having a huge bet at 4/5 because you think it's value. For statistics to play a useful part in the selection process, you must use a much bigger sample.

That's not to say this bet wasn't without merit. Manchester United's season is effectively over and they certainly looked ripe for opposing in this local derby. I backed City at 15/2 to win the match. City, desperate for points and fired up by a vocal away following, almost certainly put more store in a derby victory than their aristocratic neighbours. With the disappointment of Wednesday weighing on their shoulders, a sup-par effort could be expected from United. Betting City to be leading at half-time was an option, albeit a strange one, and was certainly a fair bet.

Julian Lord of the Guardian Unlimited Punters Collective: £5 double on Manchester United to beat Manchester City (4/11) and Leicester to beat Middlesbrough (6/4)

Bet lost: the Manchester derby ended 1-1 while Boro won 3-0

My stomach churned and my gills turned a nasty shade of green when I saw this bet. Horrible. That was my only printable reaction to it.

As I have outlined above, I didn't think United were a viable bet in their local derby, certainly not at odds of 4/11. The bookmaker grows fat on the profits of punters lumping money on short-priced favourites as, week in week out, a succession of them get beaten or held to draws. Put it this way, if I asked you to make me a £20 profit on this game, but you had to accept the risk, which option would you choose? Sticking £60 on United and hoping that the Munich nightmare wouldn't affect them, or £3 on City in the hopes that the derby atmosphere would lift their performance to necessary levels? I know which one I would choose.

But the second leg of this X-rated horror show was really the part that made me feel queasy. Julian, have you been on holiday for the last six weeks? I could rarely entertain backing a team that had lost their last seven matches. Certainly not against one that was fighting for their Premiership survival, whose win at Highbury proved they weren't totally without merit.

Go to the back of the class. And write 100 lines: "I will only back value selections, I will only back value selections."

Sean Ingle: Manchester United v Manchester City: draw half-time/United to win full-time £5 @ 4/1

Bet lost: the match was drawn at half-time, but despite United taking the lead, a late City goal meant the match ended 1-1

As I have intimated before, when faced with a short-priced selection, I think this maybe the way to support it. I am certainly going to do some research during the summer, but I feel if a team has a 75% chance of winning a game (in this case I dispute that figure, but that is beside the point) then there is more than a 20% chance that they will be drawing at half-time before winning the game.

For this game, at best prices, United were 10/11 to lead at half-time and full-time (52.38%); 4/1 to be drawing at half-time and full-time (20%); and 16/1 to come back from a half time deficit to win (5.88%). Off the top of my head, I would suggest that odds of 5/4, 3/1 and 16/1 would be more appropriate here and the 4/1 you took was probably value.

Steve Howey was the unlikely shatterer of your bet, but it proves that the value seeker doesn't always come out smiling. Grin and bear it Mr. Ingle this was a vast improvement on most of your bets I've analysed, and proves you are on the right road to long-term punting success.

webTitle: US tourists may not return for years

fields.headline: US tourists may not return for years
fields.standfirst:
Special report: foot and mouth disease

Election 2001: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: American tourists may not return to Britain after the foot and mouth outbreak for up to four years, the culture secretary, Chris Smith, warned yesterday.
fields.body:
American tourists may not return to Britain after the foot and mouth outbreak for up to four years, the culture secretary, Chris Smith, warned yesterday.

As tour operators disclosed that foreign tourism was down by up to 30% over the Easter holidays, Mr Smith said the "real worry" was that, after the initial drop in visitor numbers, "the American market in particular could take a long time to recover".

On GMTV's Sunday programme, he pointed to the "major fall-off" in American tourists coming to Britain for several years after the 1991 Gulf war, when many were alarmed at the prospect of terrorist attacks. "Even though Britain was thousands of miles away, the American tourist perspective was that Europe was not somewhere to go, and that effect lasted for about three or four years".

European tourists were expected to take a far less sensitive approach over returning to Britain on holiday, he indicated.

The government also sought to reassure the public last night that burning pyres of animals slaughtered during the foot and mouth epidemic were not causing a health risk. A report by the National Environmental Technology Centre claimed the pyres were emitting higher levels of polluting dioxins than all the country's factories combined.

American visitors form the core of the UK's tourism market, being worth £2.5bn annually, but they have proven quick to steer clear over threats such as IRA terrorism or reverberations from the Gulf or Balkan conflicts. Numbers dropped by a quarter in 1991 as a result of the Gulf war.

The culture secretary's remarks coincided with a warning from Richard Tobias, chief executive of the British Incoming Tour Operators Association, that the industry - normally worth £13bn a year to Britain's economy - faced serious problems in the run-up to summer.

Trade was 25-30% down, he said on GMTV. The next eight weeks would be a crunch period as operators sought to win summer bookings, he warned.

Mr Tobias called on Mr Smith to persuade cabinet colleagues, notably the chancellor, Gordon Brown, to release funds to pay for a big publicity campaign to attract overseas visitors.

Tourism leaders are furious after Mr Brown had approved only £6m to convince domestic and overseas tourists that Britain was not closed for business.

The culture secretary appeared to hint at further cash, acknowledging: "We have to make sure that we throw as many lifelines as we can to the hard-pressed tourism industry."

He also made his most forthright attack yet on Conservative-controlled local authorities such as Buckinghamshire which he claimed were refusing to open footpaths to the public "for ideological reasons". He said: "I would appeal to them, because they are affecting the tourism and hotel businesses in their county."

fields.headline: Recipe for disaster
fields.trailText: 11.30am: Delia Smith has joined a growing list of celebrities who are out of pocket from online ventures, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
TV cook Delia Smith has lost £60m on the internet, joining the growing list of celebrities who have made vast paper losses from online ventures.

Her Deliaonline.com, which offers consumers recipes and tips on food and wine, was valued which at £60m at the height of the internet boom last June. It is now worth virtually nothing.

The PR guru, Matthew Freud, comes in second, according to the survey by the Mail on Sunday, with a paper loss of £53m from disasters including Oxygen Holdings and Toyzone.co.uk.

Pop star David Bowie's fortune is down by £30m, wasted on improvident ventures such as Bowiebanc.com, while the Manchester United manager, Sir Alex Ferguson, is said to have lost £10m in value on Toptable.co.uk.

Absolutely Fabulous star Joanna Lumley lost £5m in paper money because of ClickMango and celebrity chefs Gordon Ramsay and Anthony Worrall-Thompson lost £5m apiece after they combined to back Foodoo.com.

Other big name losers include Bob Geldof (£3m) for Deckchair.com and WapWorld; Jonathan Ross (£2m) for Toyzone.co.uk; Jim Kerr (£1.7m) for Student24-7.com; and Madonna (£665,000) for Artistdirect.

The losses were revealed in the Mail on Sunday's survey of "dot.goners", part of its 2001 Rich Report.

Tim Jackson, the former Financial Times journalist and founder of QXL, forms part of the Rich Report's 20 biggest losers with a paper loss of £417m to his current value of £5.8m.

Four prominent internet people make the Mail's top 50 richest young list among the likes of David and Victoria Beckham and Robbie Williams.

These include Jonathan Rowland, son of David Rowland, who founded Jellyworks and is now said to be worth £26m.

Ajaz Ahmed, the AKQA agency man used to making appearances in rich lists, beats Geri Halliwell to 18th place with a paper fortune of £24m.

Tom Hadfield, the 19-year-old A-level student from Brighton who set up Soccernet and Schoolsnet, is worth £19m; and Ernesto Schmitt, the 29-year-old founder of Peoplesound.com, enters at 28 with £17m.

It was the weekend of rich lists, with the Sunday Times also publishing its latest list.

Easy founder Stelios Haji-Ioannou was top of the "fastest fortunes made" list, with an annual average growth rate of £145.5m.

Publisher Felix Dennis appears at number 67 in the list with a fortune of £425m; Peter Wilkinson (a founder of Freeserve) comes in at 73 with £400m; and Express boss Richard Desmond appears at 105 with £300m.

Other big name losers include Bob Geldof (£3m) for Deckchair.com and WapWorld; Jonathan Ross (£2m) for Toyzone.co.uk; Jim Kerr (£1.7m) for Student24-7.com; and Madonna (£665,000) for Artistdirect. The losses were revealed in the Mail on Sunday's survey of "dot.goners", part of its 2001 Rich Report. Tim Jackson, the former Financial Times journalist and founder of QXL, forms part of the Rich Report's 20 biggest losers with a paper loss of £417m to his current value of £5.8m. Four prominent internet people make the Mail's top 50 richest young list among the likes of David and Victoria Beckham and Robbie Williams. These include Jonathan Rowland, son of David Rowland, who founded Jellyworks and is now said to be worth £26m. Ajaz Ahmed, the AKQA agency man used to making appearances in rich lists, beats Geri Halliwell to 18th place with a paper fortune of £24m. Tom Hadfield, the 19-year-old A-level student from Brighton who set up Soccernet and Schoolsnet, is worth £19m; and Ernesto Schmitt, the 29-year-old founder of Peoplesound.com, enters at 28 with £17m. It was the weekend of rich lists, with the Sunday Times also publishing its latest list. Easy founder Stelios Haji-Ioannou was top of the "fastest fortunes made" list, with an annual average growth rate of £145.5m. Publisher Felix Dennis appears at number 67 in the list with a fortune of £425m; Peter Wilkinson (a founder of Freeserve) comes in at 73 with £400m; and Express boss Richard Desmond appears at 105 with £300m.

fields.headline: Satisfaction no longer guaranteed
fields.standfirst: Public sector staff are increasingly suffering from stress and depression, writes Tracey Boles
fields.trailText: Public sector staff are increasingly suffering from stress and depression, writes Tracey Boles.
fields.body:
If you are unhappy in your work, you are not alone. Job satisfaction among Britain's 6 million public sector workers has plummeted over the past decade - and stress is to blame, says a new study from Warwick University.

The study by Andrew Oswald and Jonathan Gardner found that an increase in depression, strain, sleep loss and unhappiness during the 1990s had made employment in the public sector more pressurised and less enjoyable.

However, despite the discontent, most people in the public sector are almost completely satisfied with their job. On a scale of one (completely dissatisfied) to seven (completely satisfied), 41 per cent of the population gave their answer as six and 18 per cent went for 7. Only 2 per cent answered one.

The sample of 5,000 workers from both the public and private sector was re-interviewed each year through the 1990s, with stress levels assessed by the answers to 12 questions used to measure mental distress and psychological ill health such as 'Can you concentrate on your work?', and 'Are you losing confidence?'.

While public-sector workers began the 1990s with far higher levels of job satisfaction than those in the private sector, the research showed that this gap had been virtually eroded by 1998, a year of tightly controlled government spending.

Rising stress due to a substantial increase in workload had caused the decline in job satisfaction, Oswald says. The workers, which include doctors, teachers, lecturers and civil servants, now have to face extra bureaucracy, pressure to meet targets and the introduction of working practices from the private sector. The latter was more stressful than in 1990, but not much.

As well as an increasingly heavy workload, public-sector workers have been subjected to much evaluation, inspection and public humiliation. Oswald says: 'Public humiliation is not found in any other job. Who, apart from teachers and doctors, gets their name published all over the papers saying they are second rate?'

This process of holding people to account has made the public sector very unpleasant to work in because human beings are not equipped to cope with it, according to Oswald.

All groups of public-sector workers have become less satisfied at work over the past decade. But the slump in satisfaction was particularly evident in the NHS, higher education, and among those working for local government. 'Local government has been the poor relation of the public sector,' says Unison, the union that represents public-sector workers. It says the worst affected are those at the lower end of the pay scale in local government, such as cleaners and caterers.

Unison does not find the report's conclusions surprising. It says low morale is the result of years of under-investment, both in staff and the workplace. 'The lack of pay awards and training have lead to loss of job satisfaction,' says a spokeswoman. 'Managing on a day-to-day level is stressful after years of cutbacks.'

It also blames the threat of violence and the effects of privatisation for the poor morale. 'When a service is privatised employees are guaranteed work - at first. The prospect of restructuring hangs over them.'

Can anything be done to turn round this unsatisfactory state of affairs?

It has become a matter for public policy, Oswald believes. 'As a nation we have to decide how important our public services are to us. We have to offer good jobs or hand them over to the private sector. At the moment we are not in equilibrium.'

Unison believes services should be run in-house. 'We are against privatisation and contracting out.'

Decent pay awards and further investment are also needed to remedy the situation. A spokeswoman says: 'In the health service the amount of money that has gone in has made a difference. Investment has been at all levels. Individual learning accounts are available to all staff. They have recognised that staff at all levels are important.'

Bad management practices also need to be eliminated, Unison says.

The Cabinet Office thinks the civil service reform programme, launched in 1999, is helping. A spokeswoman says: 'There may be issues of motivation and stress in the public sector due to the pace of change. But our own research indicates we are investing in the right kind of personnel policies such as a family friendly environment and training.'

But Oswald is not convinced that anything is about to change. He says: 'We expect these trends to continue. I think this is very serious for Britain.'

Other findings of the research were that job satisfaction was u-shaped in age, with initial contentment at work during teenage years disappearing by the age of 25. Job satisfaction was discovered to be lowest when people were in their 20s and 30s and highest among staff in their 50s and 60s.

Oswald explains: 'It is a process of adaptation. Young people just finishing university have very high expectations then they go through a very painful period which involves coming to terms with their limitations. Once they have gone through this they are happy in their work again.' This pattern is true for all types of occupations and among all nationalities. 'It is something very deep in human nature,' Oswald says. 'It is nothing to do with balancing work and home commitments as some people have reported.'

The theory also explains why Britons with university degrees report the lowest levels of satisfaction at work. Workers with no qualifications are the happiest, the study found.

Job satisfaction was found to be higher among women than among men, lower among blacks than whites, slightly lower in union workplaces than non-union ones, high in small workplaces, and highest of all in not-for-profit organisations.

Women were more satisfied no matter where they came from. Oswald says two theories have been proposed to explain this. One is that women have low expectations and are more pleased with any level of achievement. The second is that they knuckle down more than men - they throw themselves into work rather than worry about external factors such as hierarchy and advancing their own status.

So be nice next time you have to deal with a man working in the public sector.

fields.headline: Media monitor
fields.trailText: Pity the poor souls who are the spin doctors for the Liberal Democrats.
fields.body:
Pity the poor souls who are the spin doctors for the Liberal Democrats. It's a thankless task at the best of times, and these times are anything but the best. The party is making little impact in the national media and its leader, Charles Kennedy, is the object of much muttering. The third party has always been squeezed in broadcast outlets, where its 20-second soundbite is deemed expendable. Sometimes this gets too much, as was the case one Friday earlier this month. Kennedy was in Dumfries, arguing the point that Scotland is coping better with foot and mouth than England because a) it has an efficient ministry for rural affairs, as opposed to the discredited Maff in London, and b) the minister in charge is a Lib Dem. That same day, the prime minister also happened to be out and about, pushing tourism. That was the tone set for the bulletins, and the BBC 10 O'Clock News chose not to carry a Kennedy clip in its piece.

That led David Walter, head of communications for the Liberal Democrats, to phone TV Centre to complain. Walter, as kindly a man as you are likely to meet in politics and a longtime BBC hand, knows he can't "do a Campbell or Mandelson". Lib Dem complaints tend to be more in sorrow than anger, although I can testify to one occasion when Paddy Ashdown didn't take to a piece I had done during his 1998 party conference. He stormed into the BBC's Brighton newsroom to bawl me out, with a rather embarrassed Walter in tow.

Now their problem is not that their leader is going over the top, but that he is not raising his head above the parapet. Criticism in the papers this month of Kennedy's laid-back style is testing the nerves. Tony Howard in the Times questioned the strategy in the face of Tory challenges in several marginals; Geoffrey Wheatcroft in the Guardian warned of the dangers of cosying up to Labour; and in last Tuesday's Telegraph unnamed Labour strategists were quoted as saying the "soft on Labour" approach was a gift to William Hague. This piece particularly annoyed those at headquarters in Cowley Street. Two ripostes have been generally deployed. The first is that it also took Ashdown a long time to establish himself as leader; the other is that voters like an ordinary bloke in charge.

Now they have found two more - Kennedy is spending most of his time in the marginals and is making more impact in the regional media than the national or, as one adviser put it in Ashdownian tones, "He's doing well in the ground war, but we're getting sniped at in the air war"; and the Lib Dems have always had a higher profile once campaigns are under way.

Certainly, in the three weeks from mid-May, the Lib Dems will be seen and heard. The broadcast formula remains the same this time - 5:5:4. Over a given week, they must get approximately four-fourteenths of the clips in each radio and TV programme. In Scotland and Wales it is 4:4:4:4, parity between them, Labour, Tories and either SNP or Plaid Cymru. In the meantime Walter and his small team of 10 - with no rebuttal unit to speak of, and only a small war room - will have to return enemy fire as best they can in defence of the "ordinary bloke" in command.

webTitle: Are you satisfied with your job?

fields.headline: Are you satisfied with your job?
fields.standfirst: Check your stress levels by answering these 12 questions. Each question must be answered on a scale of 0 to 3 with 0 indicating the highest level of well-being and 3 the lowest.
fields.trailText: Find out if you're too stressed by your job.
fields.body:
Have you recently . . .

1. Been able to concentrate on whatever you are doing?

2. Lost much sleep over worry?

3. Felt that you were playing a useful part in things?

4. Felt capable about making a decision about things?

5. Felt constantly under strain?

6. Felt you couldn't overcome your difficulties?

7. Been able to enjoy your normal day-to-day activities?

8. Been able to face up to problems?

9. Been feeling unhappy or depressed?

10. Been losing confidence in yourself?

11. Been thinking of yourself as a worthless person?

12. Been feeling reasonably happy, all things considered?

A score of 10-12 indicates you are normal; worry if it's up in the high 20s or more. Scores can vary daily.

Source: Warwick University, department of economics

webTitle: Gary Younge on the London Underground

fields.headline: Human traffic
fields.standfirst:
The creaking, crowded London Underground has become a byword for underinvestment and political inaction. Can it be fixed? As the city braces itself for another strike and a courtroom showdown over the tube's future, Gary Younge investigates

Special report: transport in Britain
Special report: Livingstone's London
Talk about it
fields.trailText: The creaking, crowded London Underground has become a byword for underinvestment and political inaction. Can it be fixed? As the city braces itself for another strike and a courtroom showdown over the tube's future, Gary Younge investigates.
fields.body:
Early in the morning, late in the shift, platform three. It is 8:30am at Victoria. The busiest time, on the busiest platform, in the busiest station on the London Underground. Chris Boyce sits in front of eight monitors and the station concourse, guiding the human traffic like a conductor before an enormous and unruly orchestra. The cleaning service has been contracted out, and only one of the three cleaners who should be there has turned up. Oxford Circus is closed due to a security alert and the Central Line is not functioning between Marble Arch and Liverpool Street. And the number of passengers on platform three is getting perilously close to unsafe.

The tube is in trouble. Not just this morning but every morning. The capital's most vital artery is both clogged by passengers and starved of the oxygen of investment. "The most important thing about the evolution of the subway as a symbol," writes Michael Brooks in Subway City, "is that it starts by expressing faith in the city's future and, once built, quickly becomes a handy rhetorical tool for expressing discontent with its present."

There are few places where this is truer than London. On its opening day, in 1863, "the crowd at the Farringdon Street station was as great as at the doors of a theatre on the first night of some popular performer", according to one observer. A few years later, Henry Mayhew overheard one workman say: "Just think of what these here trains save you at night after your work's over. If a man gets home tired after his day's labour he is inclined to be quarrelsome." While if he gets a ride home, and has a good rest "he is as pleasant a fellow again over his supper".

Today, as it ferries 1bn passengers around the capital every year, the tube is as liable to make a commuter quarrelsome as his work. It is a byword for underinvestment, overpopulation, industrial strife and political squabbling. In June, Ken Livingstone, the London mayor, will take the government to court over its plans to privately finance the underground. Next month, on May 3, on the day Tony Blair planned to call the election, tube workers will strike over safety and job security. The last time there was an industrial action, just over a month ago, the capital became one huge car park; paralysed as traffic that normally dawdles simply stood still. Journeys that would usually take 20 minutes were lasting two hours or more.

During his mayoral campaign, Livingstone once said that he would wake up in the middle of the night thinking of how the tube might be better run. It was a testament to his commitment to the city. Whatever you thought about his views on Irish politics or global capitalism, here was a man who was dedicated to London. And there was no greater, costlier or more cumbersome signifier for the city than the tube. At one stage, the battle for the mayor became a referendum on how the underground should be funded. But what started as a local transport matter has grown into a national issue - the first serious test both to the limits and possibilities of devolution and to Blair's Third Way. Commuters are also voters and none of the three main parties came close to Livingstone, who made his plans for the underground the centrepiece of his campaign. More than a dozen of Labour's most marginal seats are in constituencies where people often use the tube. Now Livingstone is not the only one for whom the tube is giving sleepless nights.

Back at platform three, Boyce is tackling a familiar problem. The Victoria Line northbound is a focal point for commuters from Sussex and suburban Kent who are on the way to the centre of town. Commuters, by their nature, are creatures of habit. They get to the station, come down the escalators, and wait for the train at the spot which will drop them at the most convenient place at the other end. Unfortunately, for all concerned, this means there is a huge bottleneck at one end of the platform. The other end, as the adjacent monitor indicates, is completely empty.

But as each individual ignores the request to move up the platform, the collective result is that a dangerous mass of bodies is crammed into one place. To avoid an accident the station assistants stop letting people through the barriers. Now there is a bottleneck in the concourse. Anxious people in three-quarter-length coats are fuming. The concourse fills up. Back at the platform the trains keep coming, but it will take several more before it is safe to let more people down. Meanwhile, the concourse fills up.

Boyce orders the entrance to the station to be closed off. "You don't like having to do it, particularly in winter when it's raining," he says. "But you have to for safety reasons. You can build the story backwards. It starts on the platform and ends up outside." With platform three clearing he gives the order to start letting them through again. "There's never a bottleneck for long. These people are late so they'll run down the escalator and it will all start again in 15 minutes," he says. On platform two, the westbound District and Circle Line, someone has pulled the passenger emergency chord. The signs that used to warn of a £100 fine for improper use have been removed now because of concern that people in genuine need might be deterred from signalling their distress because of the cost. A woman has fainted, and has been led off the train and assisted.

An abandoned duffel coat, masquerading as a potential security risk, has been found, kicked and cleared. It belonged to a tout - one of the men who try to sell tickets they have found to other passengers. "It's a shame he wasn't in it," says one of Boyce's colleagues. Back on platform three the bottlenecks have returned. Different faces etched with the same, time-starved angst held up by the same problem.

"I'll tell you the biggest change," says one manager who has worked on the tube for more than 30 years. "It's not so much the technology, although that is different. It's the people. They want to be everywhere yesterday. I don't ever remember people being in as much of a rush as they are nowadays. We have to provide the best service we can. But sometimes you want to say to them: 'It wasn't us who left the bag there.'"

Thanks to Britpop, Britart and Blair, in the latter part of the past decade London gained the adjective "swinging". For those who live there seething, straining or struggling would seem more appropriate. The pace of change is scarcely sustainable. London's population will grow 9.4% by 2021, far faster than anywhere else in the country. In 20 years there will be 7.71m in the capital - more than the current populations of Ireland, Latvia and Estonia combined, crammed into less than one hundredth of the space. "[London] is no longer simply the nation's capital, but now almost an international city-state," said a report by the Joseph Rowntree Foundation last year. Yet this massive and chaotic growth has, for the past 15 years, coincided with the absence of any democratic authority to develop or coordinate it. Since the abolition of the Greater London Council, London has literally been out of control. And one of the principal casualties has been the tube. On that much, probably, both Livingstone and the government can agree. Near Euston station a team of men staring at a wall full of grids are making sure the Victoria and Northern lines keep running smoothly. Sitting in a semi-circle monitoring traffic flows with the help of numbers and symbols the staff could be on the starship Enterprise. But the equipment they are using looks like it was rented from the Doctor Who archive of Jon Pertwee's era. "We are still working with 60s technology," says Peter Neal, services manager. "Everything you see around you where technology is concerned has been here since we started operating from this room. If you buy a car then you replace it every 10 years. At least. But train systems have to last for a lot longer."

The thorny issue is how to raise the money to set it right. The government favours a public-private partnership (PPP) whereby private companies operate the tunnels, tracks, signals and stations while the trains would remain in public control. Livingstone supports a fully publicly funded service, where the money is raised through bonds.

His overwhelming victory at the polls suggested that Livingstone had persuaded Londoners. With privatised railways fulfilling their political destiny as the poll tax on wheels, the Thatcherite orthodoxy that the private sector inevitably provides cheaper, better services than the state was in abeyance. But Livingstone could not convince the government. New Labour, it seemed, had attached itself to a dogma just as it was going out of fashion.

Livingstone vowed not to give up. He enlisted Bob Kiley, a former CIA agent, with an impressive reputation for turning around ailing underground infrastructures in America. He had done it in Boston during the 70s and then again in New York during the 80s. On paper, the socialist and the ex-spy made unlikely bedfellows. "I can't believe that I am trying to recruit a CIA agent," were Livingstone's first words to Kiley.

"Well, I find it hard to believe that I'm going to work for an unreconstructed Marxist," replied Kiley. The first tube ride Kiley took on his arrival saw him stuck in a tunnel on the Circle Line for 11 minutes. In practice their different world outlooks have caused problems. Livingstone supported the last strike. Kiley did not. "I told Ken that this strike was self-defeating," he said.

But the two things they did agree on was their support for public funding and opposition to PPP: "It has no basis in reality or common sense," says Kiley. Months of negotiations lead nowhere. If public opinion could have decided the outcome, Livingstone would have won. So skilful has his campaign been that the government has made the rare admission that even it has been outspun. "We took the view that through all the negotiations we would play a straight bat, not try and play to the gallery," said Prescott. "We are behind in the propaganda stakes but our argument is sound."

When months of negotiations collapsed and the government decided to push ahead with PPP, Livingstone decided to take it to court, claiming that the government had usurped his constitutional right to control transport policy and that its decisions will endanger lives. Mr Justice Sullivan said he was satisfied that the mayor's statutory powers were "novel, complex and untested in the courts" and that the issue was "of vital importance to Londoners generally".

Rattling around in the darkness, the promise of light in the cab of a tube driver is made long in advance. The next platform announces itself initially in a small shaft. Its growth is gradual, but little can prepare you for the glare of your arrival, where blank faces are waiting - a blur of people looking up from their books and newspapers. They have been waiting for you. Physical geography is meaningless here. You are travelling hundreds of miles a day and yet the city looks the same - long monotonous stretches of penumbra followed by short bursts of fluorescent yellow. Only through human geography can you map your way through time and place. Suits in the morning, tourists at lunchtime, schoolkids in the afternoon, impatient before 9am, rowdy after 9pm, blacker in the south and north, browner to the east. You are both in and out of control. Gliding through the city's underbelly, ferrying your human cargo to and from work, you are all-powerful. But on the Victoria Line at least, almost everything is operated electronically. With shifts lasting eight hours a day there is little to stimulate the mind. "Boredom is a big problem," says Jan Mowbray who works on the Victoria Line. "There's not much to do and it's dark all day. In the winter you leave home in the dark, work in the dark and then go home in the dark. In the summer it's really lovely and sunny outside and bloody dark in here. You can't win." And then she closes the doors and glides away. Through tunnels that offer occasional glimpses of light, but to which there is apparently no end.
fields.bodyText: Early in the morning, late in the shift, platform three. It is 8:30am at Victoria. The busiest time, on the busiest platform, in the busiest station on the London Underground. Chris Boyce sits in front of eight monitors and the station concourse, guiding the human traffic like a conductor before an enormous and unruly orchestra. The cleaning service has been contracted out, and only one of the three cleaners who should be there has turned up. Oxford Circus is closed due to a security alert and the Central Line is not functioning between Marble Arch and Liverpool Street. And the number of passengers on platform three is getting perilously close to unsafe. The tube is in trouble. Not just this morning but every morning. The capital's most vital artery is both clogged by passengers and starved of the oxygen of investment. "The most important thing about the evolution of the subway as a symbol," writes Michael Brooks in Subway City, "is that it starts by expressing faith in the city's future and, once built, quickly becomes a handy rhetorical tool for expressing discontent with its present." There are few places where this is truer than London. On its opening day, in 1863, "the crowd at the Farringdon Street station was as great as at the doors of a theatre on the first night of some popular performer", according to one observer. A few years later, Henry Mayhew overheard one workman say: "Just think of what these here trains save you at night after your work's over. If a man gets home tired after his day's labour he is inclined to be quarrelsome." While if he gets a ride home, and has a good rest "he is as pleasant a fellow again over his supper". Today, as it ferries 1bn passengers around the capital every year, the tube is as liable to make a commuter quarrelsome as his work. It is a byword for underinvestment, overpopulation, industrial strife and political squabbling. In June, Ken Livingstone, the London mayor, will take the government to court over its plans to privately finance the underground. Next month, on May 3, on the day Tony Blair planned to call the election, tube workers will strike over safety and job security. The last time there was an industrial action, just over a month ago, the capital became one huge car park; paralysed as traffic that normally dawdles simply stood still. Journeys that would usually take 20 minutes were lasting two hours or more. During his mayoral campaign, Livingstone once said that he would wake up in the middle of the night thinking of how the tube might be better run. It was a testament to his commitment to the city. Whatever you thought about his views on Irish politics or global capitalism, here was a man who was dedicated to London. And there was no greater, costlier or more cumbersome signifier for the city than the tube. At one stage, the battle for the mayor became a referendum on how the underground should be funded. But what started as a local transport matter has grown into a national issue - the first serious test both to the limits and possibilities of devolution and to Blair's Third Way. Commuters are also voters and none of the three main parties came close to Livingstone, who made his plans for the underground the centrepiece of his campaign. More than a dozen of Labour's most marginal seats are in constituencies where people often use the tube. Now Livingstone is not the only one for whom the tube is giving sleepless nights. Back at platform three, Boyce is tackling a familiar problem. The Victoria Line northbound is a focal point for commuters from Sussex and suburban Kent who are on the way to the centre of town. Commuters, by their nature, are creatures of habit. They get to the station, come down the escalators, and wait for the train at the spot which will drop them at the most convenient place at the other end. Unfortunately, for all concerned, this means there is a huge bottleneck at one end of the platform. The other end, as the adjacent monitor indicates, is completely empty. But as each individual ignores the request to move up the platform, the collective result is that a dangerous mass of bodies is crammed into one place. To avoid an accident the station assistants stop letting people through the barriers. Now there is a bottleneck in the concourse. Anxious people in three-quarter-length coats are fuming. The concourse fills up. Back at the platform the trains keep coming, but it will take several more before it is safe to let more people down. Meanwhile, the concourse fills up. Boyce orders the entrance to the station to be closed off. "You don't like having to do it, particularly in winter when it's raining," he says. "But you have to for safety reasons. You can build the story backwards. It starts on the platform and ends up outside." With platform three clearing he gives the order to start letting them through again. "There's never a bottleneck for long. These people are late so they'll run down the escalator and it will all start again in 15 minutes," he says. On platform two, the westbound District and Circle Line, someone has pulled the passenger emergency chord. The signs that used to warn of a £100 fine for improper use have been removed now because of concern that people in genuine need might be deterred from signalling their distress because of the cost. A woman has fainted, and has been led off the train and assisted. An abandoned duffel coat, masquerading as a potential security risk, has been found, kicked and cleared. It belonged to a tout - one of the men who try to sell tickets they have found to other passengers. "It's a shame he wasn't in it," says one of Boyce's colleagues. Back on platform three the bottlenecks have returned. Different faces etched with the same, time-starved angst held up by the same problem. "I'll tell you the biggest change," says one manager who has worked on the tube for more than 30 years. "It's not so much the technology, although that is different. It's the people. They want to be everywhere yesterday. I don't ever remember people being in as much of a rush as they are nowadays. We have to provide the best service we can. But sometimes you want to say to them: 'It wasn't us who left the bag there.'" Thanks to Britpop, Britart and Blair, in the latter part of the past decade London gained the adjective "swinging". For those who live there seething, straining or struggling would seem more appropriate. The pace of change is scarcely sustainable. London's population will grow 9.4% by 2021, far faster than anywhere else in the country. In 20 years there will be 7.71m in the capital - more than the current populations of Ireland, Latvia and Estonia combined, crammed into less than one hundredth of the space. "[London] is no longer simply the nation's capital, but now almost an international city-state," said a report by the Joseph Rowntree Foundation last year. Yet this massive and chaotic growth has, for the past 15 years, coincided with the absence of any democratic authority to develop or coordinate it. Since the abolition of the Greater London Council, London has literally been out of control. And one of the principal casualties has been the tube. On that much, probably, both Livingstone and the government can agree. Near Euston station a team of men staring at a wall full of grids are making sure the Victoria and Northern lines keep running smoothly. Sitting in a semi-circle monitoring traffic flows with the help of numbers and symbols the staff could be on the starship Enterprise. But the equipment they are using looks like it was rented from the Doctor Who archive of Jon Pertwee's era. "We are still working with 60s technology," says Peter Neal, services manager. "Everything you see around you where technology is concerned has been here since we started operating from this room. If you buy a car then you replace it every 10 years. At least. But train systems have to last for a lot longer." The thorny issue is how to raise the money to set it right. The government favours a public-private partnership (PPP) whereby private companies operate the tunnels, tracks, signals and stations while the trains would remain in public control. Livingstone supports a fully publicly funded service, where the money is raised through bonds. His overwhelming victory at the polls suggested that Livingstone had persuaded Londoners. With privatised railways fulfilling their political destiny as the poll tax on wheels, the Thatcherite orthodoxy that the private sector inevitably provides cheaper, better services than the state was in abeyance. But Livingstone could not convince the government. New Labour, it seemed, had attached itself to a dogma just as it was going out of fashion. Livingstone vowed not to give up. He enlisted Bob Kiley, a former CIA agent, with an impressive reputation for turning around ailing underground infrastructures in America. He had done it in Boston during the 70s and then again in New York during the 80s. On paper, the socialist and the ex-spy made unlikely bedfellows. "I can't believe that I am trying to recruit a CIA agent," were Livingstone's first words to Kiley. "Well, I find it hard to believe that I'm going to work for an unreconstructed Marxist," replied Kiley. The first tube ride Kiley took on his arrival saw him stuck in a tunnel on the Circle Line for 11 minutes. In practice their different world outlooks have caused problems. Livingstone supported the last strike. Kiley did not. "I told Ken that this strike was self-defeating," he said. But the two things they did agree on was their support for public funding and opposition to PPP: "It has no basis in reality or common sense," says Kiley. Months of negotiations lead nowhere. If public opinion could have decided the outcome, Livingstone would have won. So skilful has his campaign been that the government has made the rare admission that even it has been outspun. "We took the view that through all the negotiations we would play a straight bat, not try and play to the gallery," said Prescott. "We are behind in the propaganda stakes but our argument is sound." When months of negotiations collapsed and the government decided to push ahead with PPP, Livingstone decided to take it to court, claiming that the government had usurped his constitutional right to control transport policy and that its decisions will endanger lives. Mr Justice Sullivan said he was satisfied that the mayor's statutory powers were "novel, complex and untested in the courts" and that the issue was "of vital importance to Londoners generally". Rattling around in the darkness, the promise of light in the cab of a tube driver is made long in advance. The next platform announces itself initially in a small shaft. Its growth is gradual, but little can prepare you for the glare of your arrival, where blank faces are waiting - a blur of people looking up from their books and newspapers. They have been waiting for you. Physical geography is meaningless here. You are travelling hundreds of miles a day and yet the city looks the same - long monotonous stretches of penumbra followed by short bursts of fluorescent yellow. Only through human geography can you map your way through time and place. Suits in the morning, tourists at lunchtime, schoolkids in the afternoon, impatient before 9am, rowdy after 9pm, blacker in the south and north, browner to the east. You are both in and out of control. Gliding through the city's underbelly, ferrying your human cargo to and from work, you are all-powerful. But on the Victoria Line at least, almost everything is operated electronically. With shifts lasting eight hours a day there is little to stimulate the mind. "Boredom is a big problem," says Jan Mowbray who works on the Victoria Line. "There's not much to do and it's dark all day. In the winter you leave home in the dark, work in the dark and then go home in the dark. In the summer it's really lovely and sunny outside and bloody dark in here. You can't win." And then she closes the doors and glides away. Through tunnels that offer occasional glimpses of light, but to which there is apparently no end.

fields.headline: Stolz und Vorurteil
fields.standfirst: ,,I'm proud to be a German"  these words recently by a German politician have launched a debate throughout the country. In view of the past, is it dangerous to admit that one loves living in Germany? Nicole Prestle asks young people their opinions.
fields.trailText: ,,I'm proud to be a German"  these words recently by a German politician have launched a debate throughout the country. In view of the past, is it dangerous to admit that one loves living in Germany? Nicole Prestle asks young people their opinions.
fields.body:
Hand aufs Herz. Wo immer in Amerika die Nationalhymne erklingt, erhebt sich das Volk von den Plätzen und singt mit. ,,Wir gehören zusammen", soll es bedeuten. ,,Wir sind stolz darauf, Amerikaner zu sein." Auch andere Nationen kennen dieses Gefühl. Kennen, akzeptieren und schätzen es. Anders Deutschland. ,,Ich bin stolz, ein Deutscher zu sein"", hat vor kurzem ein Politiker betont und wurde gleich darauf von einem Minister der anderen Partei angegriffen, der ihm die ,,Mentalität eines Skinheads" bescheinigte.

Die Begeisterung für das eigene Land, für die eigene Nationalität - in Deutschland hat sie aufgrund der Vergangenheit oft einen schalen Beigeschmack. Schnell erinnert man sich an das, was sich im Zweiten Weltkrieg abspielte. Schnell spielt man den eigenen Stolz herunter, um nicht als ausländerfeindlich zu gelten.

Kann man stolz darauf sein, Deutscher zu sein? Oder müssen die Deutschen mit dieser Überzeugung vorsichtiger sein, als alle anderen Nationen? Wir haben uns bei jungen Menschen erkundigt.

Bist du stolz, Deutscher zu sein?

Alf (23) : Naja, ich kann ja eigentlich nichts dafür, wo ich geboren bin. Aber ich lebe schon sehr gerne in Deutschland. Ich bin auch der Meinung, dass man so etwas zugeben darf.

Petra (18) : Jeder fühlt sich seiner Heimat doch verbunden. Das ist ja auch in Ordnung so. Stolz auf Deutschland zu sein bedeutet ja nicht automatisch, alles gut zu heissen, was in diesem Land so passiert ist.

Alexandra (16) : Ich bin froh, hier zu leben. Ich akzeptiere aber auch alle anderen Nationen und kann mir auch vorstellen, mal für einige Zeit in einem anderen Land zu wohnen.

Ein Politiker wurde vor kurzem verbal von einem Kollegen attackiert, weil er betont hatte, stolz auf Deutschland zu sein...

Felix (17) : Schlimm genug, dass man das nicht mehr sagen darf, ohne gleich an den rechten Rand gerückt zu werden. Und dass sich dann auch noch Politiker solche Attacken an den Kopf werfen, halte ich für besonders schädlich.

Patrick (20) : Die Deutschen reiten viel zu sehr auf ihrer Vergangenheit herum. Wir können doch nicht ein Leben lang mit eingezogenem Kopf herumlaufen, weil einmal etwas Schlimmes bei uns passiert ist. Natürlich wird das nie jemand von uns vergessen, auch wir Jungen nicht. Aber ich denke, wir müssen uns wieder normal äu§ern können, ohne sofort mit der Vergangenheit konfrontiert zu werden.

Wie ist das Bild der Deutschen eurer Meinung nach im Ausland?

Petra: Ich war vor einigen Jahren im Schüleraustausch in Amerika und wurde gefragt, ob wir immer noch das Problem mit Hitler und den Juden haben. Ich war, ehrlich gesagt, geschockt und wusste nicht, wie ich diese Frage verstehen soll. Als Provokation oder als Unwissenheit...

Patrick: Die meisten Nationen wissen schon, was die Deutschen im wissenschaftlichen und künstlerischen Bereich geleistet haben. Namen wie Goethe und Schiller sind doch überall bekannt. Auch sie waren Deutsche und werden heute in aller Welt zitiert. Ich glaube schon, dass man auf so etwas stolz sein kann.

Vor allem in den neuen Bundesländern ist die rechte Szene sehr aktiv, gibt es immer wieder Zwischenfälle zwischen Deutschen und Ausländern...

Alf: Erst kürzlich habe ich einen Bericht gesehen, der von der rechten Szene in Italien handelte. Dort huldigt man noch immer Mussolini und zieht mit ,,Ausländer-raus"-Parolen durch die Straßen. Das wird von der Weltpresse nur nicht so kritisch beobachtet wie das, was in Deutschland passiert. Und genau das ist die Wurzel des Problems: Uns Deutschen werden all diese Vorfälle mehr angelastet als anderen Völkern.

Felix: Ich denke nicht, dass es besser ist, was in Tschetschenien oder anderen Ländern geschieht. Genau genommen kämpfen doch viele Völker gegen andere Rassen, wir haben dieses Problem auf der ganzen Welt und müssen es auch überall lösen. Den Blick nur auf eine Nation zu lenken, halte ich für falsch.

Alexandra: Gerade die Deutschen haben aufgrund ihrer Vergangenheit gelernt, mit solchen Strömungen umzugehen. Ich denke, nirgendwo anders ist man so sehr darauf bedacht, den richtigen Umgang auch mit ausländischen Bürgern zu pflegen wie bei uns. Und ich wünsche mir, dass irgendwann kein Mensch mehr Angst davor haben muss, in einem anderen Land zu leben.

Glossar

jmd. angreifen to attack sb.

sich erheben to rise

geschockt sein to be shocked

Hand aufs Herz to be honest

etw. gut heißen to approve sth.
auf etw. herumreiten (coll.) to insist on sth., to say it again and again

huldigen to praise

jmd etwas an den Kopf werfen to attack sb. with words

schal stale

etw. schätzen to appreciate sth.

sich verbunden fühlen: to feel close to

zitieren to quote

zugeben to admit

webTitle: Bridget Jones hits number one in US

fields.headline: Bridget Jones hits number one in US
fields.trailText: Despite an "over-weight" leading lady, copious cigarette smoking and vast alcohol consumption, word of mouth and warm reviews have pushed Bridget Jones's Diary to the top of the American box office chart
fields.body:
Despite an "over-weight" leading lady, copious cigarette smoking and vast alcohol consumption, word of mouth and warm reviews have pushed Bridget Jones's Diary to the top of the American box office chart.

The Working Title film starring Renee Zellweger as the neurotic, 30-something singleton, opened at number three last weekend in the US (see earlier story) but during it's second week of release, took an estimated $10.5m, pushing the family-friendly Spy Kids starring Antonio Banderes from the number one slot. The film, which also stars Hugh Grant and Colin Firth, has now taken an estimated $25.6m. According to research into US cinema-going habits, it seems that American women are so enamoured with the adaptation of the Helen Fielding book they are making return trips to see the film with girlfriends and even men in tow.

Meanwhile, there was less joy for Paul Hogan's return as the native outbacker from Down Under in the much-hyped Crocodile Dundee In Los Angeles. The first 'croc' film in 13 years, only managed to take an estimated $8m, slipping into fourth place behind Spy Kids and the Morgan Freeman thriller Along Came A Spider. Freddy Got Fingered, comedian Tom Green's gross-out comedy, opened in the number five slot, taking a disappointing $7.2m.

In Britain, the Bridget bandwagon continues to be hugely successfully. The film has taken an estimated $22m (£15m) in the 10 days since it opened.

fields.headline: 'Rogue Male' bags Bafta
fields.trailText:
11am: A director at the centre of a TV documentary fakery row three years ago picked up a Bafta award last night, writes Jason Deans.
Full list of winners: Bafta website
fields.body:
A director who was at the centre of a television documentary fakery row three years ago picked up a Bafta award last night for his latest work, a drama.

Channel 4 was forced into a public apology in 1998 after the Mirror revealed that scenes in Dominic Savage's Cutting Edge documentary, Rogue Males, were faked.

But last night at the 2001 Bafta Television Craft Awards Mr Savage completed his rehabilitation by picking up the prize for best new director of fiction for the BBC2 drama, Nice Girl.

He beat off competition from Caroline Aherne, nominated for her work on the Royle Family, and Chris Morris, for Jam.

Ms Aherne, who recently revealed she would be concentrating on behind-the-camera work to avoid the paparazzi attention that goes with acting, did not attend the awards ceremony.

Nice Girl told the story of a pregnant Welsh teenager whose husband leaves her for her sister.

Mr Savage developed an improvised script after interviewing 40 people who had been through similar experiences.

The programme was co-funded by the BBC's drama and documentary departments and used a cast of relative unknowns.

Mr Savage first hit the headlines in February 1998 when Rogue Males was exposed after faking scenes involving cowboy builders, carpet fitters and aggrieved customers.

The Channel 4 drama, Longitude, was the other big winner at last night's Bafta ceremony, picking up three craft awards.

The Granada Television production triumphed in the production design category, original TV music and photography and lighting for a fiction or entertainment show

BBC2 picked up seven of the 14 Bafta craft awards, including Mr Savage's prize.

Winners from the channel included League of Gentlemen for best costume design; Sarah MacDonald, who won best new director of factual for her work on the Newsnight child abuse special, A Family Affair; and Ed McCardie, who won the new writer's award for Tinsel Town.

fields.headline: Arts and Humanities Research Board
fields.trailText:
Funding body
Arts and Humanities Research Board (AHRB)
fields.body:
Funding body
Arts and Humanities Research Board (AHRB)

People to know
Chief Executive: Professor David Eastwood (Professor Geoffrey Crossick takes over in September)
Chairman: Professor Sir Brian Follett
Director of Corporate Communications: Angela Murphy
Director of Programmes: Dr Michael Jubb
Director of Corporate Affairs: Frances Marsden
Head of Research Division: Yvonne Hawkins
Head of Postgraduate Awards: Vijay Chandy

Click here for information on peer review panels.

Aims
Supporting highly rated research in the arts and the humanities; improving the understanding of human culture to enhance "the quality of life and creative output of the nation"; supplying the next generation of scholars as well as graduates entering a wide range of professions; publicising the results of research both to researchers and the wider public.

Background
Established in 1998 by the British Academy, the Department of Education for Northern Ireland, and the English, Welsh and Scottish funding councils, the board emerged after a long campaign by the arts and humanities community to create a national arts and humanities funding body - a research council in all but name for research outside the sciences. From April 2001, the AHRB becomes a legally independent organisation, seen as another step nearer to the ultimate goal of becoming a fully fledged arts and humanities research council.

Key challenges are to improve the standing and recognition of academic research in the arts, and oversee the broad and sometimes disparate community of academics in the humanities. But with a budget of £19m a year, the board distributes a tiny proportion of funds to the academic sector compared with the six government science research councils.

Future issues and priorities
On April 1 the AHRB will take the next step towards becoming an Arts and Humanities Research Council, becoming legally independent of their funding bodies under their new title of AHRB Co. This will give them the advantage of proper legal status. Chief Executive Professor David Eastwood believes this will allow them to "be established as an independent company, with charitable status, and a firm organisational footing."

HEFCE will be increasing its grant to the AHRB significantly (how much?) over the next three years, which will help to reduce the huge discrepancy between the number of applications and the few projects the board can currently afford to fund. Last year, for example, 145 researchers applied for the research centre scheme, but there was only enough money to support 10 proposals. Also, only 17% of applications to scheme were successful.

Advanced research programme
Research grants

Deadline: Next closing date: 30th November 2001.
For more information, click here.

Research leave
Purpose: To relieve staff of teaching and administrative responsibilities in order to bring a research project to completion and publication or other public output.
Funding: To meet the full salary costs of the applicant for a period of three or four months. The period of leave funded by the Board must be matched by a preceding period funded by the employing institution.
Success rate: In 1999-2000, 390 people applied for research leave - 189 of them were successful.
Deadline: Next closing date: 31 October 2001 Research leave details

Small grants in the creative and performing arts
Purpose of scheme: To meet the costs directly related to advanced projects in the arts only, including such items as travel, maintenance and consumables. This scheme will now support replacement teaching for short periods. For small grants in the humanities, see the British Academy sponsor profile.
Funding: Awards of up to £5,000.
Success rate: In 1999-2000, 147 people applied for small grants. A hundred and two were accepted.
Deadline: Next closing dates: 30 April 2001, 31 October 2001 and 31 January 2002.
Small grant details

Fellowships in the creative and performing arts
Purpose of scheme: To support researchers who wish to pursue a sustained programme of high quality research in the creative and performing arts.
Funding: Flat-rate grant of £17,500 per annum, for three years.
Success rate: In 1999-2000, 90 people applied for the 32 awards.
Deadline: Next closing date: Not known as yet - probably July 2001.
Research Fellowship details

Research exchanges
Purpose of scheme: To facilitate collaboration between academic researchers and those who work in libraries, archives, museums, theatres, studios and other similar environments.
Funding: Flat-rate grant of £3,500 per month, for three or four months.
Success rate: In 1999-2000, 28 people applied and 20 were successful.
Deadline: Next closing date: 30 November 2001.
Research exchange details

Research centres
Purpose of scheme: To help to provide high quality research within AHRB centres that demonstrate areas of strategic importance by supporting groups of researchers in a range of activities beyond individual projects.
Funding: Research centres will be funded for five years, offering up to 80% of costs in the first and second years (maximum £250,000) and 40% in years three to five (maximum £125,000). The maximum grant of £875,000 will be offered over a five-year period.
Deadline: Next closing date: Scheduled for January 2002
Research centre details

Resource enhancement
Purpose of scheme: To promote access to and availability of high volume research resources; to support development of high level finding aids; to support enhanced, value-added access and the development of generic tools for exploitation of resources.
Funding: Under this scheme, grants of up to £100,000 a year are available for up to three years to meet the costs of projects to improve the utilisation and accessibility of research resources and materials of all kinds, or to develop the intellectual infrastructure of a specific area of study.
Deadline: Next closing date: scheduled for early 2002
Resource enhancement details

Types of postgraduate award
Postgraduate studentships in the humanities.
Studentships are divided into two types:

Competition A for one year or two year (full-time study) studentships, primarily for Masters degrees or for training in research. 1,701 applications were made in 1999-2000 and 454 awards were granted.

Competition B for studentships of up to three years of full-time or five years of part-time study for a doctorate. In 1999-2000 there were 1,837 applications and only 573 were successful.

Professional and vocational awards
These cover art and design, practice-based drama, interpreting and translating, film and TV studies, archive administration, archaeology and theology. 819 people applied for one of theses awards in 1999-2000 and 565 were successful.

Dependants' Allowance.
Young Dependants' Allowance.
Disabled Students' Allowance.

Purpose: To provide a single source of funding towards the core costs of stewardship for major collections for which HEIs are responsible, for the next five years.
Funding: 25 - 75% of current stewarding costs.
Deadline: February 16 2002.
