webTitle: A look in the Mirror: the wit and wisdom of Piers Morgan

fields.headline: A look in the Mirror: the wit and wisdom of Piers Morgan
fields.trailText: On the coverage he has received:
fields.body:
On the coverage he has received:

There's nothing more ridiculous than tabloid editors squealing about attacks in other papers - I would never dream of doing that other than to say that I think the Sun went way beyond the acceptable levels of dog eat dog.

The positive thing is I get to this stage and I can look public figures and celebrities in the eye and say I know how it feels. I look at Posh and say, "You've had it easy love, what about me?" Keith Vaz? Do me a favour mate, I've had two years of it. And it does make a difference, actually, to your bargaining point. They all feel quite sorry for me - "At least I'm not you."

It's been such an interesting experience to be on the receiving end because you see how bruising a lot of it can be. I've had all the doorsteps and all the stuff on a pretty ferocious level sometimes and it's been quite educational.

I've had a good kicking, it's carrying on. But we've got to the point now where we've got to fight back a bit and get on with what we're doing.

Cretinous actually means stunted growth and I've actually, I think, lost a quarter of an inch over the last year through worry and panic, so technically I am cretinous.

On David Yelland:

The thing about Yelland is that he's been calling me a cocky little chancer as if in some way I would find that a derogatory comment. I actually see that as an accolade because he is a boring little bean counter.

Mr Yelland is operating under a strange code where he clearly thinks that there will be no payback for what he's doing and I can assure him that I come from the Corleone school of editing which is that family business will be settled.

He hasn't done anything wrong. That's the trouble. The problem is if he gets a parking ticket he goes to confession.

Every time he splashes on me the sale goes down about 3%. It's personally quite upsetting that I don't sell papers - that Jordan can sell more papers than me is personally quite depressing.

I wouldn't be editor of the Sun if they paid me £1m a year.

I just refused to surrender the Arsenal shares. I would like to thank Yelland because actually I had to sell them all just before the market crashed so he probably did me a favour in the long run.

I'm not obsessed with the Sun, I'm obsessed with that idiot Yelland who's been writing about me for 490-odd days.

On his role model, Tom Cruise in Top Gun:

For a tabloid to be sharp and controversial and cutting edge, you've got to be right on the hard deck as they say in Top Gun. Unfortunately, as Maverick discovered, you occasionally drop below the hard deck when you shouldn't do and you catch your comeuppance and Goose, for want of a better phrase, is dead.

fields.headline: Today's media stories from the papers
fields.trailText: THE GUARDIAN
fields.body:
THE GUARDIAN

A new Tory advert on bogus asylum seekings has inflamed the race row eating up the Tory party. P1
ITV's overhaul of ONdigital will change the name to ITV Digital and elevate boss Stuart Prebble to chief executive of the ITV network. P2
As a BBC man accuses camera crews of endangering lives, does the media circus make disasters worse? P3
Official football club websites will soon introduce a missile tracing technology which transforms ordinary footage into 3D graphics. P11
Ebookers.com joins the London Stock Exchange today, its third listing after Frankfurt's Neuer Markt and Nasdaq. P21

MEDIA
Mirror editor Piers Morgan gives his first interview since the share-dealing scandal broke. P2
Peter Bazalgette of Endemol discovers TiVo. P4
David Abraham, co-founded of ad agency St Luke's, on why he has left one of the world's sexiest ad agencies. P4
Politics and media scrutiny - how the media's concern with ratings poses a real threat to democracy. P6
Commercial broadcasters are introducing "contracts with viewers" this week as a dry run for a new deregulated system backed by the communications white paper. P8
Why sometimes editors need to take a risk on contempt. P10

NEW MEDIA Simon Rogers of Guardian Unlimited looks at the web as a voyeuristic medium. P54
John Pluthero of Freeserve on what the future may hold for his company P54
Why consumer focus groups are a depressing sight for marketing departments. P56

THE FINANCIAL TIMES

Stuart Prebble heads for the top job at ITV. P28
What are the changes being considered for ONdigital? P28
Pearson has signed a strategic alliance with IBM to boost its home education credentials. P28

THE WALL STREET JOURNAL EUROPE

Viacom and News Corp are heading for a closer relationship. P4
Rupert Murdoch will today personally present his bid to General Motors to gain control of Hughes Electronics, the No1 US satellite broadcaster. P4
Sports webcast site Quokka Sports will close this week. P28
Outdoor specialist JC Decaux is finding new competition from American players coming to Europe. P28

THE INDEPENDENT

Newspaper cartoonist Bernard Venables died yesterday, aged 94. P5
Caroline Aherne misses out on a Bafta for best new director. P7
Bridget Jones's Diary makes it to the top of the US box office. P7
Granada and Carlton will unveil the biggest shake-up in commercial TV this week. P15

DAILY TELEGRAPH

ITV companies will this week shake up the network by rebranding ONdigital. P23

THE TIMES

British TV shows have more nominations than ever at this year's Montreux TV festival. P9
Granada and Carlton are aligning their pay TV and internet interests under the ITV banner and handing control to Stuart Prebble. P21

DAILY MAIL

Is TV commentator Lucinda Green really too posh for the BBC? P11
The Queen joined Sophie Wessex for dinner last night. P23
BBC sport boss Peter Salmon is to wed his lover Sarah Lancashire. P24
How Anne Robinson's country cottage became a £2m mansion. P27

DAILY EXPRESS

Celebrity Big Brother's Claire Sweeney has landed a dream role in hit West End musical Chicago. P3
BBC2 scooped half of the Bafta craft awards last night. P17
Complaints about tasteless and indecent adverts have tripled over the past decade. P18
Ralf Little on why living with Lisa Rogers is his greatest achievement. P29

THE SUN

Jack Straw has praised the second winner of Who Wants to be a Millionaire? after he guessed his real first name correctly Ð only the piece fails to mention what it is. P8
Anne Robinson has turned a cottage into a £2m mansion. P17
The bloke from the Diet Coke advert has been axed in favour of three Bridget Jones lookalikes. P21

THE MIRROR

Tony Parsons says Dom Joly will never be the funniest man on TV because he uses too many old people (easy targets) in his sketches. P6
Matt Kelly tracks down Henry Hill, the ex-Mafia man on whom the film Goodfellas was based. P8
Eight million Twix bars have been destroyed after beetle grubs were found in a flour silo. P15
The Weakest Link was watched by 52.4m viewers in its first week in the US. P15

THE STAR

Chris Tarrant may quit Who Wants to be a Millionaire? after one more "good year" and wants a woman to take over from him. P13

AND FINALLY...

A sad tale from the Sun. "The Queen's corgi agony" - the death of Ma'am's favourite dog, 17-year-old Kelpie, ruined her 75th birthday. So there, it's official, the Queen does have a heart after all. P1

webTitle: Violence stops short of the summit

fields.headline: Violence stops short of the summit
fields.standfirst: The latest bout of conflict between police and anti-globalisation protesters, at the Summit of the Americas, was strangely restrained, writes Anne McIlroy
fields.trailText: Conflict between police and anti-globalisation protesters at the Summit of the Americas was strangely restrained, writes Anne McIlroy.
fields.body:
The Summit of the Americas ended yesterday in Quebec City, with 34 world leaders from North and South America promising that only democracies are welcome in the new hemispheric trade deal now being negotiated.

The controversial meeting, which the Canadian prime minister, Jean Chrétien, called a success, saw the leaders doing their best to appear to be responsive to the concerns raised by thousands of protesters.

Activists argued the potential trade deal undermines democratic principles and poses a threat to environmental protection and social programmes and denounced the leader's final communiqué as a sham.

That much was expected. But the summit also saw an evolution in the dance between protestors and police that has come to dominate international trade meetings since riots brought an end to World Trade Organisation talks in 1999 in Seattle. Both sides showed a little restraint.

Not that Quebec City was pretty. Police used tear gas, water cannon and rubber bullets to keep protesters at bay and more than 400 people were arrested. Human rights observers say police used excessive force in many of those cases. Some demonstrators broke windows, started fires and threw Molotov cocktails. But it could have been much worse.

Perhaps the most dramatic encounters between police and protesters happened on Friday afternoon, when about 200 demonstrators in black masks stormed the 10ft high security fence. The fence was supposed to keep a crowd of thousands away from negotiations of a new hemispheric free trade zone that would stretch from the Arctic to the tip of South America.

But it didn't stand in the way of the "Black Bloc", believed to be anarchists, who despite the concrete reinforcements knocked a section of the chain-link fence to the ground. Suddenly, there was a way in, but the majority of protesters, who had insisted that they had come in peace, hung back instead of surging through the opening and following the lead of the black-masked protesters who attacked the police with concrete and sawn off hockey sticks.

Most protesters made no attempt to get by the line of police. Violence at previous talks in Seattle and in Windsor, in Canada, left no doubt there would be violence again in Quebec City. There had been meetings in advance to discuss tactics and many protesters had thought about what they would do if they found themselves in an ugly situation.

Unlike in Seattle, the police in Quebec City also showed restraint, and for the most part were not caught on camera provoking protesters into violence. There was very little footage and few reports of protestors been tackled or bloodied by police during their arrests as there was in Seattle.

Instead, Canadians saw police largely defending the three-mile-long fence the Canadian government raised to protect the US president, George W Bush, and other leaders, rather than going on the attack. "We have a measured approach in dealing with these situations," said Royal Canadian mounted police spokesman Mike Gaudet.

The postmortem is yet to come, but the Summit of the Americas was not the disaster for police, protesters, property owners or the politicians that it could have been. But a new trade deal is still years away, 2005 at the earliest, and there will be many more meetings to come.

fields.headline: Politics under pressure
fields.standfirst: Serious media scrutiny of government policies is giving way to a more populist concern with scandals and personalities.  Steven Barnett  and  Ivor Gaber  believe that the media's increasing concern with ratings poses a real threat to democracy in Britain
fields.trailText: Steven Barnett and Ivor Gaber believe the media's increasing concern with ratings poses a real threat to democracy in Britain.
fields.body:
The day that Charlie Whelan was sacked as press secretary to chancellor Gordon Brown in January 1999 happened to coincide with the first day's trading of the euro. In comparison to the impact of launching a currency that was set to transform the economic and political landscape of Europe, the dismissal of a middle-ranking civil servant should have been small beer indeed.

Predictably, however, it was Whelan's departure that consumed political journalists in the press and on TV not just that day, but for several days. His tactics, his influence, his role in Peter Mandelson's resignation, and his impact on the relationship between the prime minister and the chancellor were scrutinised and dissected. Much the same has been apparent with the various "leaks" about Alastair Campbell's change of role in the next Blair government.

Some would hold up these episodes as examples of healthy political journalism. They argue that laying bare the mechanics of a government's publicity machine is exactly the kind of leading-edge reporting that enhances the media's democratic role and empowers ordinary voters by taking them behind the scenes.

We believe otherwise. The government's increasing expertise in controlling publicity - and the media's growing obsession with "exposing" the techniques and personalities involved - is displacing genuinely useful information about, and inves tigation into, real policies. Moreover, this is just one of a much broader series of problems which, taken together, is progressively undermining political journalism in Britain - and these downward pressures are almost irresistible and possibly irreversible.

The first of these pressures, inevitably, is the inexorable growth of the professional and centralised publicity machine run by the political parties. The techniques of media control are well known and hardly concealed by their practitioners. In his book The Unfinished Revolution, Blair's pollster Philip Gould wrote: "In a campaign you must always seek to gain and keep momentum, or it will pass immediately to your opponent. Gaining momentum means dominating the news agenda, entering the news cycle at the earliest possible time, and repeatedly re-entering it, with stories and initiatives that ensure that subsequent news coverage is set on your terms."

Nothing revolutionary there: both Margaret Thatcher's key media advisers - Tim Bell and Gordon Reece - made news control via the tabloid papers a primary goal.

What is new is the weight of effort, resources and professional personnel involved. Media are monitored, interviews on political programmes are ruthlessly controlled and government or party interviewees meticulously prepared. The skill of the spin doctor is not simply in putting the best gloss on government announcements (which is as old as politics itself), but in the array of tactics and subtle techniques used to deflect the bad news and promote the good throughout the burgeoning number of media outlets.

This applies to all governments. During the Major years, whenever a new chapter in the Charles and Diana saga was revealed, Downing Street would immediately phone all government press offices to suggest it would be a good time for them to release to a distracted media any awkward announcements they had been saving. More recently, when the News of the World revealed that Robin Cook was having an affair with his secretary, the BBC was offered two "smokescreen" stories: one involved MI6 allegedly investigating the former governor of Hong Kong, Chris Patten; the other suggested that the government might reprieve the royal yacht Britannia. Neither came to pass, but Cook's marital difficulties suddenly had competition on the nation's front pages and news bulletins.

The second pressure is the scale of today's media environment and the impact on budgets. Newspapers have to compete not just with each other, but with four 24-hour news TV channels, internet news sites, more radio stations than ever (not all devoted to music), and a plethora of Sunday lunchtime political slots. Media operations are being forced to cut costs as they struggle to carve out or hang on to a profitable share of the market. The impact is greatest on those areas in need of high investment and perceived as low interest - which makes political reporting the perfect victim.

Media organisations are placing far more emphasis on aspects of politics that will generate interest and thus increase ratings or readership. That means a greater premium on political tension, scandals, conflict and entertainment. The relentless concentration on personality clashes and rows about the minutiae of presentation does little credit to the vast array of political initiatives which deserve more thoughtful (and certainly critical) scrutiny.

Unfortunately, much of this is too dull to satisfy TV or newspaper editors struggling to beat myriad competitors into submission. In the words of Peter Riddell, formerly political editor of both the Times and the Financial Times: "While many broadsheets, if not tabloids, still carry plenty of space devoted to politics, the style has changed. An increasing number of stories are about scandal and misconduct rather than policy or procedure."

Then there are the pressures imposed by owners or institutions looking after their own self-interests or ideologies. Proprietorial intervention is scarcely new, and today's crop of newspaper owners is probably less intrusive than the Beaverbrooks and Northcliffes of an earlier age (although Murdoch can be a ruthless political intruder when it suits his purpose). On issues that matter to their owners, however, political journalists are no more liberated than their predecessors: positive stories on Europe or the euro will not be found in the Sun, the Times, the Mail or the Telegraph.

Today's proprietors are more likely to be looking for commercial advantage than were their predecessors, and increasingly in the age of corporate expansion this means looking to governments to remove obstacles to further profitability. Any unflattering political story that might get in the way is likely to be spiked. This applies particularly to broadcast journalism, where governments are increasingly inclined to update their media policies. As one broadcasting or communications act follows swiftly on the last, journalists come under pressure from bosses seeking to protect their organisations from interference or to further their corporate advantage.

Nearly seven years ago, after a career in commercial TV and before he had even been thought of as a BBC director-general, Greg Dyke warned in his first MacTaggart lecture of the threat of broadcasters continually seeking legislative favours from government. "It will take a very brave ITV broadcaster to make or broadcast a controversial programme about government," he said, "if by doing so it believes it is seriously threatening its chance of persuading the government to change a particular piece of legislation."

With frequent threats of privatisation, Channel 4 is also vulnerable. This "chilling" effect on hard-hitting, independent journalism is becoming integral to a highly commercialised system. What is true indirectly for commercial TV is true directly for the BBC. Despite the unstinting professionalism of individual journalists in news and current affairs, it is becoming increasingly difficult to mount the kind of painstaking investigations that make governments uncomfortable. This is partly because of diminishing resources, but also because of the inherent risk to the BBC's survival that rises with each new revelation or damning Panorama - especially at a time when publicly funded broadcasting is under permanent siege by commercial competitors. Journalists at the BBC are hardly craven, but self-censorship - what Michael Grade famously called its "pre-emptive cringe" - is inevitable in the face of such hostility.

Rigorous, independent political journalism is the lifeblood of democracy. When political reporters have the freedom to do their job properly, governments are not allowed to get away with autocratic, corrupt or irresponsible behaviour. Policy initiatives are scrutinised and their benefits and problems laid bare. Accurate and properly researched information is put before the electorate by independent arbiters who have nothing to gain by distorting the truth. Representatives are held to account in the glare of a media spotlight that can inform and enlighten millions of voters as well as exposing political humbug.

That is the ideal, but we believe that today's reality is different. There has always been competition in the press, there have always been meddling and self-interested owners, there have always been manipulative governments and a vulnerable BBC. Moreover, the story is not black and white: both Mandelson resignations owe much to the intensity of the media spotlight, and no amount of spin can disguise the burning carcasses across the country. But for a variety of technological, economic and political reasons, we believe that the pressures on providing a continuous diet of painstaking, interrogative, oppositional and informative political journalism have never been so intense nor so irresistible. Today's political reporters are probably better qualified and better equipped for their task than ever before, but they may be pursuing a lost cause.

fields.headline: Answering back
fields.standfirst: Right to Reply has been axed after more than 18 years on Channel 4, and Friday's programme was the last. Presenter Roger Bolton laments its passing
fields.trailText:
Right to Reply has been axed after more than 18 years on Channel 4, and Friday's programme was the last. Presenter Roger Bolton laments its passing.

20.04.2001: Channel 4 takes away Right to Reply
20.04.2001: 'Black day for viewers'
fields.body:
"Right to Reply is the viewer's chance to answer back. It is, in its way, the quintessential Channel 4 programme". That was the view of the broadcaster's first chief executive, Jeremy Isaacs. Now that the series has been axed, how are the channel's viewers going to answer back in future? And not just answer back but have the opportunity of arguing their case with the producers and executives responsible? It's not just regular Channel 4 viewers who are affected. There will now be no answer back programme on any terrestrial TV channel.

It has always staggered me that the publicly funded BBC has no such programme, which somewhat diminishes its claims to be fully accountable,although the willingness of BBC executives like Alan Yentob and Mark Thompson to appear on R2R was greatly appreciated by the programme makers at Horseferry Road.

So why has the series been cancelled? If they were tired of the presenter then he could have been changed. After all, I have done it for more than six years and wouldn't have complained much. Perhaps the audience figures had dropped dramatically? Not true either. They still hover around the million mark. Perhaps the channel has a fresh idea for a new accountability show? Not so.

Has the series become too much of a pain in the neck for those sensitive TV executives and producers who enjoy dishing it out but do not see why they should be answerable for what they do? I think that's unlikely because, while some executives in every broadcasting organisation I've worked for grumble about scoring "own goals" and think anybody who complains is a bit peculiar, support for the series at the top of the channel has been unwavering.

Perhaps new technological developments like online mean that the channel can be accountable in a different way? Well, it would certainly be different and not remotely as effective because, for a start, disagreements would not be argued out eye to eye in front of the public. Were I a broadcasting executive, however, I would much prefer to answer online , away from the glare of the lights and with my advisers clustered around the word processor. I doubt if the viewer would find it as satisfactory, however.

The only answer I can think of is that in the increasingly multichannel world the competition for ratings is such that only an handful of half hour slots (20) given to the viewer is too much even for a channel which claims a special relationship with its public.

In the absence of any viewers' programme anywhere on terrestrial television perhaps we should adapt that movie cliche and say "Broadcasting means never having to say you're sorry". There is now an accountability gap at Channel 4 and on British Television. It needs to be filled.

 Roger Bolton was the last presenter of Right to Reply.

fields.headline: 'I'm the last man standing'
fields.standfirst: While other internet bosses have fallen by the wayside, he remains in charge after overseeing his company's flotation and sale.  Amy Vickers  meets John Pluthero, the modest head of Freeserve to ask: where does he go from here?
fields.trailText: Amy Vickers meets John Pluthero, the modest head of Freeserve to ask: where does he go from here?
fields.body:
For most people, John Pluthero, the chief executive of Freeserve, has become something of a conundrum. He has tried his deftest to avoid the limelight, keeping as much out of the public eye as possible. He kept quiet all the way through the "Freeserve up for sale" speculation last year, sealed the deal and then subtly avoided the publicity frenzy that such events usually bring about.

His mugshot may have been in all the papers and his name bandied about in internet power-generation lists, but he has carefully kept his distance from the often rumbustious internet scene. Staff talk of his calm, temperate manner and his approachability. Asking around to find a few skeletons in the closet, all I managed to discover was that Pluthero was once a self-confessed MC Hammer fan. Someone had to be.

What is he like? "He's a good bloke, intense but thoughtful," responded one employee. "He has a youthful approach and is big on team bonding," said another. Freeserve workers seem respectful of him, but say it is sometimes quite difficult to pin him down as he only spends a few days a week in the London office. The rest of the time he is either at offices in Hertfordshire or Leeds, or jetting over to Paris to be with Wanadoo, who bought Freeserve for £1.6bn in November 2000.

Some staff have discovered the art of catching Pluthero: if in doubt look outside the building, as he can often be found pacing up and down at the front entrance, smoking a Silk Cut. For a journalist, however, it is not easy to pin him down. It took six months to get this interview off the ground and even now, after our chat, it is difficult to say just what exactly it is that presses his buttons.

Pluthero is very adept at keeping his professional and personal lives separate. He doesn't like to talk about himself, and admits that he is embarrassed about all the attention he gets. It has been two full years since Pluthero was made chief executive of Freeserve in time for its flotation, and he spent the two years before that building up the precocious internet business. In that time he has become something of a figurehead for the UK internet industry, but he laughs off his "minor celebrity" status.

"I've always tried to play it straight down the line. I'm perfectly comfortable with running the business side of things, but you have to accept that some of the [media] attention comes with the territory," he says. While he would now like to take a step back from the public eye, he acknowledges that it is part and parcel of the business. "When we did the deal with Wanadoo they told me that I could still be the figurehead in the UK, but I was actually looking forward to moving away from that, and moving out of the limelight for a while."

This last year has been the pinnacle of Pluthero's business career. After turning a year-old internet company into a stock-market success story, he then had to dilute Dixons' 80% shareholding in Freeserve by managing a sale before internet companies lost all their value. Last year, at just 37, he became one of the youngest ever FTSE100 chief executives.

Now 38, does he have anything left to prove? He reckons he does: "We're not Johnny-come-lately, get-rich-quick people. Freeserve was born out of Dixons as a subscription business, and personal pride means that I'm keen to see it through." To this end, he sees himself sticking around at Freeserve and hopes there are plenty more achievements up his sleeve. After all the departures of other big internet companies' bosses, "I'm kind of like the last man standing - and I rather like that," he grins.

"I said to Michel Bon [France Telecom's chairman] and Nicholas Dufourcq [Wanadoo's chief executive] when we were doing the deal that I loved my job and this company and it was up to them whether I stayed or not - and they kept me."

Four months on and Pluthero says things are just getting better and better. "It's almost treacly how well we get on and how easy it is. It's wonderful, it really is wonderful. We went through a time where we were being unbelievably nice to each other. I was thinking cracks would appear but they haven't to any material extent."

He insists it has been a very smooth transition period and, on a day-to-day working basis, not too much has changed. "We have very similar strategies and approaches to things. The important factor is that they not only know their markets, but they are very calm, authoritative grown-up businesspeople. It also helps that the executive board of France Telecom is very tight and that they all sing the same tune."

The party at the Natural History Museum to celebrate the deal has been given legendary status at Freeserve Towers. Pluthero says staff still talk about it and that it was the best party he has ever been to - not surprising given that it came at the end of a stressful year.

But what about Dixons? Pluthero says the relationship with Dixons has got much better. "It's more straightforward. We haven't got this other thing going on at the same time. We've taken a complex variable out of the equation. They've got a clear schedule on what they can do with their shareholding." He is convinced that Dixons, which holds a 12.5% stake in Wanadoo, will always maintain something of a shareholding in the French internet service provider, despite it recently cashing in £141m of its Wanadoo stake.

The reasons for this are twofold, explains Pluthero: firstly, it's an important part of Dixons' strategy to move away from a dependence on hardware profit margins and develop ongoing revenues as an important but smaller part of an internet company; secondly, Dixons needs a European strategy and a partner such as France Telecom gives it a strong ally in several European countries.

Pluthero comes across as a modest, unassuming man. He has a boyish grin and an infectious, mischievous laugh. He seems approachable, fun and, most of all, young at heart. He was born and raised in Colchester, where his father ran a pub, and came to London to study economics.

His contemporaries and bankers tend to admire him; most make an effort to get to know him, not simply because he has floated a nascent internet company and then sold it for £1.6bn, but because he has done it with such remarkable grace. He persevered with a deal after a buyout by T-Online collapsed, and maintained a cool "no comment" exterior when others would have used the press for back-stabbing and turning deals to their own advantage.

He admits it was a difficult period, and laughs when I suggest that he is glad a deal didn't happen with T-Online, which has since been rocked by boardroom upheavals. "Possibly," he says. "It was a tough time. But business is not measured by adversity, it's measured by achievement. You can't give up at the first hurdle. We had to get on with it, and it's self-evident we're at the right place now."

Pluthero once played rugby to county standard and says he used to be a huge sportsman. But not any more. He has a lower-back problem and doesn't have the time to maintain a golf handicap. Besides, he has an eight-year-old daughter to spend time with.

During the week, Pluthero still finds himself working late most nights, but insists he doesn't subscribe to 14-hour day working practices. "I've never liked the workaholic macho stuff. I've always thought that was really bad. My late nights are because I'm having [working] dinners and not in the office doing stuff."

His latest extracurricular activity is learning French, a group-wide initiative to save the faces of Freeserve staff when dealing with colleagues on the other side of the channel. It will also facilitate two-way staff traffic between the UK and Paris. Pluthero says he spends four hours a week learning French and plans to spend a month in France this summer to improve his conversational skills. He learns French while being driven by his chauffeur between Freeserve's three offices and says he is coming on in leaps and bounds. He certainly has the time when travelling - last year he did 33,000 business miles, and this year he finds himself jetting back and forth to Paris.

What is next on the agenda for Pluthero? One question people are now starting to ask is: will the Wanadoo brand eventually replace the Freeserve brand? Pluthero says it is something they are looking at this year, mainly because the combined companies have so many brands (including Viola, iCircle etc). "We've not taken any decisions on a rebrand yet, but we discussed the option of Freeserve becoming the no-ties subscription brand across Europe or possibly bringing Wanadoo as a brand to the UK. But we're not going to change brands lightly."

So it's full steam ahead for Freeserve and Pluthero. With French lessons, UK supremacy, cash in the bank and Europe on his mind, world domination is surely not far off.

fields.headline: Now we're in the pink
fields.standfirst: National newspaper circulations
fields.trailText: Roy Greenslade on the national newspaper circulation figures.
fields.body:
One statistic in the latest official circulation figures leaps from the page: the Financial Times has broken through the 500,000 barrier for the first time in its history. A decade ago it was selling 290,000 and seemed to have reached a plateau, rising just a little over the following five years to reach 308,000.

It was in the autumn of 1997, when editor Richard Lambert went off to New York to focus on the US edition, that the FT began to grow more rapidly. Sales in America were then running at 30,000. Last month it achieved 125,000, a rise of more than 300% in less than four years.

The FT's internationalisation strategy has begun to pay off in continental Europe, where its latest figure of 155,000 is 13% up over the past year, easily eclipsing the Wall Street Journal's European venture. Circulation has also risen sharply in Asia, helped by printing from two new sites in Korea and Malaysia, but it is still relatively low at 22,000.

In the UK, which accounts for just 39% of the FT's overall sale, its 197,000 average last month was down a little on 12 months ago, but this is probably due to the effects of the dot.com industry's burst bubble. Looking at the longer term, UK circulation has improved by 12% in the last five years.

Even so, only 158,000 FTs were sold at the full cover price last month and bulk sales were up to 35,000, a rise of 15,000 on March last year. Britain's competitive newspaper market remains the hardest to crack.

Despite the high cost of printing across the world, and a larger journalistic staff than any rival, the FT is highly profitable because of its strong hold on premium advertising. Lambert also believes that, despite having had its share of dot.com problems, it will achieve its pledge to its owners, Pearson, to make ft.com profitable by next year.

This month, the FT's sale will probably dip under 500,000 again for seasonal reasons - and, just possibly, because the weekday cover price rises by 5p today to 90p - but I would expect it to be back above the half million regularly by autumn.

At the other end of the market, the Daily Star continues to shine, selling more than 9% more than a year ago. Its stablemate, the Daily Express, boasted of reversing its decline but the non-bulk chart shows the truth: it is down almost 10% on a year ago.

The Sunday Express's rise was undoubtedly due to the addition of OK! magazine and increased promotion, the first major success for new owner Richard Desmond.

Incidentally, you will note a couple of changes to the chart: in order to make the figures consistent, the six-monthly averages now exclude bulks. I have also streamlined the list, using objective criteria to exclude some titles. In order to qualify for entry, a paper must be truly national (available for sale in England, Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland) and must sell at least 100,000 within the UK for a continuous six-month period.

Of course, when appropriate, I will refer to papers no longer in the chart, such as the Scotsman and Scotland on Sunday, and the two rising Sunday football titles, Sport First and the Non-League Paper. But the remaining 21 titles amply illuminate general newspaper- buying trends.

For chart see today's MediaGuardian.

fields.headline: Freeserve set to take on Europe
fields.standfirst: Interview with John Pluthero
fields.trailText:
9.45am: The Freeserve brand could be extended across Europe under plans being considered by owner France Telecom. By Amy Vickers.
Interview with John Pluthero
Post your questions for John Pluthero online
20.04.2001: Internet Magazine's top 50
fields.body:
The Freeserve brand could be extended across Europe under ambitious plans being considered by owner France Telecom.

The move would mean Freeserve becoming the company's no-ties subscription-free internet brand across Europe.

France Telecom is also considering introducing its French internet brand, Wanadoo, to the UK.

These are just two of the options being looked at by John Pluthero, the chief executive of Freeserve and Nicholas Dufourcq, chief executive of Wanadoo.

In an interview for MediaGuardian, Mr Pluthero talked about the issues facing them as they consolidate the two businesses.

"We're looking at how to rationalise and take the business forward," said Mr Pluthero.

"Freeserve has fantastic brand recognition in the UK. It actually stands for something, so we're not going to change brands lightly."

But he said they would be looking at options during the course of the year.

"We've discussed the option of Freeserve becoming the no ties subscription-free brand across Europe and the possibility of bringing Wanadoo as a brand to the UK," he said.

If brought to the UK, Wanadoo, a subscription internet service in France, would go head to head with AOL.

If promoted heavily by both Freeserve and Dixons, which holds a 12% stake in Wanadoo, it could give the US internet giant a run for its money.

Mr Pluthero was insistent that while they would look at branding issues this year, no decisions had yet been taken.

"There are lots of brands within the group - Viola, iCircle, Apres L'ecole, Wanadoo and Freeserve for instance - and we're looking at how to make the best of them," he added.

fields.headline: The break-up of Britain
fields.standfirst:
The shift of power away from London may make this election unexpectedly revolutionary

Full coverage of Election 2001
fields.trailText: Here is something you know already, or half-know, or haven't begun to get your head round yet. It concerns 72 MPs with nothing to do and 14 MPs who will soon be terminated, wiped from the face of the earth. No debate about "Britishness" (or indeed federal superstates) is complete without it.
fields.body:
Here is something you know already, or half-know, or haven't begun to get your head round yet. It concerns 72 MPs with nothing to do and 14 MPs who will soon be terminated, wiped from the face of the earth. No debate about "Britishness" (or indeed federal superstates) is complete without it.

Welcome to an increasingly foreign land, one with no election pending. In that land, the supreme political leader does many familiar things. He takes the rap for foot and mouth, he journeys to Washington plugging tourism, he preaches consensus and inclusivity. But his ministers pursue fascinatingly unfamiliar agendas. When GPs cut up rough, his health minister ponders "urgent action" to address crumbling morale. When teachers make waves, they win a 23% pay rise and a (count it!) 22.5-hour classroom week.

Welcome to the world of Henry McLeish, Susan Deacon and Jack McConnell. Welcome to Scotland. In a way, these past two years, Scotland has ceased to exist south of the border. It is up there somewhere, pursuing its own concerns. And in just the same way, from Berwick on, England has faded into the mists of public consciousness. What you see and read is what you get.

Take a brilliant new study* of creeping change called Open Scotland? by three academics at the Stirling Media Institute. They quote the political correspondent of the Scottish Sun: "I can't think of the last time that I spoke to an MP - they're just irrelevant," he says. They quote the political editor of BBC Scotland: "We have all these Scottish MPs and we never write, we never phone, we never make contact with them. They don't have anything to say." And here's the Scotland correspondent of Channel 4 News: "I just don't have the names of the UK cabinet at my fingertips the way I used to. I don't think anybody thought we would feel quite so disconnected so quickly."

When Scottish TV compared October 1998 (before devolution) and October 1999 on their main news programme, Scotland Today, they found that in 1998 they'd interviewed only Westminster MPs - but 12 months on, they'd talked only to MSPs. "So little now comes from Westminster," says the head of news and current affairs, "that we can concentrate on looking at Edinburgh."

There is (alas) no Preston Media Institute to look at the reverse side of the coin, but I think you'd find a parallel disconnection in London. When I dialled "American politics" into the database of a heavy broadsheet, I got 12,088 items; when I dialled "French politics" I got 10,058; "Scottish politics" trailed in third at 9,342 (with a sharp decline since 1999). Our London-based national papers may, for the most part, have put in extra editorial resources in Edinburgh, but much of that effort goes walkabout once the Scottish editions have finished. The two separate countries, in effect, are left to talk to themselves but not to each other.

Only the BBC struggles with overarching dialogue. How do you react to such a revolution? If you're Brian Wilson, secretary of state for Up There, you fulminate about journalistic standards and BBC competence. But if you're required to be a little more thoughtful about the human condition, you know that newspapers and broad casters follow the broad interests of their audiences and that the authors of Open Scotland? are right when they talk about "a quite fundamental shift in how Scotland is viewed as a polity within the UK. Processes of political communication that involve parliamentarians and government are now seen as largely situated north of the border."

So to an election campaign stuttering into reluctant life, orchestrated from Millbank and Smith Square, fuelled by speeches released in the smoke, covered by editors who live in the great arc between Hammersmith and Hampstead. What will it be about? Education? Off the Scottish map. Health? Likewise. Nick Brown's foot and Nick Brown's mouth? He is not responsible and the Scottish agriculture minister who is faces no vote. The future of Lib-Labbery? Brothers, it exists in Cardiff and Edinburgh and if it has no future there, then neither does devolved Labour governance. Europe? The three big parties in Scotland are all in favour. Immigration and the "preservation of our Anglo-Saxon identity"? Tell that to the Celts.

For the first time in our history, we're about to engage in a national election campaign where most of the big issues apply only scantily to semi-devolved Wales and barely at all to Northern Ireland and Scotland. Yet those 72 Scottish seats - due to come down to 58 next time, as the West Lothian question gets a half-hearted answer - are utterly vital. They are the difference between battered Blair and triumphant Tony. They are life and death for Hague and (probably) Charlie Kennedy.

Turn-out, we're repeatedly told, is crucial. But if I were voting in Dundee, not Dulwich, I'd feel a bit short of motivation on a chilly spring day. My chance to get a word in edgeways on schools or hospitals or crime or the law is two (fixed-term) yearsdistant. My bread and butter will have to wait. I can - as the Nats would have it - send a signal about independence to Westminster or Holyrood, but that's a pretty distant, second-hand business when the Nats' real test comes much later. I can keep Tony and Gordon in charge; but I maybe feel more nuanced than that, seeking a few bob from the Treasury along the way. Since nobody, now, is threatening to scrap devolution, I might even give the Tories a byelection-style punt. Vote for Malcolm Rifkind because he's not William Hague.

We have not, in sum, even begun to get our heads round the enormity of this shift. From our metropolitan fastnesses (where undesirable immigrants get Widdecombed at Calais) we assume that this is just another general election. We witter about a Britishness which does not - in any sense of a shared politics or perspective - exist as heretofore. We are in flux, but we have failed to notice it.

Yet the wheels are off this wagon. They came loose with Scottish university tuition fees and (after that three-year pay deal, with a 35-hour week and £35,000 for a classroom teacher) they are beginning to wobble into an English ditch. Are we separate or together? Do we know what true federalism is about? Fasten your seatbelts. This, as reality dawns, is going to be one hell of a ride.

 Open Scotland? by Philip Schlesinger, David Miller and William Dinan is published by Polygon at Edinburgh (£15.99).

And here's the Scotland correspondent of Channel 4 News: "I just don't have the names of the UK cabinet at my fingertips the way I used to. I don't think anybody thought we would feel quite so disconnected so quickly." When Scottish TV compared October 1998 (before devolution) and October 1999 on their main news programme, Scotland Today, they found that in 1998 they'd interviewed only Westminster MPs - but 12 months on, they'd talked only to MSPs. "So little now comes from Westminster," says the head of news and current affairs, "that we can concentrate on looking at Edinburgh." There is (alas) no Preston Media Institute to look at the reverse side of the coin, but I think you'd find a parallel disconnection in London. When I dialled "American politics" into the database of a heavy broadsheet, I got 12,088 items; when I dialled "French politics" I got 10,058; "Scottish politics" trailed in third at 9,342 (with a sharp decline since 1999). Our London-based national papers may, for the most part, have put in extra editorial resources in Edinburgh, but much of that effort goes walkabout once the Scottish editions have finished. The two separate countries, in effect, are left to talk to themselves but not to each other. Only the BBC struggles with overarching dialogue. How do you react to such a revolution? If you're Brian Wilson, secretary of state for Up There, you fulminate about journalistic standards and BBC competence. But if you're required to be a little more thoughtful about the human condition, you know that newspapers and broad casters follow the broad interests of their audiences and that the authors of Open Scotland? are right when they talk about "a quite fundamental shift in how Scotland is viewed as a polity within the UK. Processes of political communication that involve parliamentarians and government are now seen as largely situated north of the border." So to an election campaign stuttering into reluctant life, orchestrated from Millbank and Smith Square, fuelled by speeches released in the smoke, covered by editors who live in the great arc between Hammersmith and Hampstead. What will it be about? Education? Off the Scottish map. Health? Likewise. Nick Brown's foot and Nick Brown's mouth? He is not responsible and the Scottish agriculture minister who is faces no vote. The future of Lib-Labbery? Brothers, it exists in Cardiff and Edinburgh and if it has no future there, then neither does devolved Labour governance. Europe? The three big parties in Scotland are all in favour. Immigration and the "preservation of our Anglo-Saxon identity"? Tell that to the Celts. For the first time in our history, we're about to engage in a national election campaign where most of the big issues apply only scantily to semi-devolved Wales and barely at all to Northern Ireland and Scotland. Yet those 72 Scottish seats - due to come down to 58 next time, as the West Lothian question gets a half-hearted answer - are utterly vital. They are the difference between battered Blair and triumphant Tony. They are life and death for Hague and (probably) Charlie Kennedy. Turn-out, we're repeatedly told, is crucial. But if I were voting in Dundee, not Dulwich, I'd feel a bit short of motivation on a chilly spring day. My chance to get a word in edgeways on schools or hospitals or crime or the law is two (fixed-term) yearsdistant. My bread and butter will have to wait. I can - as the Nats would have it - send a signal about independence to Westminster or Holyrood, but that's a pretty distant, second-hand business when the Nats' real test comes much later. I can keep Tony and Gordon in charge; but I maybe feel more nuanced than that, seeking a few bob from the Treasury along the way. Since nobody, now, is threatening to scrap devolution, I might even give the Tories a byelection-style punt. Vote for Malcolm Rifkind because he's not William Hague. We have not, in sum, even begun to get our heads round the enormity of this shift. From our metropolitan fastnesses (where undesirable immigrants get Widdecombed at Calais) we assume that this is just another general election. We witter about a Britishness which does not - in any sense of a shared politics or perspective - exist as heretofore. We are in flux, but we have failed to notice it. Yet the wheels are off this wagon. They came loose with Scottish university tuition fees and (after that three-year pay deal, with a 35-hour week and £35,000 for a classroom teacher) they are beginning to wobble into an English ditch. Are we separate or together? Do we know what true federalism is about? Fasten your seatbelts. This, as reality dawns, is going to be one hell of a ride.  Open Scotland? by Philip Schlesinger, David Miller and William Dinan is published by Polygon at Edinburgh (£15.99). peter.preston@theguardian.com

webTitle: Roy Hattersley: Minds of the mandarins laid bare

fields.headline: Minds of the mandarins laid bare
fields.standfirst:
Read this book and you'll forgive Robin Cook everything

Special report: Whitehall
fields.trailText: A new volume in the Whitehall Histories series has just been published. I mean no offence to the contributors when I say that if their collected works were made into a Broadway musical, it is unlikely that a rave review of the first night would predict that it would run and run.
fields.body:
A new volume in the Whitehall Histories series has just been published. It is entitled Detente in Europe and it consists of selected "documents of British policy overseas for the period 1972-1976". I mean no offence to the contributors when I say that if their collected works were made into a Broadway musical, it is unlikely that a rave review of the first night would predict that it would run and run. Indeed many of the documents justify the foreboding provoked by the subtitle "volume III, series III". But it is well worth a couple of hours' examination. For it includes pages that reveal the working of the Foreign Office mind. Read them and you will forgive Robin Cook everything.

I confess that as soon as I tore my complimentary copy from its wrapping paper, I turned to the index of Detente in Europe to see if it included anything written by me. For most of the period under review I was minister of state at the Foreign and Commonwealth Office and I vaguely remember what MBFR stood for. I recall more vividly losing my mutual and balanced force reduction briefing notes before discussions in Washington with Henry Kissinger.

Whatever they may pretend, ministers of state have little independent authority. So, not surprisingly, ENS 2/20, FCO 30.7.74 began with the announcement that I was acting under instructions from the foreign secretary himself. My task was to recommend how he could build on his promise to the House of Commons "to look for opportunities to build a safer and more productive relationship with eastern Europe".

The paper concluded that British self-interest was "often best served by activity and a willingness to initiate movement rather than respond to the proposals and policies of others". For all I now know, my proposals were misconceived and inadequately supported by detailed evidence. Though I was relieved to discover when I had waded through my suggestions for reinvigorating the Conference on Security and Co-operation that the foreign secretary appended a note saying that he approved my general approach. The importance of the document - and diplomatic reaction to it - was not that Roy Hattersley and Jim Callaghan might have been right but that the Foreign Office refused to consider the possibility that it might have been wrong.

The officials' position was set out in a minute to my private secretary, dated June 4 1975 . It was written by Mr Julian Bullard, a considerable scholar as well as a distinguished diplomat and a man whose company I much enjoyed. He sought to squash me with a delicacy that did him credit. Officials, he said, "might have to consider how best to convey the point that there had been a certain continuity in British policy towards the east which transcended change of government in London. To work for new attitudes and initiatives may be an understandable emotion but it confuses the issue by asking officials to search their cupboards and minds for types of action which have never previously been thought to be in the British interest... Naturally these do not exist."

A further note adds that the criticism of the ministerial approach was made "openly" in a meeting. I remember the occasion well. It was one of the long, but for me rewarding, discussions that I hoped would end in acceptance of, if not agreement with, the ministerial wish to encourage detente. One document records that I had agreed to "drop from [the] paper three points which officials had previously contested". If my intention was to mollify the outraged diplomats, I failed. For long after Jim Callaghan had "accepted the line of approach" they still fought a rearguard action.

Their attitude is revealed in Julian Bullard's letter to Sir Thomas Garvey, the British ambassador to Moscow, who complained (with some justification) that ministers were examining a new approach to detente and he was not being told about it. Bullard reassured him. The status of the paper (the foreign secretary's endorsement notwithstanding) was still "ambiguous". It contained "quite a lot with which officials disagreed". Mr Callaghan had "never heard the counter-arguments". So Bullard was "not particularly anxious to give the paper the status of official policy". And there were Callaghan and I in our posh offices thinking that was a job for ministers. Anyway, "nothing could be done until the domestic situation (an impending general election) had been clarified".

Jim Callaghan became prime minister and I joined the cabinet. Not at all to my surprise, Tony Crosland, the new foreign secretary, pursued the same policy in a slightly less diplomatic way. Detente in Europe's last document sets out (in reported speech) a conversation in his office. "There's a strong anti-detente feeling on the opposition benches in the House," Crosland said. "Was it true that FCO officers do not share the Tories' view?" Nobody gave a straight answer.

webTitle: Comment: England may get its turn

fields.headline: England may get its turn
fields.standfirst: Full coverage of Election 2001
fields.trailText: Britishness, as Robin Cook, has noticed, will be a key issue at the general election. Conservatives will claim that Britain can be held together only if government remains concentrated at the centre. The left, by contrast, believes that national unity will be better secured through dispersing power.
fields.body:
Britishness, as Robin Cook, has noticed, will be a key issue at the general election. Conservatives will claim that Britain can be held together only if government remains concentrated at the centre. The left, by contrast, believes that national unity will be better secured through dispersing power.

The debate began very long ago. In his Midlothian campaign of 1879, Gladstone declared: "If we can make arrangements under which Ireland, Scotland, Wales, portions of England, can deal with questions of local and special interest to themselves more efficiently than parliament now can, that, I say, will be the attainment of a great national good." Tony Blair's first administration has gone far towards the attainment of this "great national good" by devolving power to Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland.

In last December's Queen's Speech, Mr Blair promised that his government would complete the Gladstonian project. The unfinished business of devolution, dealing with "portions of England" - the regions - may form an important part of the programme of constitutional reform in Labour's next term.

The growth of regional government in England has been one of the unnoticed developments of recent years. In 1994 the Conservatives established government offices for the regions, integrating the regional offices of four government departments with common boundaries. "For the first time," John Gummer, the Conservative environment secretary told the Commons, "there will be coterminous regions for the departments."

Labour has gone much further, by establishing regional development agencies and encouraging the formation of regional chambers. Regional government has now become a reality everywhere in England. But it is top-heavy and unaccountable, comprising in each region an outpost of the centre, a quango and a voluntary grouping of the indirectly elected and appointed. There are no directly elected regional bodies at all, making an integrated approach to regional issues virtually impossible. Yet one important leitmotif of the Blair administration is joined-up government, linking together the concerns of different departments on such matters as social exclusion and the fight against crime. Devolution to Scotland and Wales allows for an integrated approach and renders the intermediate tier of government accountable. In the regions, by contrast, the structure is fragmented.

The obstacles to regional devolution, however, appear formidable. In England, it seems, there is little of that sense of regional identity upon which devolution must be founded. In the recent British Social Attitudes survey, just 15% favoured regional devolution in England. For the English, the regions seem little more than ghosts.

Moreover, regional devolution would almost certainly involve a further reorganisation of local government. In Scotland, Wales and London, devolution was inserted above single-tier systems of local government. But there is a two-tier system in at least part of every English region. To introduce regional government above two local authority tiers would yield over-government with a vengeance.

These obstacles, however, are not insuperable. The key to reform is to recognise that the strength of regional feeling varies in different parts of the country. In the south-east it is virtually non-existent. In the north, by contrast, it is a genuine political force, fuelled by fears that devolution to Scotland and Wales will handicap the regions in the quest for inward investment and funds from Europe. It is hardly surprising, therefore, that English devolution is championed most powerfully by ministers such as John Prescott and Richard Caborn, whose roots lie in the north.

In the north, the two-tier structure of local government has already been broken up by the introduction of new unitary authorities. In the south of England, the natural unit seems to be the county; in the north, it is becoming the region, since the counties have become pock-marked with unitary authorities.

It is the internal diversity of England that constitutes both the problem and the opportunity for regional devolution. The problem is that it makes a uniform solution impossible: the opportunity is that of introducing devolution piecemeal, as and when particular regions seek it. Only through piecemeal and asymmetrical devolution can regional government in England become a reality, fulfilling the Gladstonian project more than 120 years after it was first formulated.

Vernon Bogdanor is professor of government, Oxford University, and author of Devolution in the United Kingdom, published by OUP.

webTitle: The new landscape of charity investment

fields.headline: The new landscape of charity investment
fields.standfirst: Charities with five or more staff have six months to sort out a pension scheme for employees and now is the time to establish an ethical investment policy, argues Clive Cutbill of specialist law firm Withers.
fields.trailText: Charities with five or more staff have six months to sort out a pension scheme for employees and now is the time to establish an ethical investment policy, argues Clive Cutbill of specialist law firm Withers.
fields.body:
Charities now have the opportunity to start with a clean sheet of paper and stipulate an ethical agenda. However, there are financial and legal issues to consider.

Ethical investment is popular amongst those with a social conscience. This will include many who support charities, either as donors or trustees, as well as those who work for them. But, while working to improve the planet, do you at the same time have to invest your pension in a way that may be having an adverse impact?

Some say that trust law causes a fundamental problem here. Trustees of charities have to consider what is in the best interests of their charity and exercise their powers accordingly.

However, the law recognises that whilst they are normally duty bound to invest for the best financial return consistent with prudence, there are some situations in which trustees of charities can properly allow other considerations to override immediate financial return.

For example, it is accepted that they should not make investments which would conflict with the aims of their charity, or which might cause recipients of aid to refuse it or cause donors to withhold funding as a result of their dislike for those investments. To do any of these things would be likely to undermine the work of the charity in a way which would outweigh any financial benefit.

In considering these issues, the charity does of course need to have regard to its own objects, not just general "charitable sentiment". The Church Commissioners, for example, believe that investing in shares in newspaper publishers is wrong given the purpose for which the commissioners are established.

This merely reflects the fact that trustees must consider "socially responsible investment" as they must consider any other issue affecting their powers: in the light of the purpose for which they hold the trust fund.

So what about charity pension schemes? Although trustees of a charity might reasonably avoid investments that conflict with the charity's objects or would hamper its work, its pension scheme assets are held to generate funds to pay pensions. The trustees of the pension scheme can no more sacrifice financial return in the interests of the charity than the trustees of the Mirror Group pension schemes could in the interests of Robert Maxwell and his companies.

Of course, trustees of a charity pension scheme might seek to justify avoiding "conflicting" investments on the basis that all the beneficiaries would disapprove of them: they work for the charity and therefore share its aims. But legally, this could be difficult, because the beneficiaries are not just the employees but will also include their spouses and dependants (who may either not share their views or be too young to have any views of their own).

One solution is, of course, to set up a pension scheme that expressly excludes "conflicting" investments; that would be fine because trustees must always take into account any restrictions contained in the trust deed.

However, if the scheme does not contain such a restriction, ultimately, the only real justifications for avoiding investments in the context of a pension scheme are likely to be either that to do so would have no financial impact on the scheme's performance, or that it would be financially better in the long term to avoid it - for example because the company's poor ethical performance might lead to its financial ruin in the long run.

These are the issues on which trustees and their advisers may have to concentrate if they, their supporters and employees are going to be able to feel entirely comfortable about the way their pension funds are invested.

 Clive Cutbill, Partner at Withers, a city law firm specialising in services to individuals, trustees and charities.

fields.headline: NatMags confirms CosmoGirl! launch
fields.trailText: 9.30am: NatMags has announced its Cosmopolitan spin-off, CosmoGirl!, will launch in September, reports Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
The National Magazine Company has ended speculation over its Cosmopolitan brand spin-off, CosmoGirl!, with the announcement that it will launch on September 20.

A question mark has hung over the magazine after its launch earlier this year.

But the company has now confirmed that the magazine will go ahead, and has announced the full editorial line-up under editor Celia Duncan.

Miranda Eason, the features editor of Sugar, will take the same job at the new magazine. Ms Eason has also worked on the launch of B magazine and spent time on Top of the Pops and 19.

James Williams becomes entertainment editor, looking after the hugely important celebrity dimension to the magazine. He joins from Top of the Pops, where he was assistant editor.

Navaz Batliwalla, a former stylist at the Sunday Times, Guardian, Cosmopolitan and Company, joins as fashion editor.

And Donna Hubbard joins from Company magazine as Beauty editor.

"I am thrilled that yet again Cosmopolitan continues to attract the best talent in the business - particularly when that talent is home-grown," said Cosmopolitan brand director Jan Adcock.

"The team will create a truly unique teen bible for Cosmopolitan girls everywhere."

Staff are breathing a sigh of relief that the magazine has been officially given the go-ahead.

Intense competition in the women's glossy market - compounded by circulation drops at the last ABCs - and a predicted downturn in the advertising market made NatMags take fright and put the magazine on ice.

Meanwhile Emap's plans for its own brand spin-off from its successful women's glossy, Elle, have also hit problems.

Emap says Elle Girl is still on target, but some insiders have raised doubts over its future.

webTitle: GP red tape protest may shut surgeries

fields.headline: GP red tape protest may shut surgeries
fields.trailText: Hundreds of GPs are planning to close their surgeries in a national day of protest against staff shortages and increased bureaucracy.
fields.body:
Hundreds of GPs are planning to close their surgeries in a national day of protest against staff shortages and increased bureaucracy.

The National Doctor Day protest on May 1 has been organised by Doctor magazine after a survey showed that eight out of 10 GPs would leave the NHS if they could.

Threatened action could include shutting surgeries, or just doing paperwork, or just seeing patients. Other GPs are planning to hand in undated resignation letters or to stage marches in London and other areas. The doctors say staff shortages and increased bureaucracy caused by government initiatives have left the profession overworked and demoralised.

Hundreds of GPs have written to Doctor magazine pledging support for the day of protest, which will coincide with anti-capitalist demonstrations expected in London and other cities.

Oliver Sykes, a GP in Otley, West Yorkshire, said doctors needed to become more militant. He added: "If we are going to do something then it should really be in the face of the government."

webTitle: Children in poverty: the issue explained

fields.headline: Children in poverty: the issue explained
fields.trailText: The government's stated aim of eradicating child poverty over the next 20 years is nothing if not ambitious. But toy libraries and "Billy Elliot-style" offerings aside - such as free music and dance lessons - what is it actually doing to achieve this goal?
fields.body:
The government's stated aim of eradicating child poverty over the next 20 years is nothing if not ambitious. But toy libraries and "Billy Elliot-style" offerings aside - such as free music and dance lessons - what is it actually doing to achieve this goal?

Most of the government's attention is focused on getting parents into work and targeting tax cuts and spending increases to those who need them most. With studies showing that most children in poverty come from no-income families, this is clearly a step in the right direction, but child welfare workers say it is only part of the solution.

To lift all children out of poverty in this way an estimated 1.5m jobs would have to be created for parents and child care facilities would have to be significantly boosted. The approach also depends on a continued fall in unemployment.

What's needed, they say, is more redistribution of wealth, more information, better services and a recognition of the link between poverty and social exclusion in general. As such, the government's Sure Start, Children's Fund and Connexions initiatives, which look at the health, educational, social and emotional development needs of poor children, have been welcomed.

The Sure Start scheme targets the under fours, focusing on their health and education. The idea behind the scheme is for local voluntary organisations and government bodies to brainstorm, decide what kinds of services they most need and apply for funding to set them up.

The services could include anything from more health visitors, to improve infant health and cut child mortality, to better child care facilities. By 2004 the government aims to have poured more than £1bn into 500 Sure Start schemes, providing support to one-third of the total or 400,000 disadvantaged children across England.

The Children's Fund, launched last year with a three-year budget of £70m, will work with national children's charities and local community organisations to identify and provide services to children and families at risk.

Meanwhile, Connexions, a personal adviser service to help 13- to 19-year-olds stay in education, will work on truancy and raising educational achievements. It will be coordinated with expanded services for vulnerable young people including mental health services, housing support and drug treatment. Five- to 13-year-olds, however, have not been forgotten, with the chancellor, Gordon Brown, promising nearly £400m in extra funding for programmes targeting that age group.

Althea Efunshile, head of the government's children and young people's unit, wants some of this money to be spent at the preventive stage, strengthening mainstream, existing services so children don't become at risk in the first place. Along with Paul Boateng, minister for young people, she wants to include young people in the consultation and decision making processes, inculcating a sense of citizenship at an early age and making them feel they have a stake in society.

fields.headline: Tory advert inflames race row
fields.trailText: Conservatives have been accused of playing on asylum fears after Tories in Kent placed an advert seeking to tap into local fears about 'bogus' asylum seekers. By Vikram Dodd, Lucy Ward and Tania Branigan.
fields.byline: Vikram Dodd, Lucy Ward and Tania Branigan
fields.body:
William Hague's efforts to neutralise the race row enveloping his party were dealt a blow last night after it emerged that Tories in Kent had placed a newspaper advertisement seeking to tap into local fears about "bogus" asylum seekers.

Former home secretary Michael Howard's constituency party in Folkestone and Hythe placed the advertisement, which a leading refugee charity said played blatantly on fears of racism.

But the Conservative leader yesterday insisted that his party would not be diverted by allegations of racism from making asylum a key campaign issue in the coming election, as the fallout from three Tory MPs' refusal to sign a pledge not to pander to racial prejudice continued.

Mr Hague's chief adviser on ethnic minority issues raised the stakes further by suggesting that the role of the commission for racial equality, which drew up the pledge, should be reviewed, suggesting it was addressing an agenda which had "outlived its usefulness".

Mohammed Riaz, who exchanges ideas regularly with the Conservative leader on race issues, told the Guardian: "A review is necessary, not because of the recent problems that the CRE has faced but because, as a body that has lasted many years, it is never ever clear what type of agenda they are working towards or what are their ultimate aims."

Defending his local party's advertisement, Mr Howard said the rise in asylum claims was "one of the most important issues" in his constituency. Tension has been high in Kent over the issue, with groups helping asylum seekers reporting violence against those who say they are fleeing persecution.

Under the heading Common Sense, the advert asks voters: "What matters most to you?", then says in bold text: "Bogus asylum seekers?", before promising that the Conservatives "reduced the number before. We will do so again. Conservatives will get it right."

Helen Bamber, director of the medical foundation for the care of victims of torture, said: "In the context of previous violence towards asylum seekers in Kent it's inviting hatred. It's so desperately untrue to suggest that most asylum seekers are bogus. It gives no recognition that large numbers of those who come to Britain are fleeing persecution and torture.

"Home office statistics show that of those applications that receive full consideration at least half get a positive decision."

The Liberal Democrats, aiming to overturn Mr Howard's 6,300 majority, condemned the advertisement. A party spokesperson said: "Michael Howard knows that his days are numbered and desperate times equals desperate measures.

"This is just the type of nasty sentiment that William Hague should be stamping on. It's no surprise that Mr Howard hasn't signed up to the CRE compact."

Mr Howard defended the advert and rubbished claims of pandering to prejudice: "People in my constituency are deeply concerned at the number of asylum seekers coming into this country illegally.

"Very large numbers are being picked up on the Eurotunnel terminal which is in my constituency. The government has completely failed to deal with this problem and its an entirely legitimate matter of public debate as is accepted in terms by the CRE document."

The Conservatives last night declined to comment directly on the advertisement or whether the national party endorsed it. A Central Office spokesman said: "William Hague made a statement on Saturday reiterating that racism has no place in the Conservative party."

For Labour, home office minister Barbara Roche said: "Given the Conservatives' record on asylum policy, it can be no surprise to the Tory party that they are accused of exploiting the issue rather than dealing with it."

The race row, which last week saw the Tory party divided over the CRE pledge, which Mr Hague signed but shadow chancellor Michael Portillo rejected, grew more bitter yesterday.

Mr Hague, writing in the Sunday Telegraph, accused Labour of a "shabby and contemptible" attempt to gag his party over asylum, and shadow home secretary Ann Widdecombe dismissed the race pledge as "silly", suggesting Labour had accused the Tories of racism to hide its asylum policy failings.

Liberal Democrat leader Charles Kennedy urged Mr Hague to expel from his party all MPs who refuse to sign the pledge not to play the race card in the election campaign. The broadcaster and Labour chairman of the Greater London Assembly Trevor Phillips described racism as "the canker at the heart of the Tories" and accused Mr Hague of failing to deal with it.

Meanwhile, the CRE faced accusations from former Conservative chairman Sir Brian Mawhinney and others of behaving irresponsibly and of being seen as partisan, with some Tories privately claiming the body had worked in league with Labour to embarrass the Conservatives over the compact.

CRE chairman Gurbux Singh said the row over which MPs had signed its pledge had overshadowed the fact that all parties had failed on the race issue. He said: "I want to see a positive, healthy discussion as opposed to political parties throwing mud at each other. That, I think, is deeply saddening.

"I believe that all political parties are failing."

But there will be pressure among some Conservatives for revenge against the CRE, though the party has no policy to reform the body. One Tory source said: "If the CRE continue to behave in cahoots with and act as the mouthpiece of the Labour party, we may think of radical reform."

A senior CRE source said claims that the watchdog had set out to embarrass the Tories were nonsense: "It's not the commission scoring points, it's the Tories scoring own goals. Their stance on race is in complete disarray, they don't know if they're coming or going."
