fields.headline: Turkey siege - Chechens surrender
fields.standfirst: Special report: Chechnya
fields.trailText: Pro-Chechen terrorists, who have been holding hostages in a hotel in Istanbul, have ended the 11-hour siege. According to NTV television reports, the gunmen have surrendered themselves to the police and released all of the hostages.
fields.body:
Pro-Chechen terrorists, who have been holding hostages in a hotel in Istanbul, have ended the 11-hour siege. According to NTV television reports, the gunmen have surrendered themselves to the police and released all of the hostages.

Pro-Chechen rebels armed with automatic rifles and shotguns had stormed the hotel in Istanbul last night and seized hostages. British tourists were among the guests at the Swiss hotel but were not believed to be among the hostages.

A fax statement from the gunmen's group said that their action was aimed at ending the "bloody and dirty Russian attack on our homeland the Caucasus". It also said that more demands would be announced later.

The statement also apologised to Turkey and Turkish tourism operators for the loss of "perhaps a few tens or hundreds of thousands of dollars". "We will not shed blood," it said, but also warned that the group could not be held responsible for any deaths in the event of Turkish security forces raiding the hotel.

The attackers appealed to Turkish authorities and pledged to make releasing Turkish hostages a priority. This suggests that they are hoping to exploit pro-Chechen feelings inside Turkey. "We cannot be described as terrorists. Despite the fact that we have been forced to limit the freedom of innocent people, to carry arms and to carry out an action that terrorises, we are definitely not terrorists," it said.

The governor of Istanbul told reporters earlier that he had spoken with the gunmen. "I have spoken to them. They have political demands. We are trying to resolve things," Governor Erol Cakir told reporters as he left the hotel around five hours into the siege.

Hundreds of police were surrounding the hotel, which overlooks the Bosphorus, and six ambulances were on standby outside.

A Belgian man visiting guests in the hotel told Reuters news agency: "I came into the lobby... then there were two or three men who rushed in. They were dressed in black and there were shots. I ran out immediately and when I was standing in the garden I heard more shots."

TV pictures taken from outside the hotel showed at least one armed man patrolling the lobby and people who appeared to be guests walking with their arms raised in the air.

Witnesses outside the hotel saw two groups of a total of 10 guests leave the main entrance. They were met by members of a heavy police cordon that surrounded the hotel complex and driven away. Anatolian said the attackers had gathered hostages in a conference hall on the fifth floor of the main block.

"We have learned that some of the guests at the hotel are being held. They (the attackers) say they are Chechen," the Istanbul police chief Kazim Abanoz said last night. He said the group had claimed to be 20-25 strong. It was not clear how many hostages had been taken.

A Foreign Office spokeswoman confirmed that Britons were staying at the hotel but were not thought to be among the hostages.

"We understand there are British people among the guests but we don't have any indication that they are being held," the spokeswoman said.

"They are probably not among the hostages but we are taking this very seriously and representatives from the British consul are en route to the hotel."

Hotel worker Alisan Ercan said he heard gunshots and saw four or five gunmen in the lobby as he ran out of the hotel. Guests were hiding in between tables in the hotel lobby, Ercan said. Other guests escaped from the hotel through the fire exits.

The rebels are apparently demanding to speak with Turkish Interior Minister Saadettin Tantan, according to the Anatolia news agency.

They identified themselves as supporters of Muhammed Tokcan, a Turkish citizen of Chechen origin who hijacked a Turkish Black Sea ferry in 1996, seizing more than 200 hostages. The hostages were all freed unharmed after four days.

Tokcan later surrendered to police and is currently in a Turkish prison.

fields.headline: Publish and be damned
fields.standfirst: The Sunday Mirror was roasted for running a story which led to the Leeds players' trial collapsing. But  Gary Mason  says editors sometimes need to take a risk on contempt
fields.trailText: The Sunday Mirror was roasted for running a story which led to the Leeds players' trial collapsing. But Gary Mason says editors sometimes need to take a risk on contempt.
fields.body:
So the street of shame has proved itself to have no shame after all, turning on one of its own following the Sunday Mirror story that triggered the recent collapse of the Leeds players' trial. Some commentators, including one former Mirror Group editor, were quick to damn the paper's editor, Colin Myler, saying he had committed an elementary mistake that would have made a trainee journalist blush.

Prosecution for contempt of court and record fines may be pending for Trinity Mirror and for Myler himself, who has since resigned. But history may prove that his decision to publish was not an elementary error but the sort of fine judgment that editors are required to make all the time.

As an editor who has been on the wrong end of several court actions and a visiting lecturer on the journalism course at City University in London, I have sympathy for Myler's predicament on several fronts.

If I were to ask my bright class of trainees to make a decision on a story similar in detail and circumstance to the one published by the Sunday Mirror, I would be surprised if any of them did not confine it to the spike. This is because early on in their crime reporter specialism course they have drummed into them the clear restrictions which apply when reporting court proceedings.

They learn in fairly black and white terms that journalists can be found in contempt of court if they publish material which creates a substantial risk of serious prejudice to criminal proceedings. On the basis of that definition, they would and should rule that an interview with an assault victim's family during a high-profile assault case published shortly before the jury's verdict does present a big enough risk of prejudice.

But these are trainee journalists being given a grounding in media law at the start of their careers. They are not experienced national newspaper editors with a duty to their readers and shareholders and with ready access to specialist legal advice.

Editors who do not push at the boundaries of the contempt and libel laws in order to publish information that is in the public interest are failing to do their jobs properly.

So when Kelvin MacKenzie, as editor of the Sun in 1994, decided to publish a photograph of a man accused of murder six weeks before a police identity parade in which the man was picked out by witnesses, both he and his legal team must have carefully weighed the risks. The £80,000 fine imposed on the paper for contempt may well have been part of that calculation.

Some of the same principles will have applied to the decisions by the Sunday Times and the Independent to publish extracts from the former MI5 agent Peter Wright's Spycatcher at a time when injunctions preventing publication of the book were in force against the Observer and the Guardian in 1987. Both papers were found guilty of contempt.

Whatever the ethics of these cases, there is a clear distinction between making fine editorial judgments based on an awareness of the risks involved and finding yourself on the wrong side of a contempt action because of ignorance of the law.

I raise the spectre of the latter because of my experience of providing media law training for experienced journalists. These courses are usually laid on by the publishing company as a form of refresher training for editorial staff. Five minutes into one particular session it became clear that there was little or no knowledge of the libel laws or the restrictions and protection which apply to journalists when reporting court cases. I was told, among other things, that it was impos sible to libel a company; that journalists were protected from an action if the defamatory passage in a story was attributed to another paper; and that there was generally no risk of libel if a reporter inserts the word "allegedly" when not absolutely sure of the facts.

Even worse was a unanimous decision by a group of hacks that a series of personal allegations in a court report were "clearly libellous" when a fair and accurate report of them would have given the journalist protection under the privilege laws.

Thirty years ago most journalists learned the ropes through the trainee reporter system on local papers, where the monotony of reporting proceedings at local magistrates courts and council meetings had to be endured by everyone. Thankfully there are many more entry points and career options for today's trainees, but the explosion in opportunity has brought with it substantial dangers in my view. In a drive to cut down on staff costs and create "multi-tasking" journalists, publishing companies, particularly those in the magazine sector, have concentrated on recruiting people with IT and other technical skills.

The huge growth in media outlets means that there are journalists working at senior level who not only have never written a report of court proceedings in their entire career but have no knowledge of the laws that apply to those proceedings and, more generally, the laws on defamation.

Companies are at last becoming aware of this training gap and organisations such as the Periodical Publishers Association are helping them to provide their staff with media law courses. But in some instances it is a case of closing the stable door after the horse has bolted. Many publishers are now obliged to provide such training by their insurers as a condition of their cover against an action for libel or contempt.

Such conditions and a hefty increase in premiums are often imposed after a company has lost an expensive action because of a simple editorial error. This training shortfall can also make it difficult for editors to publish challenging and controversial material. This is because in some cases an additional condition of insurance is that a title is scanned for libel risk by a lawyer prior to publication.

In such cases the lawyer is acting more in the interests of the insurer than to support an editor's natural desire to publish challenging and controversial material. It cannot be good for the freedom of the press to have editorial policy dictated by lawyers and insurance people.

These courses are usually laid on by the publishing company as a form of refresher training for editorial staff. Five minutes into one particular session it became clear that there was little or no knowledge of the libel laws or the restrictions and protection which apply to journalists when reporting court cases. I was told, among other things, that it was impos sible to libel a company; that journalists were protected from an action if the defamatory passage in a story was attributed to another paper; and that there was generally no risk of libel if a reporter inserts the word "allegedly" when not absolutely sure of the facts. Even worse was a unanimous decision by a group of hacks that a series of personal allegations in a court report were "clearly libellous" when a fair and accurate report of them would have given the journalist protection under the privilege laws. Thirty years ago most journalists learned the ropes through the trainee reporter system on local papers, where the monotony of reporting proceedings at local magistrates courts and council meetings had to be endured by everyone. Thankfully there are many more entry points and career options for today's trainees, but the explosion in opportunity has brought with it substantial dangers in my view. In a drive to cut down on staff costs and create "multi-tasking" journalists, publishing companies, particularly those in the magazine sector, have concentrated on recruiting people with IT and other technical skills. The huge growth in media outlets means that there are journalists working at senior level who not only have never written a report of court proceedings in their entire career but have no knowledge of the laws that apply to those proceedings and, more generally, the laws on defamation. Companies are at last becoming aware of this training gap and organisations such as the Periodical Publishers Association are helping them to provide their staff with media law courses. But in some instances it is a case of closing the stable door after the horse has bolted. Many publishers are now obliged to provide such training by their insurers as a condition of their cover against an action for libel or contempt. Such conditions and a hefty increase in premiums are often imposed after a company has lost an expensive action because of a simple editorial error. This training shortfall can also make it difficult for editors to publish challenging and controversial material. This is because in some cases an additional condition of insurance is that a title is scanned for libel risk by a lawyer prior to publication. In such cases the lawyer is acting more in the interests of the insurer than to support an editor's natural desire to publish challenging and controversial material. It cannot be good for the freedom of the press to have editorial policy dictated by lawyers and insurance people.

fields.headline: Government set to bail out telecoms industry
fields.trailText:
8.30am: The government is set to bail out debt-laden telecoms companies by giving back the £22bn spent on 3G licences. By Dan Milmo.
20.03.2001: How BT got the numbers wrong
fields.body:
The government is set to bail out debt-laden telecoms companies by giving back the £22bn spent on 3G mobile phone licences.

Senior Whitehall sources and telecoms industry insiders confirmed that discussions have taken place over a rebate.

The government has watched with mounting concern as stock market heavyweights BT and Vodafone have built up a combined debt of £37bn paying for licences across Europe, with the cost of rolling out a continent-wide network estimated at £100bn.

BT, Vodafone, Orange, One2One and the TIW consortium paid £22.5bn for the UK licences last year, sparking a pan-European spending spree that saw £30bn spent in Germany alone.

However, a source close to the negotiations between the operators and the government confirmed that some kind of rebate was inevitable.

The most likely scenario is a "vendor finance" deal, where the government loans back the licence money to pay for the networks, which will send high-speed internet signals and video images to customers' phones.

"It would be strange if we were not discussing some kind of deal. There will be some sort of deal done over investing in the networks," said the source.

"The government will dress it up as encouraging investment, but in effect it will be paying back the companies. They are putting the money back in the pockets of those who paid."

The source added that "things went a bit crazy" during the 3G auction, and the competing companies paid way over the odds for the licences.

"If you are looking for UK plc to build super-services quicker than anywhere else in the world, then you don't want a financial burden to start with," the source said.

One senior Whitehall source confirmed that the payback was under serious consideration, but the government did not want to be seen to be bailing out BT, which owes £30bn.

BT originally intended to reduce its deficit by floating 25% of its BT Wireless subsidiary, but volatile market conditions forced the postponement of the idea.

The last-ditch option would be a £5bn share issue, in which shareholders agree to buy new shares in the group, but it would almost certainly cost the jobs of BT's chief executive, Sir Peter Bonfield, and the chairman, Sir Iain Vallance.

Meanwhile, a study by telecoms consultancy Quotient Communications has predicted that it could take more than 10 years for the telecoms companies to get their money back, particularly if tight budgets force the operators to offer below-par services.

Some analysts fear that the major European telecoms operators will be forced to default on their debts, after they spent a staggering £97bn last year.

One way to ease the mounting debt burdens is vendor financing, which has seen telecoms equipment manufacturers such as Nokia loan £1.25bn to Orange to build networks with their products.

However, £100bn will have to be spent on 3G networks over the next four years and Nokia, Ericsson and Motorola have a total of £90bn available in shareholders' funds.

The European Investment Bank has already been mentioned as a possible source of financing for the networks, and the UK government's involvement will raise hopes of intervention from other European governments.

Germany's Deutsche Telekom owes £36bn and the German government is a major shareholder in the company.

fields.headline: New Media Diary
fields.trailText: "Whether you're looking to sample the magical delights of one of Europe's most exciting capital cities, or simply indulge in its history and art, this is the offer you've been waiting for," read the offer Diary just couldn't refuse. All I had to do was sign up to LineOne and I'd be Eurostarred to Paris free! I did, and this week received my "free tickets", only to find that you have to fork out for three nights' accommodation in a very expensive hotel or the offer is void. Is this a great example of transparent online marketing or just LineOne up to dirty tricks to ramp up its figures as it seeks out a gullible buyer?
fields.body:
"Whether you're looking to sample the magical delights of one of Europe's most exciting capital cities, or simply indulge in its history and art, this is the offer you've been waiting for," read the offer Diary just couldn't refuse. All I had to do was sign up to LineOne and I'd be Eurostarred to Paris free! I did, and this week received my "free tickets", only to find that you have to fork out for three nights' accommodation in a very expensive hotel or the offer is void. Is this a great example of transparent online marketing or just LineOne up to dirty tricks to ramp up its figures as it seeks out a gullible buyer?

Diary was thrilled to return to work last Tuesday and find wires and websites chock-a-block with news that Vodafone had made a historic phone call. Had they got in touch with aliens in a faraway galaxy? Had they connected a call through to the deceased? Er, not quite. The hype came out of two Vodafone execs testing a 3G phone, which the PR people spun as the UK's first live 3G call. But with 3G little more than 18 months away (supposedly), why haven't they tested the service already? The two participants in the ground-breaking exchange were old mates who ran out of things to say after 15 minutes of chatting about the weather. But the 30 or so other employees who had schlepped in on bank holiday Monday to witness the exchange didn't get a look in and, I'm told, were not happy at being denied a go. An epic moment indeed. Hip hip for Vodafone.

Americans are going bonkers about the internet hype about the release of AI, the movie from the late Stanley Kubrick and Dreamworks. Remember how Blair Witch became an overnight internet phenomenon? Well, the guerrilla marketing for AI is blowing that old stunt away. Movie buffs are practically palpitating over the cryptic clues planted in trailers and obscure promotional websites - of which there seems to be around 100 so far - and thousands of net users are now scouring sites and search engines for clues about AI's characters and plotlines. Netribution.co.uk's film sleuths have to be praised for being the first site this side of the pond to cotton on to it. Good work, fellas.

To confirm or not to confirm, that is the question. Whether it is nobler to admit defeat and suffer the slings and arrows of embarrassing bitching, or vehemently deny and then hope people will eventually lose interest. It seems that internet companies today, annoyingly, much prefer the latter. GUS, the company that bought Breathe for £1.4m three months ago, has now admitted that it plans to sell the ISP, despite heavily protesting against suggestions of such a sell-off just weeks ago. Soccernet is doing the same, although at the moment it's still in the vehement denial stage. It's difficult to keep up. Is anyone ever going to start talking straight?

Amy Vickers is new media editor of mediatheguardian.com

fields.headline: My New Media
fields.standfirst: David Annat, managing director of sportinglife.com
fields.trailText: David Annat, managing director of sportinglife.com.
fields.body:
Favourite websites? Our own because I'm a sports nut but also citywire.co.uk for city news and FasTrade.co.uk, which works brilliantly, for online share dealing. I use multimap.co.uk for every appointment and love decanter.com for wine.

Last online purchase? A Skoda Fabia for my wife. I knew the model I wanted so it was just a question of getting the cheapest price. I couldn't believe how many cars there were - literally thousands to choose from.

Last technological faux pas? Quite recently I took a laptop to a conference but left my power lead behind. I can't believe that nobody has invented a universal power lead.

News sources on the web? I tap into the PA site because we're part of it and I've used it from the word go. I also use ft.com, thisismoney.com and thisislondon.co.uk in the afternoon. I use the BBC quite a lot and look at newspapers online.

Time spent on the web? Probably about two hours a day by the time I've looked at our competitors and about two hours at the weekend. I love the sports information on it and rarely use the TV now. The internet is much more convenient.

Site least likely to succeed? I think they've got to have an e-commerce model. I think the ones that are succeeding are sites which have this but don't have to shift goods. We subsidise it through the betting. You can't rely on advertising and sponsorship.

Most useful site? Farmgate.co.uk because I live in the country and we keep pet pigs and dogs so I've had to look up where you get disinfected and what you use.

Most irritating thing about the web? There aren't many but probably the late-afternoon congestion when everyone in America comes online. Also the lack of broadband service channels.

Ever been in a chatroom? Only to see how they work. Some of the stuff is fairly banal. My son's very into garage and rap and I find that he's been in those kind of chatrooms when I look at the computer's history.

Do you still bother with old media? I get the papers in the office but I've noticed that I don't buy magazines as much as I used to. I was reading how the circulation of football magazines and car magazines has slumped and I'm not surprised because the information on the net is so up to date.

David Annat is managing director of sportinglife.com which is part of Trinity Mirror Group. The website is currently up for sale for £25m

fields.headline: Eat, watch and be happy
fields.standfirst: Imagine there's no adverts . . . it's easy if you have TiVo. It may even get your children to join in family meals, as  Peter Bazalgette  discovers
fields.trailText: Imagine there's no adverts . . . it's easy if you have TiVo. It may even get your children to join in family meals, as Peter Bazalgette discovers.
fields.body:
In a desperate attempt to keep ahead of our children's techno-mastery we bought a TiVo in December. I was curious as to whether this "personal video recorder" spells the end of the scheduled channel. But I have discovered that TiVo may be more revolutionary still.

The fact that our TV has an integral VCR made installation problematical. Over-technical, on-screen instructions and a handset firing blanks were further irritations. And there were other things we hadn't picked up from TiVo's advertising. The system takes a daily download of the up-to-date schedule from the telephone. This makes you a subscriber, for which privilege you must pay £10 a month.

I'll come to whether TiVo is a mortal threat to the channel system. But right now I would feel more threatened were I editor of Radio Times, new and improved though it may be. The detailed scheduling information that pops up, superimposed (and legible, unlike Teletext) is a great convenience.

The biggest failing is TiVo's inability to record one digital channel while you watch another. Hence when one of us wanted to watch the thriller NCS: Man Hunt and another wanted to record A Midsummer Night's Dream, it was impossible. We did not find reprogramming the beast to receive E4 that easy either. But the humans at the TiVo helpline are well- programmed and we are now getting there. So our planned digital library of Ally McBeal will be inaugurated shortly.

Dispensing with those clunky old video tapes is a boon. Buffy and Angel are recorded in a trice and viewed at least six times each. But for the "best quality" recording, the capacity is 12 hours, rather than the 40 advertised so promi nently. We have disabled TiVo's much-vaunted capacity to analyse your preferences and scoot around recording shows that you might like. It started off by recording about 10 episodes of The Simpsons - a not inaccurate summary of our 10-year-old's tastes, but a rather monothematic archive.

I have not yet revealed TiVo's most miraculous, most beneficial facility - something that could bring peace and harmony to domestic life while, coincidentally, lowering the crime rate. Family mealtimes have been all but destroyed by TV suppers. Now, the pause button in the TiVo handset could change all that. Instantly, the rest of a programme can be recorded, and thus attendance at meals is inescapable.

But while TiVo is reforming and purifying western society, will it be destroying both the brand and the economics of the TV channel? Not really. To use it intelligently you still instruct it to go to particular channels to record programmes. Indeed, its whole architecture is based on the channel structure. Hence its deal, announced on Friday, with Channel 4 to preview its shows as the beginning of a relationship. But, no one is yet distributing a truly flexible electronic programme guide through which you can locate a programme via its star or production company. Even TiVo's relatively liberating listing of genres does, in the end, direct you to a programme description that includes a channel identity.

Then there is the question of whether we skip the advertisements of TiVo-recorded programmes. On the evidence of our household, yes. On the evidence of research from Continental Research presented by Caroline Bell at March's TV2001 conference, yes again. It asked respondents to list the TiVo facilities they thought they would most like. Skipping ads was the most popular. But, for now, TiVo has not sold that many boxes. Even the few who own them still watch a reasonable amount of television live.

Indeed, TiVo's Davina Kent presented her company as the friend of advertisers at the recent European Media & Entertainment Summit in London. She told assembled media folk that some users employ TiVo's fast forward to watch favourite ads. Maybe they'll soon be running the ads and skipping the programmes. But until most households have digital services and until a powerful personal video recorder is a standard part of that, the revolution appears to be postponed.

The ad industry accepts that TV will gradually deliver fewer "impacts" (when an ad is viewed by an individual). But as long as there is an adroit shift towards sponsorship and away from spot advertising there is no need to man the lifeboats yet. As for TiVo - not the greatest search engine we will ever have, but great for family meals.

fields.headline: Abraham's journey of discovery
fields.standfirst: He was a co-founder of St Luke's and one of advertising's brightest young guns. But Discovery Networks Europe managed to snare him to become its new general manager. David Abraham tells  Claire Cozens  why he has left one of the world's sexiest ad agencies for the worthy environs of a leading pay TV brand
fields.trailText: David Abraham tells Claire Cozens why he has left one of the world's sexiest advertising agencies for the worthy environs of a leading pay TV brand.
fields.body:
Look around the swish central London building Discovery Networks Europe shares with Flextech and, apart from a few cute posters of polar bears, there are few clues to the identity of its occupants. The smartly-dressed executives you see beavering away at their computers through the glass walls of the atrium could belong to any bank or management consultancy.

It's all a far cry from St Luke's, London's trendiest advertising agency, and home, for the moment, to Discovery's new general manager, David Abraham.

As one of the founding partners of St Luke's, Abraham has spent the past five and a half years in an environment more akin to a Soho nightclub than an office, complete with chill-out rooms and a staff dominated by twenty-somethings with dreadlocked hair and the latest trainers. Hot desking is the norm, there is a bright red room called The Womb and, in one of the agency's wilder moments, the entire office was covered in bubble-wrap.

More importantly, the agency is run as a co-operative. St Luke's is owned and run by its staff, all of whom, in theory at least, have a say in everything from the accounts the agency works on to the people it hires. The agency's highly innovative approach to advertising has produced some of the most memorable campaigns of the last few years, including Ikea's "Chuck out your chintz" and Eric Cantona's philosophical ramblings for Eurostar.

So what makes a young man who works for one of the sexiest agencies in the world and has been described as the brightest advertising executive of his generation want to move to Discovery, a company that even its fans would agree has a rather worthy reputation?

"It's not difficult to sign up to as an ideal," says Abraham. "There's already a lot of Lukishness about Discovery. It's an organisation that has managed its brand extraordinarily well. It knows what it's about and feels strongly about that, but it is by no means a soft touch when it comes to effective business.

"Is it too worthy? Well, that's the challenging part. For me, it builds on the St Luke's experience - everyone said, 'It's too idealistic, it won't work,' but we made that very distinctive idea work. Discovery now needs to build on its availability and start to break out of what might be perceived to be a niche positioning."

Andy Law, who has worked with Abraham for 15 years as co-founder of St Luke's, says the job has Abraham's name written on it. "Had he been going to another advertising agency I would have been upset - in fact I would have thought he'd caught a touch of foot and mouth," he says. "But this is a genuinely good career move and I'm delighted for him."

The role of general manager is new and Abraham's remit covers all aspects of the company that touch the consumer - from marketing and PR to programming. Joyce Taylor, managing director of DNE, says it was created to ensure Discovery's place in an increasingly competitive European TV market. Because of that she was looking for someone with experience of both programming and marketing.

"All the other candidates had either one or the other; it's very rare to find someone with both," she says. "We were also looking for someone who had run a business and who understood the dynamics of business. And the fact that David comes from a very interesting and creative business was very important. There is a saying that the more you concentrate too much on the bottom line, the harder it is to hit."

Certainly, Abraham's business acumen is rock solid. When St Luke's was set up it was he and Law who engineered a buy-out from the original owners of the business, secured funding and put together a business plan. Friends say that while Law is the ideas man, Abraham is the pragmatic one in the background making sure things get done.

Dan Brooke, deputy managing director of pay TV at Channel 4 and another ex-ad man, says: "There's a sense that David is the one actually making it happen and making sure the company makes money. He is that rare mix of very strong commercial instincts married with a strong sense of social conscience."

Interestingly, Brooke says he has always seen Abraham as a businessman, not an ad man. Anyone looking for an opportunity to dismiss St Luke's as a bunch of hippies was handed it on a plate.

You can do it in a way that's purely pedagogical, like an Open University programme. That's not what Discovery's about, although it is often perceived to be of that ilk."

The challenge for Abraham is to persuade people otherwise. Rather like Economist subscribers who end up throwing the magazine away unread every week, people who subscribe to Discovery's channels do so with the best intentions but somehow always seem to end up slumped on the sofa in front of Who Wants to be a Millionaire? instead.

"We know people don't just want to watch EastEnders or Millionaire all evening. Clearly there are times when you don't want to absorb scientific advances, but everyone has curiosity about the world, travel and hobbies - that's what we want tosatisfy."

fields.headline: Room at the top?
fields.standfirst: Thelma Agnew reports on new opportunities for NHS staff to climb the career ladder
fields.trailText: Thelma Agnew report on new opportunities for NHS staff to climb the career ladder.
fields.body:
When Unison's head of health Bob Abberley joined the NHS in 1972, as a trainee theatre technician, it was made obvious that progressing within the service to a career in the health professions or in management was not an option for the likes of him.

"I was an 11-plus failure," he says. "I went to a secondary modern and ended up with some CSEs. It was made very clear that people with CSEs were not as good as people with GCSEs."

He had joined the service in a low-status job and was expected to stay there. "I remember walking up a corridor in the hospital and passing a senior manager. I looked at him, he knew who I was, but it was as if I didn't exist."

The memory of these early humiliations gives a personal edge to Mr Abberley's support for the government's drive to improve learning and training opportunities for non-professional NHS staff.

The introduction of individual learning accounts to the health service is intended to ensure that the young Abberleys of today - bright and able, but lacking traditional academic qualifications - are not invisible to managers, but are given the chance to climb the career ladder.

As far as Mr Abberley is concerned, ILAs - and the change in attitude that they represent - are long overdue. "Hospitals are full of people like me, and that potential is not tapped.

"We still have an academic elite culture, and a power structure that means if you work with your hands you are not valued."

In the 1970s Mr Abberley would certainly have benefited from access to funded training to further his career; as it was, he even had to campaign to get the minimum training which was supposed to be a compulsory part of his job.

Union activism was his salvation: "As the union started to invest in me, I became aware that I did have some potential." That potential, which the health service overlooked, has taken him to the top of his union.

The NHS confederation's head of human resources - and NHS human resources director designate - Andrew Foster says that ILAs, in themselves, won't make a dramatic difference to the chances of low-status staff finding a way into professional or management roles. But as another step in what he calls the "skills escalator" they are certainly welcome.

"The skills escalator is something we have strongly argued for. Instead of being recruited to a vocation, you come onto the escalator and are always moving upwards or sideways , so you have a much more varied and interesting career."

Unison official Ian Barber, who has helped develop Department of Health guidance on ILAs during a secondment to the London regional executive office, predicts that ILAs will have an "enormous impact" on thousands of NHS staff.

Unlike NVQs, which merely establish competency in a particular job, ILAs are a "flexible financial resource" which open up a broader range of training opportunities.

"I think it would be perfectly possible through the ILA route to take up management studies."

In the absence of ILAs, staff lacking academic qualification have needed exceptional drive, and luck, to carve out a management career. "It's taken enormous tenacity and determination - and to a certain extent, the ability to be in the right place at the right time," Mr Barber.

Susan Osborne, former chief executive of the Royal London Homeopathic hospital trust, admits that her career in general management was kick started by "fortuitous" circumstances in the late 1980s, when hospital services were being reconfigured.

As a qualified nurse she was never in the category of non-professional staff which the government is targeting through ILAs, but nor was she in a position to aspire to run a hospital some day.

"I was at the new Homerton hospital, where I was responsible for nursing services for 18 months. Then the acute services manager left to take up a promotion elsewhere, and the unit general manager decided to restructure and asked me if I would like to take on a general management function."

She soon discovered that she enjoyed the challenge of having to take a "broader view" of patient care.

Ms Osborne, who is currently director of nursing at St Mary's trust in Paddington, London, says she would have appreciated an ILA-type learning opportunity to advance her career. As it was, she had to plan the next step herself - a masters degree in public policy.

Initiatives like the ILA scheme are vital, suggests Osborne, because they invite staff to think about climbing the career ladder. Without this invitation staff who don't fit the standard management model - white, male and middle class - are far more likely to keep their heads down and stay where they are.

Ms Osborne's time as an assessor on career development courses, run by the now-defunct NHS women's unit, made her acutely aware of women's tendency to underestimate, and under-sell, their abilities.

Getting into top NHS management from a non-conventional background is never going to be easy. Ms Osborne has sometimes found her abilities questioned because of her sex, and her nursing background.

"There have been throwaway remarks about nurses not being able to count properly - and therefore unable to manage budgets."

Any help and encouragement from central government and employers is welcome. But funding and courses can only do so much. Ms Osborne says much depends on supportive managers being willing to look out for talent in the non-professional grades.

Once the opportunity has been given, the rest is down to the individual. "I do think that you have to have an inner drive. In top management you have to have a fairly thick skin, and you have to be quite dogged in what you do. Some people can do that, and some people find it difficult."

webTitle: A learning alternative for health service staff

fields.headline: A learning alternative for health service staff
fields.standfirst: New schemes aim to help develop the skills and potential of the huge 'invisible army' of non-professional health service staff. Thelma Agnew reports
fields.trailText: New schemes aim to help develop the skills and potential of the huge 'invisible army' of non-professional health service staff. Thelma Agnew reports.
fields.body:
The NHS plan signalled the government's determination to end years of neglect and recognise the skills and potential of non-professional health service staff.

It guarantees that staff without a professional qualification will have access to either an individual learning account, with £150 funding per year, or dedicated training to national vocational qualification (NVQ) level two or three.

The investment is intended to improve the training opportunities available to a huge "invisible army" of healthcare assistants, operating department practitioners, pharmacy technicians and others.

The NVQ system is well established but individual learning accounts (ILAs) are, as far the health service is concerned, something new.

The scheme, which begins this month, will run alongside the existing ILA arrangements, run by the Department for Education and Employment.

Indeed, guidance recently released by the Department of Health states that NHS employees should also be encouraged to open a DfEE ILA, which is worth an additional £150.

This means that £300 in central government funding is now available to individual health service staff who have previously had little, or nothing, spent on their training needs.

Two ILA courses have been launched, following a collaboration between the NHS executive, Unison and the Workers Educational Association (WEA).

Pathways to the future offers practical help with re-entry to learning, while improving study skills prepares those already qualified to NVQ 2 and 3 levels to step up to professional training.

Each course involves 10.5 days of study supported by a tutor. Employers who want to provide their staff with opportunities for group learning can turn to WEA regional co-ordinators for help in setting up learning at work courses.

Unison's well-established return to learn courses will also be funded under the ILA scheme.

To be eligible for an ILA payment, the training or learning must be work-related - in other words, it must contribute to employees' ability to carry out their current job, or help them in a job to which they might realistically expect to be appointed to in the future.

Learning activities must also fit within the employee's personal development plan. It is up to individual employees to apply to join the scheme; employers authorise or reject applications.

If the application is successful, the employee presents the authorisation form to the relevant education provider, who in turn invoices the NHS regional executive office for payment.

webTitle: Hague hit by leak over image

fields.headline: Hague hit by leak over image
fields.trailText: William Hague's standing as leader of the Tory party was dealt another blow last night after the leaking of confidential papers which revealed the despair of senior Tories at a failed overhaul of the party's image.
fields.body:
William Hague's standing as leader of the Tory party was dealt another blow last night after the leaking of confidential papers which revealed the despair of senior Tories at a failed overhaul of the party's image.

Under a "kitchen table" modernisation of the Conservative party, Mr Hague ordered the shadow cabinet to adopt a more modern approach and to concentrate on "bread and butter" issues.

But the rebranding was abandoned months later, angering many senior Tories who saw it as essential to make the party electable.

The timing of the leak, reported in the Daily Telegraph, will be seen as a further attempt to undermine Mr Hague's credibility in preparation for a leadership battle after the general election. It will also be seen as an attack on Mr Hague's concentration on asylum and crime issues rather than health and education, which were at the centre of the rebranding strategy.

The documents were written by Andrew Cooper, then Tory director of operations and an ally of Michael Portillo, and Danny Finkelstein, the party's head of policy. Mr Portillo is seen as a contender for a future leadership battle although he has pledged his loyalty to Mr Hague.

The first paper, dated November 1998, reveals the depth of despair within Conservative Central Office and the feeling that Mr Hague is even more unpopular with voters than the party.

It said the party must realise it is seen as "selfish, sleazy, out of touch" and "arrogant". Mr Hague was described as being even less popular with voters who "continue to project all the party's negatives on to him... he is seen as aloof, out of touch, remote from ordinary people and weak".

The paper recommended focusing on "kitchen table" issues such as health and education seen as of concern to ordinary voters.

"Recovery cannot begin until we understand that a lot of the things people said about us before the election were true. We were out of touch. We had stopped listening. We were undisciplined and divided. We didn't have any clear idea of the direction in which we wanted to take Britain," it added.

The strategy was fully endorsed by Mr Hague and he told members of the shadow cabinet that their political careers depended on adhering to its recommendations.

But three months later a second paper warned that nothing had improved. It said: "We have been unable to concede and move on. We lost the 1997 election because we had become arrogant and out of touch, because we broke our promises to the electorate, because we put up taxes and forfeited our reputation for sound economic management, because we alienated and let down almost every conceivable interest group."

Six months later Mr Hague abandoned the strategy altogether and all its main supporters had left Central Office. There was no explanation for the u-turn and some shadow cabinet members are said to be frustrated that their leader did not pursue the rebranding.

Last week the Tory environment spokesman, Archie Norman, called on Mr Hague to use a "more measured and competent tone" when discussing issues.

fields.headline: Common law strife
fields.standfirst: Not all of the European Union's internal market legislation is implemented by member states. Is it because of inertia or something worse?
fields.trailText: The European Commission last week reviewed progress since the Lisbon summit a year ago and complained that member states are proving slow in making the "internal market" a reality. The reason why a single market has been so long in arriving rests on the peculiar relationship between Brussels and the nations. Commissioner Frits Bolkestein says it is no good the European Union setting frameworks for a common market if member states do not then introduce legislation at home to allow citizens and business to take advantage of the new commercial opportunities offered. In all, about one eighth of EU internal market legislation has still not been implemented by one or more member states.
fields.body:
The European Commission last week reviewed progress since the Lisbon summit a year ago and complained that member states are proving slow in making the "internal market" a reality. The reason why a single market has been so long in arriving rests on the peculiar relationship between Brussels and the nations. Commissioner Frits Bolkestein says it is no good the European Union setting frameworks for a common market if member states do not then introduce legislation at home to allow citizens and business to take advantage of the new commercial opportunities offered. In all, about one eighth of EU internal market legislation has still not been implemented by one or more member states.

The explanation is that the political game continues long after legislation has been passed in Brussels. Fierce bargaining (and some cheating) go on long after the event. Domestic interest groups exert pressure to water down rules they disagree with or beef up others. It is not easy for national governments. Conflict with interest groups can cost votes which is why they like to shift blame to Brussels. The European commission gets stick although it is the council of ministers - made up of members of national governments - and the European parliament, which is of course directly elected from member states, that formally adopt most EU laws.

In the mid-1990s the Tory government fiercely opposed the 48-hour week directive in the council of ministers, not only for ideological reasons, but also as a means of depicting themselves as an guarantor of the national interest against "intrusions". Having lost the battle in Brussels, the Major government decided to fight it again at the implementation stage.

National governments are quick to claim the credit for popular EU initiatives, leaving the EU in a no-win situation. The theory is that EU laws need to be turned into laws in the member states to allow account to be taken of national peculiarities. In practice the transposition process is so highly politicised that it becomes a bottle- neck. The problem is that if EU law is not transposed properly, or at all, firms and other interested parties, such as workers deserving protection in their workplace, are obliged to take legal action in order to force national authorities to comply with EU obligations. Both Italy and Austria have been taken to the European Court by the commission for not putting into law a directive on protecting workers from exposure to biological agents. Such legal process is cumbersome, slow and costly.

The UK is often portrayed as a bad European partner but has a relatively good record. The UK certainly plays political hardball in Brussels when European legislation is being formulated and decided. Yet when it comes to transposition and actual implementation, the UK shifts to a much more technical and less political mode.

France is often seen as the key case of a member state which is at the "centre of Europe" yet often fails to implement European law. Last year the commission issued a "reasoned opinion" against France for the non-transposi tion of directive 93/35 relating to cosmetics.

There are good reasons why the transposition of EU law does not happen. European law is often a mess in the first place and would be difficult to transpose and implement even with the best will in the world. Secondly, the transposition of EU law can be difficult for purely domestic institutional reasons. National civil servants who have negotiated EU law in Brussels frequently move to a new post prior to the preparation of the corresponding national laws. The national laws are then prepared by civil servants who are not familiar with the technical and the political factors that shaped EU law in the first place. National officials are often overworked and mistakes and delays occur.

Civil servants either translate EU into national law by reinterpreting it or else they simply reproduce it, sometimes word for word. But the process may result in watered down domestic provisions or even excessive regulation. UK civil servants are often accused of "gold-plating" EU laws, doing more than is necessary. They are said to seize the opportunity to force through policy changes of which they approve. On the other hand, copying works only when EU law is very clear.

Problems with transposing EU law can be dealt with by legal action. The juris- prudence of the European Court obliges member states to pay damages to citizens and companies if belated or erratic transposition has infringed their rights. National statutes carrying EU law are examined by the commission which has and frequently uses the power to take member states to the European court.

For example, Greece has been taken to the European court for not giving effect to a directive on food hygiene. Similarly the Irish Republic was taken to court over a directive on the transport of dangerous goods by road.

When the commission, a comparatively small administration with over-stretched resources, fails to spot cases of ineffective transposition, firms, pressure groups and citizens may be in a position to blow the whistle.

The UK has well developed and active pressure groups, especially in the environmental field, and generates a significant number of complaints to the commission. But there is no reason to believe that the number of complaints is a good indication of which states are a good or bad Europeans.

We tend to focus on the Brussels game, but the fight over Euro-legislation continues right down to street level implementation. The commission is often seen as an overbearing and bloated bureaucracy. In practice, member states lead it a merry dance.

The authors are at the centre for European politics, economics and society at Oxford University; their work was supported by the Economic and Social Research Council's future governance programme.

webTitle: Peter Preston: The break-up of Britain

fields.headline: The break-up of Britain
fields.standfirst:
The shift of power away from London may make this election unexpectedly revolutionary

Full coverage of Election 2001
fields.trailText: The shift of power away from London may make this election unexpectedly revolutionary.
fields.body:
Here is something you know already, or half-know, or haven't begun to get your head round yet. It concerns 72 MPs with nothing to do and 14 MPs who will soon be terminated, wiped from the face of the earth. No debate about "Britishness" (or indeed federal superstates) is complete without it.

Welcome to an increasingly foreign land, one with no election pending. In that land, the supreme political leader does many familiar things. He takes the rap for foot and mouth, he journeys to Washington plugging tourism, he preaches consensus and inclusivity. But his ministers pursue fascinatingly unfamiliar agendas. When GPs cut up rough, his health minister ponders "urgent action" to address crumbling morale. When teachers make waves, they win a 23% pay rise and a (count it!) 22.5-hour classroom week.

Welcome to the world of Henry McLeish, Susan Deacon and Jack McConnell. Welcome to Scotland. In a way, these past two years, Scotland has ceased to exist south of the border. It is up there somewhere, pursuing its own concerns. And in just the same way, from Berwick on, England has faded into the mists of public consciousness. What you see and read is what you get.

Take a brilliant new study* of creeping change called Open Scotland? by three academics at the Stirling Media Institute. They quote the political correspondent of the Scottish Sun: "I can't think of the last time that I spoke to an MP - they're just irrelevant," he says. They quote the political editor of BBC Scotland: "We have all these Scottish MPs and we never write, we never phone, we never make contact with them. They don't have anything to say." And here's the Scotland correspondent of Channel 4 News: "I just don't have the names of the UK cabinet at my fingertips the way I used to. I don't think anybody thought we would feel quite so disconnected so quickly."

When Scottish TV compared October 1998 (before devolution) and October 1999 on their main news programme, Scotland Today, they found that in 1998 they'd interviewed only Westminster MPs - but 12 months on, they'd talked only to MSPs. "So little now comes from Westminster," says the head of news and current affairs, "that we can concentrate on looking at Edinburgh."

There is (alas) no Preston Media Institute to look at the reverse side of the coin, but I think you'd find a parallel disconnection in London. When I dialled "American politics" into the database of a heavy broadsheet, I got 12,088 items; when I dialled "French politics" I got 10,058; "Scottish politics" trailed in third at 9,342 (with a sharp decline since 1999). Our London-based national papers may, for the most part, have put in extra editorial resources in Edinburgh, but much of that effort goes walkabout once the Scottish editions have finished. The two separate countries, in effect, are left to talk to themselves but not to each other.

Only the BBC struggles with overarching dialogue. How do you react to such a revolution? If you're Brian Wilson, secretary of state for Up There, you fulminate about journalistic standards and BBC competence. But if you're required to be a little more thoughtful about the human condition, you know that newspapers and broad casters follow the broad interests of their audiences and that the authors of Open Scotland? are right when they talk about "a quite fundamental shift in how Scotland is viewed as a polity within the UK. Processes of political communication that involve parliamentarians and government are now seen as largely situated north of the border."

So to an election campaign stuttering into reluctant life, orchestrated from Millbank and Smith Square, fuelled by speeches released in the smoke, covered by editors who live in the great arc between Hammersmith and Hampstead. What will it be about? Education? Off the Scottish map. Health? Likewise. Nick Brown's foot and Nick Brown's mouth? He is not responsible and the Scottish agriculture minister who is faces no vote. The future of Lib-Labbery? Brothers, it exists in Cardiff and Edinburgh and if it has no future there, then neither does devolved Labour governance. Europe? The three big parties in Scotland are all in favour. Immigration and the "preservation of our Anglo-Saxon identity"? Tell that to the Celts.

For the first time in our history, we're about to engage in a national election campaign where most of the big issues apply only scantily to semi-devolved Wales and barely at all to Northern Ireland and Scotland. Yet those 72 Scottish seats - due to come down to 58 next time, as the West Lothian question gets a half-hearted answer - are utterly vital. They are the difference between battered Blair and triumphant Tony. They are life and death for Hague and (probably) Charlie Kennedy.

Turn-out, we're repeatedly told, is crucial. But if I were voting in Dundee, not Dulwich, I'd feel a bit short of motivation on a chilly spring day. My chance to get a word in edgeways on schools or hospitals or crime or the law is two (fixed-term) yearsdistant. My bread and butter will have to wait. I can - as the Nats would have it - send a signal about independence to Westminster or Holyrood, but that's a pretty distant, second-hand business when the Nats' real test comes much later. I can keep Tony and Gordon in charge; but I maybe feel more nuanced than that, seeking a few bob from the Treasury along the way. Since nobody, now, is threatening to scrap devolution, I might even give the Tories a byelection-style punt. Vote for Malcolm Rifkind because he's not William Hague.

We have not, in sum, even begun to get our heads round the enormity of this shift. From our metropolitan fastnesses (where undesirable immigrants get Widdecombed at Calais) we assume that this is just another general election. We witter about a Britishness which does not - in any sense of a shared politics or perspective - exist as heretofore. We are in flux, but we have failed to notice it.

Yet the wheels are off this wagon. They came loose with Scottish university tuition fees and (after that three-year pay deal, with a 35-hour week and £35,000 for a classroom teacher) they are beginning to wobble into an English ditch. Are we separate or together? Do we know what true federalism is about? Fasten your seatbelts. This, as reality dawns, is going to be one hell of a ride.

 Open Scotland? by Philip Schlesinger, David Miller and William Dinan is published by Polygon at Edinburgh (£15.99).

webTitle: Record numbers apply for headships as government fights crisis claims

fields.headline: Record numbers apply for headships as government fights crisis claims
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: The government is expected to seek to stem claims of a teaching crisis by announcing this week that record numbers of teachers have applied to become heads.
fields.body:
The government is expected to seek to stem claims of a teaching crisis by announcing this week that record numbers of teachers have applied to become heads.

Headteachers' leaders have expressed concern about the large numbers of experienced teachers shying away from taking on the enormous responsibilities of a headship under Labour's programme of raising school standards.

But ministers will seize on the figures as evidence that teachers are keen to move up the career ladder.

Last week the Department for Education published figures showing a steep rise in the number of teacher vacancies over the past six months in state schools in England and Wales. Overall, 1.4% of posts in state schools remain unfilled, meaning schools are short of 4,690 teachers. This led to claims of a crisis by teachers' leaders.

But the education secretary, David Blunkett, said teacher numbers had risen during this parliament by more than 11,000, which meant the system was not in crisis, "but growing in importance and confidence".

Ministers will emphasise the professional development now in place for existing and would-be teachers, with a clearer career path towards senior jobs such as deputy headships and headships, and enhanced training and qualifications.

The figures on headships will come amid a growing focus on teachers' workload, a key issue at the teacher conferences over Easter. Talks between the government and employers and leaders of the two largest teaching unions - the National Union of Teachers and the National Association of Schoolmasters Union of Women Teachers - setting out the scope of a proposed inquiry into workload could start this week.

Meanwhile, the school standards minister, Estelle Morris, admitted yesterday that the government's plans to reform schools had "hugely" increased teachers' workload. She conceded in a television interview that some teachers' morale was flagging because of the "great stress" brought about by modernisation.

She said: "A lot has happened in four years and I am sure that has put pressure on teachers, I don't deny that.

"To manage great change and improvement is tough for anybody working in the service. That has been achieved but it has meant huge extra work for teachers. What we set about four years ago was the modernisation of the teaching profession and education and we are delivering, but I absolutely accept it has brought great stress on teachers."

Last week she told teachers they were "unprofessional" for pursuing their claim for a 35-hour week.

webTitle: Ministers to redirect aid to the rural poor

fields.headline: Ministers to redirect aid to the rural poor
fields.standfirst:
Clinics and play buses to go to families in need

Special report: welfare reform
fields.trailText: Travelling playbuses and mobile health clinics are to be introduced in rural areas as the government extends its Surestart scheme for poorer families with young children.
fields.body:
Travelling playbuses and mobile health clinics are to be introduced in rural areas as the government extends its Surestart scheme for poorer families with young children.

The public health minister, Yvette Cooper, will today unveil plans to spend £40m on 16 rural programmes targeted at 10,000 children initially, rising to 20,000 by 2004.

The move is an acknowledgement by the government that it must be seen to be addressing rural poverty as well as inner city problems. Locations for the first wave of schemes include Allerdale in Cumbria and north Devon.

Ms Cooper, addressing a conference organised by the National Children's Bureau, will say that one in four children living in poverty lives in a rural area. She said yester day: "We know that the problems they face can be quite different from those faced in inner cities. People in rural areas can miss out completely at the moment on childcare, or simply opportunities to meet other families with young children. Yet what happens in a child's early years can have a huge impact on the rest of their lives."

The Surestart programme, designed to provide health care and other support for low-income families with children up to four, will be tailored to meet the specific needs of rural communities.

Ministers believe a prime concern for parents in the countryside is the distances they must travel to get to vital services, and believe that much of the money allocated for the new schemes should be spent on tackling the problem.

"Getting to antenatal classes if you've got to take a stroppy toddler on three different buses makes life incredibly difficult, and parents can become isolated if they can't get to childcare or play facilities," Ms Cooper said.

Surestart funds will not be used merely to provide transport to give parents better access to services, but are intended to bring services to rural communities.

Plans include providing travelling health centres bringing doctors and antenatal clinics nearer to rural families. Ms Cooper is also enthusiastic about the concept of playbuses, in which one floor of a double decker is used as a creche, while the other is filled with computers so that their parents can improve their IT skills.

The Surestart scheme is regarded as one of the government's success stories in its attempt to tackle child poverty.

fields.headline: Russians accused of bugging MoD
fields.trailText: Mystery last night surrounded reports that as many as 30 eavesdropping devices had been discovered in Ministry of Defence buildings, including its headquarters in Whitehall.
fields.body:
Mystery last night surrounded reports that as many as 30 eavesdropping devices had been discovered in Ministry of Defence buildings, including its headquarters in Whitehall.

The ministry said the Sunday newspaper reports could not be confirmed but it was "always vigilant about security" and "regularly" swept the buildings for devices.

Defence sources suggested that the bugs were planted over the past 10 years by Russian spies and, more recently, by representatives of foreign arms companies, including French ones.

According to the Sunday Times, two bugs were found at Turnstile House, an MoD building in London where surveillance devices were designed and tested for British agents. Another bug was said to have been found at the Royal College of Surgeons, used by the MoD for a meeting between its arms procurers and a British defence firm.

However, it emerged later that the MoD had never told MI5 - which is responsible for advising Whitehall departments about security - about the bugs. MI5 would have known if devices had been found, Whitehall sources said. The bugging scare was said by security sources to have been unwittingly started by a sergeant from RAF Digby in Lincolnshire where military personnel attached to GCHQ, the government's electronic eavesdropping centre, are trained.

The sergeant was lecturing MoD officials about the need to be vigilant as part of a briefing on "threat awareness," a Whitehall source said. He was deliberately quoting "frightened bureaucrats", the source added. The sergeant's warnings about bugs and where they might be placed were taken at face value by MoD officials.

Geoff Hoon, the defence secretary, muddied the waters when he told BBC1's Breakfast with Frost programme: "These reports were over a 10-year period and if we weren't able to find these bugs and deal with them in the way we have, then we might have a problem. My security experts tell me the fact that we can detect these things does indicate that security remains at the very highest level in the MoD."

Mr Hoon will have the opportunity to explain the mystery when he is questioned by MPs in the Commons today.

Another bug was said to have been found at the Royal College of Surgeons, used by the MoD for a meeting between its arms procurers and a British defence firm. However, it emerged later that the MoD had never told MI5 - which is responsible for advising Whitehall departments about security - about the bugs. MI5 would have known if devices had been found, Whitehall sources said. The bugging scare was said by security sources to have been unwittingly started by a sergeant from RAF Digby in Lincolnshire where military personnel attached to GCHQ, the government's electronic eavesdropping centre, are trained. The sergeant was lecturing MoD officials about the need to be vigilant as part of a briefing on "threat awareness," a Whitehall source said. He was deliberately quoting "frightened bureaucrats", the source added. The sergeant's warnings about bugs and where they might be placed were taken at face value by MoD officials. Geoff Hoon, the defence secretary, muddied the waters when he told BBC1's Breakfast with Frost programme: "These reports were over a 10-year period and if we weren't able to find these bugs and deal with them in the way we have, then we might have a problem. My security experts tell me the fact that we can detect these things does indicate that security remains at the very highest level in the MoD." Mr Hoon will have the opportunity to explain the mystery when he is questioned by MPs in the Commons today.

webTitle: Cancer fear from animal pyre chemicals

fields.headline: Cancer fear from animal pyre chemicals
fields.standfirst:
Campaigners warn of lasting dangers

Special report: foot and mouth disease
Election 2001: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: Foot and mouth pyres are releasing more potentially cancer causing chemicals to the atmosphere than all of the country's most hazardous factories put together, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
Foot and mouth pyres are releasing more potentially cancer causing chemicals to the atmosphere than all of the country's most hazardous factories put together, it emerged yesterday.

Official figures indicate that in six weeks of the crisis, up to April 6, the pyres had released 63 grams of dioxins. This compares with 88 grams released by all of Britain's biggest, most dangerous, factories in a year.

By now, the emissions from the burning heaps of animals will almost certainly have exceeded those from factories.

Dioxins are among the most poisonous man-made chemicals. They affect children's growth and possibly cause cancer. Even low level exposure is known to interfere with the immune and reproductive systems. Environmental campaigners have warned that dioxins accumulate in fat and milk and will work their way through the food chain.

Alan Marshall, a farmer who is resisting the lighting of a massive fire at Arscott farm, in Devon, said last night: "We have told Maff the situation is not acceptable. Their experts say it is quite safe - which nobody believes."

Up to 7,000 animals are to be burned on the Arscott fire, which was due to be lit last night. It is expected to burn for between five and eight days and is just one mile away from the town of Holsworthy.

After fears of pollution a pyre of 750 sheep and cows in Langrigg, Cumbria, was being dismantled by Maff yesterday at the request of the local health authority. The carcasses will be buried instead.

But work was continuing at the giant Ash Moor site at Petrockstow, Devon, capable of taking up to 432,000 animal carcasses. The site, composed of giant burial mounds lined with clay, is not expected to be ready for at least two weeks.

A government spokeswoman said yesterday that it was misleading to compare the foot and mouth pyres with heavy industry. "Most dioxin emissions are not from factories, they are from agricultural burnings and public bonfires."

Geoff Hoon, the defence secretary, told BBC1's Breakfast with Frost: "I have seen reports which compare the burning to the equivalent of two bonfire nights - it is important to put this in context."

But Adrian Bebb, Friends of the Earth's food campaigner, said: "These are big burnings in concentrated areas, which are very different to lots of small bonfires in gardens. You could end up with farmers facing a double whammy. They will not just lose their current stock because of foot and mouth but may not be able to sell products in future because their land is contaminated."

FoE believes the preferred options outlined by the environment agency - the use of rendering plants, controlled incinerators and state of the art landfills - should be fully used before burning or burying on farms.

In 1991 milk from farms near an incinerator at Bolsover in Derbyshire had to be thrown away because it contained excess dioxins. Dioxins form at high temperatures in the presence of carbon, hydrogen and chlorine. Pyres contain chlorine because they are built with creosote-soaked railway sleepers and tyres. The dead livestock contain hydrogen and carbon compounds, and the fires are lit with hydrocarbon fuels such as kerosene.

 Fears that foot and mouth had infected wild deer were raised yesterday after a vet claimed to have identified the symptoms in a dead roe deer found near Penrith in Cumbria last week. The finding could undermine the government's "isolate and slaughter" policy as experts believe it is a practical impossibility to cull deer since panicked wild animals scatter. Tests are being carried out on the carcass.

Andrew Hoon, chairman of the government's deer initiative body, said: "The more you chase wild deer around the more they run around. It's impossible. An epidemic would be a very serious situation." Maff said it had no confirmation of any wild deer being infected with foot and mouth.

By yesterday the number of confirmed foot and mouth cases had reached 1,439. Restrictions were lifted, however, in north Somerset, east and central Wiltshire, and in parts of Berkshire and Hampshire. More than 2,600 farms were last night due to be released from infected area restrictions on moving animals.

fields.headline: Farmer found hanged
fields.standfirst:
Barn death 'Tragedy' after livestock slaughtered

Special report: foot and mouth disease
Election 2001: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: A farmer has been found dead in a barn a week after some of his beef cattle were slaughtered because of the foot and mouth crisis.
fields.body:
A farmer has been found dead in a barn a week after some of his beef cattle were slaughtered because of the foot and mouth crisis.

Glyn Lewis, 59, who kept cattle and sheep and ran a haulage business at Llanfyllin, near Welshpool, is believed to have committed suicide. He was found hanged on Saturday morning at Derw Lyn farm. Police said there were no suspicious circumstances.

Mr Lewis was said to have been very upset last week when some of his livestock were killed as a precaution after they had come into contact with infected animals.

Robert Thomas, a friend, said: "I just hope something can be done before anyone else takes their own life." Welshpool is one of the most badly affected areas in Wales. Mr Lewis, who had lived in the area all his life, was concerned about an outbreak three miles from his farm.

Mr Lewis's former wife, Joyce, 57, and their three children were being comforted by relatives yesterday. Alan Owen, National Farmers' Union of Wales group secretary for Welshpool, said: "My thoughts go out to Mr Lewis's family."

Three weeks ago another farmer from Powys was found dead in what was believed to be a foot and mouth related suicide. The body of John Bayliss, 56, was discovered with a shotgun nearby, at his farm in Kerry, Powys.

fields.headline: Report slams regeneration agency
fields.trailText: A Liverpool regeneration agency run by a city councillor received nearly £300,000 of public money over a six-year period but failed to create one permanent job.
fields.body:
A Liverpool regeneration agency run by a city councillor received nearly £300,000 of public money over a six-year period but failed to create one permanent job.

A scathing report into the regeneration project has revealed that on three separate occasions officers from the local authority voiced their concerns about the running of the agency, headed by Liberal Democrat councillor Frank O'Donohue, who retired from the company in January. But, claims the Labour opposition, the authority has only now moved to withdraw funding. Labour is calling for a full investigation into why the agency continued to receive grant aid when the local authority's own officers had been highly critical of its performance.

They also want the authority to draw up guidelines that prevent anyone whose major income derives from council funding to be barred from standing for election.

Up to his retirement in January, Mr O'Donohue, 65, ran the Valley and Netherley Together Economic Development Trust, a community-based economic development organisation which attempts to encourage social enterprises in those two areas of Liverpool.

Since 1995, the agency has received a total of £270,000 and helped created 20 jobs in a company involved in CCTV, but these jobs are on fixed-term contracts and are not permanent.

In his highly critical report, executive director for regeneration Charlie Parker says after an assessment in 1997 officers made numerous recommendations, including the drawing up of a long-term business plan, which had not been done.

Two years later officers found that progress had been slow and suggested a qualified agency be brought in to help. A year later, in February 2000, council officers decided the firm was unlikely to succeed.

In the report, Mr Parker says: "The organisation has not demonstrated any move towards self-sustainability, has failed to deliver agreed outputs and it is considered that further financial assistance does not reflect an effective use of public money."

Labour's economic development spokesman, councillor Malcolm Kennedy, said: "There are a lot on unanswered questions, such as why it has been left so long to do anything about this business.

"What is an issue is that political parties should not be putting people forward as candidates whose major income comes from public funds and that is something we are approaching the authority about."

The council has now decided to stop funding the regeneration project but has made £16,000 available as a contingency fund to cover any outstanding liabilities.

Mr O'Donahue could not be contacted for comment.

fields.headline: Women turn to internet for sex
fields.trailText:
8.30am: Women are increasingly using computers as sex aids, according to eye-opening research from the BBC, reports Amy Vickers.
Useful link: allabouteve.co.uk
fields.body:
Women are increasingly using computers as sex aids, according to eye-opening research from the BBC.

Four out of 10 women surveyed by Eve magazine's website, Allabouteve.co.uk, said they visit sex websites, with a third doing so in the company of their partner.

While 63% said they were interested in getting online tips for a better sex life, 78% said they would steer clear of sex chat rooms.

Cybersex also got the thumbs down with 84% rejecting it out of hand and 87% stating they would not be interested in finding a sexual partner online.

However, visiting sex sites is largely seen as something that will help enhance an existing relationship rather than a way of meeting new partners.

More than half said they were interested in advice and support on sex, 46% said they would buy sex books, toys or videos online, and 40% said they were interested in using the internet to explore different sexual practices.

The survey polled more than 1,100 people, of which 65% were married, 70% were aged 26-45, 96% were heterosexual and 48% had children.
