webTitle: London listing will give Ebookers homely feel

fields.headline: London listing will give Ebookers homely feel
fields.standfirst: More internet news
fields.trailText: Online travel firm Ebookers.com is braving turbulent market conditions for hi-tech stocks by joining the London stock exchange today. By Julia Snoddy.
fields.body:
Ebookers.com, the online travel firm, is braving turbulent market conditions for hi-tech stocks by joining the London stock exchange today.

The London-based firm is already listed on Frankfurt's Neuer Markt and America's Nasdaq.

"We are better known in the UK than in any other country in the world so we would rather list in our home country," said chief executive Dinesh Dhamija.

Ebookers, which was worth $730m at the height of the dot.com boom in March last year, has since seen its value drop to $63m. Its shares begin trading in London at about 100p.

It had been seeking a London placing to give it access to future funding from British-based investors and to raise its profile.

"The move brings us closer to our investor base in our largest market," the company said. "It is expected to allow us access to institutional funds that could not previously buy Ebookers.com stock."

The company will retain its listings on Nasdaq and the Neuer Markt and none of the directors has any plans to sell shares.

Ebookers, which raised $45m from European institutional investors last July, said it had enough funds in the bank to take it to cash flow-positive status at the end of this year or beginning of 2002. It expected to be profitable shortly after that, said Mr Dhamija.

fields.headline: BBC2 downsizes dot.com drama
fields.trailText:
8.30am: BBC2 dot.com start-up drama Attachments is to return in a shorter 30-minute version for its second series this autumn. By Jason Deans.
Useful link: Seethru.co.uk
fields.body:
BBC2 dot.com start-up drama Attachments is to return in a shorter 30-minute version for its second series this autumn.

Creator Tony Garnett and the BBC2 controller, Jane Root, took the decision to cut Attachments down from 50 to 30-minute episodes after disappointing ratings for the first run last autumn.

Attachments averaged just 1.2m and a 5% share - less than half BBC2's average share for 2000 of 10.8% - across 10 weeks on Tuesday night from late September.

"Attachments is going to be coming back in a 30-minute guise on BBC2 later this year," a BBC spokesman confirmed.

Ms Root ordered two 10-part series of the show when she originally commissioned it last year.

It was not yet decided whether Attachments would still return as a 10-parter, the spokesman said. "They are working on the scripts right now," he added.

Attachments followed the trials and tribulations of Mike, a young dot.com entrepreneur attempting to turn Seethru.co.uk, the cutting-edge music site he started in his bedroom, into a viable internet content business.

The show was commissioned while the dot.com bubble was still growing, but by the time it was broadcast last autumn the internet crash was well underway and the public's love affair with all things new media had turned sour.

Mr Garnett is a legendary drama producer with a track record running from Cathy Come Home in the 1960s to This Life and the Cops in the 1990s, through his company World Productions.

The real life Seethru.co.uk website was launched when the series was broadcast and year and has been maintained as an independently functioning content site since then.

Creator Tony Garnett and the BBC2 controller, Jane Root, took the decision to cut Attachments down from 50 to 30-minute episodes after disappointing ratings for the first run last autumn. Attachments averaged just 1.2m and a 5% share - less than half BBC2's average share for 2000 of 10.8% - across 10 weeks on Tuesday night from late September. "Attachments is going to be coming back in a 30-minute guise on BBC2 later this year," a BBC spokesman confirmed. fields.headline: Club websites wooed by 3-D system that leaves fans with no argument
fields.standfirst: More internet news
fields.trailText: Arguments between fans about controversial goals could become a thing of the past thanks to revolutionary technology, writes Vivek Chaudhary.
fields.body:
Arguments between football fans about controversial goals and offsides could become a thing of the past thanks to revolutionary technology that provides a unique insight into key moments of football matches.

Using missile tracing technology, experts from the Israeli computer company ORADNet have been able to transform ordinary footage from football matches into three-dimensional graphic images, similar to those used in football video games, allowing the viewer to watch the action from any angle, even through the players' eyes.

The system, called TOPlay, could clear up controversial incidents in a match, such as whether or not the ball crossed the goalline, as they could be observed from several different angles.

The company is negotiating with a number of football clubs, including Liverpool and Manchester United, about making the system available on their official websites. Fans would then be able to view and review controversial moments on their computer, making the need to rush down to the pub for intense postmatch debate slightly less pressing.

ORADNet is also negotiating with Fifa, world football's governing body, about setting up a database on the internet of all goals scored in World Cup tournaments. This would allow supporters to observe, in 3-D and from a number of different angles, every goal scored in the tournament since it was first televised in 1954.

The company unveiled its new system in London last week, showing in 3-D the controversial goal scored by Diego Maradona against England during the 1986 World Cup. Although it will come as no surprise to England fans, the graphic image clearly shows the Argentine player using his hand.

A similar system has been used on occasions by football experts on satellite television for their football coverage. ORADNet officials say that the attraction of TOPlay is that it would be available to ordinary fans, who could return home from a match and view controversial incidents or the entire match through their computer in 3-D form and from a choice of different angles.

Aya Evan, marketing direc tor of ORADNet, said: "Technology is progressing all the time and a system like ours could lead to an end to disputes between fans over key moments in a game. It is a unique system because you can choose to see the game through the eyes of a player or the referee.

"It can give the fans an in sight into the game that they currently don't have. At the moment, they are relying on the broadcaster to bring them the pictures. This way, they can view a game or an incident however they want to."

The technology used in TOPlay was initially developed for missile tracking systems by Israeli army engineers Ari Shahir and Miki Tamir, who seized on its marketing potential when they realised that it could be adapted for football.

Ms Evan said that a number of clubs and broadcasters had shown interest in the system and Fifa was considering using it on its official website to help explain the rules of football. Using TOPlay, incidents could be shown on the website accompanied by a referee's explanation of what the decision should be and why.

She added: "TOPlay would help attract users to websites being run by football clubs and Fifa."

webTitle: ITV revamps ONdigital in attempt to rival BSkyB

fields.headline: ITV revamps ONdigital in attempt to rival BSkyB
fields.trailText: ITV is overhauling the loss-making pay TV business ONdigital in a bid to create a more powerful rival to Rupert Murdoch's BSkyB. By David Teather.
fields.body:
ITV is overhauling the loss-making pay television business ONdigital with the aim of creating a more powerful rival to Rupert Murdoch's BSkyB.

Carlton Communications and Granada, the shareholders in ONdigital, hope to better exploit the relationship between the struggling operation and ITV, Britain's most watched channel. The ONdigital brand name is be phased out and replaced with the more recognisable ITV Digital.

The restructuring will be overseen by Stuart Prebble, who runs ONdigital and will later this week be named chief executive of the ITV network, a post which has been vacant for the past 15 months.

Mr Prebble will be given a remit across the existing free-to-air services, the pay-TV operation and the soon to be launched website ITV.com. His job will also include beefing up the ITV2 digital channel and overseeing the launch of a series of new channels, the first of which will be ITV Sport.

The job will catapult Mr Prebble, a former producer of the current affairs programme World in Action, into one of the most powerful jobs in British media. He joined ONdigital in July 1999 after a 25-year career in TV which be gan as a graduate trainee at the BBC.

The overhaul is the result of Carlton and Granada taking control of ITV last summer when they bought the three ITV franchises owned by Lord Hollick's United News & Media. In doing so, they fully aligned the ownership and interests of ITV and ONdigital allowing better use of brands and cross-promotion.

Discussions have been going on behind the scenes to strengthen their relationship for the past nine months. The two also hope to reduce costs by working more closely together which could result in job losses.

The attempt to build tighter links between ONdigital and ITV comes as at a critical time for the pay TV business which is finding it difficult to compete with the vast resources of BSkyB.

The business is the world's first digital TV operation to use ordinary aerials instead of satellite dishes or cable. Carlton and Granada hoped the service would appeal to middle England, a market it assumed would want more TV channels but not necessarily the 200 or so on offer from BSkyB or the dish that comes with it. ONdigital offers about a quarter of that number.

But figures due to be published on Wednesday will show ONdigital's growth slowing in the first three months of the year, during which it added only around 50,000 customers. The company has 1m subscribers and appears to have given up hopes of reaching its target of hitting 2m by the end of 2002. BSkyB, the market leader, has more than 5m customers.

Subscribers are also abandoning ONdigital at a faster rate than BSkyB. Its churn rate, the percentage of cus tomers giving up their subscriptions, is understood to be between 20-25%.

Carlton and Granada are under pressure from investors to cap the amount of money they are pouring into ONdigital. When the pair unveiled the platform in May 1998, they said it would need £300m funding before it reached breakeven, but that figure has escalated to £1.2bn. ONdigital has come under severe pressure from the aggressive tactics of BSkyB and was forced to match its expensive giveaway of the set top boxes needed to receive digital signals.

Regulations preventing a full merger of Carlton and Granada will be removed by the forthcoming Communications Bill but competition law would prevent a deal taking place for some time. ITV still accounts for 60% of television advertising despite the arrival of Channel 5 and the proliferation of new digital channels.

A number of candidates turned down the job of ITV Network chief executive last year, a role vacated by Richard Eyre in January 2000. Carlton and Granada put the search on ice after buying United's ITV assets.

fields.headline: BBC experiments with current affairs
fields.trailText:
8.30am: The BBC has commissioned a six-programme current affairs pilot to be called Four by Four, writes Jessica Hodgson.
30.03.2001: Panorama move urged
More BBC stories
fields.body:
The BBC has commissioned a six-programme current affairs pilot to be called Four by Four.

Edited by the head of BBC Manchester's current affairs unit, David Stanford, Four by Four will look at a single story from four different perspectives.

The format would, for example, allow a farmer, an animal rights activist, a city dweller and a vet to have their say on the foot and mouth crisis.

The programme will be broadcast in July and August and will not be presenter led, although Mr Stanford said it may use some of the BBC's higher-profile current affairs and news reporters.

He said it would be "highly packaged and glossy, popular current affairs", but would mix short-form, fast turnaround programmes with more investigative issues.

"We could do either four angles on a story, or four different stories on a single theme," he said.

Four by Four will air on Monday night at 7.30pm, the slot occupied by current affairs shows like Kenyon Confronts, Crime Squad and Hard Cash.

The BBC has been experimenting for some time with different current affairs formats in a bid to find an enduring popular format.

Head of current affairs Peter Horrocks has expressed his intention to develop a new generation of strong, popular current affairs programmes.

The corporation's decision to move its flagship current affairs programme Panorama to Monday night was read by critics as evidence of a lack of confidence in the programme, and the BBC is still under pressure to reinstate the programme.

webTitle: Does the media circus make disasters worse?

fields.headline: Does the media circus make disasters worse?
fields.standfirst:
BBC man accuses camera crews of endangering lives in race to get best Mozambique flood pictures

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: A BBC newsman has accused camera crews of endangering lives in race to get the best Mozambique flood pictures, write Matt Wells and Steven Morris.
fields.body:
Dramatic images of flood victims being pulled from treetops alerted the world to a disaster in Mozambique. But a BBC correspondent who covered the crisis has suggested that the race to get the best TV pictures may have had tragic consequences.

Air turbulence caused by the helicopters hired by television crews to film rescue operations almost certainly blew away some who would otherwise have been saved, according to the corporation's respected foreign affairs reporter David Shukman.

He said: "Who knows ... such was the power of the downdraft, the enormous forces of the wind produced by the rotor blades from all those helicopters that it is more than likely that a few - possibly more - hungry, exhausted Mozambicans who had been sheltering in those trees were blown out of them. While everybody was focusing on the winching to safety of one or two people from one tree, all the others waiting in nearby trees were at risk," he said.

Speaking on a BBC World Service documentary being broadcast today, Shukman says it is "agony for a journalist to talk about" such events.

The pictures - including those of a woman who gave birth in a tree shortly before being rescued - delivered a huge boost to the aid operation. But Shukman expresses concern that lives may have been lost in the process.

Shukman's remarks have caused controversy among other correspondents and news organisations who challenge him to back up his claims with evidence.

His remarks raise serious questions - from which journalists often shy away - about the role of media organisations in high-profile disasters.

Martin Bell, the independent MP and former BBC correspondent, said he found the claims "troubling". He said: "Journalists have extreme responsibility. There is always the danger that television especially affects the situation it is supposed to be reporting by the mere fact of its presence. In Mozambique the helicopters were being used to take pictures when perhaps they could have been used to rescue people."

Mr Bell said he once had to decide whether to use his vehicle to help refugees flee a disaster or to get the story out. He convinced himself that the right course was to let the world know what was happening.

War correspondent Kate Adie said it was an "age old problem". She said: "You weigh up the risks but you just get to where you have to to get the story."

Broadcasters from rival organisations doubted that the helicopters had caused any deaths. Broadcaster Jon Snow said: "I think it sounds rather fanciful. I think he's missed the main point of the story. Journalists were there because it was so easy to hire a helicopter and get there. The debate to be had is how we select the stories which are covered."

Andy Rex, a cameraman whose work with ITN journalist Mark Austin on last year's floods, won them plaudits and awards, said: "At no time did we see anyone put in danger by the helicopters."

Privately ITN sources expressed surprise at Shukman's claims and called on him to provide details to back them up. One well-placed source said: "If he has no evidence it seems irresponsible to make these claims."

Aid agencies were quick to point out that their jobs were made much easier by the coverage - though some did say it had become difficult for them to hire helicopters because the presence of the media had pushed the prices up.

Jean-Michel Piedagnel, executive director for Medicins Sans Frontieres, UK, said: "It is crucial that journalists cover events like the floods. The world has to be made aware. I have seen a lot of journalists act with courage to get to a story. Sometimes mistakes are made but we all make mistakes."

A spokeswoman for Oxfam said: "The world would not have responded as it did had the media not given it the prominence it did."

In the programme, which is part of the World Service's Omnibus series, Shukman suggests the image of the baby born in the tree created a false impression on viewers. "We reach out for a kind of intimacy, we really want to know an individual story and this was a classic individual story. But it is a false intimacy."

The programme reveals ambivalent attitudes to the pictures from the floods. Some believe the images of white South African airmen rescuing black Mozambican villagers reinforced the racial perceptions of western news editors who put the pictures to the top of newscasts around the world.

Other images of rescue operations by Mozambique's navy did not command the same prominence, it was argued.

Stella Orakwue, a Nigerian-born journalist who writes on African affairs from London, expresses particular concern about the images of the woman who gave birth shortly before being rescued. "I thought it was grotesque, I thought it was horrible, I thought it was vile. I was not one of the people at the time who thought it was noble or uplifting, demonstrating the strength of the human spirit. I thought it was absolutely shocking and appalling that any woman would be forced to give birth in the tree.

"There is a real problem with this image because of course it galvanised people into donating more money. My problem with that image is why did you have to see an African woman giving birth in a tree before you can be drawn to the calamity that was affecting hundreds of thousands of Africans, not just her?"

What the media say

'It is more than likely a few Mozambicans were blown out of trees. While everybody was focusing on the winching to safety of one or two people, others were at risk'
David Shukman, BBC

'It is crucial journalists cover events like the floods. The world has to be made aware'
Jean-Michel Piedagnel, Médicins Sans Frontières

'I think it sounds rather fanciful. The debate to be had is how we select the stories which are covered'
Jon Snow, broadcaster

'At no time did we see anyone put in danger by helicopters. The South African military was doing a great job. People were holding their babies up to the helicopters'
Andy Rex, ITN cameraman

fields.headline: Ken must be cannier
fields.standfirst: The mayor has corporate responsibilities
fields.trailText: The next couple of weeks will be a testing time for Ken Livingstone, not just as mayor of London but also as an ongoing and future player in national politics.
fields.body:
The next couple of weeks will be a testing time for Ken Livingstone, not just as mayor of London but also as an ongoing and future player in national politics. Realising any ambitions he may harbour for national office depends on choices he must shortly make - on the tube, industrial action by its workers and May day. Last year he as good as condoned violence and mayhem in the capital on May 1. This year he has appeared to urge the Metropolitan police to make preventative arrests. Such sentiments are not going to win him friends on the left, whence has recently come criticism of his use of public relations consultants and his generally emollient tone.

But Mr Livingstone knows two things his erstwhile friends on the left will find it hard to accept. One is that the mayor of London has to be a friend of business if he is to appear remotely credible as the capital's advocate at home and abroad - and that means stopping anti-corporate violence next week. The other is that Mr Livingstone's national aspirations depend on his acquiring the same kind of broad base, inside and outside the Labour party, that Tony Blair built up in the 1990s. Espousing anarchy does not just put off the right; it frightens people in the middle, too. In London the people in the middle ride the tube, but so far Mr Livingstone's political instincts have led him in curiously different directions in terms of winning their support.

The public wants a transport system publicly owned and operated under unified public management; they, if not Gordon Brown and his colleagues, think Hatfield has lessons for London's underground. The London mayor might have done a better job of explaining why the apparently arcane discussions going on between would-be tube manager Bob Kiley and the government (which for most practical purposes means the Treasury) are in fact about clear matters of principle. Instead, by siding with the rail unions in their campaign of disruption, which continues next week, he gives ammunition to those in the Labour leadership who say their public-private partnership is the only way to avoid 1970s-style domination by producers. The mayor of London - especially one with wider ambitions - should shoulder his public service responsibilities, condemn the unions' self-defeating stoppages and use his still high credibility with the public to wage political and legal war with the government over control of the underground.

One is that the mayor of London has to be a friend of business if he is to appear remotely credible as the capital's advocate at home and abroad - and that means stopping anti-corporate violence next week. The other is that Mr Livingstone's national aspirations depend on his acquiring the same kind of broad base, inside and outside the Labour party, that Tony Blair built up in the 1990s. Espousing anarchy does not just put off the right; it frightens people in the middle, too. In London the people in the middle ride the tube, but so far Mr Livingstone's political instincts have led him in curiously different directions in terms of winning their support. The public wants a transport system publicly owned and operated under unified public management; they, if not Gordon Brown and his colleagues, think Hatfield has lessons for London's underground. The London mayor might have done a better job of explaining why the apparently arcane discussions going on between would-be tube manager Bob Kiley and the government (which for most practical purposes means the Treasury) are in fact about clear matters of principle. Instead, by siding with the rail unions in their campaign of disruption, which continues next week, he gives ammunition to those in the Labour leadership who say their public-private partnership is the only way to avoid 1970s-style domination by producers. The mayor of London - especially one with wider ambitions - should shoulder his public service responsibilities, condemn the unions' self-defeating stoppages and use his still high credibility with the public to wage political and legal war with the government over control of the underground.

webTitle: The real relationships of website users

fields.headline: Through the looking glas
fields.standfirst: Consumer focus groups are one way of testing the value of web advertising. Martin Baker watches one from behind a one-way mirror - and it is a depressing sight for marketing departments
fields.trailText: Consumer focus groups are one way of testing the value of web advertising. Martin Baker watches one from behind a one-way mirror - and it is a depressing sight for marketing departments
fields.body:
How sad is this? I'm watching people logging on to the internet. I'm staring at two men in their mid-20s and two slightly older women, who are all staring into computer screens. This is the virtual world's equivalent of watching grass grow - and I'm finding it interesting.

But that's maybe because of the voyeuristic thrill of it all. I'm standing, observing but unobserved, behind a huge 12ft x 6ft two-way mirror. It looks like a lightly electrified cinema screen, set before two rows of tip-up seats and a well-stocked fridge for the use of advertising executives and clients as they watch their guinea pigs.

But we are not here for voyeuristic thrills. The whole purpose of this session at the offices of the leading advertising agency BMP in Paddington, London, is to get rid of the idea of the internet as something that is sexy but aimless and unproductive. Gone are the days of companies saying "we've got a lot of money and this is a whole new sector, so let's suck it and see. Whoopee!"

Now it's path-to-profit time, and the internet industry is learning that if it doesn't work, it doesn't eat. Advertising, in particular, has to be seen to work to justify the spend from a marketing director's budget, which is why I'm behind the screen, watching the consumer group brought together by Billco, the new-media agency subsidiary of BMP.

The old economy and the economics of the corner shop have caught up with, and publicly disembowelled, last year's cyperbole. The businesses and ideas left standing now that the hype has exploded have to satisfy some very serious, old-economy tests. BMP is generally regarded as being a very serious advertising agency, and Billco's managing director, Alison Parker, is leading the consumer group through a classic qualitative research session.

Parker asks the group about their general use of the internet and whether they use sites offering holiday services (the client is in this sector), then asks them to go online and play with the site. The users have the classic technophile profile. They use the research engine to squeeze comparative value out of the market. And they are not afraid to send their credit card numbers out into the ether. One of the women used a shopping site to buy a Dyson cleaner at a discount of £60 on its high-street price, and had the appliance delivered within two days. One of the men has used the net to search out the best price for a car. Both men and one of the women go online for football news, and everyone agrees that Amazon has a good site - especially if you belong to a book club and want to crib a review.

All this confidence and enthusiasm, not to mention the exquisite bits of prawn toast, are reasons to be cheerful. But there is, of course, a downside to this consumer sophistication: "I never give real information," says one of the guys. "I've got a duplicate email that's related to me, but gets all the dross that you can get from the internet. I bought some car insurance over the net, and then got bombarded by Norwich Union trying to sell me personal loans. I'm also pissed off about not being able to unsubscribe from lastminute.com. I've tried and tried, but I just can't get rid of them."

Leaving aside the possibility that the market may well solve his lastminute problem for him in the next few weeks, the idea of consumers setting up virtual doppelgangers on message systems like Hotmail and Excite is depressing news for all those carefully targeted mailshots and cleverly calibrated marketing strategies. It's also a bit depressing for the likes of Hotmail to realise that so much of their traffic is just dross for decoys.

This is the heart of the problem - so much dross, so little gold. The conversation on the look and feel of the site Billco is testing is particularly interesting on this point. Those still enthusiastic about the internet - and I am one - often make the comparison between today's online industry and the early days of television. When ITV was launched, many people felt that screen advertising would never be taken seriously. It is now of course the single most important advertising medium. So the obvious parallel to draw is that as consumers become better acclimatised to and more trusting of their PC screens, online advertising will, at the very least, become far more important. But anyone who thinks that golden scenario is just round the corner is a couple of pixels short of a liquid crystal display. The quality and power of the computers used to go online varies massively. Given the kit most consumers have in their homes and offices, online advertising is destined to remain the poor relation of television for some time.

"At the risk of stating the screamingly obvious, a banner ad on a website is not going to have the same impact as a 60-second television commercial," says Parker. "What's important is that what's on the internet is integrated into the brand's overall marketing strategy. The website is another opportunity for a brand to enter into a relationship with the consumer, so the language, colour and functionality must be right for the brand. The site for Polly Pocket is very pink and playful, whereas the site we built recently for Haystack (an online media-agency search facility) is about professionalism and speedy results - in red and black. If a site doesn't give users what they want, they'll turn off."

The consumer group has now done just that. It expresses a preference for one of the sites competing with the client's. This one is "friendlier", more "human" than the client's site. As a consequence, the group is less resistant to "paying". They see themselves paying with time, not money. The alternative currency, of course, is information. And it's now clearly established that unless the registration process is very subtly handled (let the user in to play around straight away, and keep the questions as short, few and easy as possible) much of that coinage will be counterfeit.

Counterfeit details or not, the consumer research is real. Who knows? If the advertising industry really does find a way to make the new economy jump through the old economy's hoops, we might one day end up with new media companies that actually do boring, old-economy things like make money.

fields.headline: Favourite son heads home for winning return
fields.standfirst: Jon Brodkin  hears the Leeds manager praise the readiness to learn of his captain Rio Ferdinand, who scored at Upton Park
fields.trailText: Despite scoring the goal which killed off his former club and kept Leeds challenging for third place, Rio Ferdinand remains popular at West Ham.
fields.body:
Ninety minutes after the final whistle Rio Ferdinand was sitting in his car down a side street less than 100 yards from Upton Park. As West Ham fans ran eagerly towards him, each request for an autograph or picture was granted patiently and with a smile. The words David O'Leary had spoken earlier sprang to mind.

Near the dressing rooms Ferdinand once called home the Leeds manager was discussing what made his £18m signing a potentially great centre-half. It was not just talent, he said, but personality: a friendly, down-to-earthness mixed with steely desire.

"From the first time I gave an autograph I wanted to make sure people had a reason to have it," was how Ferdinand put it. "I have always tried to be the best." The number of programmes shoved through his car window meant his signature at the very least should be perfect.

Despite scoring the goal which killed off his former club and kept Leeds challenging for third place, Ferdinand remains popular at West Ham. As his mother waited in the passenger's seat for the admirers to disperse, the picture was far from the stereotypical arrogant, moneyed star. Ferdinand is not labouring under the illusion he has arrived.

"Last night in the hotel he was asking me about players I played against," O'Leary said. "He wants to talk about football and he wants to learn. He's the last off the training pitch.

"The first time I met Rio I got a good feel for him. The questions he asked me were all about how he could improve himself, not about money. I point out things to him all the time. You can get young players nowadays who take it very personally if you try to tell them things constructively. Rio takes it in the way that I'm trying to improve him."

To suggest that Ferdinand returned and gave a masterful display would be stretching the point. He was solid but unspectacular against a lightweight West Ham who remain a victory from safety.

Only after David Batty's 50th-minute dismissal for elbowing Joe Cole did they threaten to deny Leeds a fifth straight Premiership win. O'Leary claimed there was no contact for the red card, which left one wondering what happens when Batty does catch someone.

Yet, if the challenge facing Ferdinand was too weak to judge fully his progress since he moved north in November, O'Leary has no doubt the 22-year-old has come on.

West Ham's manager Harry Redknapp had a point when he said, tongue firmly in cheek, that Ferdinand "was absolutely crap here; he couldn't trap a ball and since he's gone there they've made him into a good player".

But O'Leary sees improvements in every area. "He can definitely be the best centre-half in England," the Irishman said. "He's not that far off it now and he can be outstanding in Europe."

Leeds themselves are proving outstanding in Europe and at home. Their trip to Arsenal on May 5 could be decisive in determining whether third place goes to Elland Road, Ipswich or Liverpool. Here they were not at their finest but they were the better organised and more lively side and the speed with which they closed down in midfield was vital.

"We cannot seem to beat teams when they make it hard for us," lamented Cole, whose regular inclusion next season has been cast in doubt by Redknapp's determination to play 4-4-2. The manager told the fanzine Over Land and Sea that Cole or Paolo di Canio will have to stand down: "You cannot get them both in if you want to play the way I want."

Too many of Redknapp's recent signings look short of quality, and he wants a forward, centre-half and a left-sided player in the summer.

He must have watched enviously as Harry Kewell crossed for Robbie Keane to score early on. Ferdinand barely celebrated his looping 47th-minute header and departed, as he arrived, to a warm reception after Nigel Martyn had been stretched four times.

Man of the match Nigel Martyn (Leeds Utd).

webTitle: Tokyo's karaoke man wins party vote

fields.headline: Tokyo's karaoke man wins party vote
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: A divorced former health minister with a penchant for singing karaoke love songs is surging ahead of a conservative martial arts expert in the race to replace the outgoing prime minister of Japan, Yoshiro Mori.
fields.body:
A divorced former health minister with a penchant for singing karaoke love songs is surging ahead of a conservative martial arts expert in the race to replace the outgoing prime minister of Japan, Yoshiro Mori.

Junichiro Koizumi, a political maverick, started out as second-favourite in the election for the new Liberal Democratic party leader, and therefore almost certainly the new Japanese prime minister.

But in early primary ballots of the party rank and file over the weekend, Mr Koizumi won more than 85% of the regional votes. The winner will be decided tomorrow in a poll of 346 MPs and 141 regional delegates.

The early returns place heavy pressure on the initial favourite, the former prime minister Ryutaro Hashimoto, to drop out of the running.

"It's beyond what I imagined," said Mr Koizumi, after hearing that he had won 20 of the 23 regions declared so far. "The simmering magma is close to the point of eruption."

The leadership race also involves the economics minister, Taro Aso, and a former construction minister, Shizuka Kamei.

Mr Koizumi, who failed in leadership bids in 1995 and 1998, is considered a loose cannon by fellow MPs, but among the party's 2.4m members he is seen as a new broom.

Although he is 59 and a member of the political aristocracy - his father and grandfather were cabinet ministers - he claims the mantle of reform and pledges to "Change the LDP, Change Japan".

Departing from the hidebound traditions of a political machine in power for almost half a century, he has split from his faction and pledged to appoint more women and young politicians to the cabinet if he becomes prime minister.

Compared to the dark suits and side partings of most of the LDP's elderly leaders, Mr Koizumi is known for his flamboyant style. His grey hair is styled into a raffish wave and he says his two heroes are Winston Churchill and the lead singer of X-Japan, an outlandish pop group.

Opinion polls claim that 55% of floating voters think he is the best choice, against 8% for Mr Hashimoto. He is also the first choice among foreign investors who are impressed by his pledge to privatise Japan's huge postal savings business and introduce painful reforms of the financial sector.

Mr Hashimoto - as leader of the LDP's biggest faction - would normally expect an advantage among MPs in tomorrow's poll. But party elders have admitted that Mr Hashimoto received such a drubbing at the weekend that he may not be able to recover. Mr Hashimoto acknowledges as much, but vowed to fight on.

If there is no clear winner in the first ballot, the LDP will hold a run-off, with Mr Kamei expected to act as kingmaker.

webTitle: Italian gourmets campaign to keep pasta on the menu

fields.headline: Italian gourmets campaign to keep pasta on the menu
fields.standfirst: Special report: globalisation
fields.trailText: Guardians of Italian food are preparing to wade into battle against a tide of sushi, curries and burgers which they say is sweeping away pasta.
fields.body:
Guardians of Italian food are preparing to wade into battle against a tide of sushi, curries and burgers which they say is sweeping away pasta.

The Academy of Italian Cooking will meet at the Umbrian medieval hill fortress of Gubbio tomorrow to plot a counterattack.

Globalisation's downfall will be toasted between courses of tagliolini with anchovies, white truffles, boar, mixed meats with cress and pigeon with olives.

Action is urgent as Italians are succumbing to the siren call of the new, said Giuseppe Dell'Osso, the academy's spokesman. "Globalisation is driving our country's traditional dishes to extinction," he told La Repubblica.

Restaurants and catering schools were exalting Japanese, Indian, Chinese, Arabic and American dishes above homegrown delicacies.

"They are losing typical plates such as bucatini all'amatriciana," said Mr Dell'Osso. Foreigners, and Italians who returned from abroad, were laying traps for the national palate with alien concotions.

"Alarm, alarm," said La Repubblica. "Even Italy is a conquered land."

Chefs scorned the initiative as xenophobic scare tactics which ignored the fact that Italian cuisine had evolved over centuries with infusions of spices, vegetables and meats.

"This is the history of a cui sine with soul, not an invasion," said Livia Iaccarini, of Don Alfonso, a restaurant with three Michelin stars.

Andrea Fenoglio said his list of non-Italian dishes at his Sissi di Merano restaurant was no cause for concern. "We still know how to prepare tortellini in brodo."

The academy was unlikely to be reassured. Purists of Italian food and drink have become increasingly defensive.

Starbucks, the American coffee house chain, announced this month that it would open outlets in Italy next year, hot on the heels of ambitious expansions by McDonald's and Burger King.

Gourmets, traditional restaurants and political activists have gathered under the banner Slow Food, a movement based in Turin.

Last October riot police mobilised to protect McDonald's outlets from thousands of demonstrators who chanted "Better a day of tortellini than 100 days of hamburgers."

webTitle: Quebec rioters cry foul, but free trade deal is done

fields.headline: Quebec rioters cry foul, but free trade deal is done
fields.trailText: Leaders of 34 countries in the Americas laid the groundwork for the creation of the world's largest free trade zone yesterday. It is due to start in 2005 and is backed by billions of dollars of aid. The Declaration of Quebec was hammered out amid accusations that the treatment of protesters against the deal violated human rights.
fields.body:
Leaders of 34 countries in the Americas laid the groundwork for the creation of the world's largest free trade zone yesterday. It is due to start in 2005 and is backed by billions of dollars of aid. The Declaration of Quebec was hammered out amid accusations that the treatment of protesters against the deal violated human rights.

At their closed meeting, the leaders also agreed that attacking poverty and democratic elections should be prerequisites for membership of the Free Trade Area of the Americas.

The Inter-American Development Bank pledged more than $40bn (£29bn) in loans and other aid to help alleviate poverty in Latin America and the Caribbean before the next summit of the Americas in 2004. The World Bank is also to offer between $12bn and $16bn in loans.

Mindful of the inequalities of the region, the leaders committed themselves to halving the number of people living in extreme poverty by the year 2015. They didn't say how they would achieve that.

More than 400 people were arrested by the Canadian authorities during three days of protests against the proposed free trade zone. More than 120 people were hurt, including two policemen, as protesters objected to the proposed pact and the three-metre steel and concrete fence closing off the centre of the 17th-century city.

The Ligue des Droits et Libertés, a Quebec-based rights watchdog, condemned police for firing plastic bullets and tear gas without provocation.

Sam Boskey, a member of the league, said the police had used a "Niagara of tear gas" to drive back protesters, many of whom were staging peaceful protests. In one instance, an observer had witnessed a police officer use a stun gun against a protester who was already on the ground. webTitle: Kashmir: Daughter of Faith who will fight the holy war for ever

fields.headline: Daughter of Faith who will fight the holy war for ever
fields.standfirst:
For hardliners trying to Islamise the Kashmiri struggle, the only way to win freedom from India is by force of arms

Special report: India and Pakistan
fields.trailText: The voice is clear. "My belief is that Kashmir will get liberated, inshallah (God willing), only by the armed struggle." Her words are concise, but she betrays a hint of nervousness. Asiya Andrabi is not accustomed to giving interviews - least of all to foreign, male journalists.
fields.body:
The voice is clear. "My belief is that Kashmir will get liberated, inshallah (God willing), only by the armed struggle." Her words are concise, but she betrays a hint of nervousness. Asiya Andrabi is not accustomed to giving interviews - least of all to foreign, male journalists.

"The way these political leaders are working, Kashmir will never get free from India. The freedom struggle is much more important to us than the peace moves they are talking about."

As she speaks, only her hazel eyes are visible through a peephole in her burqa, the Islamic veil. Her one-year-old son is playing on her lap, sometimes pulling at the burqa, causing it to ride up and catch repeatedly on her lower eyelids.

Does she support the killing of Indian police and soldiers? "Not only the police, but all the Indian politicians, too. We support that." Does she back a call made by a Kashmiri militant group for the assassination of India's prime minister? "We'd be very happy, inshallah .."

Asiya Andrabi is the head of Dukhtran-e-Millat, Daughters of the Faith, a women's Islamic group in Indian-administered Kashmir. It claims no more than a few hundred members. But her views have importance. While her organisation has no direct links with the Pakistan-based armed separatist groups, it shares with them the concept of jihad, of an Islamic holy war, to rid Kashmir of what she describes as Hindu-majority India's "Brahmin imperialism". She's one of the rare voices in Srinagar who speaks what the new, hardline militants think.

Although not herself a fighter, Andrabi has spent time in jail. Her husband has been an armed militant - she prefers the term mujahid - and served a seven-year prison term. They keep on the move, to try to avoid the Indian security forces.

My rendezvous had been arranged through an intermediary. One of Andrabi's associates, a 20-year-old, met me, took the back seat of the car while insisting that I sit in the front, and guided the driver a short distance across Srinagar.

"This is not my home," Asiya Andrabi explained, as she welcomed me into a comfortable middle-class house, and offered a cup of kehwa, the fragrant, spiced Kashmiri tea. "I won't stay here more than an hour. I'm not scared. It's just that if I'm arrested, I can't do my work."

Her work is to Islamise the Kashmiri movement. While many separatist leaders proclaim that their cause is political - to achieve the right of self-determination for the former princely state of Jammu and Kashmir lost when India and Pakistan gained independence in 1947 - Andrabi insists the issue is religious.

"This struggle is purely an Islamic struggle," she argues. "We have sacrificed 80,000 martyrs [the more accepted figure is 30,000 dead in 12 years of insurgency] and we are ready to sacrifice more."

In the Indian-ruled Kashmir valley, which is now 98% Muslim, that message gets a mixed response. Kashmir has a long history of a composite culture, much diminished by the recent flight of the Kashmiri-speaking Hindu minority.

Kashmiriat, the local word for the relaxed Kashmiri outlook on life, encompasses a rather mystical, Sufi-influenced type of Islam. Chants are intoned in the mosques, and there are Islamic shrines, even relics, housed in buildings with an architectural style more akin to central Asia than to the Punjab plains.

All this earns the disapproval of Asiya Andrabi. "I oppose traditional Kashmiri culture," she declares. "We want to return our women to Islamic culture."

Most Kashmiris are ambivalent about the new breed of militant. While Asiya Andrabi is a Kashmiri, many of the like-minded fighters are seen as outsiders, from Pakistan or further afield. Two British Muslims have been among the "guest militants" killed in Kashmir, according to the Indian army.

Ceasefires failing

But the new militants are better equipped and trained, and altogether bolder, as the Indian authorities acknowledge. The armed separatist movement, once close to being humbled by the military, is again showing its mettle.

As a consequence, Srinagar is a violent city. The weekend before last, 10 people were killed in two separate clashes and 10 more died elsewhere in the Kashmir valley. The two ceasefires being observed by Indian security forces have engendered little optimism, because while one is holding, the other is not. For the past five months, the Indian and Pakistani artillery guns facing each other across the line of control have been quiet. But the more crucial ceasefire, with the militants inside Indian-administered Kashmir, has had little effect. The armed separatists have not responded to New Delhi's unilateral initiative.

Separatists divided

The Indian government has offered unconditional talks with Kashmiri groups. The main separatist alliance in Srinagar, the All Parties Hurriyat [Freedom] Conference, has responded cautiously. It wants Pakistan involved, and does not trust Delhi to consider any option which might loosen India's sovereignty over the 5m people of the Kashmir valley.

The mainstream separatists are divided - some want accession to Pakistan, others an independent Kashmir, a prospect widely supported by Kashmiris, however impractical it might be for a remote mountain valley.

Asiya Andrabi has no time for the moderates of the Hurriyat Conference. "We want Pakistan," she says. "Then it will be our first and foremost duty to Islamise Pakistan."

She escorts us to the door. She asks about my children, and I enquire after hers. Her elder son, now eight, was confined with her in jail and she's still angry about that. "When he grows up, I would like him to be a jihadi, and fight for Islam anywhere in the world." Unless the deadlock in Kashmir is broken, Asiya Andrabi's son will not have to search far for his battleground.

Andrew Whitehead presents The World Today on the BBC World Service.

webTitle: Virgin trains to take a tilt at airlines

fields.headline: Virgin trains to take a tilt at airlines
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Manchester and Liverpool will in become the first two cities to be linked with London by 125mph tilting trains in autumn next year, cutting journey times to under two hours.
fields.body:
Manchester and Liverpool will in become the first two cities to be linked with London by 125mph tilting trains in autumn next year, cutting journey times to under two hours.

The 53 trains are part of a £600m deal between Sir Richard Branson's Virgin Trains and its supplier, Angel Trains. Virgin has been struggling to provide an adequate service on the west coast main line between London and Glasgow with old rolling stock on 30-year-old track since it was awarded the franchise four years ago.

Haydn Abbott, Angel's managing director, said yesterday that the tilting train, pioneered in Britain more than 20 years ago, would be put through its paces on a new test track site in Leicestershire later this year. The tilt is required because of the curving nature of the west coast route.

Under Virgin's plans, eight tilting trains will leave Euston every hour. The company said yesterday it was too early to say whether fares would have to be increased.

It has just announced a price rise of almost 10% on its inter-city services. Virgin says it hopes to freeze fares for some time, if passenger numbers return to the level they were before the Hatfield rail crash in October and then start to increase.

Chris Green, Virgin's chief executive, said he was disappointed that Railtrack's timetable for the £6.3bn upgrade of the west coast line had slipped by six months. This would not prevent Virgin running its new trains at speeds of 110mph before the official launch.

Virgin's 15-year franchise on the line, which expires in 2011, is supposed to transform the route from needing a £77m-a-year subsidy from the taxpayer to paying a premium of £220m a year to the Treasury.

Mr Green said that by 2005 the speed of the tilting trains would be increased to 140mph, with 11 trains an hour each way. "This effectively creates a five-minute metro frequency all day on the west coast which is intended to claw back business from airlines and the motorways."

Every seat will be equipped with an audio entertainment system, and there will be electronic seat reservations and sophisticated passenger information displays.

Mr Green said the service would allow Britain to catch up with other parts of Europe. "We have let our sights drop. The first advanced passenger train in the world was produced in Britain in December 1979 and broke the UK speed record at 160mph."

webTitle: Pro-Chechen rebels hold hostages in Istanbul

fields.headline: Pro-Chechen rebels hold hostages in Istanbul
fields.standfirst: Special report: crisis in Chechnya
fields.trailText: Pro-Chechen rebels armed with automatic rifles and shotguns stormed into a hotel in central Istanbul late last night and seized hostages, according to local news reports.
fields.body:
Pro-Chechen rebels armed with automatic rifles and shotguns stormed into a hotel in central Istanbul late last night and seized hostages, according to local news reports.

The rebels were apparently demanding to speak to the Turkish interior minister, Saadettin Tantan, the Anatolia news agency said.

Hundreds of police surrounded the Swissotel in central Istanbul early this morning and at least six ambulances waited outside.

A local television station showed scenes of Turkish police crouching behind cars, slowly approaching the hotel. It was not clear if anyone was injured or how many hostages were taken.

A hotel worker, Alisan Ercan, said he heard gunshots and saw four or five gunmen in the lobby as he ran out of the hotel. Hotel guests were hiding between tables in the hotel lobby, he said.

Police said there were 15 to 20 gunmen involved.

fields.headline: Secs in the City
fields.trailText: The working week is routine and repetitive - an endlessly recycled ascent from the despair of Monday morning, through Tuesday and Wednesday's painful drudgery, the light-at-the-end-of the-tunnel on Thursday, right through to the irrepressible joy of Friday afternoon.
fields.body:
The working week is routine and repetitive - an endlessly recycled ascent from the despair of Monday morning, through Tuesday and Wednesday's painful drudgery, the light-at-the-end-of the-tunnel on Thursday, right through to the irrepressible joy of Friday afternoon. But at least everyone knows where they are. Five working days equals two days of torture, one day of limbo, and two days of weekend-anticipating high (well, high-ish) spirits.

Which is why bank holidays mess things up so much. Not that I'm objecting to the extra lie-in. Indeed, if the good people of the banking community want to get together and reward themselves with a few additional random days off - well, go right ahead, lads, as long as the rest of us can join you. You do work so hard for your multibillion pound profits, after all, it's only fair that every once in a while you should have a rest from putting calls on hold for 45 minutes at a time and inexplicably stopping my overdraft facility. Try to pick a different month for the extra holidays this time, though, because there are only so many Mondays to go round and, to be frank, you don't work many of them in May as it is.

No, the problem with bank holidays is that they tamper with my colleagues' internal diaries - a highly regimented and delicate piece of equipment. Last weekend - featuring the bank holiday double whammy of Good Friday and Easter Monday - only made the problem worse. Four days out of the office, especially when coupled with excessive consumption of chocolate and/or alcohol, does not make for a productive workforce. For most of Tuesday, my colleagues could be observed wandering aimlessly around the office, while trying very hard to remember what it was that they were employed to do, which floor they worked on and where exactly they had abandoned that confidential file in the exodus of Thursday night.

Worse, no one knew what mood to be in. Tuesday morning saw the black scowls that are perfectly suited to Monday, but excessive for the second day of the week. We were still feeling as if work had only just started on Wednesday, and then, suddenly, before we'd even had time to relax into it, it was Friday again. Trouble was, it felt so much like Thursday that everyone had left a full day's worth of work piled up to do "before the weekend". All in all, a four-day week is more exhausting than you'd expect. We're just holding out for the next bank holiday, and a chance to recover.

fields.headline: WPM
fields.trailText: Of late, as WPM has scuttled into the office in her pink kitten heels at a barely acceptable number of minutes past nine, she has observed that her thoroughfare has been impeded by thousands of sheets of A4 paper, billowing across the office, like, like ... freshly laundered linen, hung out to dry on a windy day
fields.body:
 Of late, as WPM has scuttled into the office in her pink kitten heels at a barely acceptable number of minutes past nine, she has observed that her thoroughfare has been impeded by thousands of sheets of A4 paper, billowing across the office, like, like ... freshly laundered linen, hung out to dry on a windy day (sorry, WPM has been sniffing the correction fluid again). Really, it's getting so very difficult to wade through, that WPM sometimes wishes she'd worn her wellingtons (although they do get a bit clammy after a while).

Actually what WPM really needs is not wellingtons, but BioRegional. Despite sounding like a herbal laxative, this is, in fact, an environmental charity which recycles your office paper and sells it back to you as high-calibre recycled office stationery. It will even pick up your waste white paper free of charge, and for every three sacks, you will save one tree (which is almost as cuddly as a panda).

The Royal Albert Hall is already at it, as is Lord Mayor of London Ken Livingstone (nice to see him continuing the tradition. London's mayors have always been in favour of recycling projects; indeed historians point to Dick Whittington's decision to "turn again" in the 15th century).

Should you feel similarly inclined, call BioRegional on 020 8773 2376. It's your first step on the road to the Mayoral office.

 Recruitment agency Blue Arrow has written to tell WPM how to "spring-clean her career". Presumably, she was looking a bit cobwebby around the gills. It offered 10 handy pointers for getting a little bit spic and a little bit span.

(i) Clear your desk. Blue Arrow says we should set aside an hour to clean out our desks. WPM assures you, she honestly did set aside an hour ... It's just that now she hasn't the foggiest idea where it was that she set it. She has checked all her pockets and emptied out her handbag and has returned empty-handed. Most likely it is mouldering under that big pile of unrecycled paper on her desk, along with that half-eaten cheese and tomato barmcake from last week. It will crawl out eventually.

(ii) Is your working environment comfortable? Blue Arrow says we shouldn't put up with "a squeaky old chair or broken stapler". We should approach our managers, apparently. Yes, Blue Arrow, but who do we approach about our squeaky old managers? Hmm?

(iii) Start making lists. WPM has a head start here. She's always making lists. She finds they are the perfect way to make her look as though she is doing something terribly important and terribly organised, even though she is actually working out which member of Westlife she fancies most.

(iv) Don't procrastinate. Bollocks.

(v) Take time out. Blue Arrow says that everyone should find a moment in the day to "stretch your legs, get some fresh air, drink a glass of water". WPM couldn't find a glass of water, so she downed a large gin and tonic instead. She doesn't remember much about the rest of the Blue Arrow spring cleaning pointers. She thinks it was some gubbins about buying a plant and not obsessively checking your email. But frankly it all went a bit hazy ...

 WPM notices that eve magazine has been telling us where to sit in a meeting. Allegedly, we want to be sitting slap-bang opposite the boss. No we don't eve, you idiot. (And frankly, eve, why would WPM want to take advice from you, after that Garden of Eden sacking debacle?) If you sit opposite the grand fromage, you won't be getting no doodling action in meetings anymore. No siree. And there'll be none of that letting your mind nip off to Tesco. No, you'll be too busy sitting bolt upright and nodding, sagely.

WPM recommends that the best place to sit in a meeting is in a different room altogether. When colleagues remark upon your absence from the all-important strategy meeting (now with extra pie-charts!), you should look mildly confused, and mutter that you "wondered where everyone was". You will find this a foolproof plan, which you can use time and time again.

 A gritted-toothed thank you to June Douglas, who has contacted WPM regarding last week's knitting reference. June took issue with WPM's mention of "knit one, pearl one". June says: "A pearl is for wearing, and purl is for knitting." WPM never claimed to be a champion speller, June, she just wanted to get on with her handicrafts in peace. (Tell you what, she doesn't drop a stitch, that June Douglas. Knit-picker).

Despite sounding like a herbal laxative, this is, in fact, an environmental charity which recycles your office paper and sells it back to you as high-calibre recycled office stationery. It will even pick up your waste white paper free of charge, and for every three sacks, you will save one tree (which is almost as cuddly as a panda). The Royal Albert Hall is already at it, as is Lord Mayor of London Ken Livingstone (nice to see him continuing the tradition. London's mayors have always been in favour of recycling projects; indeed historians point to Dick Whittington's decision to "turn again" in the 15th century). Should you feel similarly inclined, call BioRegional on 020 8773 2376. It's your first step on the road to the Mayoral office.  Recruitment agency Blue Arrow has written to tell WPM how to "spring-clean her career". Presumably, she was looking a bit cobwebby around the gills. It offered 10 handy pointers for getting a little bit spic and a little bit span. (i) Clear your desk. Blue Arrow says we should set aside an hour to clean out our desks. WPM assures you, she honestly did set aside an hour ... It's just that now she hasn't the foggiest idea where it was that she set it. She has checked all her pockets and emptied out her handbag and has returned empty-handed. Most likely it is mouldering under that big pile of unrecycled paper on her desk, along with that half-eaten cheese and tomato barmcake from last week. It will crawl out eventually. (ii) Is your working environment comfortable? Blue Arrow says we shouldn't put up with "a squeaky old chair or broken stapler". We should approach our managers, apparently. Yes, Blue Arrow, but who do we approach about our squeaky old managers? Hmm? (iii) Start making lists. WPM has a head start here. She's always making lists. She finds they are the perfect way to make her look as though she is doing something terribly important and terribly organised, even though she is actually working out which member of Westlife she fancies most. (iv) Don't procrastinate. Bollocks. (v) Take time out. Blue Arrow says that everyone should find a moment in the day to "stretch your legs, get some fresh air, drink a glass of water". WPM couldn't find a glass of water, so she downed a large gin and tonic instead. She doesn't remember much about the rest of the Blue Arrow spring cleaning pointers. She thinks it was some gubbins about buying a plant and not obsessively checking your email. But frankly it all went a bit hazy ...  WPM notices that eve magazine has been telling us where to sit in a meeting. Allegedly, we want to be sitting slap-bang opposite the boss. No we don't eve, you idiot. (And frankly, eve, why would WPM want to take advice from you, after that Garden of Eden sacking debacle?) If you sit opposite the grand fromage, you won't be getting no doodling action in meetings anymore. No siree. And there'll be none of that letting your mind nip off to Tesco. No, you'll be too busy sitting bolt upright and nodding, sagely. WPM recommends that the best place to sit in a meeting is in a different room altogether. When colleagues remark upon your absence from the all-important strategy meeting (now with extra pie-charts!), you should look mildly confused, and mutter that you "wondered where everyone was". You will find this a foolproof plan, which you can use time and time again.  A gritted-toothed thank you to June Douglas, who has contacted WPM regarding last week's knitting reference. June took issue with WPM's mention of "knit one, pearl one". June says: "A pearl is for wearing, and purl is for knitting." WPM never claimed to be a champion speller, June, she just wanted to get on with her handicrafts in peace. (Tell you what, she doesn't drop a stitch, that June Douglas. Knit-picker).

webTitle: Do astrologers hold your career answers?

fields.headline: Can astrologers help you to climb the career ladder?
fields.trailText: Are you adrift in the world of work? Need some direction? Career answers could lie in your zodiac, according to research by recruitment agency Pertemps.
fields.body:
Are you adrift in the world of work? Need some direction? Career answers could lie in your zodiac, according to research by recruitment agency Pertemps. A third of job-seekers interviewed felt that clues to their prospects lay in their birth charts, and 6% had seen an astrologer for career advice.

More than a third of respondents felt that knowing a person's star sign could prevent office arguments. Really? And more than half regularly checked horoscopes for advice on their emotional lives. Yet only 9% said they believed what they read. So why resort to horoscopes? After all, Mystic Meg and Russell Grant surely aren't the first names to spring to mind when wondering who to turn to for professional advice? Or are they?

"In order to really understand yourself, you have to have a full reading by a trained astrologer not just read your sign in a newspaper or magazine," says Eileen Hull, spokesperson for Pertemps. Astrologer and tarot reader Carolynn Townsend has been working in her field for 23 years and is keen to point out that "astrology is actually a science". Hmmm.

"Sun signs give a broad picture. For example Capricorns are ambitious and deliberate and will get to the top in the end. This applies equally to a woman wanting to be a good mother or to someone who wants to be the chairman of Microsoft. But to get an accurate picture, an individual's time, place and hour of birth are needed for a chart," says Townsend.

Townsend is fully aware that astrology can too easily be written off as mumbo jumbo. "Anyone can become an astrologer or tarot reader. That's the problem, that's why there are so many charlatans, and there are certainly some very strange tarot readers around," she says. Anyone seeking to gain a reading should rely either on personal recommendation or otherwise check with the British Astrological and Psychic Society, advises Townsend.

Oliver Morrish, a 24-year-old physics graduate from Kent University, heeded the advice of a friend and had a reading done by a recommended astrologer on the subject of his non-starting career. "I had a third-class degree and wanted a job in medical physics. Everyone told me to forget it because it wasn't going to happen. I tried every career method I could think of and wasn't getting anywhere so I was open to an alternative perspective," he says.

Morrish became frustrated with conventional career counsellors who had a fixed way of regarding people. "A lot of career advisors categorise you and put you in a box, and then try to match that up with a job. But it's important to look at an individual's character traits and see what they want out of their own career. It should be about you choosing a career for yourself rather than being told what you should be," he says.

As a scientist, Morrish says he was sceptical, but his confidence in his career choice and in himself were flagging, the consultation was a present from his friend, so he felt he had nothing to lose. "It's not about fortune-telling. It's a way of clarifying things. I was told that my career choice was right and that I should carry on pursuing it. Since then I've found a job in the medical field," he says.

Spooky or plain coincidence? Pertemps has yet to decide if and how it is going to implement the findings of its research. Perhaps it, too, should consult the stars.

webTitle: The inside track: What women want

fields.headline: What women want
fields.trailText: What, asked Freud, do women want? The answer is a banker, apparently. Or at least, that's what they wanted last year.
fields.body:
What, asked Freud, do women want? The answer is a banker, apparently. Or at least, that's what they wanted last year. Drawing Down The Moon, a dating agency that specialises in intoducing professional people to each other, analysed which professions appeal most to each sex, based on the selections of their 1,500 members.

Bankers and stockbrokers made a surprise leap to the number one slot of professions desirable to women, while doctors, the perennial favourite, slipped to number four. Whether this change of heart will survive the current uncertainty of the stock markets remains to be seen. Selections were no doubt influenced by the dot.com mania of a year ago, which made share-dealing sexy for the first time since the 1980s, and must also account for the new entry of internet designer/editor at number three.

Men on the other hand, apparently get frightfully excited about marketing, their number one choice. Indeed, they seem to favour media women in general. PR and advertising make it into number eight in their chart, but do not feature on women's lists significantly. Artists are at number two. Recruitment also has its charms for men, in at number five, one above finance.

Both sexes fancy management consultants. They are number two women's favourite and number three for men. A rather masochistic taste, although they must be well practised at letting people go gently. Journalists are another profession which appeal to both sides of the gender divide, but for different reasons. Men like them for their creative skills, women admire them for their exciting lives. The law also has its romance, at number eight for women and number seven for men.

One inexplicable new entry to the women's list is publisher, the profession's first ever appearance in the the top 10. Last year they nudged in at the bottom. But with Hugh Grant playing a rascally publisher in Bridget Jones's Diary, perhaps will shall all learn to look at the book trade in a new light.

fields.headline: After hours
fields.trailText: Single people look just like normal people. Sure, there's a glimmer of desperation in the eyes, a slight sweatiness to the palms but, essentially, they are honest and decent folk, who simply have not yet stumbled upon that thing we call "love".
fields.body:
Single people look just like normal people. Sure, there's a glimmer of desperation in the eyes, a slight sweatiness to the palms but, essentially, they are honest and decent folk, who simply have not yet stumbled upon that thing we call "love".

As we toil later and later in the office, it becomes increasingly difficult for us to meet new people and potential new lurves. Sure, you can fantasise over your luscious boss, Mr Postlethwaite, but you know, in your heart of hearts, that should your unspoken love ever be consummated it might bring a certain, ahem, "tension" to your working environment.

Thank goodness, then, for match.com. This is the largest international online dating agency, with a nifty line in smart, professional types like your good self. Launched in 1995, it now has more than 5m registered singles on the site, with tens of thousands of British singletons (curse that phrase) just slavering for your affections. Since it began, it has seen loves blossom, knots tied and, erm, loins fruit.

Last week, match.com held its first UK singles event - a screening of Bridget Jones's Diary, with a post-flick party (canapes and vino included!) in London's Notting Hill. The film was introduced by Cindy Hennessy, match.com's president, and Trish McDermott, vice-president of romance (boy, would I kill for that title), who made us all stand up and shift to the left to introduce ourselves to the person we would be sitting next to during the show. Surprisingly, everyone looked remarkably normal, and curiously attractive.

A quick glance at the website, found Office Hours the perfect date in the shape of a 6ft 3in executive manager from Guildford, who likes "movies". What more could you want in a man? I'll let you know when we've set the date and chosen the honeymoon.

fields.headline: Office pin-up
fields.trailText: Post-it notes on a roll are 68mm wide and a whopping 10m long.
fields.body:
You might not recognise the latest incarnation of this veteran of the office world. Rippling, like Birds Eye custard, over treacle sponge; curling, like the sort of fancy scroll of butter you expect to get in a Trusthouse Forte restaurant, along with your soup of the day and your white bread roll. Or not, obviously. They're just bloody Post-it notes, but longer - less cute, but more versatile.

Post-it notes on a roll are 68mm wide and a whopping 10m long. You could probably Post-it an elephant with that. They come on an "indispensable dispenser" (eh?), which allows you to cut them to any length you like, so you can Post-it an entire piece of A4, a lengthy computer printout or perhaps an engineering drawing, if you're feeling that way inclined. You could even Post-it your work-experience laddie, so he doesn't keep forgetting what he's supposed to be doing.

Although we at Office Hours are not the most devoted fan of those little yellow Post-it notes - flapping about, as though a small flock of canaries has alighted on one's desk - they are, undeniably, annoyingly useful (and boast the additional feature of making you look as though you live the kind of streamlined life in which your tights are filed according to denier and your underwear always matches). What is more, the seemingly limitless possibilities for jiggerypokery with the new Post-it Notes on a Roll, make it our number one Must-Have Yellow Sticky Item of the week.

 Post-it Notes on a Roll cost £2.17 for pastel yellow, and £2.36 for the neon yellow variety. Call 01234 229 470 for stockists.

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: A photograph of a Type 1 tank, ostensibly used by the British during the 1916 Easter rising, accompanied A farewell to armour (G2, page 6, April 16). No tanks were deployed in Dublin during the rebellion but a number were used in Ireland during the Anglo-Irish war of 1919-1921. The first public appearance of the tank was in September 1916 at Flers-Courcellette as part of the larger offensive on the Somme.
fields.body:
A photograph of a Type 1 tank, ostensibly used by the British during the 1916 Easter rising, accompanied A farewell to armour (G2, page 6, April 16). No tanks were deployed in Dublin during the rebellion but a number were used in Ireland during the Anglo-Irish war of 1919-1921. The first public appearance of the tank was in September 1916 at Flers-Courcellette as part of the larger offensive on the Somme.

The feature on South African writer Nadine Gordimer (Stranger than fiction, G2, page 2, April 19) referred to the Gauteng province township of Alexandria. This should be Alexandra.

In a caption for a photograph of the Peak District national park (Park's birthday tramp cancelled, page 16, April 17), we said that the area had seen an 80% drop in visitors over Easter. This was a misinterpretation of the information in the piece, which stated that tourist organisations "reported visitor numbers during Easter at about 80% of what might have been expected".

There was some unintended generational confusion (Diplomats worry over Prince Michael's trips, page 1, April 13), when Prince Michael of Kent was described as the second son of the Duke of Kent. His father was, indeed, the Duke of Kent, but his brother, who was born in 1935, is presently Duke of Kent, having inher ited the title when their father died in 1942.

When a Thai senator said he had information about a "horde" of treasure left by retreating Japanese troops in 1945 (Frenzy to find treasure that could pay Thai debt, page 15, April 17), he was, of course, referring to a "hoard".
