webTitle: Cammell Laird's youngest feel hardest hit

fields.headline: Cammell Laird's youngest feel hardest hit
fields.standfirst: 'Jobs for life' boast rings hollow for 240 apprentices
fields.trailText: The pain of rejection is etched on the faces of the young apprentices at Cammell Laird shipyard in Birkenhead. They are facing a bleak future following the company's collapse into receivership.
fields.body:
The pain of rejection is etched on the faces of the young apprentices at Cammell Laird shipyard in Birkenhead. They are facing a bleak future following the company's collapse into receivership.

When the 240 workers began their four-year apprenticeships, they were assured that they had a career for life. Because they have not finished their training, they feel all their efforts have been wasted.

An air of uncertainty hangs over the shipyard, with its panoramic views of Liverpool's Anglican and Catholic cathedrals.

"If we have not got our certificates behind us, then it doesn't mean anything to other companies because we are not time served," said Anthony Hardacre, 20. "This doesn't just affect me. Some members of my family are subcontractors here and they do the painting. They will be badly hit if this place closes."

Paul Gillies, 23, who is in the fourth year of his apprenticeship, is so close to finishing in September but is unlikely to do so because of the problems.

Darren Reid, 20, said the apprentices made up a third of the workforce but believed they were being treated by the management as third-class citizens. "There was a mass meeting at Cammell Laird the other week and we weren't even mentioned. It's as if we don't exist. I would like to know what our future is, because all we can see now is doom and gloom. In three weeks' time we will all be out of a job and we feel robbed of our future."

His grandfather was a foreman fitter at the yard. "I remember being told by someone how lucky I was to be taken on as an apprentice. Now I just want to rip his tongue out." He is supposed to complete an NVQ level 3 in July but is unsure whether he will be able to do so.

Carl O'Shea's grandfather was a chargehand shipwright and his uncle is a fitter. "When we started here we thought it was a job for life - it shows how wrong we were."

James Mitchell, 22, said apprentices were always the last to know about the crisis at the yard. He predicted the first thing they would learn about their jobs being axed was when they arrive at work to find padlocks on the gates. He feels as if he has wasted three years of his life. He has taken home his tools - which are worth £2,000 -so he doesn't lose them to the receivers when the gates are barred.

All of the apprentices say that Cammell Laird has handled the crisis badly. Ian Adamson, 20, has a partner and an eight-month-old baby to support. He said he was worried about the future but did not really talk about the crisis at home because he does not know what will happen to him.

Paul Burns, 23, bought a new car three weeks before the shipyard got into difficulties. He did not take out payment protection insurance because he thought there would be no need. "When we became apprentices, the prospects looked good for us. Three weeks later, I found out that I did need the payment protection, but it is too late. I am now worried that I am going to get blacklisted if I get into difficulties."

The apprentices have written to em ployment secretary David Blunkett and Tony Blair expressing their concern. They asked the prime minister: "How would you feel if, at the age of 18 years, one of your sons came home from work and said to yourself and your wife: 'If we don't get the contract to build these ships, I may not be able to complete my apprenticeship'?" They received a reply from the prime minister which said their letter had been forwarded to the Department of Trade and Industry.

Last week the shipyard shed 150 jobs; another 170 were lost at the company's yards on Teesside and Tyneside. Brendan Reynolds, the AEEU's shop steward, said the apprentices represented the future of the shipyard. "Where are these kids going to go when this place closes down? It is like an extended family for them here - everybody knows one another and that is the spirit of the yard. We feel that these kids have been abandoned by Tony Blair's government."

There are hopes the business can be sold. Potential bidders are said to include A&P, a group owned by the private equity arm of Royal Bank of Scotland, the bank that pulled the plug on Cammell Laird.

He said he was worried about the future but did not really talk about the crisis at home because he does not know what will happen to him. Paul Burns, 23, bought a new car three weeks before the shipyard got into difficulties. He did not take out payment protection insurance because he thought there would be no need. "When we became apprentices, the prospects looked good for us. Three weeks later, I found out that I did need the payment protection, but it is too late. I am now worried that I am going to get blacklisted if I get into difficulties." The apprentices have written to em ployment secretary David Blunkett and Tony Blair expressing their concern. They asked the prime minister: "How would you feel if, at the age of 18 years, one of your sons came home from work and said to yourself and your wife: 'If we don't get the contract to build these ships, I may not be able to complete my apprenticeship'?" They received a reply from the prime minister which said their letter had been forwarded to the Department of Trade and Industry. Last week the shipyard shed 150 jobs; another 170 were lost at the company's yards on Teesside and Tyneside. Brendan Reynolds, the AEEU's shop steward, said the apprentices represented the future of the shipyard. "Where are these kids going to go when this place closes down? It is like an extended family for them here - everybody knows one another and that is the spirit of the yard. We feel that these kids have been abandoned by Tony Blair's government." There are hopes the business can be sold. Potential bidders are said to include A&P, a group owned by the private equity arm of Royal Bank of Scotland, the bank that pulled the plug on Cammell Laird.

webTitle: Debate: The hypermobile must not be allowed to rule roost

fields.headline: The hypermobile must not be allowed to rule roost
fields.standfirst: Debate Judith Doyle and Max Nathan
fields.trailText: The world is becoming more mobile. Every day, at least 4m people catch a plane. Every year, there are more than 600m international passenger arrivals and each year half a million hotel rooms are built worldwide.
fields.body:
The world is becoming more mobile. Every day, at least 4m people catch a plane. Every year, there are more than 600m international passenger arrivals and each year half a million hotel rooms are built worldwide.

By the 1990s people in Britain were travelling five times further than in the 1950s. This figure is predicted to double by 2025. Much of this additional mobility is to do with work. People are travelling further and faster for work, but spending less time when they get there.

In 1993, one of these "road warriors" spent 330 nights at Hilton hotels. Hilton estimates that the 10,000 customers who account for the top 1% of their frequent customer programme provide the chain with 15% of all its revenue.

However, there is also a growing mobility gap. Most travel still occurs within advanced industrial societies; flows within southern and western Europe and North America account for about 80% of international movement. Within Britain, people with jobs travel more than twice as far as the unemployed and inactive; within work, some travel much further than others. The rich travel further than the poor. In 1997-99, the richest 20% travelled nearly 3.5 times further than the poorest 20%.

Who are the winners and losers in a mobile world? The winners, commentators argue, are a hypermobile elite: cosmocrats and global souls living in global cities.

The vast majority, 98% of the world's population, never move to another place on a permanent basis. Globally, the number of people who do not own a car has increased from 2.5bn to 5bn, because population growth has outstripped growth in car ownership. Work aside, 50% of the British population still live within five miles of where they were born and raised.

In Britain, immobility is a good proxy for social exclusion. More than 70% of the poorest 20% do not own a car. The government's research shows that in an increasingly mobile society, a lack of access to transport can cut people off from work, shops and the other services of modern life.

Employment policy in Britain is predicated on connecting people to jobs - which includes moving people to where work is. It is clear there are practical transport barriers to achieving this, and psychological ones, too. For nearly half of all jobseekers, transport-related problems present a barrier to employment prospects.

Connecting people to jobs can be considered as part of a wider policy bias which assumes that moving fast over a long distance is inherently good and moving around locally is an issue which is either unimportant or able to be ignored.

Government and corporate policies often work in favour of the more mobile, through company car tax breaks, free workplace parking and, as in the recent 10-year Transport Plan for the UK, concentration of transport investment in large capital projects.

Even in urban areas, where the unemployed are close to places where work is, there is strong anecdotal and research evidence that people feel geographically disconnected from work.

Lack of employment opportunity aside, the mental geographies of many people in poor neighbourhoods militate against travel for work or services.

The problems faced by the hypermobile and the immobile lie at extremes of a spectrum. For the former it is often about making desperate efforts to stay connected because work takes them away from home so much. For the latter it is about lacking the opportunities, knowledge and skills to venture far from home in search of work.

The hypermobile may be a growing band but the real priorities for policymakers lie closer to home. For the immobile it is high time we thought of moving jobs to people, rather than feel that everyone must reach for the skies.

 Judith Doyle and Max Nathan are researchers in the futures unit of the Industrial Society

fields.headline: Glaxo may renew AHP courtship
fields.trailText: GlaxoSmithKline is considering reopening multi-billion-pound merger talks with US rival American Home Products, according to reports at the weekend, in an attempt to regain its position as the world's biggest pharmaceutical company.
fields.body:
GlaxoSmithKline is considering reopening multi-billion-pound merger talks with US rival American Home Products, according to reports at the weekend, in an attempt to regain its position as the world's biggest pharmaceutical company.

It is believed to have decided to renew efforts after being overtaken by American rival Pfizer, best known for its impotence treatment Viagra.

GSK, formed last December from the combination of Glaxo Wellcome and SmithKline Beecham, is still in the process of integrating the two businesses and this is not expected to be completed for another 2 years. Despite this, group chief executive Jean-Pierre Garnier is said to have appointed a team of executives to find acquisition targets, with AHP said to be the favoured partner.

AHP and SmithKline Beecham planned to merge in 1998 but the deal collapsed when SKB rejected that option in favour of a combination with Glaxo Wellcome. Those talks in turn fell through because of disagreements about who should run the company, though the two sides finally overcame their difficulties.

AHP is attractive to GSK because it is strong in vaccines and consumer products, and has a good new drugs pipeline.

AHP describes itself as being "firmly committed to pharmaceutical innovation".

Its company website states: "Our investment in research and development has given rise to one of the richest pipelines in the industry."

While refusing to comment on any takeover plan, a GSK spokesman said yesterday: "We haven't made a secret of the fact we are on the lookout for pipeline products."

The spokesman said GSK was primarily interested in buying products but added that in some cases companies come attached to products.

GlaxoSmithKline is this week expected to report first-quarter profits of about £1.3bn.

fields.trailText: Sunday Times
fields.body:
Sunday Times

Swedish healthcare group Capio has emerged as the front runner to acquire Community Hospitals, the £230m private hospital group.

Britain's biggest rail operator, National Express, has described Railtrack as arrogant, mismanaged and more interested in intellectual debates about itself than getting on with the job.

Nissan's Sunderland plant is likely to keep production of the Almera when the present model is replaced in about 2004. The move will guarantee the plant's future for at least 15 years and secure 5,000 jobs.

Mail on Sunday

Workers at Unipart, the car parts and distribution group that helped pioneer employee shareholding, have seen the value of their shares plummet more than 50%, according to leaked documents.

Observer

Serious technical problems are forcing the mobile phone networks to delay for up to a year the commercial introduction of the crucial next-generation wireless internet service.

A break-up of HMV Media, the chain of record and book shops, will be quashed when the debt-laden privately owned group agrees new profit targets with its bankers later this month. Tim Waterstone, the company's former chairman, recently attempted a buy-out of his old book chain, Waterstone's, which would have left the group with just the HMV chain. HMV's revised target means a renewed bid is unlikely.

British Airways chief executive Rod Eddington will warn this week that Britain will lose its place at the top table of world air transport unless the government quickly sanctions more airport capacity in the south-east.

Senior executives from De Beers are flying to South Africa in a last-ditch attempt to salvage the diamond group's £12bn buyout by the country's Oppenheimer dynasty. This follows a decision on Friday by two of De Beers' biggest US shareholders to oppose the deal.

Sunday Telegraph

Cash rich telecommunications group Cable & Wireless is eyeing US web hosting company Exodus Communications in its drive for international expansion. Exodus, valued at $4.7bn, would be a strategic fit for the group.

John Swingewood , one of BSkyB's most senior directors, is poised to leave the satellite TV group after a series of disastrous investments in the internet and new media.

Scottish & Newcastle is to sell an estate of about 650 pubs to a joint bid from Enterprise Inns and Noble House Leisure for up to £350m.

Sunday Business

The president of the European Central Bank, Wim Duisenberg , hit back at implied criticism of his interest rate policy by US treasury secretary Paul O'Neill. The Dutch ECB president defended his decision to leave rates unchanged, despite a severe slowdown in the US.

WestLB , the German investment bank, is plotting a counter-bid for Southern Water, which is part of Scottish Power. The Italian energy group Enel has already tabled an £800m offer for the business and is holding preliminary talks with Scottish Power.

Distribution company Hays is putting together a bid to deliver mail in direct competition with Consignia, the renamed Post Office.

Morgan Stanley will this week invite firm offers from potential buyers of Emap's troubled US business. But the price is expected to be just half the £1.05bn Emap paid for the operation two years ago.

webTitle: Marks & Spencer board rallies to Vandevelde

fields.headline: Board rallies to Vandevelde
fields.trailText: The board of embattled retailer Marks & Spencer last night attempted to present a united front and rally behind the store's chairman, Luc Vandevelde, who faces angry protests from shareholders over an £800,000 bonus.
fields.body:
The board of embattled retailer Marks & Spencer last night attempted to present a united front and rally behind the store's chairman, Luc Vandevelde, who faces angry protests from shareholders over an £800,000 bonus.

Amid rumours of a damaging rift between the executives and non-executives on the board, the company insisted that a decision had not been taken by the remuneration committee, headed by former spy boss Dame Stella Rimington, on whether Mr Vandevelde should receive the controversial bonus despite the continued poor performance of the company.

In a move to defuse the situation, new non-executive director Kevin Lomax took the unusual step of publicly supporting Mr Vandevelde as the Belgian chairman faced fresh pressure to voluntarily forgo the bonus.

Mr Lomax, the chairman of computer group Misys, said last night: "We all want what is best for the company and believe Luc Vandevelde is the man to do the job. There is no difference of opinion on this issue. The problems at Marks & Spencer were already well known a year ago when the contract was negotiated and no world-class retailer would have taken such a high risk position without a number of assurances on the financial front.

"The company's remuneration committee is in the process of reviewing a number of issues, as is normal at the financial year end, and arrangements regarding the chairman's bonus have not been finalised."

M&S's institutional investors are demanding an emergency meeting with the company about the issue. They are seeking an explanation of the criteria used to determine the potential payment of the bonus to Mr Vandevelde, who joined last year with a £2m signing-on package and a two-year mission to rescue the ailing group. The shareholders are represented by the Association of British Insurers, whose members control 20% of share, and include Standard Life Investment and Clerical Medical.

At the meeting with investors M&S, which has refused to publish any criteria attached to the bonus, is likely to focus on non-financial targets achieved by Mr Vandevelde. These include the progress in refurbishing the dowdy M&S stores, pulling out of the least profitable businesses and attracting new top management, such as Roger Holmes to run the UK stores and former Next and Asda executive George Davies who is to design a new clothing range.

But shareholders may not be appeased by such a justification, with many increasingly concerned about Mr Vandevelde's overall stewardship of the company and his plan to revive its fortunes by focusing on Britain and selling off businesses in Europe and the US.

One major shareholder said: "The bonus looks excessive in the circumstances. There is no clear evidence business is getting any better. One of Mr Vandevelde's achievements has been to appoint a head of UK retailing. It's rather early to say if it's a successful appointment."

Mr Vandevelde refused to discuss the potential bonus last night or give any indication whether he is likely to waive the payment, which is believed to be his entitlement under the terms of his contract. If the remuneration committee refuses to endorse the payment, there is a possibility that Mr Vandevelde could resign and seek compensation.

The committee is scheduled to meet twice before next month's announcement of M&S's profits, which are expected to fall to £430m from £517m according to forecasts in internal M&S documents seen by the Guardian.

 British Telecom chief executive Sir Peter Bonfield is in line for a £5m golden parachute if the company falls prey to a takeover or merges with a rival it emerged yesterday.

A BT spokesman described the contract, which was re-written to include the clause two years ago as "standard practice". The termination clause would allow him to cash in all his shares, worth about £3m at today's price, plus a year's salary and bonus.

webTitle: Business: Pile-it-high strategy pushes discount king to top of heap

fields.headline: Pile-it-high strategy pushes discount king to top of heap
fields.standfirst: Microsoft mastermind toppled as world's richest man by American supermarket supremo
fields.trailText: As a symbol of the resurgence of the old economy at the expense of the new it could hardly be bettered.
fields.body:
As a symbol of the resurgence of the old economy at the expense of the new it could hardly be bettered.

Bill Gates, the Microsoft billionaire, has been overtaken as the world's richest man by the head of a US low price supermarket dynasty. Gates has occupied the top slot for three years, but the recent bursting of the technology bubble has seen shares in Microsoft - the basis of his fortune - come tumbling down. He was worth an estimated £53bn last year, but his wealth is now put at £37.5bn in the latest Sunday Times Rich List.

Gates's replacement at the top of the heap is Sam Robson Walton, whose retail chain Wal-Mart owns Asda in the UK. Walton is said to be worth £45.3bn.

The dominance of old money is also shown in the British listings. The Duke of Westminster is named as Britain's richest man, his property empire valued at £4.4bn, though some rich list aficionados claim its true worth could be more than double that.

Bernie Ecclestone, the motor racing tycoon, and his wife Slavica, have climbed from sixth to third in the list, amassing a cash fortune of perhaps £2.4bn, plus a stake in formula one worth another £600m.

The Sainsbury family, founders of the supermarket chain, have also seen an upturn in their fortunes by £700m to £2.9bn, as investors return to safer havens after the dot.com boom and bust.

The Queen has edged up from 106th to 105th on the list, with her assets reportedly rising from £275m to £300m.

webTitle: Dixons chairman said to be looking for successor

fields.headline: Dixons chairman said to be looking for successor
fields.trailText: Sir Stanley Kalms, the chairman of Dixons and one of the best known figures in British retailing, is believed to be preparing to retire from the electrical goods group he founded 43 years ago.
fields.body:
Sir Stanley Kalms, the chairman of Dixons and one of the best known figures in British retailing, is believed to be preparing to retire from the electrical goods group he founded 43 years ago.

Sir Stanley is expected to step down at the end of the year shortly before his 70th birthday.

Friends of Sir Stanley say he is likely to spend more time lobbying for his political interests, in particular law and order. He is said to be in favour of increasing competition in the police force and advocates the establishment of a ministry of justice separate from the Home Office.

Reports suggested Dixons had appointed headhunter Whitehead Mann to begin the search for a replacement. A number of senior figures have already been approached to see if they would be interested in taking over as executive chairman.

Sir Stanley built Dixons from a single photographic studio run by his father to a retail business valued at £5bn. As well as the main Dixons chain, the group owns Curry's, mobile phone store The Link and PC World.

He has built a reputation for an aggressive, hands-on management style and has remained a dominant force in the group despite giving up day-to-day running to chief executive John Clare. He keeps a watchful eye on each day's sales and confers with Mr Clare most mornings before 8am.

A prominent supporter of the Conservative party, he has argued loudly against the introduction of the euro. He was knighted in 1996.

Sir Stanley took Dixons on to the stock market in 1962 and continued to grow the business steadily, apart from a disastrous foray into the US where he bought the electrical goods chain Silo and later sold it, incurring a heavy loss.

More recently Dixons became known as the company which spawned what was briefly Britain's most valuable internet business, Freeserve. Dixons cashed in £300m when it floated a minority stake.

A spokeswoman for Dixons described the reports of Sir Stanley's departure as speculation.

fields.headline: Sweet Lorraine
fields.standfirst: Martin Luther King called her an inspiration. Nina Simone wrote a song for her. So why has Britain taken so long to discover the playwright Lorraine Hansberry, asks  Alfred Hickling
fields.trailText: Martin Luther King called her an inspiration. Nina Simone wrote a song for her. So why has Britain taken so long to discover the playwright Lorraine Hansberry, asks Alfred Hickling.
fields.body:
In 1969 Nina Simone halted a concert at New York's Philharmonic Hall and announced that she wished to introduce a new song. The emotion of the moment was captured on the live album Black Gold: "I want to talk about a friend ... It seems that she comes alive more and more. I'm talking about Lorraine Hansberry. This is the story of her life, and each time I do it she comes a little bit closer and I miss her a little bit more. It's called Young, Gifted and Black."

Ten years earlier Hansberry, who herself coined that beautiful phrase, had become an overnight celebrity with her first play, A Raisin in the Sun. She was the first black woman to have a play produced on Broadway and, at 29, the youngest winner of the New York Critics' Play of the Year award. Raisin was later made into a film, with Sidney Poitier recreating his performance in the leading role. Hansberry's striking, statuesque features appeared in Vogue, while Show magazine dispatched a list of questions about Shakespeare and published her response alongside those of TS Eliot, Harry S Truman and Igor Stravinsky.

In America A Raisin in the Sun now has the status of an unassailable classic. Libraries are named after Hansberry and she is studied in college, the cult boosted by a dramatisation of her writings called To Be Young, Gifted and Black, brought together by her ex-husband, Robert Nemiroff. But in Britain, in the words of actor Lennie James, Raisin has become "one of those classics people recognise by name but can never remember who wrote it".

James is currently preparing to star as Walter - the role that made Poitier famous - in the first major staging of Raisin in this country for 15 years. This co-production between the Young Vic and Salisbury Playhouse is one of two plays set to re-impress Hansberry's name on the British consciousness. This month Manchester's Royal Exchange presents the British premiere of Hansberry's last work, Les Blancs, which has never before been seen outside America.

The almost total disappearance of Hansberry's work from the UK - where none of her writing is now in print - has less to do with its quality than with its quantity. When Martin Luther King proclaimed that she "would remain an inspiration to generations yet unborn" he did not know how quickly that would be put to the test. Hansberry's second play, The Sign in Sydney Brustein's Window, closed on Broadway after mixed reviews on January 12 1965. On the same night Hansberry, 34, died. She had been diagnosed with cancer less than 18 months earlier.

In his memoir Sweet Lorraine, writer James Baldwin fondly recalled days spent debating and shooting the breeze with his fellow Greenwich Village intellectual. He claimed that A Raisin in the Sun, written while Hansberry made a living as a waitress and cashier, "put more of the truth of black people's lives on the stage than any other play in the entire history of theatre". That statement has been quoted to the point of cliche, but New York-born actress Novella Nelson, currently rehearsing the role of Mama for the Young Vic revival, was a young student at the time of the original production, and confirms its impact. "I saw those people up on stage and thought, 'My God - that's my family up there.' There had simply never been plays of colour in that arena before - it made me want to become an actress. It changed my life."

A Raisin in the Sun borrowed its title from a line in the poem Harlem by Langston Hughes, whom Hansberry met while writing for the radical African American paper Freedom. Hughes's poem asks what happens "to a dream deferred":

Does it dry up

Like a raisin in the sun?

Or does it explode?

Even though the play was written well before the marches on Washington, the death of Martin Luther King or the inner-city uprisings, Hansberry, according to Nelson, "somehow managed to foresee history whole - the rise of black nationalism, the Pan-African movement, even feminism".

Raisin depicts the hostility faced by a black family when they attempt to move into an exclusive white neighbourhood - a bitter experience drawn from life. Although Hansberry was born in Chicago's Southside ghetto, her father was a relatively prosperous businessman. As such, she remembered "being the only child in my classes who did not come from the Rooseveltian atmosphere of the homes of the 1930s. My mother sent me to kindergarten in a white fur in the middle of a depression. The kids beat me up, and I think it was from that moment that I became a rebel."

Yet it was the universal dream of material advancement that led to the play's overwhelming acceptance by white middle-class audiences on Broadway. When an excited interviewer exclaimed: "This is not really a negro play - it could be about anybody. It's a play about people!", Hansberry coolly replied: "Well, I hadn't noticed the contradiction because I'd always been under the impression that negroes are people."

The unprecedented popularity of Raisin changed the face of American theatre. Between 1964 and 1974, more than 600 African American theatre companies sprang into existence across the US. In 1970 Charles Gordone's No Place to Be Somebody became the first play by an African American writer to win the Pulitzer prize. But somewhere in there Hansberry got lost. She spent four years drafting what would have been her third play, but it was still unfinished when she died.

"I sit at this desk for hours and hours," she once wrote, "and sharpen pencils and smoke cigarettes and nothing happens. I begin to think more and more of doing something else with my life while I am still young. I mean, almost anything - driving an ambulance in Angola or running a ski lodge in upstate New York, instead of this endless struggle. I expect the theatre will kill me."

The two plays Hansberry did complete show how hard she pushed herself. After the all-black domestic drama of Raisin, The Sign in Sydney Brustein's Window turned out to be a sprawling multiracial play of ideas. Les Blancs was more ambitious still; Nemiroff, who finally whipped it into shape, declared it would stand as his former wife's greatest work. It is a neocolonialist drama set in a missionary compound in the middle of an African civil war. A teeming, complex drama drawn on an almost Shakespearean scale, the play is a vivid examination of an ideological conflict escalating into bloodshed. "Les Blancs could serve as an analysis of any war, anywhere, at any time," says Marianne Elliott, who is directing the Royal Exchange production.

The stageworthiness of Les Blancs will only become apparent in performance, and it will always stand as a historical reconstruction as much as an original piece of work. But as the final entry in Hansberry's journal entreated: "If anything should happen - before 'tis done - may I trust that all commas and periods will be placed and someone will complete my thoughts. This last should be the least difficult since there are so many who think as I do."

• Les Blancs opens at the Royal Exchange, Manchester (0161-833 9833), tonight. A Raisin in the Sun is at Salisbury Playhouse (01722 320333) from May 11-26 and the Young Vic, London SE1 (020-7928 6363), from June 1-30.

webTitle: Going out: pop, classical, exhibitions, cinema

fields.headline: Going out
fields.trailText: Pop | classical | theatre | exhibitions | cinema
fields.body:
Pop

Monday
The Fall

Various mutinies among long-standing members of his crew notwithstanding, Mark E Smith is still The Fall, and The Fall keep going. Nowadays the kind of wiry rockabilly ensemble that they were at their inception 20-odd years ago, Smith's unpredictable stewardship continues.

Mean Fiddler, Charing Cross Road, WC2 (020-7434 9592) 8pm, £11.

Tuesday
Sigur Ros

Like Mogwai, this Icelandic group are epic in ambition and atmospheric in scope, but their lack of anything like a tune to hang all this on can sometimes lead to a sum total that is simply spooky ponderousness.

Shepherds Bush Empire, Shepherd's Bush Green, W12 (0207-7771 2000) 8pm, £16.50.

Thursday
Kristen Hersh

The qualities of Kristen Hersh's songwriting - vocal passion and guileful guitar - are undoubtedly still a draw for those still with one foot in the early 90s, but for the newcomer this is arguably difficult terrain. As part of the Throwing Muses, Hersh rocked in a crisp and pointed style, endearing to the humanities graduate. Now acoustic, it's a bit harder to see her charm. In a word - oldplay.

Empire, Shepherd's Bush Green, W12 (0207-7771 2000) 8pm, £10-£12.

Friday
Clearlake

Clearlake's name derives from an imaginary town in which all their songs are set, and from this quiet and residential location, frontman Jason Pegg has built an impressive imaginary world. Taking inspiration from Pink Floyd and the Cardiacs, the band create an essentially English sound.

The Spitz, Commercial Street, E1 (020-7392 9032) 8pm, £6.

John Robinson

Classical

Monday
Vienna Philharmonic Orchestra; NDR Symphony Orchestra

Difficult choice with two top orchestras on the same night. The Vienna Philharmonic is on safe ground with Schubert's Unfinished and Tchaikovsky's fourth symphonies, conducted by Zubin Mehta. From the NDR players: Beethoven's quartet op.59 no.3, Shostakovich's cello concerto and the fifth symphony, conducted by Christoph Eschenbach.

Royal Festival Hall, South Bank, SE1 (020-7960 4242) 7.30pm £10-£65;

Barbican Hall, Barbican Centre, Silk Street, EC2 (020-7638 8891) 7.30pm, £6-£25.

Tuesday
Jascha Heifetz

A centenary tribute to one of the great violinists of all time, from another master: Itzhak Perlman, who is accompanied by Bruno Canino in Handel, Beethoven, Saint-Saëns, and transcriptions by Heifetz.

Royal Festival Hall, South Bank, SE1 (020-7960 4242) 7.30pm, £10-£40.

Wednesday
Double Bill

The Bournemouth Symphony Orchestra is conducted by Jerzy Maksymiuk in the "organ" symphony by Saint-Saëns and Mendelssohn's violin concerto played by the young virtuoso Maria-Elisabeth Lott. Immediately afterwards, the Bournemouth Symphony Chorus take the stage for choral music by Schoenberg, Stravinsky, and Messaien. The orchestra's concert is repeated in Bristol and Portsmouth.

Poole Arts Centre, Kingland Road, Poole (01202-685222) 7.30pm/9.45pm £6.50-£26/£5.

Friday
Lewes Festival

This is the fifth Lewes Festival but the first one to have an Early Music Festival. The director Rob Bickley has pulled together names such as Trio Medieval, The Cardinall's Musick, the Palladian Ensemble, and the Hilliard Ensemble in a programme entitled Revelations.

St John-Sub-Castro, Lewes (01273-685861) 7.30pm, £7-£15.

Christopher Lambton

Theatre

Shock-Headed Peter

Positively your last chance for this brilliant evening of pop-up Victorian theatre and nastiness. A bright, not too easily frightened 8 year-old would enjoy it as much as a 21 year-old dripping tongue studs and irony.

Piccadilly, Denman Street W1 (020-7369 1734) Tue, Wed, Fri & Sat 8pm, Thurs 6.30 & 10pm £10-£29.50.

The Swing At Night

A new play by Howard Barker is always an event. This one is even more remarkable as it is performed entirely by puppets. A meditation on the sexuality of a mother and her infant son, the play is in poem form and promises to be transgressive and intimate in a way that only Barker knows how.

Barge Theatre, Blomfield Road, W9 (020-7249 6876) Wed-Fri 8pm, £7.

Feelgood

Alistair Beaton's insider satire on a party in power that is more obsessed with image than content is bound to get people in a spin for tickets. Henry Goodman stars in Max Stafford-Clark's Out of Joint production.

Garrick Theatre, 2 Charing Cross Rd, WC2 (020-7494 5085) Thur-Sat 8pm, Sat mat 4pm, £15-£35.

Henry VI

Immerse yourself in Shakespeare's history plays as the RSC This England season draws to a close with David Oyelowo fantastic as the king made powerless by warring factions. See this and Part II as well and finish the story with a ticket for Richard III. That's your week taken care of.

Young Vic, The Cut, SE1 (020-7928 6363), Tue 1.30pm, Sat 10.30am, £18-£25.

Lyn Gardner

Exhibitions

Art Now: Art And Money Online

A series of digital works investigating the interaction between art online and the museum. Central to the exhibition is a stunning projection of (what appears to be) the night sky but is in fact a live representation of the London Stock Market by Lise Autogena and Joshua Portway.

Tate Britain, Millbank, SW1 (020-7887 8008) until June 3, free.

Ross Sinclair

Large scale installations and photographs by Scottish artist Ross Sinclair, who continues his inquiry into REAL LIFE Vs THE WORLD.

The Agency, Charlotte Road, EC2 (020-7613 2080) until April 28, free.

Borrowed Ware

Forty years of contemporary art in Iran before and after the 1979 Islamic revolution.

Curve Gallery, Barbican Centre, Silk Street, EC2 (020-7638 4141) until June 3, free.

Solo Shows

Victoria Miro's new space is so big it can easily fit three substantial solo shows. Tracey Moffat's weirdly sinister photo-collages, Annika von Hausswolff's deserted rooms, and Alex Hartley's aspirational interiors concealed by layers of frosted glass.

Victoria Miro, Wharf Road, N1 (020-7336 8109) until May 12, free.

Jessica Lack

Cinema

Bridget Jones' Diary

Maguire's enjoyable picture finds Helen Fielding's sophisticated creation torn between the sexy cad Daniel (Grant) and the sullen but morally superior human rights barrister Mark Darcy (Firth).

(15) (Sharon Maguire, 2001, UK/US) Renée Zellweger, Colin Firth, Hugh Grant. 105 mins ***

Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon

A martial arts movie in a traditional Chinese action idiom which manages to be both electrifyingly exciting and sweetly romantic.

(15) (Ang Lee, 2000, China/US) Chow Yun-Fat, Michelle Yeoh, Zhang Ziyi. 120 mins *****

A Hard Day's Night

Easily the best Beatles film, directed by Richard Lester who emerges as a neglected modern master, chucking the camera about with wonderful flair, capturing the sheer joy of the Fab Four in the springtime of their career. His direction is experimental, radical, surreal, suffused with endless invention and fun. And this film is a fascinating picture of the country in 1964, with the Beatles as our cheerfully anarchic heroes.

(U) (Richard Lester, 1964, UK) The Beatles, Wilfred Brambell. 87 mins ****

Last Resort

Pavlikovsky brings rigour, as well as blazing compassion, to this story of an eastern European woman and her young son, washed up in a grim seaside "holding area" for asylum seekers.

(15) (Paul Pavlikovsky, 2000, UK) Dina Korzun, Paddy Considine, Artyom Strelnikov. 77 mins *****

A One And A Two

This spacious family drama is exquisitely considered, richly textured, beautifully acted, moving, funny and wise. A film about the interconnecting tribulations of one extended family in contemporary Taipei, it revolves around a man beset with problems, who meets the person he jilted when she was a schoolgirl 30 years before. (15) (Edward Yang, 2000, Taiwan/Japan) Nien-Jen Wu, Elaine Jin. 173 mins *****

Peter Bradshaw

If you're only going to see one thing this week...

Mill On The Floss

It begins with the ducking of a witch and ends with a flood, and in between you will be swept away by Shared Experience's adaptation of George Eliot's novel. First produced by the company in 1994, Helen Edmundson's version has taken a long time to reach the West End, but it undoubtedly deserves its berth. It is devastatingly good.

New Ambassadors, West Street, WC2 (020-7369 1761) 7.30pm, £12.50-£24.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Two more die in Turkish protest | Italy rescues 600 immigrants
fields.body:
Two more die in Turkish protest

The death toll in Turkey's hunger strike rose to 16 yesterday, following two more deaths in Istanbul.

Leftwing prisoners and their relatives began the protest last year against a new cell system in Turkey's new maximum-security prisons. The policy sparked clashes in December which left 30 inmates and two soldiers dead. AP, Istanbul

Italy rescues 600 immigrants

A ship carrying 600 illegal immigrants, including scores of children, was towed under police escort to the town of Gallipoli on the heel of Italy yesterday after being in trouble in the Adriatic sea. Police were trying to find out if the smugglers had left the ship or had tried to pass themselves off as passengers when the boat docked. AP, Rome

fields.headline: ANC whip defiant on 'car bribe'
fields.standfirst: The one time champion of the poor may be in trouble over his taste for the high life
fields.trailText: The chief whip of the ruling African National Congress, Tony Yengeni, has failed for a second time to explain adequately to a parliamentary ethics committee how he acquired a luxury car from a European arms manufacturer which won a lucrative weapons contract from the South African government.
fields.body:
The chief whip of the ruling African National Congress, Tony Yengeni, has failed for a second time to explain adequately to a parliamentary ethics committee how he acquired a luxury car from a European arms manufacturer which won a lucrative weapons contract from the South African government.

Mr Yengeni is at the centre of an inquiry by three government agencies and the ethics committee to discover if a £32,000 Mercedes four-wheel drive vehicle was a bribe by the European Aeronautic Defence and Space Company.

When the car was delivered three years ago, Mr Yengeni was chairman of the parliamentary defence committee. He only took steps to start paying for the car seven months later, after rumours about its origin began circulating.

While Mr Yengeni is evasive about the origins of his Mercedes, he is frank about his taste for such cars and the good life. The former guerrilla and communist said just a few months ago that he did not fight for South Africa's liberation to be poor. "There's nothing wrong with the good things in life," he said.

And Mr Yengeni so loved his chrome-enhanced Mercedes that he told a reporter last year: "It's very fast and very stable. One feels as though you're flying in a jet."

That proved to be an unfortunate comparison. Many of those who wonder how Mr Yengeni got his car also question why South Africa needs £4bn worth of jets, warships, tanks and submarines when its hospitals, schools and police force are in much greater need of the cash.

Most critics - which include the ANC's union allies and the church - accept the need for some defence spending on a continent wracked by instability, but the submarines have proven particularly contentious. Almost no one imagines a sea-borne threat to South Africa's security.

Mr Yengeni sees no more contradiction in the arms deal than he does in flaunting his lifestyle when most of the ANC's supporters do not even have jobs.

"I'm a Mercedes-Benz man. I bought a 4x4 because it's the in thing and I'm part of the trend," he said before the scandal broke. "I'm not immune to society's fashions. I'm part of society and influenced by it."

It wasn't always this way. Mr Yengeni has undergone an even more dramatic transformation than his country. Once a fervent communist and champion of the poor, he today personifies the "waBenzi" - that small section of the new black elite with a taste for big houses, expensive clothes and flashy cars, particularly cars made by Mercedes-Benz.

After studying political science in the Soviet Union 20 years ago, he trained as a soldier in Angola and became the Western Cape commander of the ANC's armed wing, Umkhonto we Sizwe, at the height of PW Botha's total onslaught against the liberation movement in the mid 1980s.

Mr Yengeni caught the eye of the security police and ended up in the hands of one of its most brutal torturers, Jeffrey Benzien. Three years ago, when Mr Benzien appeared before the truth and reconciliation commission, the victim asked his torturer to demonstrate the "wet-bag" technique.

In front of a stunned commission, Mr Benzien placed a plastic bag over Mr Yengeni's head and showed how victims were brought to the brink of death and then back again.

Mr Yengeni was charged with treason and was still on trial when Nelson Mandela was released in 1990. The case was dropped and he rose rapidly through the ANC's parliamentary ranks, chairing the defence committee with a firmness that earned him his party's chief whip.

Mr Yengeni used that position in February to order ANC members of a parliamentary watchdog committee to reject proposals for the independent anti-corruption investigator, Judge Willem Heath, to probe the arms deal despite widespread public support for the judge's involvement.

The ANC's response to the accusations against its chief whip has been to allege that questions about Mr Yengeni's conduct - and allegations of corruption in the arms deal as a whole - are a racist witch hunt. To add to the chief whip's woes it was revealed last month that his wife also received a Mercedes car through the same weapons manufacturer, and that Mr Yengeni is the owner of a 268,000 rand (£25,000) home - not cheap when most South Africans live in houses a tenth of the value - which has not been declared on the on the parliamentary register.

"I am ready to submit to a formal investigation and will not subject myself to a trial in the media. I'm clean. I have nothing to hide," he said.

Yet weeks after the allegations were first levelled, even the official investigators are still waiting to hear Mr Yengeni's explanation.

webTitle: Talks go on after Israeli suicide blast

fields.headline: Talks go on after Israeli suicide blast
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: A Palestinian suicide bomber blew himself up in a bus queue during the morning rush hour near Tel Aviv yesterday, killing himself and an Israeli doctor and spraying dozens of commuters with shards of metal and glass.
fields.body:
A Palestinian suicide bomber blew himself up in a bus queue during the morning rush hour near Tel Aviv yesterday, killing himself and an Israeli doctor and spraying dozens of commuters with shards of metal and glass.

The attack at a bus stop in Kfar Saba, the second fatal suicide bombing in the central Israeli town in a month, came a day after Israel admitted it was holding secret talks with senior Palestinians, and only hours after security officials from the two sides met for the first time since the latest escalation in the seven-month uprising.

Previous bombings inside the borders of the Jewish state have overwhelmed attempts to restart negotiations, leading instead to Israeli reprisals.

However, the foreign minister, Shimon Peres, said he hoped to continue the talks he has been conducting with the speaker of the Palestinian parliament, Ahmed Queria, or Abu Ala as he is usually known.

"Clearly, the violence makes it more and more difficult," Mr Peres told reporters in Jerusalem. "But we hope to stop the violence not just by exchanges of fire, but also by talking. We will continue to talk despite all the sorrow and agony such attacks create."

Witnesses said the bomber, who carried a computer case, detonated the explosives as he leaned against a bus pulling into the stop, killing the doctor, who had treated the victims of earlier bombings, and seriously injuring five people, including a schoolboy.

"I won't forget it for all the world," one woman on the bus told Israel Radio. "There was a boy, with his schoolbag still on his back, lying on the ground without moving. There was a pool of blood beside his head, and all I could do was run away, screaming, 'the boy, the boy'."

Once seen as an up-market community, its industrial parks a magnet for the hi-tech industry, Kfar Saba has become a target of suicide bombers in the last seven months. The town is only a few minutes drive from the West Bank city of Qalqiliya.

"Now, with the situation, you're near all the Arab towns, and it's scary," said Eyal Tidhar, aged 18. "Until now, I thought of myself as living near Tel Aviv. Now I think of how close I live to Qalqiliya."

There was no immediate claim of responsibility, but the attack comes only a day after the Islamist militant group Hamas renewed its warning that it had enlisted willing volunteers for its campaign of suicide bombings.

The bombing could imperil the efforts now underway, with CIA support, to restart joint security co-operation between the Israelis and Palestinians.

The hardline prime minister, Ariel Sharon, has been adamant that such talks do not constitute negotiations, in an attempt to appease rightwing allies demanding that he keep to an election promise of a ban on contacts with the Palestinians until they give up their revolt against Israel's occupation in the West Bank and Gaza.

In an attempt to shield Mr Sharon from his far-right critics, spokesmen for the prime minister yesterday were swift to blame Yasser Arafat's Palestinian Authority for the suicide bombing, and to play down the importance of the four-hour security meeting on Saturday night. "The security meetings were actually good, but they are clearly not enough. What is important is what happens on the ground," said Dore Gold, an adviser to Mr Sharon.

The last14 10 days have seen a steep climb in violence, defined by Palestinian mortar attacks, and Mr Sharon ordering Israeli invasions of Palestinian-ruled areas in the Gaza Strip.

However, there are signs that both sides are trying to find an escape from the pattern of escalation.

Mr Peres's secret talks with Abu Ala follow reports that Mr Arafat has offered to join Mr Sharon in making a public appeal against violence.

However, in keeping with Mr Sharon's policy of placating the right, Mr Peres yesterday seemed unmoved by Mr Arafat's apparent change of stance. "Let him make the call. Why not?" he said.

webTitle: Montenegro independence bloc on course for majority

fields.headline: Montenegro independence bloc on course for majority
fields.trailText: Pro-independence parties were claiming victory last night in the hotly contested Montenegro election.
fields.body:
Pro-independence parties were claiming victory last night in the hotly contested Montenegro election.

Early projections suggested that President Milo Djukanovic's Socialist Democratic party (DPS) had won 42% of the vote, enough to give it 35 of the 77 seats.

The pro-independence Liberal Alliance party won six seats, according to the projections, enough to give a pro-independence coalition a working majority. Anti-independence parties won 40% of the vote.

Official results are not expected until tomorrow.

Leader of the opposition "Together for Yugoslavia" bloc and president of the Socialist People's party (SNP), Pedrag Bulatovic, indicated soon after polls opened that his supporters might dispute the election results.

"The coalition for Yugoslavia claims that these elections are not fair because the conditions are not the same for all the parties," he said after voting in the capital, Podgorica.

"All state institutions were in the service of the DPS and SDP, including the police and media, especially the state media. Considering the irregularities of the election there is huge doubt [about the final results] and there is a great deal of misunderstanding between the two coalitions."

The election was fought largely on the question of whether or not the small republic of 650,000 people should secede from the Yugoslav federation.

Mr Djukanovic's "Victory belongs to Montenegro" coalition has pledged to hold a referendum on independence in the summer if it wins.

More than 71.2% of the 450,000 registered voters had cast their ballots by 5pm yesterday, observers said.

Marko Blagojevic of the Belgrade-based Centre for Free Elections and Democracy (Cesid), whose monitors have observed the polls, said the "turnout was extremely high" and could reach 80%, a record for an election in Montenegro.

Despite the presence of 3,000 monitors, there were reports of irregularities.

Cesid said thousands of voters had been turned away because their names had been spelled wrongly.

In the town of Niksic, members of the election board at one polling station were accused of entering polling booths and trying to influence votes. Cesid did not say in whose favour the officials were allegedly acting.

The size of any government victory is seen as critical to its drive for independence.

While a simple majority would allow the government to hold a referendum, it needs a two-thirds majority in parliament to change the constitution, and to secede from Yugoslavia..

Peter Palmer, an analyst with the International Crisis Group, based in Podgorica, said that a narrow majority might force Mr Djukanovic to seek opposition support for his plans.

"I don't think it would stop the process, but if he falls short of the two-thirds majority, a lot would still be open," Mr Palmer said.

"They won't give up their push towards independence and they may attempt to persuade pro-Yugoslav parties to change their minds."

The Organisation for Security and Cooperation in Europe is expected to announce its verdict on the fairness of the ballot today.

webTitle: Row over plane shot down in Peru

fields.headline: Row over plane shot down in Peru
fields.standfirst: Surveillance by US may have played part in death of its citizens
fields.trailText: US drugs officials tipped off the Peruvian fighter plane that killed an American missionary and her baby daughter after their aircraft was mistaken for a drug-trafficking flight and shot down.
fields.byline: Duncan Campbell in Los Angeles and agencies
fields.body:
US drugs officials tipped off the Peruvian fighter plane that killed an American missionary and her baby daughter after their aircraft was mistaken for a drug-trafficking flight and shot down.

"The United States is certainly upset by the fact that two American citizens lost their lives," President George Bush said at the Summit of the Americas in Quebec City.

Washington suspended all its surveillance flights in the area as the incident focused attention on its involvement in similar operations, particularly in Colombia.

James and Veronica Bowers, Baptist missionaries from Michigan, their seven-year-old son, Cory, and their baby daughter, Charity, were on a small single-engine Cessna 185 "floatplane" when the Peruvian fighter opened fire.

The pilot, Kevin Donaldson, also a missionary, was shot in the leg but survived after landing the plane on the Amazon river. The survivors, who were rescued by villagers and returned to the US yesterday.

The Peruvian air force has a policy of shooting at planes suspected of carrying drugs if they do not obey instructions and fail to identify themselves. A total of 25 planes have been shot down since the policy was introduced. In 1992 the Perumistakenly shot down a US Air Force C-130 over the Pacific.

A US state department official said that an American tracking aircraft was in the area and supplied "location data" for the intercept mission.

"It was mistaken for an airplane carrying contraband drugs," the spokesman said. The Peruvians were "responsible for identifying aircraft and deciding on any action", he said.

A US intelligence official said yesterday that the CIA-hired American crew aboard the surveillance plane had tried to stop the fighter shooting at the plane. He said the light plane was a mile away from the incident.

"The US crew repeatedly expressed their concern that the nature of the aircraft had not been determined," the official told Reuters.

He also confirmed that the surveillance plane was part of a US programme to support anti-drug efforts in Peru.

The Bowers had been in Peru since 1994, working for the Pennsylvania-based Association of Baptists for World Evangelism.

webTitle: Heroine of Italian left freed after 17 years in prison

fields.headline: Heroine of Italian left freed after 17 years in prison
fields.standfirst: Deal with US lets 70s activist go home for cancer care
fields.trailText: An icon of the Italian left walked free into Roman sunshine at the weekend after nearly two decades in prison for bank robbing, jail-breaking and kidnapping in America.
fields.body:
An icon of the Italian left walked free into Roman sunshine at the weekend after nearly two decades in prison for bank robbing, jail-breaking and kidnapping in America.

Silvia Baraldini, 53, was released to be treated for breast cancer under terms agreed by the United States and Italy.

She will spend the next five months of her 43-year sentence under house arrest in Rome but supporters sensed that she would not return to jail.

She popped on sunglasses to mingle with tourists at the Spanish Steps, smiled for cameras and vowed to start a new life in a country which regards her as a hero.

A native Italian, she was transferred to a Rome prison in 1999 after serving 17 years in American jails for offences linked to the black power movement.

"Today I am happy. I'm trying to be an optimist and to have hope. I am starting a new stage of my life," she said.

Ms Baraldini will be free to leave her apartment from 9am to 2pm daily and to try to lead a normal life until September, when her situation will be reviewed.

American justice officials are understood to have blocked Italian requests for an unconditional release but supporters believe that is only a matter of time.

"It is better than nothing. I am used to disappointments. I'm prostrate from so much waiting and suffering in these last years," said the former inmate.

"I spent in prison the years most important to a woman. I would like to be able to recuperate. I would like to live my years of maturity in peace."

She was convicted of offences connected with a series of robberies including a hold-up in 1981 of a Brinks truck near New York in which a guard and two policemen were killed.

She planned but did not directly participate in the robberies which were to raise funds for political campaigns.

Ms Baraldini was also convicted for kidnapping prison guards in 1979 to help the Black Panther leader, Assata Shaku, escape prison.

The daughter of an Olivetti executive, she moved to New York with her family and became a student radical in the late 1960s, protesting for women's rights and against the Vietnam war.

Incarcerated in maximum-security prisons, her case was championed by the Italian left which lobbied for a transfer to Italy with a million signatures, demonstrations and parliamentary resolutions.

She was flown to Rome in 1999 on the understanding that she would serve nine more years of her sentence but Italian diplomats have sought US approval for an immediate unconditional release on health grounds.

According to the Italian media the US justice department quashed the plea, threatening to seek her return to America and hinting at ruptured relations.

Last week, the two sides agreed a compromise of five months' house arrest. Negotiations will continue to find a permanent solution.

A grey Rover picked up Ms Baraldini from the Gemelli clinic on Saturday and delivered her to her late mother's apartment on Via del Babuino, a smart shopping area in the heart of Rome.

Italy's left, three weeks from a general election, hailed the release. The only criticism came from the far right National Alliance which questioned whether other prisoners in Italy would have received such treatment.

Returning to a childhood home was said to be especially emotional for Ms Baraldini as her mother, Dolly, died only recently. Her only sibling, Marina, died in an air crash in 1989.

Ms Baraldini has not renounced her political beliefs and is expected to campaign for political prisoners in the US.

First she intends to visit an exhibition of the work of the photographer Tina Modotti. "And I dream of being able to see Rome at midnight," she said.

webTitle: Doubts grow over Saudi bomb confession

fields.headline: Doubts grow over Saudi bomb confession
fields.standfirst: Supporters claim that Briton who faces death penalty is a stooge, framed by an oppressive state to hide its fight with fundamentalists
fields.trailText: Supporters claim that Briton who faces death penalty is a stooge, framed by an oppressive state to hide its fight with fundamentalists
fields.body:
When Sandy Mitchell appeared on Saudi television to confess his involvement in bombings and murder, his family and friends said he was drugged - he had been set up by a callous regime.

It was an understandable reaction: Mr Mitchell is a kind of fly-guy, a hospitable technician and alcohol bootlegger with friends in high places. He is the sort of man who skates on the edge of trouble, but premeditated murder? Difficult to believe.

Mr Mitchell, however, is facing public beheading in the Saudi Arabian capital, Riyadh. As yet he has been charged with nothing. No date has been set for his trial, he has had only limited access to British consular officials, and no Saudi lawyer has been engaged.

Yet, publicly at least, the Saudis are taking a hard line. Mr Mitchell and his co-accused - Canadian William Sampson and Belgian Raf Schyvens - have confessed to two car bombings, the endgame of a supposedly bitter feud over the control of illicit alcohol. Under sharia law their penalty is execution and the Saudi interior minister, Prince Nayef, has hinted he believes they should pay the price.

Explosions continue

But as diplomats juggle Saudi oil and trade interests with the necessity of having their nationals tried or released, doubts are emerging about the feasibility of Mr Mitchell's confession and the alcohol feud story.

Although the alleged perpetrators of the Saudi bombing campaign are in prison, explosions have continued, the latest only three weeks ago. British survivors of one bomb attack said they had difficulty believing these men were guilty. A leading Saudi dissident said Islamic fundamentalists, opposed to the influx of westerners and the Saudi royal family's involvement in the illicit alcohol trade, were responsible for the bombings: Mr Mitchell and his co-accused were merely stooges, framed to convey the impression of stability in an oppressive country where Islamic rebellion was growing, albeit in isolated pockets.

On December 17 last year, Mr Mitchell, 44, from Kirkintilloch near Glasgow, was arrested in Riyadh for suspected alcohol offences. To the expat community, his involvement in alcohol was an open secret. For a while he had supplemented his income as chief anaesthetic technician at the security forces hospital in Riyadh with a profitable sideline as owner of the Celtic Corner. He had sold the pub a year previously, but still kept a hand in alcohol.

In a country where westerners live in compounds, where the boredom is as oppressive as the heat, the habit of selling whisky at £120 a bottle is difficult to break. Besides, Mr Mitchell counted police officials and members of the Saudi royal family among his friends. He could usually pull a few strings to get himself - and others - out of a scrape.

Despite this, things had been getting tough in the alcohol trade. Only a few months earlier, Mr Mitchell had helped his friend, Gary Dixon, owner of the biggest illicit bar in Saudi Arabia, escape across the desert to Dubai.

After a crackdown by the mutawwa, the religious police, Mr Dixon's wife, Mary, was already in jail. The jailing had surprised everyone. The expats embroiled in the drinks trade believed the involvement of the royal family left them immune to the mutawwa. "The main source [of alcohol] is the royal family," said Mrs Dixon. "And the idea of a turf war is ridiculous."

But alongside the crackdown on alcohol, there were other, more serious, things for westerners to worry about. On November 17, Christopher Rodway, 47, from Salisbury, was killed when a bomb exploded in his car. His wife Jane, 50, narrowly escaped. Five days later, a bomb went off under a British car in Riyadh. No one was killed, but six were injured.

Within the expat compounds, rumour spread that westerners were being targeted by Islamic fundamentalists. There was an underground movement within Saudi Arabia prepared to use violence in protest at the influx of westerners and what it saw as the un-Islamic excess of the royal family. The rumour, according to Saad Al-Fagih, of the Movement for Islamic Reform in Arabia, in exile in London, carried more than a hint of veracity.

"There are people, you may call them fundamentalists, who believe in using violence who are behind these bombings," he said. "These groups are too small to attack the big targets, like the American army presence, so they have to [go] for something achievable, a soft target. Hitting westerners will make a big fuss. It will intimidate westerners and embarrass the regime.

"Our sources in the interior ministry tell us that Sandy Mitchell has been arrested only to distract attention from what the regime really believes. Fifty fundamentalists have been arrested since Mitchell."

Whatever Dr Al-Fagih's sources, Mr Mitchell's confession remains to con demn him. Yet, on analysis, the confession appears tainted.

Looking pallid - and almost two months after his arrest - Mr Mitchell told Saudi television: "I confirm and confess that I was ordered to carry out an explosion here in Riyadh." He said he planted a bomb under the driver's seat of the car and Mr Sampson detonated the device by remote control. Neither Mr Mitchell nor the Saudi authorities have revealed who "ordered" the explosion.

The second bombing

Then came his confession to the second bombing. Mr Mitchell said he was talking about the plan for the second attack with Mr Sampson when Mr Schyvens overheard. Bizarrely, Mr Schyvens confessed that he agreed to be recruited into the campaign. But, according to the confessions, Mr Mitchell and Mr Sampson were unsure of Mr Schyvens's commitment.

Mr Sampson said he gave Mr Schyvens a dummy device and then telephoned him and told him to plant it on a car owned by a Briton, Steve Coughlan, which was parked outside the Celtic Corner bar. When Mr Schyvens went inside, Mr Sampson said he then planted the real bomb.

This scenario does not ring true to survivors of the attack. Mr Coughlan said Mr Schyvens was already inside the bar when he arrived and remained there until they left together, so it would have been impossible for him to take the telephone call. Mr Schyvens was part of Mr Coughlan's drinking group and he left in convoy with Mr Coughlan when the group went to another pub. When the bomb exploded, Mr Schyvens offered assistance.

"It doesn't make any sense to me that if you plant a bomb you sit around in a bar, you leave your car parked next to the bomb, you drive off after the bomb, you help the victims, you give your name to police," nurse Jackie Gill, a passenger in the bombed car, told BBC Scotland.

So if those who admit to being key players in the illicit Saudi alcohol trade - such as Gary and Mary Dixon - rubbish the idea of a turf war, and the confessions do not ring true to the victims of the crime, why would Mr Mitchell, Mr Sampson and Mr Schyvens make them? Stephen Jakobi, of Fair Trials Abroad, said confession was almost the necessary conclusion of any Saudi interrogation.

"We know that the Saudis use relay interrogation until prisoners will confess to virtually anything," he said. "It is only then that the embassy is allowed to see them, by which point it is too late."

As Mr Mitchell and his co-accused wait in prison, little information is filtering out of Saudi Arabia. If a trial goes ahead, their only hope of escaping execution is the acceptance of a blood money payment by Mr Rodway's family. It would be a convenient scenario, one which would allow everyone to save face. It is almost possible to hear the diplomatic wheels turning.

webTitle: Real lives: on being a vicar's wife

fields.headline: 'It does your head in'
fields.standfirst:
Vicars are finding it so hard to find wives that they are now resorting to specialist dating agencies. But is it really so grim being wedded to the church? Susan Devonshire Jones knows

Special report: religion in the UK
fields.trailText: Vicars are finding it so hard to find wives that they are now resorting to specialist dating agencies. But is it really so grim being wedded to the church?  Susan Devonshire Jones knows.
fields.body:
Eighteen years ago when I married the local vicar it left a queue of disappointed hopefuls. My husband Tom probably fell for me because I was a bit different. I was a single mother and a teacher of deprived children. "You're not a frump," a bishop friend told me years later.

Tom thought I knew the scene because my father was a vicar. People told me that being a vicar's wife was like having another job - and I took no notice. If you love a guy do you dump him because of his work?

The vicar's wife has to get on with everyone - but you can only take so much of hearing that the sun shines out of your husband's bum. An intelligent but disturbed middle-aged woman in the parish never stopped inviting us round. Once, when she came to a meal, we had a variety of guests. When a young man said something about the Green party the woman started screaming. She ran from the room and off down the road. I was furious with Tom for trying to comfort her.

In my mother's day they didn't make church a social thing. Nowadays the congregation is encouraged to stay for coffee. Being nice to the range of people that turns up in a London church is draining. One way of getting a breather is to look after a tramp. Tramps always find the vicarage. If it weren't un-Christian I'd say that other callers were con-men; always with a story - and broke. One Sunday a persistent guy tried to follow me into the house. I pushed him back out, but as an encore he went round to the garden and started flashing.

Early on people asked how I was enjoying the house. There is no polite answer. You're lost in a big, old place, difficult to clean and expensive to heat, constantly answering the phone. If you want the loo seat fixed you have to discuss it with the diocese first. For years I begged to have a tap in the garden. Then when it finally arrived it was four years before someone came back to put water in it.

When you've at last settled down you have to move on, or it's time for retirement. Unless you want to live in the back of beyond, you must scale down. This happened to us a year ago and I'm still confused. Not so many people phone and I don't know who my friends are.

If only the undertakers would ring - undertakers are my favourite people. (In Tom's absence I could arrange a funeral standing on my head). When I wanted a lift to the burial of our bishop's mother outside London, my favourite undertaker said he would nip to the shops to get me some travel-sickness pills. Aren't there any in the glove box? I asked. "No," he said. "The people we drive don't get travel sick."

According to the founder of Christian Connection, expectations of a vicar's wife aren't what they were. She wants members to write about their religious outlook. If the hopefuls from church queues start applying, the poor clergy might be back where they started.

Let's just say that being married to a vicar does your head in. Of course, its good that Anglican clergy can have a family life. (God knows, I've spent enough time trying to persuade excellent gay clerics to become straight). And look at the poor Roman Catholics, threatened by all that paedophile stuff.

A church organist told me a joke: once a bishop, always a bishop; once a duke, always a duke ... once a knight, dead at forty (or: once a knight's enough). Once a priest always a priest. Recently Tom had to preach in Oxford. Horrors for me when he said it would be easier if he wore his cassock. There's a useful (but often filthy) loo in a lay-by just off the M40. Other Sunday travellers won't forget the sight of this robed cleric headed for the flooded gents. And they don't know that for a few tense moments he was stuck in there, like the two old ladies in the rhyme.

Other Sunday travellers won't forget the sight of this robed cleric headed for the flooded gents. And they don't know that for a few tense moments he was stuck in there, like the two old ladies in the rhyme.

fields.headline: No 1,864
fields.standfirst: Donny Osmond
fields.trailText: Pass notes: Donny Osmond
fields.body:
Aaaaaaaaaaaaaaagh! Sut ydach chwi?

It's ... it's ... Donny Osmond! Ia yn siwr, dyma Donny Osmond.

Why are you speaking Welsh? Gan ei bod yr iaith yng ngymru.

I had a sneaking suspicion that was the case. But Donny was a member of a top bubblegum pop outfit, not a male voice choir. Well ia, gan mae Cymru yw cartref y teulu Osmonds!

The Osmonds don't come from Wales, you moron! Y gwir mae Mormons oeddent.

No, I said moron, not Mormon. Anyway, the Osmonds were from Utah. Well ia, 'roedd hen, hen, hen nain Donny wedi dod o'r Cymoedd

Really? His great-great-great-grandmother came from Wales? Whereabouts? Yn agos i Ferthyr Tydfil.

Merthyr Tydfil? So Little Jimmy Osmond trilling about Long Haired Lovers from Liverpool wasn't too far-fetched? Na, nid yw ond rhyw daith fer i lawr y brif ffordd.

And has Donny any plans to return to Wales? Maybe in October. But Donny is a busy guy. He has got touring to do, an album to promote, that smile to polish ...

I notice that you have ditched the phony Welsh act. Well yes, let us hope that Donny soon does the same. He has been in the British papers wittering on about how he can't wait to take his family to Merthyr.

Perhaps it is all a cunning ploy to woo the record-buying public of Wales. Why, yes, Tom Jones has been looking a little complacent of late ...

But will all that spandex and sparkle go down well in Merthyr Tydfil? Well, it worked for Shirley Bassey.

And Dylan Thomas. Well, maybe not him. But what with Sir Anthony Hopkins and the Catherine Zeta Jones legging it Stateside, it's only fair that the Welsh should nab some Yanks.

And what delights await Donny in sunny Merthyr? Well, it's an industrial town. It is named after Tydfil the Martyr - a Welsh Christian princess.

Donny should feel right at home then.

fields.headline: Food, glorious food
fields.standfirst: The Lake District
fields.trailText: Country diary: The Lake District
fields.body: The tiny hamlet of Broughton Mills, snuggled deep in the Dunnerdale fells, dozed in the morning sunshine. There was nobody about, the Herdwick sheep had been cleared off the fells, and the lovely mountain road over the tops, past Stickle Pike and down to the Duddon, was closed, with a locked gate across the tarmac. The long-dreaded foot and mouth had finally hit this secluded corner. In the Blacksmith's Arms they had sold no lunches in the bar all week but the welcoming fires were still ablaze, the tables polished and the brasswork gleaming. It was just 70 years since I had first dined here - at the very first annual dinner of our little climbing club, the Coniston Tigers. How well I remember that meal - delicious Herdwick mutton that had been slowly cooked all day in the big, farmhouse oven, swimming in hot gravy and topped with a glorious, golden brown crust! And they served it, dumped unceremoniously on the massive apple-tree wood table, in a child's tin bath, from which we carefully sliced eight or ten, I think it was, exactly equal portions. Even today, after all those years, I can still picture the scene and almost savour the relish of that most delicious meal for young mountain appetites. Today, the apple-tree wood table has gone - how they got it through the door I can't imagine - and there have been some modern improvements, but the friendliness and the welcoming fires are still there. We enjoyed splendid food and they told us the sad story of the last few weeks - the slaughter of the innocents. So, no Stickle Pike - my first hill in the 1920s - this time. Just the drive home along deserted roads with a lot to think about.
