webTitle: BBC1 turns to crime to lift ratings

fields.headline: The usual suspects
fields.standfirst: BBC1 is turning to crime in an attempt to pull itself out of its ratings doldrums. Bad move, reckons Mark Morris
fields.trailText: BBC1 is turning to crime in an attempt to pull itself out of its ratings doldrums. Bad move, reckons Mark Morris.
fields.body:
Who would ever have thought that a permanently grumpy, middle-aged, opera-loving pint drinker with a vintage Jag could cast such a long shadow over British television?

With its combination of ratings and cultural (or at least dinner party) respectability, Inspector Morse represents everything that lurks just out of reach for the bosses of Britain's big two channels. Oh, you can have ratings: Who Wants To Be A Millionaire? or a soap will give you that. And respectability is easy enough, although best left to BBC2 or Channel 4. But having both is much harder. Which is why BBC1 is trying so hard for a Morse of its own, and why the bulk of its new drama is crime-based, one way or another. Crime, the thinking goes, can be both popular and clever, so crime plus established stars, such as Ricky Tomlinson and David Suchet, is the current blueprint for BBC1's salvation.

Lorraine Heggessey, the channel's controller, desperately needs both the ratings and respectability that crime drama might bring. That ITV has had the cheek to run Dickens adaptations, while BBC1 has been painfully discovering that only a relatively small audience exists for TV versions of mid-20th-century novels, such as Take A Girl Like You, can only have made her dilemma more acute.

So with docusoaps out, and a big lurch into Big Brother/Survivor reality TV too risky (except on Saturday night, when any pretence of quality is abandoned), the BBC's thoughts have turned to crime. Drama, having been displaced by the docusoap frenzy a couple of years ago, is back: 20% more of it is promised.

New drama cannot be overambitious, though: Clocking Off and The Sins have proved that conceptually smart series are not ratings winners in the current climate. Which leaves those TV staples: cops and docs. BBC1 has its medical warhorses Casualty and Holby City, and a solid crime performer in Silent Witness. Now it wants another crime series (two or three would be better).

Holding the fort is the series of one-offs Murder In Mind, with established stars such as Steve McFadden and Kevin Whately. But that can only be a stopgap measure. BBC1 needs a Morse, or at least a big ratings winner such as A Touch Of Frost. The search for a new, long-running crime series began a few weeks ago with the Crime Doubles (two-parters run on Mondays and Tuesdays) which were, with the unhappy exception of Second Sight, reasonably successful. At least two of the shows - NCS and In Deep - will be back. But the channel needs a series that pulls in more than the 7.4 million managed by NCS: Manhunt.

The contenders include: Ricky Tomlinson as a private eye (Nice Guy Eddie); Ken Stott (most recently of ITV's The Vice) in the cop-hunts-serial-killer vehicle Messiah: The First Killings; a station-based police drama called Mersey Beat; and - this isn't a joke, they assure us - The Fabulous Bagel Boys, which blends "investigative policing with the manic hubbub of the local deli" - Denis Lawson and Michael French star.

It is hard to see the new Taggart or Bergerac surfacing out of that lot. Not that it is ever safe to write off shows before they have aired. Morse - with its two-hour running time, impenetrable opening quarter of an hour of each episode and a potentially off-putting central character, did not have the look of a winner either. What is more worrying is the idea that BBC1 is run by people shouting "Crime! That's the answer!", in the same way that quiz shows were last year's saviours, and docusoaps before that. Opting for one genre at a time is dangerously reductive thinking.

The appeal, though, is understandable. Go into any bookshop and it will be packed with crime novels. Crime drama allows the audience cheap thrills and the reassurance of resolution, with a bit of sociology or the psychology of evil chucked in. There is something familiar about even the tougher detective shows (Prime Suspect, say) that there isn't with drama that doesn't fit in a box, such as Clocking Off. Whether we are talking a noirish private-eye theme or The Bill, there are genre rules that make viewers feel comfortable, and even the programmes that twist them are doing so within a framework. You know where you are with crime.

And - maybe because of our tradition of crime novels - it never looks like the tacky option. Even Britain's most down-market crime drama - The Bill - has switched to one-hour episodes to make it clear that it is no soap. With crime drama - especially post-Morse and Poirot - you get production values. Morse, at two hours long, was a useful training ground for directors such as Danny Boyle. The lighting and sets denotes "quality TV" even as we watch the first person getting brutally murdered.

If BBC1 shouldn't be immersing itself in crime, what are the alternatives? Both TV executives and critics have spent much of the last 10 years looking enviously across the Atlantic. Throughout the 90s, the US TV ratings were dominated by quality sitcoms and ensemble dramas.

Recently, due at least partly to British influence, reality shows and quiz shows have made big inroads, but the bulk of peak time is filled with narrative fiction, a surprising percentage of which is either good or at least sharply competent. One key difference is that the networks have fewer shows to commission: seasons run for 22-24 weeks, and when you've added reruns, that is most of the year covered for that time slot. BBC1 could end up needing as many as eight programmes per slot. (The other, inescapable, difference is money.) There have been experiments with longer seasons here, and if one of BBC1's new dramas turns out to be the magic one, giving it a longer run might take some of the headaches out of commissioning.

What about sitcoms, though? When the Nine O'Clock News was moved, One Foot In The Grave and The Royle Family were brought in to get the new 9pm slot off to a solid start. However, both shows have ended, and nothing has stepped into their space (ITV is equally short of a big sitcom). The death of the popular British sitcom is a mystery in itself. But Heggessey has the luxury of knowing that sitcoms - like panel games, and quiz shows - can grow up on BBC2 and then make the leap to BBC1 if they show signs of attracting a mass audience. Drama doesn't work the same way.

Heggessey thinks her strength is her willingness to shake things up. "BBC1 is not going to be as slow to change as it has in the past, and we will take some risks. That's very important - if you don't take risks and fail, that's one thing, but at least if you take some risks and fail then you feel better, you can move on to the next thing and try something else."

What the channel really needs though is time: time to run shows until people can discover them, work out whether they like them or not. For that the BBC needs the backing of Chris Smith (or his successor). The BBC needs the government to make a firm defence of its remit, to tell the Murdoch family that British broadcasting is not and never will be a free market, and the BBC will never be allowed marginalised indulgence for the over-educated along the lines of the US channel PBS. Then BBC1 could work towards building smart populist successes of all genres. Crime is not the answer.

webTitle: Real IRA in grenade attack on police station

fields.headline: Real IRA in grenade attack on police station
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: The Real IRA is believed to have carried out a grenade attack on a Derry police station over the weekend, as the dissident republican terrorist group continued its violent campaign for a united Ireland by stepping up activity in Ulster and London.
fields.body:
The Real IRA is believed to have carried out a grenade attack on a Derry police station over the weekend, as the dissident republican terrorist group continued its violent campaign for a united Ireland by stepping up activity in Ulster and London.

Nobody was hurt in Saturday night's blast, which damaged two parked cars outside Strand Road RUC base. Nearby residents were evacuated before the device exploded.

Gregory Campbell, a local Democratic Unionist Stormont assemblyman, said those responsible had no regard for anyone who got in the way.

"If they repeatedly do this, then at some point there are going to be people killed or seriously injured," he said. "The security forces must maintain their vigilance."

The Real IRA marked last week's anniversary of the 1916 Dublin Easter Rising, one of the most important dates in the republican calendar, with a bomb at a post office sorting depot in London.

The dissidents, who split from the Provisional IRA in 1997 over opposition to the Good Friday agreement, have a cell in London, which has carried out attacks over the past year, including last month's car bomb outside the BBC.

But they are also increasingly active in Derry, where 12 soldiers had a narrow escape in January when a barrack buster bomb partially exploded just a few feet from their sleeping quarters at Ebrington army base.

Earlier this month, the Prehen Road in Derry was closed off for three days while experts dealt with a car bomb, and last week security forces made safe a fully primed mortar discovered in Altmore forest, Co Tyrone.

However, Sinn Fein's former publicity director, Danny Morrison, writing in yesterday's Observer, claimed the Real IRA would never have the pop ular support to sustain its campaign or achieve its political objectives.

"The Real IRA will never be able to replicate the [Provisional] IRA's firepower and thus bring the British to the negotiating table," he said.

The Real IRA's alleged leader, Michael McKevitt, is due in court in Dublin tomorrow, to apply for bail in connection with charges of membership of Real IRA and directing terrorism. McKevitt, 51, of Blackrock, Dundalk, Co Louth, in the Irish Republic, is the first person in the republic to face the new charge of directing terrorism, introduced two weeks after the Real IRA bomb killed 29 people in Omagh, Co Tyrone, in August 1998. The charge carries a penalty of life imprisonment.

The key witness at his non-jury trial, which will take place at Dublin's special criminal court, is purported to be a US double agent, David Rupert, who provided information on the Real IRA to the FBI, M15 and Irish police, and is now in a witness protection scheme.

Irish-American dissidents are thought to be extremely embarrassed that Mr Rupert, 49, an Illinois truck company chief, could infiltrate a secretive terrorist organisation and befriend its top people in less than three years.

But Martin Galvin, the New York lawyer who previously raised money for Sinn Fein and now works with the hardline Irish Freedom Committee, has claimed on American radio that Mr Rupert owes hundreds of thousands of dollars to US tax authorities.

This could complicate the case against McKevitt as defence lawyers could argue Mr Rupert might have been pressurised into becoming a witness because of his debts.

There were similar problems with several "supergrass" trials in Northern Ireland in the 1980s, when ex-paramilitaries were persuaded to give evidence against ex-associates.

fields.body:
 Fate hasn't been looking too kindly on West Wing creator Aaron Sorkin in recent days. If being busted last week for possession of magic mushrooms last week wasn't enough to send him over the edge, the news that Channel 4 has shunted his sparky White House drama to the 11.05pm graveyard slot might just be. The channel has done so, it says, in response to "disappointing" viewing figures. The multi-Emmy-award-winner was pulling in only just over a million viewers. The show's second series, meanwhile, will have its first airing on E4 starting in June.

 Donna "Who?" Air's new show, Donna In Need, begins on E4 early next month. Her mission: to see how many freebies her "celebrity status" can land her in various British cities. Donna is kind enough to share with us her views on the subject: "People seem to be hooked on celebrity gossip these days. You only have to turn on the TV to be swamped with stories about soap and pop stars." Perhaps she should try watching something other than E4.

webTitle: Mark Lawson: Michelle Collins in Perfect

fields.headline: One drama about bigamy is all very well. But two...
fields.standfirst: Hot on the heels of the BBC's Best Of Both Worlds comes Michelle Collins in Perfect. Is it a wedding too far?
fields.trailText: Hot on the heels of the BBC's Best Of Both Worlds comes Michelle Collins in Perfect. Is it a wedding too far asks Mark Lawson?
fields.body:
It's often said that the art of comedy is timing, but hitting the right moment can also be vital in drama. In an extreme example, the prestigious ITV drama Thursday The 12th - neatly intended for screening on this month's Thursday 12th April - has been delayed because of concerns about its political content in a pre-election period.

And Perfect, a serial about a serial female bigamist, appropriately but infuriatingly finds itself the victim of someone doing something twice. A BBC1 series about a double wife - Best Of Both Worlds - was shown two months ago.

Guests at this second set of weddings, however, will soon realise that it's a different cover story this time. Whereas Paul Abbot's BBC three-parter featured a woman who moved between two marital homes - a sort of adultery plus - Susan Oudot's two-part drama for ITV focuses on a woman who restricts herself to one husband at a time, but never bothers with the precaution of divorcing his predecessors, or explaining why she's left the marital home.

Julie (Michelle Collins), a flirty nurse, is a time-delay version of the Julia Roberts character in The Runaway Bride. But while that woman's problems made her dash from the church on her wedding days, Julie tends to flee from the marital kitchen shortly after the honeymoon.

In a twist on Mr Rochester's tactics, Julie keeps her husbands in the attic. When Julie's husband Karl comes home to find his house emptied except for a tier of wedding cake with the model of the groom on it - a trick perhaps more likely to occur to a dramatist than a bigamist - he eventually finds a padlocked box in the loft which contains padded albums of photographs recording marriages to various sailors. But, by then, Julie has already walked out on Karl's replacement Dave - who she tricked into thinking she was pregnant - and is lining up Mike at the top of the aisle.

Oudot's script neatly employs the fact that the viewer knows more than the blokes. An unexplained cutaway to a man leaving prison or a previously unseen teenager at a kitchen table suddenly alert us to another part of her past. And, while the BBC series made no attempt to explain the bigamist's behaviour, Perfect finds an answer in childhood.

Featuring a runaway, the drama is frequently on foot. Hand-held cameras follow characters as they dash down streets, around supermarkets, along hallways. This isn't new - in fact, the visual signature of current television drama is that people talk while they walk - but there's a distinctive motivation this time.

Borrowed from documentary, on-the-trot dialogue is usually used in series - LA Law, ER, The West Wing, Cops - in which the characters are frantically busy, the sprint of the pictures reflecting the speed of their lives. This doesn't apply in Perfect, where Julie spends most of the time sitting around planning another wedding. Here, the dashing chat gives a documentary feel to material that might otherwise seem ridiculous. Bigamy is generally the plot of comedies because, in a time of almost habitual divorce, it seems improbable that someone would tie themselves down twice simultaneously. Making a wedding obsessive seem plausible, Perfect is slick and intelligent popular drama.

While producers would like us to sit down with fresh eyes, it's hard to see television shows in isolation. Perfect exists in relation to Best Of Both Worlds, and Simon Nye is now so well-known a writer that his latest sit-com - The Savages - seems to complete an unofficial trilogy after Men Behaving Badly and How Do You Want Me?

The first show featured the courting rituals of the unmarried young; the second the manoeuvres of young marrieds, leaving London to discover the sinister truth about rural life. None of the couples in these comedies were troubled by children. Now The Savages deals with middle-class married life with small babies. Adam (Marcus Brigstocke) and Jessica (Victoria Hamilton) are recognisable young parents: yawning, bickering, interviewing au pairs.

The presence of Geoffrey Palmer as a grandad commandeered for childcare connects the series with the past of sit-com but also reminds us of how thin in young children that history is. With the exception of the labour ward episode in Only Fools And Horses, most comedy characters - such as Palmer's dentist in Butterflies - have had grown-up children or none at all.

That's probably no accident. The problems that offspring bring in real life - making it hard to go out, dominating the conversation, inducing brain-death through exhaustion - are equally handicaps in drama. Kids in fiction always bring the risk of sentimentality. When we say that our children "did something funny" today, we usually mean something cute and to which outsiders are immune.

Nye sensibly keeps the Savages' children in bed for most of the time, but the opening episode doesn't solve the problem of the lack of incident in home-bound life. Promising signs, though, are a series of classy visual gags including an original act of marital revenge - putting your husband's filofax through a blender - and a pay-off involving a cuddly toy bought as a peace gift for a wife. This doesn't rank yet with Men Behaving Badly or How Do You Want Me?, but Nye is such a good writer that you hope he goes on to complete the seven ages of man in sit-coms, ending with a less whimsical alternative to The Last Of The Summer Wine.

 Perfect, tonight, 9pm, ITV. The Savages, Tuesday, 9pm, BBC1.

fields.headline: Pick of the day
fields.trailText: Radio: Inventors Imperfect | Lamacq Live | Nature
fields.body:
Adam Hart-Davies, embarking on a survey of Inventors Imperfect (11.0am, Radio 4), retells the story of George Stephenson. It took some time before this impoverished factory hand could develop an effective railway engine. As an adult he first had to learn to read and then to educate himself further with his son's homework. He worked as a cobbler, watchmaker, and tailor before tinkering sufficiently with John Blenkinsop's original locomotive to make it commercially viable. Even then, it was Stephenson's son Robert who did most work on the Rocket, for which George now figures in the history books.

An investigation into the corrupting power of rock music is inserted into the middle of Lamacq Live (8.0pm, Radio 1). The feature focuses on the thrash metal group Slayer, whose lyrics have praised everything from Satanism to the Nazi death camp doctor Joseph Mengele. The segment includes an interview with a couple who say their child was murdered because of the band's glorification of violence.

One exotic victim of the present foot and mouth epidemic was a pet llama. It was not actually infected: it just had the misfortune to be cloven-hoofed in a zone where that automatically brought the knacker's men. In Nature (9.0pm, Radio 4) Mark Carwardine wonders if the government's decision to kill almost any species remotely connected with the disease can be justified.

webTitle: TV review: Murder In Mind and Crime Team

fields.headline: Death by misadventure
fields.trailText: Murder In Mind | Crime Team
fields.body:
I wondered, perhaps for an inordinately long time, about The Mystery Of The Disappearing Pantomime Horse, as reported in Edward Palmer's newspaper in Murder In Mind (BBC1, Sunday). From where did the horse go missing? Was it ever found? Had it been dismembered? Did it stage its own disappearance to leave behind pantomime and ridicule and instead embark upon a life in serious theatre? Alas, we'll never know, for Edward (David Suchet) was much more concerned with the story headlined "YOUTH STABBED IN ALLEY", as you would be if you had knifed the said youth in the said alley.

While not quite relying on the Shaggy defence ("It wasn't me"), he hadn't meant to do it. As buttoned up as Ann Widdecombe's bloomers, this teacher had simply gone for a walk on a common, met a young man and given in to his repressed homosexual desires. After the junkie rent boy turned on him (and not in a good way), David accidentally stabbed him and scooted off - but not without being seen by the Branston estate's neighbourhood watch. And all this after an impressive six minutes, an indication of the pace and economy of this delicious and riveting story.

In a pickle after his encounter on the Branston estate, poor middle-class Edward was in turmoil when another horrible junkie - wearing the regulation scraggy jumper and hooded top they hand out at needle exchanges along with syringes - started to blackmail him, having found his credit card at the crime scene. So Edward did what any sane bloke would do. He tried to kill himself. On a day when his daughter was coming round to visit. Timing, it seems, wasn't his greatest forte.

It helped that his daughter was a nurse. Not so that she could help him recover from his carbon monoxide poisoning, but so she could also come over all murderous and calculating and organise the demise of his blackmailer.

Catrin (Gillian Kearney) was determined not to see her father vilified in the papers in the same way as her dead mother had been ("Doped Up Doctor In M1 Horror") and so set about nicking drugs from the hospital, tailing the bad junkie and plotting to inject him with methadone and diazepam. Now that's something you'd see in Where The Heart Is.

But in a twist in this tale, which was blissfully reminiscent of Alfred Hitchcock Presents and Tales Of The Unexpected, her dad stopped her with his decision to confess. Not one for giving up - the woman gave enemas for a living, remember - she persevered and immolated the bad junkie on his stinky mattress, but not before planting the murder weapon in his squat.

With the bad - and now crispy - junkie blamed for junkie rent boy's murder, they all lived happily ever after. Well, not exactly. Wracked with guilt, Edward returned to his car and suffocated himself with exhaust fumes once more (but at least Catrin would get the house in the will). Edward's involvement in the disappearance of the pantomime horse, however, will remain forever mysterious.

The morals of Murder In Mind seem pretty straightforward.

1) Don't mess with civil servants of any kind or they are liable to stab and/or fry you to death. (David Blunkett, take note.)

2) If you're an aspiring murderer, make sure it's the night before bin day so the dustbin men can dispose of your bloody clothes.

3) If you're going to kill someone, try and make sure that they are either a junkie or a prostitute or, ideally, both. The authorities won't really care all that much about them and you are quite likely to get away with it. (But you probably don't need me to tell you that.)

Crime Team (Channel 4, Sunday) picked up this theme and ran with it through the labyrinthine twists and turns of a Victorian quadruple murder. As compulsive as Murder In Mind, I can only hope it is the first in a series as it combined history, detective work, and the consultation of all sorts of jolly experts with an admittedly rather dubious fascination with true crime and the horrible effects of strychnine poisoning (it acts on the body in the same way as repeated viewing of Holby City) on prostitutes.

When the three investigators - Frances the novelist, Noel the private detective with the Beppe beard, and Yasmin the journalist - finally reached their conclusions, it was as exciting a dénouement as any detective novel's.

And the killer is...

fields.headline: A night to remember
fields.trailText: Radio review: Penny Gaffs And Angel Places | Beautiful Visions
fields.body:
Having once been stranded on the streets of Chelsea in full Dickensian costume (en route to a festival in Rochester, young and under duress), I warmed instantly to Penny Gaffs And Angel Places (Radio 4), a new play about a 30 mile walk Dickens took from London to Gad's Hill in Kent. Just as I did, the writer's presence on the city streets attracted unwanted attention, snide remarks and glances - in my case because I was in a get-up that was out-of-time by more than a century; in Dickens' case because it was the middle of the night.

But the writer had a lot on his mind, and this was the imaginative starting point for Mike Dorrell's play about Dickens's troubled marriage to his wife of 20 years, Catherine, as he falls in love with the 18-year-old actress Ellen Ternan. Nothing new there, you might be thinking, but Dorrell told his story with deft, innovative touches - the perfect prelude to the new five-part serial of Little Dorrit that began yesterday.

As Dickens walks along the dark streets, his own story unravels as he passes the settings for his novels; fictional scenes collide with childhood memories. Shady characters of the night shadow him ("it's only us, the voices of London, what have made you rich and famous"), sounding like John Lydon, Billy from EastEnders and Denise Van Outen. You wouldn't want them as company on your long journey of existential terror, asking the big questions ("why would a man like 'im frequent cemeteries and morgues and knackers' yards?") and reminding you of your lowly origins.

Siobhan Redmond played Georgina, Dickens's sister-in-law, and their house-keeper, a woman constrained by convention (she offers to get a doctor's letter to prove her virginity when there are rumours about her relationship with Dickens), but also strong enough to resist the languish-on-a-sofa-suffering-from-nerves response her sister takes to life. Fair enough, you might think, after 10 children in 10 years, several miscarriages, two treatments of laudanum and marriage to a genius with a wandering eye, but it's Georgina that we - and Dickens - prefer.

How different it might all have been had the long-suffering Catherine lived half-a-century later in Bourneville, the village that George Cadbury built for his workers and the subject of this week's Beautiful Visions (Radio 4). Cadbury's guidelines for a healthy life included bee-keeping, a cold bath each morning, and never brewing tea for more than three minutes.

webTitle: Satellite, cable & digital pick of the day

fields.headline: Pick of the day
fields.trailText: Satellite, cable & digital: The Man With The Golden Arm | Diner | My Name Is Joe | The Negotiator | Orphans | Live Football
fields.body:
Films

The Man With The Golden Arm (Otto Preminger, 1955) 8pm, FilmFour
The subject of drug addiction was supposedly a no-go area, but Preminger did it anyway, making a solid drama out of Nelson Algren's novel. Frank Sinatra is excellent as a Chicago jazz drummer trying to kick his heroin habit. Eleanor Parker as his disabled wife overloads the emotion; Kim Novak is better as the bargirl on the side. Good jazz music too.

Diner (Barry Levinson, 1982) 9pm, TCM
Levinson's directorial debut is set in his beloved Baltimore, circa 1959, where five pals are sitting out the vexatious rites of passage to adulthood in the neighbourhood diner. It's Christmas Eve-nostalgic, with engaging performances and a be-bopping soundtrack of period hits.

My Name Is Joe (Ken Loach, 1998) 10pm, FilmFour
Loach's romance between the unemployed, alcohol-dependent Joe (Peter Mullan) and middle-class social worker Sarah (Louise Goodall) beautifully points up social rifts in 90s Britain. Joe is getting by, coaching a local football team, but has to take another job - running drugs - to help heroin addict Liam (David McKay) out of the clutches of the local crime boss, and suddenly his relationship with Sarah is endangered. A perceptive, tender and funny film: nobody does real life, the marriage of bleak and warmth, like Loach.

The Negotiator (F Gary Gray, 1998) 10.05pm, Sky Premier
Samuel L Jackson's ace hostage negotiator is framed for murder and embezzlement; he reacts by taking his main accuser (JT Walsh) and a bunch of admin staff hostage, demanding that a negotiator from another district (Kevin Spacey) investigates the crisis. The pair are soon working together to root out top-level corruption. The face-off between two of US cinema's most charismatic leads provides Gray's clever drama with a powerful charge; it's a pity, though, that the pair share so little time on screen.

Orphans (Peter Mullan, 1997) 12.15am, FilmFour
This directorial debut of actor Peter Mullan, seen earlier this evening in My Name Is Joe (above), is a hard-hitting blend of social drama and gallows humour. It has the Flynn siblings - Michael (Douglas Henshall), Thomas (Gary Lewis), Sheila (Rosemarie Stevenson) and John (Stephen McCole) - gathering in a Glasgow pub the evening before their mother's funeral. There is a stabbing and the four go their separate ways, each dealing with feelings of grief and anger through one long, boozily eventful night.
Paul Howlett

Sports

Live Football 7.30pm, Sky Sports 1
With the Scottish Premier Division title already decided, interest and attention turns to the bottom of the league. St Mirren currently occupy the 12th spot, and Dundee United are the only team that have given them a run for their money in the failure stakes this season. Generally these less fancied sides are only ever on television if one of the Old Firm are the opposition - you don't get a chance to see them win very often. Let's hope it's not a draw.
Simon Burnton

Diner (Barry Levinson, 1982) 9pm, TCM Levinson's directorial debut is set in his beloved Baltimore, circa 1959, where five pals are sitting out the vexatious rites of passage to adulthood in the neighbourhood diner. It's Christmas Eve-nostalgic, with engaging performances and a be-bopping soundtrack of period hits. My Name Is Joe (Ken Loach, 1998) 10pm, FilmFour Loach's romance between the unemployed, alcohol-dependent Joe (Peter Mullan) and middle-class social worker Sarah (Louise Goodall) beautifully points up social rifts in 90s Britain. Joe is getting by, coaching a local football team, but has to take another job - running drugs - to help heroin addict Liam (David McKay) out of the clutches of the local crime boss, and suddenly his relationship with Sarah is endangered. A perceptive, tender and funny film: nobody does real life, the marriage of bleak and warmth, like Loach. The Negotiator (F Gary Gray, 1998) 10.05pm, Sky Premier Samuel L Jackson's ace hostage negotiator is framed for murder and embezzlement; he reacts by taking his main accuser (JT Walsh) and a bunch of admin staff hostage, demanding that a negotiator from another district (Kevin Spacey) investigates the crisis. The pair are soon working together to root out top-level corruption. The face-off between two of US cinema's most charismatic leads provides Gray's clever drama with a powerful charge; it's a pity, though, that the pair share so little time on screen. Orphans (Peter Mullan, 1997) 12.15am, FilmFour This directorial debut of actor Peter Mullan, seen earlier this evening in My Name Is Joe (above), is a hard-hitting blend of social drama and gallows humour. It has the Flynn siblings - Michael (Douglas Henshall), Thomas (Gary Lewis), Sheila (Rosemarie Stevenson) and John (Stephen McCole) - gathering in a Glasgow pub the evening before their mother's funeral. There is a stabbing and the four go their separate ways, each dealing with feelings of grief and anger through one long, boozily eventful night. Paul Howlett Sports Live Football 7.30pm, Sky Sports 1 With the Scottish Premier Division title already decided, interest and attention turns to the bottom of the league. St Mirren currently occupy the 12th spot, and Dundee United are the only team that have given them a run for their money in the failure stakes this season. Generally these less fancied sides are only ever on television if one of the Old Firm are the opposition - you don't get a chance to see them win very often. Let's hope it's not a draw. Simon Burnton

webTitle: 30,000 runners take London in their stride

fields.headline: 30,000 runners take London in their stride
fields.standfirst: Last-minute drama and a wedding at Cleopatra's Needle as the marathon hits the road with Steve Redgrave in the vanguard
fields.trailText: The rain stayed away and the sun came out yesterday as more than 30,000 runners took to the capital's streets in one of the biggest turnouts in the 21-year history of the London marathon.
fields.body:
The rain stayed away and the sun came out yesterday as more than 30,000 runners took to the capital's streets in one of the biggest turnouts in the 21-year history of the London marathon.

The race was marred when a spectator burst from the crowd and tried to trip up the victor in the women's marathon, Derartu Tulu, as she approached the finishing line.

Tulu managed to evade the attacker and cruised home in a personal best time of two hours 23 minutes and 56 seconds. The Ethiopian runner crossed the line six seconds ahead of Svetlana Akharova, from Russia, who finished second.

Despite that incident, the event was described by organisers as a tremendous success with the usual mixture of professional runners, fun runners and charity fund raisers pounding the route.

The men's race was won convincingly by the Moroccan Abdelkader El Mouaziz, in a personal record time of two hours, seven minutes and 11 seconds. Paul Tergat, a Kenyan, came second - taking two hours, eight minutes and 15 seconds - and completing his first marathon.

The marathon was started by the rower Sir Steve Redgrave - five times an Olympic champion - who had the honour of wearing the bib bearing number one, normally reserved for the defending champion. "This is the biggest lap of honour I've done in my life," he said.

Among those running the course was New Yorker Adam Weintraub, who at 91 was the oldest taking part. He finished in just over seven and a half hours.

One couple running together managed to fit in their wedding at the 25th mile.

Angela Stratford, 34 (in knee-length wedding dress), and Nigel Jones, 48, both from Cwmbran, Gwent, enjoyed a 20-minute ceremony on the steps of Cleopatra's Needle on the Embankment after running for four hours and before continuing to the finishing line proudly waving a "Just Married" banner.

fields.headline: Letter: Wilf Page
fields.trailText: Shortly after Wilf Page (Obituary, April 20) was posted to RAF Uxbridge, before the first world war, he came across two men shouting they were going to "scrub the dirty Yid clean" while holding another down in the ablutions.
fields.body:
Terry Monaghan writes..
Shortly after Wilf Page (Obituary, April 20) was posted to RAF Uxbridge, before the first world war, he came across two men shouting they were going to "scrub the dirty Yid clean" while holding another down in the ablutions. The bigotry was lost on a former country lad, but he recognised bullying and, together with my uncle, Dan Cohen, summarily dealt with the two anti-semites.

It was the beginning of a lifelong friendship, but it wasn't until Dan was excluded from the Royal Tournament RAF gun-carriage team for being Jewish that Wilf discovered there were wider issues involved. After protesting vigorously, Wilf became the only non-Jewish member of the Lancaster that Dan eventually captained. At the end of the war they volunteered to ferry Italian Jewish survivors from Belsen back to their homeland.

In 1951 Dan persuaded Wilf to become his election agent when he stood as the Communist Party candidate for North Paddington. Street fighting with the local fascists echoed their first meeting, but Wilf was on the ascendant, as he remained for the rest of his uncompromising but productive life.

fields.headline: The Duke of Argyll
fields.standfirst: Landowner who rebuilt his family fortune
fields.trailText: The multilingual 12th Duke of Argyll, who has died of heart failure during surgery aged 63, always said he wanted to keep "a low profile behind my ramparts" at Inveraray Castle.
fields.body:
The multilingual 12th Duke of Argyll, who has died of heart failure during surgery aged 63, always said he wanted to keep "a low profile behind my ramparts" at Inveraray Castle. Despite a double fistful of honorary titles, such as the Keeper of the Great Seal of Scotland, and an active business life, he succeeded in cultivating new obscurity, partly by staying away from the House of Lords, where he took the Conservative whip.

This was normal for a man who retained 81,000 of the family's acres, spread over much of Argyll, reduced from the 175,000 held in 1877. He sold the island of Iona in 1979 to pay off family death duties. When Inveraray Castle, his 90-room 18th-century family home overlooking Loch Fyne, was badly damaged by fire in 1975, he made a public appeal to the clan Campbell, which he headed, to finance its restoration. When, shortly thereafter, he was revealed as one of Britain's richest men with a fortune of £87m, lots of contributors asked for their money back.

He rebuilt his family fortune by such things as charging tourists £1,000 a week to stalk deer at Inveraray. He also charged the Japanese £245 a bottle for his 21-year-old Highland single malt whisky.

The family history of the Campbell clan was colourful, especially that of the first duke, whose father and grandfather were executed.

Ian Campbell was born the son of Captain Ian Campbell and Louise (Clews). It was only in 1949 that his father succeeded a cousin to become the 11th duke. "The first time I saw (Inveraray) castle was when I was nine and my parents had come to have tea. They made me wait outside in the car with the chauffeur. It was just another big house to me. Until then I'd never heard of it - and certainly not that one day I would inherit it." His mother did not even tell him that he was Marquess of Lorne when his father became the 11th duke.

After his mother died he acquired a vivacious stepmother, Mathilda, who employed young, male, Oxbridge secretaries, insisting: "It's rather convenient when you need an escort or an extra man at the dinner table." He acquired the first of his seven foreign languages by starting his education at Le Rosey in Switzerland, going on to Glenalmond in Scotland and then McGill University in Montreal.

Before he succeeded to the dukedom in 1975, he used his command of languages in business. He was a Rank Xerox export executive in the late 1960s and was able to take credit when the first photocopy shop later opened in Moscow.

Recently his activities had been concentrated more locally on increasing his estate's profits by putting in caravan parks, and on companies such as the Aberlour Glenlivet distillery.

He leaves his wife of 36 years, Iona Mary (Colquhoun), a daughter and his son and heir, Torquil, recently the Marquess of Lorne, who inherits as the 13th Duke of Argyll.

 Ian Campbell, 12th Duke of Argyll, businessman and landowner, born August 28 1937; died April 22 2001

webTitle: Michele Hanson: kids having kids of their own

fields.headline: When the kids have kids of their own
fields.trailText: Rosemary was staring into her new garden the other day, dreaming of grandchildren. In her dream, the child fell and hit its little head on the paving stones. So Rosemary started planning a lawn and a swing.
fields.body:
Rosemary was staring into her new garden the other day, dreaming of grandchildren. In her dream, the child fell and hit its little head on the paving stones. So Rosemary started planning a lawn and a swing. But wait a minute. Who is she kidding? Things have changed since she last entertained an infant. Grass and a swing will be only a brief diversion. Then what will she do?

Last week Rosemary's chums had their grandchildren to stay. The children were rather picky about their yoghurts - having one taste, shouting "Yuck!" and then begging for PlayStations.

"We don't have a PlayStation," said Grandma. "Let's go to the park."

"We went there last week," said the grandchildren grumpily and demanded a video. The grandparents did as they were told. They always do. Every birthday and Christmas they must buy the latest monstrous robotic, crying, weeing, yabbering toy or repugnant dolly, or the grandchildren won't be bothered to visit them. What's more, the grandchildren do not have a bedtime. Their parents insist that they be allowed to wander around until they faint with exhaustion.

But things could go the other way. Your child might become a fearfully austere mummy and forbid chocs, cakes, crisps, Sindy, Furbies and videos. Now that we live on a poisoned and dying planet, this sort of mummy is on the up. Or perhaps the mummy is blameless. There she is, trying to preserve her child's teeth and protect it from E numbers, but the grandparent will stuff it with chocs and puddings or clamp it on the potty for life. Imagine the argument potential.

What a turn-up for the books. One minute your child is a wilful teenager, nothing is your business, then suddenly she's turned into a ghastly martinet, bossing you about over childcare. It seems that the wilder and ruder she was as an adolescent, the tidier and bossier she may be as a mummy.

Hopefully Rosemary's experience would be different: cooperative, civilised and striking the perfect balance between liberal and structured. She had a chat with her own daughter about future grandchildren. "Would you have them to stay, Mum?" asked the daughter.

"Of course," sighed Rosemary dreamily. "I'd give them fish fingers, chips and ketchup."

"No you would not!" snapped the daughter. "It didn't do us much good!" Dream on, Rosemary.

fields.headline: Me, myself, I
fields.standfirst: According to the latest figures, more than a quarter of all British women are single. How does it feel to be one of them? Are you delighted about it - or are you desperately seeking someone, anyone, to make a couple? We asked four single women to come clean. Interviews by Marina Cantacuzino
fields.trailText: According to the latest figures, more than a quarter of all British women are single. How does it feel to be one of them? Are you delighted about it - or are you desperately seeking someone, anyone, to make a couple? We asked four single women to come clean. Interviews by Marina Cantacuzino.
fields.body:
Tor Docherty, 25 A helpline manager for Cruse Bereavement Care.

I have always enjoyed being single but recently I've realised that I would actually quite like not to be any more. I'd like to have someone I can come home to, someone to snuggle up to. It's the soppy side of things I'm after. Often I go places and it's a little bit coupley which makes me feel I'd like to have that, too. I'm not exactly pining or actively searching but by the time I'm 35 I would like to have children with another woman, which means probably being in a relationship by the time I'm 30.

Gay life operates around "the scene" which takes place in clubs and pubs, but I'm not into that. I look miserable in a club and am not very approachable. So I rely on meeting people through friends. Of course there are fewer choices like this, but there are fewer anyway if you're gay. If you accept the statistic that 10% of people are gay, that means 90% aren't interested even before you begin. Unlike heterosexuals, you can't assume most people are like you, so the chance of my meeting someone at work, for example, is slim.

If I bump into someone I quite fancy in the street, before I can even think whether she fancies me back, I have to ask myself: "Is she gay?" So I always have to jump that hurdle first. I've met bits of the right person but I want them all rolled into one.

Over the past couple of years, I've come out to more or less everyone (thanks to having friends and a supportive family), though obviously each time I go into a new situation I have to begin all over again. I don't think being out makes meeting someone any easier but it does mean that at least everyone knows the kind of person I'm interested in.

A couple of years ago, I placed an ad in a newspaper with a gay friend. He wrote my ad and I wrote his - it seemed easier to be honest that way. I remember he said something about my loving life, which people responded to. I didn't follow up any of the replies because at the time it was just a bit of fun, but if I'm still searching in the future, I wouldn't rule out doing it more seriously.

My social life revolves around my friends, who are mostly gay men and lesbians, plus some straight women. We get together for dinner and recently I went on a girlie weekend to Europe. We hired an apartment and did a few cultural things, as well as a few drunken things!

What with my friends and my work, my life is extremely full and I know if I had a relationship I'd have to make space for it. Living alone makes you a bit selfish and I'd have to adjust. What I like about being single is the irresponsibility of it. I can do whatever I want, when I want. I don't have to ring anyone to say I'm not coming home. Not having to negotiate things with someone is great. But if I met the right person I'd be willing to sacrifice all that.

Carol Slesser, 50 An executive coach working in career and confidence building.

Single women my age are in a strong position these days because there are a lot of men out there: widowers, divorced men and people like me who've never married. My main place for meeting new people is at ceroc nights. Ceroc is a blend of jive and salsa, and what's great about it is that there are always more men than women. It's also acceptable for women to ask men to dance.

I adore it. Usually I try things and get bored but not with ceroc. It's fun, it's good for the soul and it's somewhere you can go on your own and not be dependent on anyone - 81% of people who do ceroc are single.

In the past I've tried dinner clubs but they were expensive and felt like cattle markets. Ceroc is an interest, not a club, and a place where you meet real quality people such as lawyers, lecturers and surgeons.

Once or twice I've tried advertising in papers, too, but that's never worked. Even if you specify that you don't want anyone married, married men still answer, saying they're alone in town during the week. I hate pubs and clubs, and at this stage of my life I'd never go there to pick someone up.

When you get over 35, the internet is a very acceptable way of meeting men and I like the fact that you're in control. If someone emails me with their number, I always call them first so I can hear what their voice sounds like. It's the best way of sifting through the replies. I've met some very interesting people through the internet - usually professional and middle-income - but I've never actually had a relationship with someone.

Last year I met a lovely 50-year-old man with his own business who was a wonderful person but just not for me, so I introduced him to a friend instead. I went to their wedding last month. Being single can be a bit like pass the parcel!

I've been on solo holidays, too, which are ideal if you don't want to go away on your own, but they've never led to a relationship because the women are usually of a higher calibre than the men. I also go to the opera and ballet, and I like entertaining my friends. Sometimes I go on courses, too. The other day I went on a fabulous one about happiness and laughter.

I've had a number of serious relationships in my life and a couple that have lasted a little over three years. Although I'm single now, for the first time in my life I've got a number of male friends. They are all people I've had relationships with but have now become good friends which is lovely.

I've reached a stage and an age at which I'm not desperately seeking a relationship. It'll happen if it happens. But I'm not like a lot of my friends who have given up and can't be bothered any more. I don't believe someone will come knocking on the door. In business, as well as socially, you've got to make your own map in this world.

Christina Sesay, 40s A bridalwear designer who makes and sells individual dresses.

When I was a few years younger, I would go out with the express intention of meeting people, but now I go out to be with my friends and to have a good time. I go to bars or for meals in people's houses, and I go to the gym. I don't like being at home too many nights in a row: home is somewhere to come back to.

About once every two weeks I go dancing at a soul and funk club. It's full of people my age who go there because they enjoy the music, not because they're off their heads on drugs. I don't necessarily go to chat or pick someone up, though it can happen.

I advertised to meet someone once but it was a jokey thing I did with a girlfriend. We even had men who were married answering the ad. My guess is that it's the same group of guys doing the rounds. We arranged to meet two of them but either they didn't turn up or they were the two old men in the corner who had lied about their age! I wouldn't do it again.

It's dreadful if people start to get hysterical about being single. I heard of one woman once who was invited to a dinner party with only couples and when she realised, she got up and walked out. A good meal would not make me leave the table!

The trouble is, you don't meet men when you design bridalwear. I sometimes wonder if that's the reason why I'm still single - a lot of people meet their partners through work, after all.

When I hit my mid-30s, a strong maternal urge took hold of me and I really wanted to get married and to have a baby - but it wasn't to be. It made me a bit hysterical for a while but once I had come to terms with it, I just got on with my life and thought about getting a dog instead.

I've never been married and I've never lived with anyone but I have had plenty of relationships, so if I'm honest there must be a part of me that is frightened of commitment. My predicament is that I meet men who are younger than me. It's fine to start with but the problem comes when you want something more serious and they're not ready.

It's not that I don't like men - I think I like men better the older I get because I'm not trying to make a man like a girlfriend any more. Recently I've been much more comfortable about myself and I've stopped wondering when Mr Perfect will turn up.

I've had many relationships over the years and enjoyed all of them. I believe that as a woman gets older, she should have a good sex life because it holds back the menopause. In some ways I feel really lucky being single because it means I've had the longest youth you can imagine.

Lesley Leigh, 34 In the second year of a complementary therapies degree.

I have never gone out searching for a partner. I've seen too many people standing there with a big neon sign over their head and a desperate look on their face. It frightens the life out of me and I've vowed I'll never be like that. I find the idea of dinner clubs, ads and dating agencies all rather amusing. It's fine for other people but it's not the level I work at.

Although I'm not out looking for someone, it doesn't mean I lead a boring life. I have a lot of good friends and try to do loads of different things. Diversity is the spice of life.

I'd like a relationship, but I can't be doing with mind games any more. The will-he-won't-he aspect of a relationship can really knock your confidence. I want someone who is comfortable and open with me.

I have an 11-year-old daughter and obviously having a child makes a difference. If I were in a relationship, the man would have to take Kady on board, too. If he didn't like children it wouldn't go anywhere because she is part and parcel of who I am.

I have one very good male friend I used to go out with all the time, until he moved up north. Now I only see him a couple of times a month and I miss him a lot. We're as close as two friends can be and tend to do what most couples do - go to pubs, clubs and cinemas. There's an element of safety when you've got a man with you. We have this thing, too, where he'll point out someone and say "He's attractive" or "He's watching you" and I'll do the same to him about a woman.

I have a network of close and reliable friends. We all go out in a group, but recently it's got a bit boring going to the same pub all the time, so now we try to organise something different each time. It's nice if someone new comes along as it adds a bit of spice.

I don't usually get lonely, but sometimes I can feel a bit sorry for myself if I haven't organised something to do or I've had one of those days that starts out on a high and ends on a low. The sort of day you just want someone to come home to.

I used to go to the West End a lot with my friend but it doesn't have such a pull any more. Everyone seems to be getting younger and I think to myself: "I was like that 10 years ago." Part of me would like to be like that again but the mature side of me says: "You've done that and you didn't really enjoy it, so what makes you think 12 years later it'll be any better?"

I don't like going to pubs where there are only people in their 20s. A few months ago a 22-year-old chap got chatting to me and he found it very hard to comprehend that a 33-year-old woman with an 11-year-old child might be there just to have a dance and not be out looking for someone.

I'm quite surprised I've been single for five years, but I certainly don't mind. It suits my life at the moment and I'm not stressed about meeting someone. If it happens, it happens.

I'd like to have someone I can come home to, someone to snuggle up to. It's the soppy side of things I'm after. Often I go places and it's a little bit coupley which makes me feel I'd like to have that, too. I'm not exactly pining or actively searching but by the time I'm 35 I would like to have children with another woman, which means probably being in a relationship by the time I'm 30. Gay life operates around "the scene" which takes place in clubs and pubs, but I'm not into that. I look miserable in a club and am not very approachable. So I rely on meeting people through friends. Of course there are fewer choices like this, but there are fewer anyway if you're gay. If you accept the statistic that 10% of people are gay, that means 90% aren't interested even before you begin. Unlike heterosexuals, you can't assume most people are like you, so the chance of my meeting someone at work, for example, is slim. If I bump into someone I quite fancy in the street, before I can even think whether she fancies me back, I have to ask myself: "Is she gay?" So I always have to jump that hurdle first. I've met bits of the right person but I want them all rolled into one. Over the past couple of years, I've come out to more or less everyone (thanks to having friends and a supportive family), though obviously each time I go into a new situation I have to begin all over again. I don't think being out makes meeting someone any easier but it does mean that at least everyone knows the kind of person I'm interested in. A couple of years ago, I placed an ad in a newspaper with a gay friend. He wrote my ad and I wrote his - it seemed easier to be honest that way. I remember he said something about my loving life, which people responded to. I didn't follow up any of the replies because at the time it was just a bit of fun, but if I'm still searching in the future, I wouldn't rule out doing it more seriously. My social life revolves around my friends, who are mostly gay men and lesbians, plus some straight women. We get together for dinner and recently I went on a girlie weekend to Europe. We hired an apartment and did a few cultural things, as well as a few drunken things! What with my friends and my work, my life is extremely full and I know if I had a relationship I'd have to make space for it. Living alone makes you a bit selfish and I'd have to adjust. What I like about being single is the irresponsibility of it. I can do whatever I want, when I want. I don't have to ring anyone to say I'm not coming home. Not having to negotiate things with someone is great. But if I met the right person I'd be willing to sacrifice all that. Carol Slesser, 50 An executive coach working in career and confidence building. Single women my age are in a strong position these days because there are a lot of men out there: widowers, divorced men and people like me who've never married. My main place for meeting new people is at ceroc nights. Ceroc is a blend of jive and salsa, and what's great about it is that there are always more men than women. It's also acceptable for women to ask men to dance. I adore it. Usually I try things and get bored but not with ceroc. It's fun, it's good for the soul and it's somewhere you can go on your own and not be dependent on anyone - 81% of people who do ceroc are single. In the past I've tried dinner clubs but they were expensive and felt like cattle markets. Ceroc is an interest, not a club, and a place where you meet real quality people such as lawyers, lecturers and surgeons. Once or twice I've tried advertising in papers, too, but that's never worked. Even if you specify that you don't want anyone married, married men still answer, saying they're alone in town during the week. I hate pubs and clubs, and at this stage of my life I'd never go there to pick someone up. When you get over 35, the internet is a very acceptable way of meeting men and I like the fact that you're in control. If someone emails me with their number, I always call them first so I can hear what their voice sounds like. It's the best way of sifting through the replies. I've met some very interesting people through the internet - usually professional and middle-income - but I've never actually had a relationship with someone. Last year I met a lovely 50-year-old man with his own business who was a wonderful person but just not for me, so I introduced him to a friend instead. I went to their wedding last month. Being single can be a bit like pass the parcel! I've been on solo holidays, too, which are ideal if you don't want to go away on your own, but they've never led to a relationship because the women are usually of a higher calibre than the men. I also go to the opera and ballet, and I like entertaining my friends. Sometimes I go on courses, too. The other day I went on a fabulous one about happiness and laughter. I've had a number of serious relationships in my life and a couple that have lasted a little over three years. Although I'm single now, for the first time in my life I've got a number of male friends. They are all people I've had relationships with but have now become good friends which is lovely. I've reached a stage and an age at which I'm not desperately seeking a relationship. It'll happen if it happens. But I'm not like a lot of my friends who have given up and can't be bothered any more. I don't believe someone will come knocking on the door. In business, as well as socially, you've got to make your own map in this world. Christina Sesay, 40s A bridalwear designer who makes and sells individual dresses. When I was a few years younger, I would go out with the express intention of meeting people, but now I go out to be with my friends and to have a good time. I go to bars or for meals in people's houses, and I go to the gym. I don't like being at home too many nights in a row: home is somewhere to come back to. About once every two weeks I go dancing at a soul and funk club. It's full of people my age who go there because they enjoy the music, not because they're off their heads on drugs. I don't necessarily go to chat or pick someone up, though it can happen. I advertised to meet someone once but it was a jokey thing I did with a girlfriend. We even had men who were married answering the ad. My guess is that it's the same group of guys doing the rounds. We arranged to meet two of them but either they didn't turn up or they were the two old men in the corner who had lied about their age! I wouldn't do it again. It's dreadful if people start to get hysterical about being single. I heard of one woman once who was invited to a dinner party with only couples and when she realised, she got up and walked out. A good meal would not make me leave the table! The trouble is, you don't meet men when you design bridalwear. I sometimes wonder if that's the reason why I'm still single - a lot of people meet their partners through work, after all. When I hit my mid-30s, a strong maternal urge took hold of me and I really wanted to get married and to have a baby - but it wasn't to be. It made me a bit hysterical for a while but once I had come to terms with it, I just got on with my life and thought about getting a dog instead. I've never been married and I've never lived with anyone but I have had plenty of relationships, so if I'm honest there must be a part of me that is frightened of commitment. My predicament is that I meet men who are younger than me. It's fine to start with but the problem comes when you want something more serious and they're not ready. It's not that I don't like men - I think I like men better the older I get because I'm not trying to make a man like a girlfriend any more. Recently I've been much more comfortable about myself and I've stopped wondering when Mr Perfect will turn up. I've had many relationships over the years and enjoyed all of them. I believe that as a woman gets older, she should have a good sex life because it holds back the menopause. In some ways I feel really lucky being single because it means I've had the longest youth you can imagine. Lesley Leigh, 34 In the second year of a complementary therapies degree. I have never gone out searching for a partner. I've seen too many people standing there with a big neon sign over their head and a desperate look on their face. It frightens the life out of me and I've vowed I'll never be like that. I find the idea of dinner clubs, ads and dating agencies all rather amusing. It's fine for other people but it's not the level I work at. Although I'm not out looking for someone, it doesn't mean I lead a boring life. I have a lot of good friends and try to do loads of different things. Diversity is the spice of life. I'd like a relationship, but I can't be doing with mind games any more. The will-he-won't-he aspect of a relationship can really knock your confidence. I want someone who is comfortable and open with me. I have an 11-year-old daughter and obviously having a child makes a difference. If I were in a relationship, the man would have to take Kady on board, too. If he didn't like children it wouldn't go anywhere because she is part and parcel of who I am. I have one very good male friend I used to go out with all the time, until he moved up north. Now I only see him a couple of times a month and I miss him a lot. We're as close as two friends can be and tend to do what most couples do - go to pubs, clubs and cinemas. There's an element of safety when you've got a man with you. We have this thing, too, where he'll point out someone and say "He's attractive" or "He's watching you" and I'll do the same to him about a woman. I have a network of close and reliable friends. We all go out in a group, but recently it's got a bit boring going to the same pub all the time, so now we try to organise something different each time. It's nice if someone new comes along as it adds a bit of spice. I don't usually get lonely, but sometimes I can feel a bit sorry for myself if I haven't organised something to do or I've had one of those days that starts out on a high and ends on a low. The sort of day you just want someone to come home to. I used to go to the West End a lot with my friend but it doesn't have such a pull any more. Everyone seems to be getting younger and I think to myself: "I was like that 10 years ago." Part of me would like to be like that again but the mature side of me says: "You've done that and you didn't really enjoy it, so what makes you think 12 years later it'll be any better?" I don't like going to pubs where there are only people in their 20s. A few months ago a 22-year-old chap got chatting to me and he found it very hard to comprehend that a 33-year-old woman with an 11-year-old child might be there just to have a dance and not be out looking for someone. I'm quite surprised I've been single for five years, but I certainly don't mind. It suits my life at the moment and I'm not stressed about meeting someone. If it happens, it happens.

webTitle: Strike threat tests new opera chief

fields.headline: Strike threat tests new opera chief
fields.trailText: Tony Hall, the new director of the Royal Opera House, faces his first major challenge this week when he will try to head off a potentially crippling strike by backstage staff furious at disciplinary action being taken against a shop steward.
fields.body:
Tony Hall, the new director of the Royal Opera House, faces his first major challenge this week when he will try to head off a potentially crippling strike by backstage staff furious at disciplinary action being taken against a shop steward.

The BBC's former head of news, who took over the reins at Covent Garden at the beginning of the month, will meet union officials in an attempt to avert the strike, which could threaten forthcoming productions including La Traviata, The Queen of Spades and Otello.

About 80% of Bectu members who voted in the ballot have backed industrial action over the way ROH management has dealt with Pat Styles, a shop steward who was suspended in January after some members of staff accused him of aggressive behaviour and bullying. The union claims it is Mr Styles's position as a union official that lies behind the disciplinary hearings and says it is not the first time union representatives have come under pressure at the Royal Opera House.

Gerry Morrissey, assistant general secretary of Bectu, said: "We hope that these talks will be successful, but this will depend on the management's attitude. We hope that Tony Hall will bring home to the management a sober recognition that, as a publicly funded body, the opera house cannot afford to wage war on its workers' trade union."

But management at Covent Garden, who instituted disciplinary procedures against Mr Styles that had to be postponed due to his ill health, said the allegations of bullying and intimidation had been made by other members of staff, including some Bectu members.

"It seems the union feels it is inappropriate for someone who is a union official to be subject to the same procedures as any other member of staff. But that is not the view of the ROH management," a spokesman said.

The spokesman said that nearly half of the Bectu members had not voted, and only 43% of the total voted yes.

So far Mr Hall has not been personally involved in the dispute, which was initially handled by John Seekings, acting executive director after the departure of Michael Kaiser in December.

Talks at the conciliation service Acas have not resolved the issue, and the union has called on management to accept a compromise involving both sides taking part in a programme of training in negotiation techniques and human resource management.

Any concessions at Acas this week are likely to be hard fought. Mr Hall, 49, is seen as a hard-nosed administrator.

Mr Morrissey said: "Initially we are not going to set out to cause performances to be cancelled, but it may get to the stage where we have no alternative."

webTitle: Two charged over bag snatch death

fields.headline: Two charged over bag snatch death
fields.trailText: A man and a woman will appear in court today charged with the murder of Liz Sherlock, who was run over and killed last week while chasing thieves who had stolen her handbag.
fields.body:
A man and a woman will appear in court today charged with the murder of Liz Sherlock, who was run over and killed last week while chasing thieves who had stolen her handbag.

Jackie Moorhouse, 23, who is unemployed, and Mark Wooley, 35, a plasterer and tiler, were charged yesterday with the killing. They will appear at Highbury Corner magistrates court, north London.

The pair, from north London, were arrested early on Thursday following an intelligence tip-off and surveillance operation.

Mrs Sherlock, 42, a costume designer from Chiswick, west London, was killed on Monday outside Euston station, central London, after her bag was snatched.

She chased the thieves into the street but was thrown on to the bonnet of their getaway car, before being shaken off and run over.

She died later of multiple injuries.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Prozac can help women with severe premenstrual symptoms, according to a study published in the British Journal of Obstetrics and Gynaecology today. The antidepressant was tested on 320 women.
fields.body:
Prozac 'helps' PMT sufferers

Prozac can help women with severe premenstrual symptoms, according to a study published in the British Journal of Obstetrics and Gynaecology today. The antidepressant was tested on 320 women.

Excuses for skipping work

A worker said he could not turn up at the office because his rabbit was sick. This was one of the more notable excuses found by the London-based recruitment firm Personnel & Care Bank during research on why workers take days off.

Bullies resort to mobile phones

Mobile phones are being used for bullying, an NOP survey claimed yesterday, after 1,013 people aged seven to 16 were interviewed in March. Overall, 14% had been bullied, with one in five aged between 14 and 16 receiving nasty calls.

In love with Shakespeare

Half of the population have seen a Shakespeare play at the theatre, according to a Mori poll commissioned by the Royal Shakespeare Company.

Duke of Argyll dies during op

The 12th Duke of Argyll has died suddenly, his estate said yesterday. Ian Campbell, Scotland's second most senior duke, suffered a cardiac arrest during surgery at a London hospital. Obituary, page 20

£12m shared

Four shared the £12m jackpot in Saturday's national lottery rollover. The winning numbers were 12, 20, 23, 26, 33 and 46, the bonus number 1. No one won lottery extra or thunderball.

webTitle: Court gig for REM star after 'air rage' episode

fields.headline: Court gig for REM star after 'air rage' episode
fields.trailText: Since they hit the big time a decade ago, it seemed REM could safely be filed alongside the Lighthouse Family as the comfortable thirtysomething's bland soundtrack of choice.
fields.body:
Since they hit the big time a decade ago, it seemed REM could safely be filed alongside the Lighthouse Family as the comfortable thirtysomething's bland soundtrack of choice.

That was until Saturday night, when guitarist Peter Buck allegedly made a belated attempt to acquire rock'n'roll bad boy status.

Buck, 44, will appear at Uxbridge magistrates court, west London, today to answer a string of "air rage" charges after claims that he was involved in a drunken outburst on a flight to Britain.

It is alleged this involved hurling a yoghurt at a steward across the first class cabin of a BA flight from Seattle to Heathrow.

REM are to headline a concert for peace in London on Sunday, paid for by the South African government as a thank you to Britain for aiding the fight against apartheid. Fellow band members Michael Stipe and Mike Mills had already flown in.

Buck, from East Seattle, Washington, is charged with criminal damage to crockery, disobeying an aircraft commander, being drunk on an aircraft, and using threatening or abusive words or behaviour. He is also charged with assaulting a male and female member of cabin crew.

He was arrested when the flight landed on Saturday and charged after spending six hours at Heathrow police station.

REM, for years a cult American college rock band, became superstars in 1991 with Out of Time, which spawned the hits Losing My Religion and Shiny Happy People.

webTitle: Welders in the buff voted best in English film poll

fields.headline: Welders in the buff voted best in English film poll
fields.trailText: When it comes to the perfect celluloid representation of Englishness, nothing, it seems, can beat a story about naked welders.
fields.body:
Forget country houses and crinolines, foppish urban comedy or classic gangster nostalgia, when it comes to the perfect celluloid representation of Englishness, nothing, it seems, can beat a story about naked welders.

The Full Monty, the film about a group of unemployed Sheffield steel workers who put on a strip show, has been voted the favourite English movie of all time, beating classics such as The Italian Job and more recent hits such as Four Weddings and a Funeral.

In a poll conducted to coincide with St George's day, 5,000 readers of Empire Online, the movie website, voted the 1997 film the finest to emerge from the land of Lord Olivier, Sir Michael Caine and the Carry On films.

The film, starring Robert Carlyle and directed by Peter Cattaneo, won an Oscar for best music and was nominated for three others. It became the highest grossing British film upon its release, a record that is under threat from the newly released Bridget Jones's Diary, which, last week, achieved the UK's highest-earning opening weekend.

Catherine Hanly, editor of the Empire Online site, expressed surprise at the preference, with the Caine classic The Italian Job coming second and Four Weddings and a Funeral sixth among the eight offered to web browsers in the poll. "I'm most surprised by how low down Four Weddings came," she said. "As the third highest grossing British movie of all time, it obviously doesn't impress our readers that much."

The English, she speculated, identify more with naked northern failures than with middle-class home counties thirtysomethings moving from one friend's wedding to the next. "Given that the Full Monty is a real triumph over adversity tale, it's the perfect movie to represent the English on St George's day," she said.

The film, which culminates in an entirely naked strip show or "full monty", became a surprise hit in the US, spawning a Broadway stage show.

However, while it has been criticised by some for portraying a cliched image of northern poverty, it is not without its high-profile admirers. Prince Charles celebrated his 50th birthday in 1998 by staging a memorable re-enactment of one of the film's dance routines during a visit to a Sheffield unemployment office, a gyrating number to the tune of Donna Summer's Hot Stuff.

Home choice

1 The Full Monty 29%

2 The Italian Job 23%

3 Lock, Stock and Two Smoking Barrels 22%

4 Withnail and I 8%

5 The Third Man 6%

6Four Weddings and a Funeral 5%

7Get Carter 5%

8 The Ladykillers 3%

webTitle: Horse ripper fears are false, says researcher

fields.headline: Horse ripper fears are false, says researcher
fields.trailText: Most mutilations of horses which have been blamed on sadistic attackers are in reality caused by accidents or by other animals, a leading member of a charity for horses claimed yesterday.
fields.body:
Most mutilations of horses which have been blamed on sadistic attackers are in reality caused by accidents or by other animals, a leading member of a charity for horses claimed yesterday.

The theory put forward by Ted Barnes, a field officer for the International League for the Protection of Horses, will upset many who believe their animals were the victims of "horse rippers".

But Mr Barnes, who has spent 20 years investigating apparent attacks, insists that the widely held view that there are gangs of sadists with a fetish for mutilating the sexual organs of horses is a myth. He said that in most of the cases he had examined, injured horses probably had been involved in an accident and then had aggravated their wounds or been attacked by another animal after death.

Mr Barnes, former head of the Metropolitan police's equine crime unit, said: "When a mare is in season she will do the most ridiculous things. She will rub her back end on a gatepost. She might start by nicking herself on a sharp object. She will try to relieve that by continuing the rubbing and inflict the most horrendous injuries on herself. She would not stop because she sees blood. Horses do not have the same interpretation of pain as human beings."

Mr Barnes added that a lot of injuries he had seen were almost certainly caused after the death of the horse. He said: "Very alarming-looking injuries can be caused. If a vet is not sure of the explanation for a horse's death, quite rightly he tells the owner to contact the police. But another problem is that because these reports are relatively rare, the officers concerned have little experience investigating them.

"The problem is that because it involves genitalia, people assume it is being done by a pervert." He conceded that a "handful" of attacks probably had been carried out by a sadist, but he claimed the problem had been blown out of proportion in the closely knit equine community.

"Horse-ripping" has been known since medieval times. It was the subject of Peter Shaffer's play Equus (1973), in which a boy is examined by a psychiatrist to find out why he put out the eyes of horses with an iron spike.

In Britain, the police and animal experts have speculated that fertility cults, rival horse owners and sadists could be behind attacks.

The worst spate of incidents occurred between 1983 and 1993 when more than 160 horses were believed to have been stabbed and mutilated. Attacks were reported in, Hampshire, Yorkshire and Scotland. Worried owners slept in stables and police warned parents not to let their children out to check on their ponies at night. The International League for the Protection of Horses set up an investigation squad.

Hampshire's police launched Operation Mountbatten after scores of attacks were reported, but no convictions were made. The force's officers are still convinced a horse ripper was at large.

The Mountbatten team established, however, that the horses were not drugged. This led them to postulate that the "mutilators" were used to working with horses. But the fact that horses were not drugged may add credence to Mr Barnes's theory that most mutilations are accidental or happen after a horse's death.

One horse owner, whose horse suffered genital cuts, said she was convinced her animal was attacked. "The cuts she suffered were horrific. The vet said he had never seen anything like them. I do believe there are some very sick people around who do get pleasure out of this kind of thing."
