But Mr Barnes, who has spent 20 years investigating apparent attacks, insists that the widely held view that there are gangs of sadists with a fetish for mutilating the sexual organs of horses is a myth. He said that in most of the cases he had examined, injured horses probably had been involved in an accident and then had aggravated their wounds or been attacked by another animal after death. Mr Barnes, former head of the Metropolitan police's equine crime unit, said: "When a mare is in season she will do the most ridiculous things. She will rub her back end on a gatepost. She might start by nicking herself on a sharp object. She will try to relieve that by continuing the rubbing and inflict the most horrendous injuries on herself. She would not stop because she sees blood. Horses do not have the same interpretation of pain as human beings." Mr Barnes added that a lot of injuries he had seen were almost certainly caused after the death of the horse. He said: "Very alarming-looking injuries can be caused. If a vet is not sure of the explanation for a horse's death, quite rightly he tells the owner to contact the police. But another problem is that because these reports are relatively rare, the officers concerned have little experience investigating them. "The problem is that because it involves genitalia, people assume it is being done by a pervert." He conceded that a "handful" of attacks probably had been carried out by a sadist, but he claimed the problem had been blown out of proportion in the closely knit equine community. "Horse-ripping" has been known since medieval times. It was the subject of Peter Shaffer's play Equus (1973), in which a boy is examined by a psychiatrist to find out why he put out the eyes of horses with an iron spike. In Britain, the police and animal experts have speculated that fertility cults, rival horse owners and sadists could be behind attacks. The worst spate of incidents occurred between 1983 and 1993 when more than 160 horses were believed to have been stabbed and mutilated. Attacks were reported in, Hampshire, Yorkshire and Scotland. Worried owners slept in stables and police warned parents not to let their children out to check on their ponies at night. The International League for the Protection of Horses set up an investigation squad. Hampshire's police launched Operation Mountbatten after scores of attacks were reported, but no convictions were made. The force's officers are still convinced a horse ripper was at large. The Mountbatten team established, however, that the horses were not drugged. This led them to postulate that the "mutilators" were used to working with horses. But the fact that horses were not drugged may add credence to Mr Barnes's theory that most mutilations are accidental or happen after a horse's death. One horse owner, whose horse suffered genital cuts, said she was convinced her animal was attacked. "The cuts she suffered were horrific. The vet said he had never seen anything like them. I do believe there are some very sick people around who do get pleasure out of this kind of thing."

Prozac can help women with severe premenstrual symptoms, according to a study published in the British Journal of Obstetrics and Gynaecology today. The antidepressant was tested on 320 women.

Jackie Moorhouse, 23, and Mark Wooley, 35, both from north London, will appear at Highbury Corner magistrates court, north London, today charged with the murder of Liz Sherlock, 42. She was run over last week outside Euston station, while chasing thieves.

Mobile phones are being used for bullying, an NOP survey claimed yesterday, after 1,013 people aged seven to 16 were interviewed in March. Overall, 14% had been bullied, with one in five aged between 14 and 16 receiving nasty calls.

In love with Shakespeare
Half of the population have seen a Shakespeare play at the theatre, says a Mori poll commissioned by the Royal Shakespeare Company.

Duke of Argyll dies during op
The 12th Duke of Argyll has died suddenly, his estate said yesterday. Ian Campbell, Scotland's second most senior duke, suffered a cardiac arrest during surgery at a London hospital.

£12m shared
Four shared the £12m jackpot in Saturday's national lottery rollover. The winning numbers were 12, 20, 23, 26, 33 and 46, the bonus number 1. No one won lottery extra or thunderball.

webTitle: GP red tape protest may shut surgeries

fields.headline: GP red tape protest may shut surgeries
fields.trailText: Hundreds of GPs are planning to close their surgeries in a national day of protest against staff shortages and increased bureaucracy.
fields.body:
Hundreds of GPs are planning to close their surgeries in a national day of protest against staff shortages and increased bureaucracy.

The National Doctor Day protest on May 1 has been organised by Doctor magazine after a survey showed that eight out of 10 GPs would leave the NHS if they could.

Threatened action could include shutting surgeries, or just doing paperwork, or just seeing patients. Other GPs are planning to hand in undated resignation letters or to stage marches in London and other areas. The doctors say staff shortages and increased bureaucracy caused by government initiatives have left the profession overworked and demoralised.

Hundreds of GPs have written to Doctor magazine pledging support for the day of protest, which will coincide with anti-capitalist demonstrations expected in London and other cities.

Oliver Sykes, a GP in Otley, West Yorkshire, said doctors needed to become more militant. He added: "If we are going to do something then it should really be in the face of the government."

fields.headline: Best tactics
fields.trailText: Tactical voting websites are fine for people who live in marginals (Billy Bragg drives in voting wedge, April 19). But what about the 80% of us who live in safe seats?
fields.body:
Tactical voting websites are fine for people who live in marginals (Billy Bragg drives in voting wedge, April 19). But what about the 80% of us who live in safe seats? Here both the voters and the parties know the name of the next MP before the election is held. Voting is a boring, worthy act of civic duty, stripped of the democratic power to really make a difference, let alone the drama of holding the powerful to account.

Once Billy Bragg has mobilised the tactical voters of Dorset, maybe he'll back our campaign and help us ensure that his Labour government holds its long awaited referendum on voting reform.
Nina Temple
Director, Make Votes Count nina@makevotescount.org.uk

webTitle: Letters: More views on the hoof

fields.headline: More views on the hoof
fields.trailText: I am not sure that the proposed giant white horse of Folkestone (Butterflies stand in way of white horse, April 20) really captures the spirit of the moment. A dead cow with hooves to heaven must be considered.
fields.body:
I am not sure that the proposed giant white horse of Folkestone (Butterflies stand in way of white horse, April 20) really captures the spirit of the moment. A dead cow with hooves to heaven must be considered.
Danny Proudfoot
Comberbach, Cheshire

• I don't usually find a lot to disagree with in Polly Toynbee's articles, but to describe (Comment, April 20) the Empress Of Blandings as a Gloucester Old Spot is to cast a slur on a fine and noble animal. She is, as all Wodehouse lovers know, a Black Berkshire.
David Allsopp
York

• Divine and Dubble are not, strictly, fairly traded chocolate, just fairly traded cocoa beans. If Jill O'Hara (Letters, April 19) wants genuinely fairly traded chocolate, it would have to be Golden Tree, made in Ghana - except that the EU won't let her have it, as it's manufactured goods, not primary produce.
Tim Gossling
Cambridge

webTitle: Letters: A way out from racism

fields.headline: A way out from racism
fields.trailText: The mill towns of west Yorkshire and east Lancashire mentioned by Faisal Bodi (Ghetto blasted, April 21), will not be served well by increased race legislation, which always seems to hurt those it purports to protect.
fields.body:
The mill towns of west Yorkshire and east Lancashire mentioned by Faisal Bodi (Ghetto blasted, April 21), will not be served well by increased race legislation, which always seems to hurt those it purports to protect. High unemployment and abject poverty breed discontent; it is naive to think that years of neglect will produce anything other than anger and discontent.

Successive post-war governments have failed to find a solution for the dispossessed masses of post-industrial Britain. What is needed is increased prosperity for all the inhabitants of these towns. We need a road from Wigan Pier into the 21st century.
Daniel Brierley
Clayton-le-Moor, Lancs brierly56@hotmail.com

 Faisal Bodi is right to worry about the future of young people who never see the outside of their racial and religious ghettoes. I hope that Mr Bodi will, therefore, oppose the government's plans to create many more religious schools. Muslim children living in the Lancashire towns he mentions will go from ghetto homes to ghetto schools and then back to the ghetto. They will have little opportunity to meet their peers from different races and religions and so suspicion and resentment will be perpetuated through another generation. By opposing the development of sectarian education, Mr Bodi could make a small contribution to achieving the assimilation he says he desires.
Terry Sanderson
London otherway@dircon.co.uk

 Your article (No go for whites in race hotspot, April 20) misrepresents the situation in Oldham. Having lived there for most of my teenage year , I can bear witness to the fact that racism was crude, violent and overwhelmingly hostile. At the time Glodwick was a Caribbean community. Attacks from local white youth were routine and the response then was much as it is now: communities fought back in defence of themselves.

The ongoing backlash to the Lawrence Report expresses itself through the subversion of the definition of a racist incident by police officers. We have received many reports of how some officers suggest the possibility of racial motivation to white victims of crime when the alleged perpetrators are reported to be from a minority ethnic group, even when the victims themselves have not suggested racism.

Oldham has historically been a town in denial - it is time the council and local police read and implemented the Lawrence inquiry report recommendations.
Lee Jasper
Secretary, National Assembly Against Racism

 As a life-long Oldhamer I cannot find any answer to the simmering racial tensions in our town. Individuals can only counter racist views wherever they meet them, and hope that someone else has enough skill to find a real solution.

The large percentage of Oldhamers who have racist views ("I'm not racist, but...") see our history starting at a point convenient to their prejudices. They forget that three generations ago professionally qualified people from Asian cultures could only find work as cotton mill labourers (things are not much better now) and that rooming house notices saying "no dogs, no blacks" were accepted. A community will stand only a certain amount of abuse before it turns to defend itself, as the residents of Glodwick are now doing.

The inner city troubles of 15 years ago were mischievously called "race riots"; if something is not done to bring our communities together we will truly have race riots.
Joan Friend
Oldham

fields.headline: Extra census questions
fields.trailText: Like many of your correspondents (Letters, April 20), I am irritated by the ethnicity and religion questions in the census.
fields.body:
Like many of your correspondents (Letters, April 20), I am irritated by the ethnicity and religion questions in the census. I am a secular Jew, and my intention is to tick the "none" box for religion and to write Ashkenazi Jew under "any other white background". However, I suspect that the statisticians will delete this and code me as "White, British".

In anticipation of this, I am refusing to sign my form. I will stipulate that my signature will be forthcoming only when I get a written guarantee that my ethnic self-classification is accepted. I urge anyone who objects to the form to do likewise.
Vera Lustig
Walton-on-Thames, Surrey

 The census totally ignores those of us who work in a voluntary capacity. More and more people do voluntary work - indeed the government encourages voluntary organisations to do much of the work once done by statutory agencies.

I have worked two days a week for six years in a demanding voluntary job. Before that, for 20 years I worked voluntarily, virtually full-time. There must be millions like me, but the census will show us up as people who have never worked.
Phoebe Winch
Bristol

 As an enumerator for the census, I can tell the couple aged 90 and 85 who asked for help filling in their form (Letters, April 20) that during our training we were advised not to offer help. However, I have decided that if invited I will go in, and if asked for help I will give it. One 90-year-old man asked me to fill his form in, which I happily did. The problem is that the workload is too great. If there were more enumerators, we could have been encouraged to be more helpful.

Since we have signed something akin to the Official Secrets Act and are civil servants for the duration, I'd rather you didn't print my name.
Name and address supplied

 Question 35 on my census form: "How many hours a week do you usually work in your main job (give the average over the past four weeks)?" As this includes the Easter break, is this a cunning attempt to prove that teachers, who had a two-week holiday, already work less than 35 hours per week?
Nigel Martin
Durham

 The only communication I have had so far from the census people has been a note through the letterbox saying: "I called but you were out." Has the job been contracted out to British Gas?
Geoff Mason
Warsash, Hampshire

fields.headline: California slumps
fields.standfirst: But Europe can limit the bad vibrations
fields.trailText: You could be forgiven for thinking that the world's economy had fallen off a cliff from the reaction to recent events.
fields.body:
You could be forgiven for thinking that the world's economy had fallen off a cliff from the reaction to recent events. The sudden collapse in the prospects of such hi-tech corporations as Ericsson in Europe and Cisco - the Californian group whose products guide traffic around the internet - have led to apocalyptic statements about the demise of the "new economy". The latest Business Week even suggests that California's hi-tech problems, aggravated by the state's energy crisis, may drag the American economy down with them. They may do - but only if consumers panic and stop buying things in the shops, thereby making commercial prospects even worse.

What has been happening so far is the predictable response to a stock market and an economy that have been expanding far too fast to be sustainable. The US economy simply could not go on growing at 5% a year, any more than Cisco could carry on expanding sales at 60% a year; it is now one of the biggest corporations in the US, even though only 11 years old. Nor could Germany carry on selling 25m mobile phones a year without running out of people to sell them to. Something had to give and, as happens increasingly in a globalised, electronic economy, the reaction has come fast and ferociously.

Part of the problem is that bad news drives out good. Cisco's difficulties obscured the fact that other giants of American industry - Microsoft, Dell, General Electric and much of the motor industry - are doing much better, or at least much less badly. Ericsson's sad decision to lay off 12,000 workers worldwide hit the headlines. But the other side of the same story is that its highly profitable Finnish rival Nokia increased sales by 20%. Nokia sold 128m mobile phones last year and is now pitching to snatch 40% of the entire world market.

Worryingly, most of the world's mobile phone operators have been saddled with huge debts resulting from excessive bids for third generation licences, while being unable to build the infrastructure quickly enough to profit from their investment. This is particularly so in Europe. But it would be wrong to castigate the companies. After all, it was governments that set up clever auctions enabling them to raise tens of billions from selling the rights to unused radio spectrum.

So far, the downturn has shattered not the new economy but some of its exaggerated claims. Chief among these was that internet-related activity had somehow abolished the business cycle. That was never the case. What is true is that internet techniques such as real-time monitoring of stocks and the just-in-time delivery of components (an "old economy" Japanese idea) should have made the troughs of the business cycle shorter. We will know before the year's end whether that is true.

Proponents of the new economy also claimed that the era of low inflation it helped to generate would usher in a period of sustainable growth, and that too remains to be tested. So far, inflation is still on track but sustained growth has encountered some in-flight turbulence. Europe will be affected by the American downturn more seriously than its out-of-touch central bank seems to realise. But an early cut in interest rates could revive Europe's sleeping potential. After that it is a case of waiting to see whether the American economy sinks into a serious recession. That, in turn, depends on individual decisions taken by millions of US citizens whether to stop spending and rebuild their depleted savings. The outcome is very difficult to predict: which is another reason why Europe must go it alone.

fields.headline: No sign of peace as the battle of Quebec rumbles on
fields.trailText: Your leader (New battle of Quebec, April 21) was correct in calling for anti-free-trade protesters to move from opposition to "constructive" proposition, but naive in expecting fundamental reform to emerge from governments.
fields.body:
Your leader (New battle of Quebec, April 21) was correct in calling for anti-free-trade protesters to move from opposition to "constructive" proposition, but naive in expecting fundamental reform to emerge from governments. These will first need to be jolted out of their acceptance of the "globalisation is inevitable" myth. Very different views emerged from research for my book Localisation: A Global Manifesto. This showed that alternatives are being proposed by activists from both rich and poor countries. These centre around calls for the protection and rebuilding of local economies - sentiments being echoed in the UK with the demands for local sustainable food production in the aftermath of the foot and mouth debacle.

In Britain's upcoming elec tion, voters will have a chance to support such an alternative while delivering a wake-up call to elected politicians. All the parties at Westminster favour globalisation, albeit hedged around with unattainable hopes that it can some day, somehow, be made a little kinder, greener and gentler. The one party that has made "localisation" a central policy is the Greens. In 1989 enough people voted for them to shake the other parties into taking the environment more seriously. This election could give many people the chance to show that they care more for the future of their localities than the interests of a globalisation that benefits big business and increases inequality worldwide.
Colin Hines
Twickenham, Middlesex chines@dial.pipex.com

 How predictable to hear Quebec's fence-busters labelled professional troublemakers. Has you any idea of the courage it takes to protest in the face of today's riot "robocops"? People are doing so in Quebec out of a passionate concern for social and environmental justice. Would the Summit of the Americas have made page two of Saturday's Guardian without them, I wonder?
Dominic Kelly
Carnforth, Lancs dominicjk@onetel.net.uk

 "The idea that trade is intrinsically bad is nonsense, and dangerous nonsense at that," your leader says. Trade is, in effect, the oil-powered movement of goods over long distances. So a growth in trade inevitably fuels the buildup of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere, with its attendant impact on the climate. Oil is a finite resource and any oil-fuelled international trade regime can expect to have only a limited lifespan.

Given that both climate change and the likely increase in the price of oil point to transporting fewer goods shorter distances, a move away from a trade-based economy to one oriented towards greater self-sufficiency makes a great deal of sense.

Given some of the extraordinarily anti-democratic decisions that have been made by the WTO and Gatt in recent years, you ought to be accusing them of spouting "dangerous nonsense".
Aidan McKeown
Dublin aidanmck@yahoo.com

This election could give many people the chance to show that they care more for the future of their localities than the interests of a globalisation that benefits big business and increases inequality worldwide. Colin Hines Twickenham, Middlesex chines@dial.pipex.com  How predictable to hear Quebec's fence-busters labelled professional troublemakers. Has you any idea of the courage it takes to protest in the face of today's riot "robocops"? People are doing so in Quebec out of a passionate concern for social and environmental justice. Would the Summit of the Americas have made page two of Saturday's Guardian without them, I wonder? Dominic Kelly Carnforth, Lancs dominicjk@onetel.net.uk  "The idea that trade is intrinsically bad is nonsense, and dangerous nonsense at that," your leader says. Trade is, in effect, the oil-powered movement of goods over long distances. So a growth in trade inevitably fuels the buildup of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere, with its attendant impact on the climate. Oil is a finite resource and any oil-fuelled international trade regime can expect to have only a limited lifespan. Given that both climate change and the likely increase in the price of oil point to transporting fewer goods shorter distances, a move away from a trade-based economy to one oriented towards greater self-sufficiency makes a great deal of sense. Given some of the extraordinarily anti-democratic decisions that have been made by the WTO and Gatt in recent years, you ought to be accusing them of spouting "dangerous nonsense". Aidan McKeown Dublin aidanmck@yahoo.com

fields.headline: Reacting to Father Rob
fields.trailText: The reaction of the Rev Rob Esdaile (Letters, April 21) to Muriel Gray's comments (April 19) on the Nolan report on child abuse in the Catholic church just goes to show that even now the church strives to defend the indefensible.
fields.body:
The reaction of the Rev Rob Esdaile (Letters, April 21) to Muriel Gray's comments (April 19) on the Nolan report on child abuse in the Catholic church just goes to show that even now the church strives to defend the indefensible.

As someone who, at the age of 13, was abused by a priest at a seminary, I found Muriel Gray's remarks rather restrained; when the actions of the priest concerned came to light, the response of the missionary order was to send him off to Kenya for two years. On his return he was allowed to leave the priesthood quietly.

Lives will continue to be destroyed as long as people like the Rev Esdaile keep springing to the defence of a perversion at the very heart of the Catholic church.
AF Sharkey
Haarlem, The Netherlands

 I hope that the Rev Rob Esdaile gave up the Guardian in time to buy Friday's Times. He might have felt as sickened as I did reading about the activities of his church's Christian Brothers (Boy's grave may bear witness to brutal regime).
Peter Bradshaw
Liverpool

 I am very pleased to see that Father Rob Esdaile would be happy to see married folk ordained. Does "folk" include both partners, Father Rob? Or do you, like the Pope, exclude half of the human race?
Pat Parkin-Moore
Croft, Leicestershire

fields.headline: Naylor inspires Vale of smiles
fields.standfirst: Late goals for Port Vale see them overcome Brentford and take the LDV Vans Trophy at the Millennium Stadium in Cardiff
fields.trailText: Port Vale manager Brian Horton claimed his first trophy as his team came from behind to beat a Brentford side who had got off to as flier in the LDV Vans Trophy final.
fields.byline: Richard Rae  at the Millennium stadium
fields.body:
Mickey Mouse eat your heart out; there is no deriding such an occasion that stirred as much pride, passion and excitement for as many people as the LDV Vans Trophy final did yesterday.

There was something cathartic about a quite marvellous game of football, a sense of release almost, probably explained by the fact it was 15th against 16th in the Second Division.

As usual both sets of supporters had, in common with the vast majority of their fellows up and down the country, spent most of the season hoping rather than expecting, and nothing was going to stop them savouring every moment.

Having failed to witness a win in a cup tie of any kind for four long years before this competition - they even lost to Canvey Island in this season's FA Cup - Port Vale's supporters must have dreaded the sort of start their team made. The goalkeeper Mark Goodlad came for, but got nowhere near, a Paul Evans corner, allowing Michael Dobson to head into an empty net after just three minutes.

But Brian Horton's young team have hit form in recent weeks and came back strongly. David Brammer shot wide and Marc Bridge-Wilkinson should have hit the target after a neat one-two with Tony Naylor.

But with the massed ranks of Burslem urging them on, the second half was almost all Vale. Naylor had the ball in the net on the hour only to be given offside, and minutes later he skimmed the bar.

Brentford might have weathered the storm but for Darren Powell bringing down Naylor on the edge of the box; the decision was a penalty and Bridge-Wilkinson sent Olafur Gottskalksson the wrong way.

Sensing it was their day, the Valiants drove towards their supporters and with seven minutes to go Naylor robbed the otherwise excellent Gavin Mahon and turned the ball inside for Stephen Brooker to drive joyfully into the net.

Even then there was time for the Brentford substitute Mark McCammon to head into Goodlad's arms when it looked easier to score, and for Gottskalksson to spend the last two minutes in the opposition area, creating a marvellous chance which Lloyd Owusu headed only inches wide.

Horton, with over 30 years' service as a player and manager and only a handful of promotions, reacted with "First major trophy!" And no one argued.

fields.headline: Cardiff rise again
fields.trailText: Cardiff's Leo Fortune-West may find the insults he has had to endure since his arrival in September will dry up after his first hat-trick secured the Welsh side's promotion to the Second Division.
fields.body:
Leo Fortune-West has not been the most popular footballer to have played for Cardiff City. The ungainly striker has had to endure an almost incessant stream of abuse since his arrival from Rotherham in September, but the insults may dry up after his first hat-trick for Cardiff secured their promotion to the Second Division - for the second time in three seasons.

As the softly spoken, bespectacled Londoner played down his achievement - "I was particularly pleased with my second header," he blushed - the head coach Alan Cork admitted that the hat-trick was long overdue.

"Leo said before the game that he owed us a performance because he has not been playing properly, but he was great today and that's how it should be very week."

Cardiff knew that a win would guarantee automatic promotion and they dominated the first half-hour. Eight minutes from the break, Fortune-West dived in to head home after an Andy Legg corner had not been properly cleared.

York equalised four minutes later when Rhys Weston was adjudged to have brought down Lee Nogan in the area and Chris Brass slotted home the penalty, but in first-half injury-time, Fortune-West emphatically headed in Willie Boland's cross from the right.

As Cardiff's inexperienced defence started to creak, Nogan volleyed home Colin Alcide's flick-on just after the hour and, five minutes later, Darren Edmundson's right-wing cross was powered in by Alcide from 10 yards.

But 19 minutes from time Fortune-West rose to head home Legg's free-kick and, with all the other results going their way, Cardiff were up - a year after being relegated.

webTitle: Richard Rogers' small wonder building in Soho

fields.headline: Good on corners
fields.standfirst: Richard Rogers is best known for his massive, bombastic buildings. But he has created a small wonder for Ford in the cramped streets of Soho, says  Jonathan Glancey
fields.trailText: Richard Rogers is best known for his massive, bombastic buildings. But he has created a small wonder for Ford in the cramped streets of Soho, says Jonathan Glancey.
fields.body:
There's a new building in Soho that could almost be a pocket Pompidou Centre, or a Lilliputian Lloyd's Building. A building that looks like a funky robot with glass lifts whizzing up and down its finely crafted steel exterior is almost bound to be a product of the Richard Rogers Partnership - and this is. The small scale is surprising, but then this part of London is a grid of narrow low-lying, 18th-century streets, packed with incident; it needs a tall building like it needs another sex shop. What's more surprising, at first, is the organisation that is making this pint-size Pompidou its home - the Ford Motor Company, which has decided to locate its latest design studio and research centre in central London.

Soho, meanwhile, has been fighting a battle with cars for many years. Banning them feels wrong, for the sheer bustle of the place is what gives Soho much of its character; yet there are always too many drivers fighting their way around Soho Square at night, looking for precious parking spaces. If drivers are sensible, they will be at the wheels of the latest generation of chic and tiny city cars, which is the sort of vehicle towards which Ford's design studio - under the direction of J Mays, the corporation's vice-president of design - has been working in recent years.

Two years ago Mays unveiled the 021C by the UK-based Australian Marc Newson. It is a bright orange bubble of a car that showed that Ford is not just the maker of Fiestas and Mondeos. In fact, since the 1960s and beneath its ever-so-sensible surface, Ford has been sporadically enthusiastic about new car design and technology. One of the greatest and best looking sports-racing cars of all times, the Le Mans-devouring GT40, was a Ford.

Ford has also been a patron of radical architecture. It created some of the first mass-production factory lines and built a number of extremely impressive plants, notably those designed by Albert Kahn around the time of the first world war. Not long after, Kahn was invited by Stalin to design and build hundreds of factories for the fast-industrialising Soviet Union. In office architecture, too, Ford took a lead in 1964 with the Ford Foun dation building in New York by Kevin Roche. This striking building set the pace for a generation of office buildings organised around winter-garden-style atria.

In other words, despite all the jokes about Mondeo man, Ford can be innovative. Now, in order to expose its designers to new trends, the company wants to bring its latest studio into the heart of London, instead of tucking away its creatives in a factory miles out of town, as it has in the past. Rogers and his team have also long celebrated the world of new technology in their colourful, adventurous and futuristic work.

Ford did not commission the Soho building. It began life as a £7m speculative office block commissioned by Derwent Valley Holdings and designed under the direction of John Young of Richard Rogers. The interior of this light and airy building has been fitted out by a team led by Adrian Caddy of the design practice Imagination, which has worked with Ford for many years on motor-show displays. Caddy explains that, when it opens later this year, the building will also have an art and design gallery open to the public, partly modelled on the ICA. There will be film screenings, seminars and lectures, some of which - but not all - will have a connection with cars. The ground floor of the building will be a design shop, and the basement is to house a public restaurant.

This permeability - the fact that the public will be invited into the domain of a normally secretive global corporation - is part and parcel of the Richard Rogers design credo. But it also suggests that at least one global corporation has begun to recognise the need to be more transparent itself, and to listen to consumers' views.

As for the building, it is an astute buy. At various times in the past century, a few manufacturing companies have learned that matching their product and image to distinguished architecture could only enhance their image. This trend started with some striking 19th-century factories, but began its modern ascent with the noble AEG factory (1908), designed by Peter Behrens, in whose Berlin studio both Le Corbusier and Ludwig Mies van der Rohe, the greatest architects of the 20th century, worked. AEG's fine industrial and domestic products were seen to emerge not from some smoky factory, but from a 20th-century reworking of a Greek temple.

The idea was not lost on Mies van der Rohe, whose stunning Seagram Building (1958) on New York's Park Avenue, and its equally stunning public restaurant, the Four Seasons, have associated the whisky brand with the utmost quality for the past 40 years. Norman Foster's bespoke headquarters for the Hongkong and Shanghai Bank (1986) in Hong Kong was a huge profile-raiser (for client and architect alike), as was Rogers's own Lloyd's Building (1986) in the City of London.

The Rogers Ford building animates a street corner, opens what in other hands might have been just another private building to the public and demonstrates how the pop thrills of the Pompidou Centre and Bladerunner bombast of Lloyd's can be happily scaled down. But, I wonder, what will Mondeo man make of it?

Wonders and blunders

Wonder: Millennium Bridge, Gateshead
Blunder: Motorway bridges

I think bridges, when they are properly designed, epitomise perfect structure. The wonderful thing about them is that they are very pure structures. When that purity is put into play, as it is in the original Severn Bridge or Chris Wilkinson's Gateshead Millennium Bridge, the results are extraordinary.

I think it is interesting to look back to the time of Isambard Kingdom Brunel, when the most beautiful bridges were built, and compare those structures with those being produced today. There was an incredible beauty in the bridges that Brunel designed, such as the wonderfully engineered railway bridge at Maidenhead.

Some of the new architect-designed bridges in Britain are amazing. The Gateshead Millennium Bridge, which was swung into position recently, is a perfect example. I like the fact that it does not have a straight arch and the shape is oblique. It is a beautiful structure; I love the way you can see exactly how it holds itself up.

What I find appalling are the numerous awful bridges built over motorways in Britain. It is extraordinary that we have been building motorways for the past 30 years and no one has yet designed a decent or elegant bridge for them. Because they tend to lack an arch, they do not even look like bridges and, instead, often seem as if they cannot hold themselves up.

They just look like awkward sticks of concrete put together with an awful, slightly curved beam that goes across the motorway like a ledge. It is a shame that our motorway bridges suggest such a lack of care and interest. They show no love for design or engineering and express nothing except their own ugliness.

James Dyson

 James Dyson is a designer and inventor.

webTitle: How Rio Ferdinand learned to play in a back four

fields.headline: How Rio Ferdinand learned to play in a back four
fields.standfirst: Big Ron's Rio analysis
fields.trailText: There was a lot of talk when Rio Ferdinand went to Leeds that he could only play in a back five. Few would doubt now that he has adapted his game.
fields.body:
There was a lot of talk when Rio Ferdinand went to Leeds that he could only play in a back five. Few would doubt now that he has adapted his game to cope as one of two centre halves.

The biggest single difference is that he will be engaging people a lot more. In a three at West Ham Rio was very seldom marking. He had to worry about cleaning up at the back, making interceptions and picking up runners from midfield like Ray Parlour.

Now he will be more in contact with strikers, getting in more tackles and challenges and having to keep a really close eye on his opposite number. Against Leeds on Saturday he had to be able to close down Paolo Di Canio if the ball is was played to the Italian's feet and also watch the longer pass down the channel behind Danny Mills.

The change will have improved his concentration and his defensive qualities, not least in the air. I remember seeing him play for England against Switzerland and he didn't seem to be able to come to terms with the heading bit. His work in challenging for the first ball has come on a lot

Since slotting into a four Ferdinand has reduced the number of runs he makes out of defence. There's nothing wrong with occasionally bursting forward, particularly if you have responsible players like David Batty who can sit in for him. But he knows he can't do it willy-nilly. As the Leeds manager David O'Leary said on Saturday: "The three allows you to take more liberties, to take more chances." In a four your first reaction has to be to make sure you get the ball.

fields.headline: Football round-up
fields.trailText: Tranmere Rovers were relegated from the First Division on Saturday, a 1-1 draw against another bottom-three side, Crystal Palace, not enough to keep their slim survival hopes alive.
fields.body:
Tranmere Rovers bowed to the inevitable and were relegated from the First Division on Saturday, a 1-1 draw against another bottom-three side, Crystal Palace , not enough to keep their slim survival hopes alive. Rovers, who have enjoyed numerous cup successes over the past two seasons, will return to the Second Division after 10 years.

"It is soul-destroying to be relegated," said Tranmere's caretaker-manager Kevin Sheedy, pictured right. "The players have given their all but our frailties have let us down."

Queens Park Rangers will join Rovers next season after Delroy Facey's injury-time winner for Huddersfield Town sent Ian Holloway's side to a 2-1 defeat. Holloway took the same line as Sheedy, saying: "The players have given me everything, but it is results over the whole season that have seen us relegated."

In the chase for Premiership riches, West Brom have moved fourth after Lee Hughes's 22nd goal of the season helped the Baggies to a 2-1 win over Gillingham.

Reading held on to the second automatic slot in the Second Division, although they were held to a 2-2 draw by Walsall . Jamie Cureton scored two goals to bring his season's tally to 29 but Jorge Leitao and the former Royal Tony Barras levelled matters. Walsall stay fourth, one place behind Rotherham United who had Kevin Watson and Mark Robins to thank for a 2-0 win at Wigan's JJB stadium.

Swansea City have become the second team, after Oxford , to be relegated to the Third Division. Oldham, who had condemned Oxford, did the same at the Vetch Field, with Sam Parkin netting both goals in a 2-1 win.

Luton are almost certain to be playing in the Third Division next season after a last-minute Colin Cramb winner for Bury sent them to an 11th home defeat of the season. However, Bristol Rovers gave their survival hopes a boost with a 6-2 win over poor Oxford. One bright moment for United came when Phil Wilson saved a penalty with his first touch in professional football, although Nathan Ellington scored the rebound. Cambridge now occupy the fourth relegation position, after having a blank weekend.

At the foot of the Third Division, Torquay are propping up the rest after losing a Devon derby to Plymouth . Halifax's goalless draw, also in Devon against Exeter, put them ahead of Torquay on goal difference. Halifax also have a game in hand on the Gulls .

Jamie Cureton scored two goals to bring his season's tally to 29 but Jorge Leitao and the former Royal Tony Barras levelled matters. Walsall stay fourth, one place behind Rotherham United who had Kevin Watson and Mark Robins to thank for a 2-0 win at Wigan's JJB stadium. Swansea City have become the second team, after Oxford , to be relegated to the Third Division. Oldham, who had condemned Oxford, did the same at the Vetch Field, with Sam Parkin netting both goals in a 2-1 win. Luton are almost certain to be playing in the Third Division next season after a last-minute Colin Cramb winner for Bury sent them to an 11th home defeat of the season. However, Bristol Rovers gave their survival hopes a boost with a 6-2 win over poor Oxford. One bright moment for United came when Phil Wilson saved a penalty with his first touch in professional football, although Nathan Ellington scored the rebound. Cambridge now occupy the fourth relegation position, after having a blank weekend. At the foot of the Third Division, Torquay are propping up the rest after losing a Devon derby to Plymouth . Halifax's goalless draw, also in Devon against Exeter, put them ahead of Torquay on goal difference. Halifax also have a game in hand on the Gulls .

fields.headline: Women's football
fields.trailText: Arsenal have dropped only two points all season and are still on course for a league and cup double.
fields.body:
Arsenal are the Manchester United of the AXA-sponsored FA Women's Premier League. They have dropped only two points all season and are still on course for a league and cup double. Only Doncaster Belles can really catch them now; and they are due at Arsenal's Borehamwood ground on the last day of the season.

But yesterday's stylish 7-1 dissection of Southampton Saints took Arsenal a step closer to rendering that game less decisive than it might be. Marieanne Spacey, arguably the English game's most famous exponent, had just returned from maternity leave when Arsenal last won the league in 1997. At 35 she has the cool-headed experience needed to win titles, the clearest measure of which is that she apparently no longer counts her goals.

Others do, however, and yesterday she scored four - the first a cross that curled in on the wind, the last direct from a corner. The others came from Jayne Ludlow (two) and Angela Banks, who is, with 24, by far the league's top scorer and "a taller version of Michael Owen with a better eye for goal", according to Spacey.

In truth, Arsenal are a cut above all round. It is not just their fluid passing game, nor the fact that they combine the meanest attack with the leanest margin of error (they have let in only seven). They stay in better hotels, travel in bigger coaches, wear Nike boots and get free Lucozade Sport. Anyone will tell you that such a luxurious set-up is amazing.

They will also tell you it has been a very strange season. Floods, postponements and, perhaps, tyrannical groundsmen have all left their mark. Charlton still have a third of their matches ahead of them; Everton have one to play.

But the run-in is shaping up. A 5-1 win at Everton kept Doncaster Belles in touch with Arsenal, a 3-1 win for Tranmere ensured their opponents Millwall remain in the relegation zone and Charlton's push for a top-three finish continued with a 4-0 win at Sunderland .

But spare a thought for poor Liverpool , whose 3-2 home defeat by Barry Town leaves them bottom with no points from 14 games. At least their goals for column is no longer the square root of their goals against, but they have only four chances left to prevent a total whitewash.

webTitle: Mystery of stolen Turners deepens as conmen try to pass off 'awful' copies

fields.headline: Mystery of stolen Turners deepens as conmen try to pass off 'awful' copies
fields.trailText: The expectation that two stolen masterpieces by JMW Turner were about to be returned seemed to have been building for months.
fields.body:
The expectation that two stolen masterpieces by JMW Turner were about to be returned seemed to have been building for months.

Some reports declared that the paintings, Shade and Darkness: Evening of the Deluge, and Light and Colour: Morning after the Deluge, would be relinquished by Serbs linked to Arkan, the assassinated warlord.

Rumours in the art world suggested German criminals, fed up with failing to sell two such recognisable works, were looking to cut a deal with the Tate Gallery, which owned them before they were stolen from the Schirn Kunsthalle in Frankfurt, where they were being exhibited on loan.

The Guardian can reveal that the phone call the Tate had been hoping and waiting for since July 1994 finally came a few weeks ago.

Detectives in Belgium announced they had arrested two men in a sting operation in Antwerp.

The pair had been touting the Tate's two stolen Turners, painted in 1843, to a private investigator, believing he was an art dealer who could secure them a reward. The canvases, which had been insured for £24m, had been recovered undamaged. To the police, they looked like the genuine articles.

Was the art theft of the decade, which had been investigated by Interpol, Scotland Yard, and forces across Europe, about to be solved?

"We were obviously excited," said Sandy Nairne at the Tate. "One of our conservation staff went straight to Antwerp. But unfortunately, it was very obvious, very quickly, that the paintings were not the Turners."

According to Mark Dalrymple, one of the country's leading fine art recovery experts, who works for Tyler & Co, the paint on the canvas "wasn't even dry". "They weren't just bad fakes, they were awful. It became clear the whole thing was just a scam by two chancers."

Police had hoped the two men, now in prison awaiting trial, may have been linked to the real villains. But it seems not.

Two years ago, the Tate paid £8m to buy back the legal title to the paintings from the insurers. The deal was struck with the help of Geoffrey Robinson, then paymaster general, and was described in the art press as a gamble which would backfire if the paintings were not recovered.

The Tate, though, believes it was sound business which made use of a part of the enormous insurance fund set up following the settlement of the gallery's £24m claim in April 1995.

"This was a commercially negotiated procedure with the insurers and was approved by the Treasury, the Department for Culture, Media and Sport, and the charity commission," the Tate confirmed in a statement. "The balance of the funds remains in a restricted fund which cannot be released until the paintings are recovered."

Neither the police, the Tate, nor Mr Dalrymple are sure whether rumours that abounded last year, suggesting the two Turners were about to be given up by the underworld, were linked to the men behind the recent attempted scam.

Mr Dalrymple is unconvinced by speculation that the works were stolen to order for a Mr Big. "I've never known of such a case," he said.

More likely the criminals behind the theft, who evaded modern alarm systems and overpowered a guard, were ignorant of the art market, and had not realised how difficult it would be to sell them.

The Turner paintings, which depict the biblical story of the deluge with reference to the work of Goethe, are acknowledged masterpieces, seen as crucial examples of the artist's later style.

"You cannot sell a Turner anywhere in the world without people knowing about it," said Mr Dalrymple. "It's possible the paintings have been destroyed, but I hope not. Once villains have stolen pictures they are loath to get rid of them. We are in a waiting game.

"We just don't know where these paintings are. I don't think we have ever really been close."

webTitle: Ministers to redirect aid to the rural poor

fields.headline: Ministers to redirect aid to the rural poor
fields.trailText: Travelling playbuses and mobile health clinics are to be introduced in rural areas as the government extends its Sure Start scheme for poorer families with young children.
fields.body:
Travelling playbuses and mobile health clinics are to be introduced in rural areas as the government extends its Sure Start scheme for poorer families with young children.

The public health minister, Yvette Cooper, will today unveil plans to spend £40m on 16 rural programmes targeted at 10,000 children initially, rising to 20,000 by 2004.

The move is an acknowledgement by the government that it must be seen to be addressing rural poverty as well as inner city problems. Locations for the first wave of schemes include Allerdale in Cumbria and north Devon.

Ms Cooper, addressing a conference organised by the National Children's Bureau, will say that one in four children living in poverty lives in a rural area. She said yester day: "We know that the problems they face can be quite different from those faced in inner cities. People in rural areas can miss out completely at the moment on childcare, or simply opportunities to meet other families with young children. Yet what happens in a child's early years can have a huge impact on the rest of their lives."

The Sure Start programme, designed to provide health care and other support for low-income families with children up to four, will be tailored to meet the specific needs of rural communities.

Ministers believe a prime concern for parents in the countryside is the distances they must travel to get to vital services, and believe that much of the money allocated for the new schemes should be spent on tackling the problem.

"Getting to antenatal classes if you've got to take a stroppy toddler on three different buses makes life incredibly difficult, and parents can become isolated if they can't get to childcare or play facilities," Ms Cooper said.

Surestart funds will not be used merely to provide transport to give parents better access to services, but are intended to bring services to rural communities.

Plans include providing travelling health centres bringing doctors and antenatal clinics nearer to rural families. Ms Cooper is also enthusiastic about the concept of playbuses, in which one floor of a double decker is used as a creche, while the other is filled with computers so that their parents can improve their IT skills.

The Sure Start scheme is regarded as one of the government's success stories in its attempt to tackle child poverty.

fields.headline: Red tide washes over Spurs
fields.standfirst: Champions League place in sight as Houllier's team rise to fifth
fields.trailText: Overcoming an inexperienced Tottenham side yesterday, Liverpool jumped above Chelsea into fifth position with games to spare in their concerted push for a Champions League place.
fields.body:
If Liverpool are to gate-crash next season's Champions League, it could still require Ipswich and Leeds to self-combust but, for the time being, Gérard Houllier's resurgent team could not be accused of failing to make their presence felt.

By overcoming a woefully inexperienced Tottenham side yesterday, Liverpool, who were playing their eighth game in 23 days, jumped above Chelsea into fifth position with games to spare in their concerted push to re-establish themselves among the elite of Europe.

That, according to Houllier, will be the only way their season can be judged successful, notwithstanding the Worthington Cup triumph and next month's FA Cup and Uefa Cup finals. Attitudes are clearly changing on Merseyside: whereas first once meant first, and second meant nothing, now third place will do very nicely indeed.

It is an enticing prospect and one that Glenn Hoddle must feel belongs to a different world. Deprived of an entire XI through injury, Tottenham's manager had little option but to deploy a makeshift side incorporating six players under 22 and three substitutes in Ian Hillier, John Piercy and Steven Ferguson who had never started a senior game.

Spurs may, indeed, have a bright future but Anfield is an unforgiving place for young pretenders and, though Liverpool may have had the heavier legs, Spurs finished with the heavier hearts after Gary McAllister and Robbie Fowler, with a goal apiece in the final 19 minutes, had added to Emile Heskey's early strike.

Willem Korsten had equalised midway through the opening half with his first Tottenham goal but Liverpool's bright and incisive attacking should, in all probability, have earned them an even more handsome victory.

Certainly it looked that way after seven minutes. Heskey has added composure to his other undoubted talents this season and, after Patrik Berger's incisive pass caught the Spurs defence square, his calm finish from the perimeter of the penalty area teed up an absorbing afternoon.

Worryingly for Liverpool, however, it was to be Heskey's last meaningful contribution. Helping out in midfield, his attempt to dispossess Korsten resulted in an ugly tangle that left both players requiring treatment and the England striker on his way to hospital. The good news for Houllier is that preliminary x-rays last night revealed nothing more than severe bruising.

The game threatened to take a marked swing in the 24th minute. Owen set off the chain of events by flashing a header beyond Sullivan from a miscued Berger drive. But, when his shrewd improvisation was ruled out for offside, Liverpool's lapse in concentration could have been costly.

Suddenly Oyvind Leonhardsen found himself with acres of space on the left. His centre picked out Korsten, who lashed a rising shot past the exposed Sander Westerveld.

Then in the 73rd minute Fowler, Heskey's replacement, worked the ball to Owen who scuffed his shot against Alton Thelwell's hand. Having turned down a more vociferous appeal against Tim Sherwood not long before, the referee Barrie Knight pointed to the spot and Gary McAllister finished with the unerring accuracy he had displayed against Barcelona last Thursday.

Hoddle accused Knight of being swayed by the Kop but television replays also showed that Owen's earlier "goal" should have stood. "If Glenn is unhappy, he just has to look at the video," said Houllier.

Two minutes from time Fowler headed Markus Babbel's precise cross past Sullivan and Liverpool's weary players left the pitch knowing they will have the rare luxury of a rest. "How will you cope without a midweek match?" Houllier was asked. He smiled, but it was through clenched teeth.

fields.headline: Villa hit the wall
fields.trailText: John Gregory, running in the London marathon yesterday, will have had more than enough time to ponder the consequences of his team's draw with Southampton which made their already outside chances of qualifying for next season's Uefa Cup even more remote.
fields.body:
Darius Vassell must have provided John Gregory with a perfect antidote to any loneliness he may have experienced as a long-distance runner yesterday.

The Aston Villa manager, running to raise funds for research into Alzheimer's disease, was participating in the London marathon - an exercise that gave him more than enough time to ponder the consequences of his team's failure to defeat goal-starved Southampton.

Although the draw extended Villa's unbeaten run to nine games, it made their already outside chances of qualifying for next season's Uefa Cup even more remote. Now they face another curtailed summer break: the Intertoto Cup appears to offer the only route into Europe.

Gregory and his players did not enjoy last year's abortive Intertoto experience but at least Vassell's display against Southampton augurs well for their prospects, especially as their record signing Juan Pablo Angel will be on Copa America duty with Colombia when the campaign begins in July.

That is, if the 20-year-old Vassell remains fit. The striker broke his leg twice when he was on Birmingham City's books as a trainee and has been plagued by injuries over the past two seasons.

"So far things have been a bit stop-start for him because of a succession of injuries over the past 18 months," Villa's assistant manager Steve Harrison explained. "But he was different class against Southampton. I think he was helped by Dion Dublin, who held the ball up well and allowed Darius to make runs up behind him.

"Darius has got quick feet and a great touch. What he needs now is a run of games and hopefully next season will be his."

There were times when Vassell's pace and trickery made Southampton's defenders appear so leaden-footed they resembled marathon runners on their last legs. But it was Southampton's James Beattie who came closest to scoring when he was foiled by a one-handed diving save from David James.

Earlier a header from the same player was disallowed for offside, a decision that adds further credence to the notion that Lady Luck has jumped ship with Glenn Hoddle.

"It looked a perfectly good goal to me," the caretaker manager Stuart Gray lamented. "And Kevin Davies had what I thought was a goal chalked off at Chelsea in our last game."

All of which is not doing Gray's hopes of succeeding Hoddle long term any favours, a point he admitted with admirable candour. "With three defeats, one draw and no goals since I took over," he said, "I wouldn't say my credentials are very good."

Man of the match: Darius Vassell (Aston Villa).

fields.headline: Tyros take the plaudits in tied Tyne-Wear tiff
fields.trailText: It may have bristled with blood and thunder but in the end Saturday's 120th Tyne-Wear league derby will be remembered for a trio of performers relatively alien to such blistering occasions.
fields.byline: Dominic Fifield  at the Stadium of Light
fields.body:
It may have bristled with blood and thunder, played to stands of partisan stripes bellowing their approval at the breakneck pace, but in the end Saturday's 120th Tyne-Wear league derby will be remembered less for the meaningless score draw and more for a trio of performers relatively alien to such blistering occasions.

Amid the mayhem of a first half dominated by the Wearsiders, Julio Arca - a twinkle-toed teenager from Argentina - flitted in among the danger, emerging with possession and creation to spur the home side on. After 22 frantic minutes, the 19-year-old, signed from Argentinos Juniors last summer for £3.5m, crossed for Niall Quinn to force Shay Given into the first of many outstanding saves; 15 minutes later he planted a centre on Emerson Thome's head and the Brazilian's effort cannoned back off the angle of post and bar.

"Julio was the most composed player on the pitch," said his manager Peter Reid. "Even I enjoyed watching him. Anyone who handles the ball like him is special, but he's only 19 and is getting stronger. Wait until he grows up. He's come halfway around the world and his progress has surprised me, but he's an exciting talent."

Had the Argentine been playing for a more fashionable team, surely a nomination for the PFA's young footballer of the year award would have been forthcoming. "I was interested in signing him, but Sunderland must have had more money than we did," added the visiting manager Bobby Robson."He's clever on the dribble and sticks a nice diagonal ball in. I think he's justified the fee."

Given continued to defy the home onslaught, tipping Kevin Phillips's effort over the bar and diving to claim Gavin McCann's shot, but the Magpies were finally breached midway through the second half from an unlikely source. Patrice Carteron, a Frenchman on loan from St Etienne with 12 first-team goals across La Manche behind him, ran from inside his own penalty area to accept Don Hutchison's pass inside Wayne Quinn. The full-back's shot crept through Given's legs and Wearside erupted in expectation of Sunderland's first home win over their arch-rivals for 21 years.

"The atmosphere was incredible," said Carteron. "In the French league you only get that much noise for games against Marseille or Paris St-Germain. I just hope I will be here next season to experience such things again."

The 30-year-old might have joined Liverpool last summer. "But my chairman didn't want me to leave," he explained. Somewhat cryptically, he was promptly sold to Lyon's biggest rivals before being given the opportunity to earn Sunderland a first league win on Wearside against their arch-rivals in 21 years.

Phillips, through on Given, might have settled the nerves, but there was to be no double to follow up November's 2-1 success at St James' Park. With their concession, Newcastle's defence became the most accommodating in Premiership history - this was their 25th successive league match without a clean sheet - but their centre-backs do have uses. fields.headline: Interview: Mike Atherton
fields.standfirst: Jim White hears the former skipper explain how Nasser Hussain has managed to make winners of England where he failed
fields.trailText: Jim White hears the former skipper explain how Nasser Hussain has managed to make winners of England where he failed
fields.body:
It is not so much a three-jumper day as the players of Lancashire cricket club put in their last few minutes pre-season training at Old Trafford. It is more like a three-jumper, bobble-hat, thermal-gloves and centrally-heated-underwear sort of day. As a bitter wind blows in from the snow-topped Pennines, bowlers trundle around trussed up like Ranulph Fiennes on an Arctic expedition. But out there in the middle, the coolest batsman of his generation appears unaffected by the chill. Michael Atherton is preparing for the season in his own way, practising air forward defensives, looking along the crook of his arm, his mental spirit level checking elbow, wrist and bat are in perfect alignment.

Not that all this will do Lancashire much good. They will be seeing precious little of this straightest of English bats this season. As his colleagues finish practice and climb aboard their executive coach on their way to Taunton for their opening championship game, Atherton finds himself at a loose end. Pulled out of the game by a higher authority - England - he will have the weekend off, a beneficiary of the central contract system.

"It's not so much designed for the likes of me, it's more for the guys who win you your Test matches," he says in his self-deprecating way as he heads for some warming Lancashire hot pot. "It's about fast bowlers keeping their overs fresh for England and not wasting them for Somerset or Yorkshire. It's the biggest change in the time I've been playing and I'm all in favour of it."

And presumably, for someone like him, who has been on the treadmill for 15 years, it is a godsend.

"Actually, I've never really had a problem with enthusiasm for the game," he says. "That said, I'm sure I would have benefited far more had central contracts been in place throughout my career."

Ah yes, things have changed since Atherton fulfilled the destiny everyone predicted for him from the age of 12 and became England captain in 1993. For a start the team is winning. Which must be rather odd for him, to sit in a dressing room and watch someone else succeed where he failed.

"I think that's far too simplistic a view to say when I was in charge things went wrong but now they're going right," he says, bristling against this version of history. "Things had been going wrong for the 15, 20 years before me. Some of us had been banging on for years about it. Then came a general realisation that the structure was not in place to create a successful international side."

So is he then Neil Kinnock to Hussain's Blair?

"Not sure about that," he smiles. "For a start, Nasser and I are the same age. No, he's done well to preside over a side which has been on the up."

But there is something there: Atherton was in charge of much the same party, began to get them into shape winning the odd Test here or there, the cricketing equivalent of a by-election, but it took his successor to complete the process and make them win series.

"It's the same players but they are not the same people," the ex-skipper points out. "When I took over they'd played between 0 and 10 Tests. Now they've all played over 60. "Experience tells. And the arrival of Duncan Fletcher has helped. He's an outstanding coach."

In what way?

"Well, when I say that, it slightly goes against my thoughts on the game. I feel the responsibility is on the players to perform. I feel there are a number of cricketers around who use the coach as a crutch to lean on, an excuse for their own failings. But what Fletcher has is a calmness. I think it's easy to get taken over by events as coach. The press, the public can see a dire performance on one day and you can get caught up in that and make changes which shouldn't be made."

And it must have tested all of Fletcher's reserves of calm in the winter heat in Sri Lanka, when perspective seemed to fly out of the window, joining several bats flung in dissent. It must be interesting being out in the middle when things are kicking off all over the field like that.

"The first two Tests there were the most unpleasant I've ever been involved in," Atherton says, swatting that idea away as he might a slow long hop. "I don't think it was an intentional thing for players to go out there and say we don't like each other, we'll have an ill-tempered series. Most of the ill-temperedness came on the back of decisions that were not up to the mark. That said, I think it should be tough out there: I think it sorts people out."

But, as someone who believes in individual responsibility, was it not up to the players to adhere to the spirit of the game in Sri Lanka? Would it not have defused things had batsmen walked when they knew they were out, for instance?

"The idea that batsmen walk I'm afraid disappeared a long time ago in international cricket. The corollary to that is, if you're going to wait for the umpire's decision, then you must be prepared to accept that decision if it goes against you without a great show of dissent."

Batsmen never walk? Is that not a terrible indictment of a decline in standards?

"Not at all," he says. "There were cricketers in the 50s, as I understand it, who would walk when it was obvious but would hang on in there if they felt they could get away with it. Personally I think that's worse than the guy who waits for the umpire's decision. For me, consistently waiting is a more honourable way to behave. I'm very comfortable with my principles and I think I adhere to them."

As Atherton talks, friendly, honest, enthralling (how many other sportsmen bandy the word corollary around?) it is hard to reconcile the figure he now cuts with the way he was when he led England. Known as Captain Grump, he appeared tetchy, frosty, paranoid. For such an intelligent man his comments were on the Shearer scale of blandness. Why did he give such an untrue impression of himself in his press duties back then?

"I am reasonably shy," he says in mitigation. "It takes me a while to get to know people and for a truer side to come out. But also I found the capacity to be mis-quoted was so great that I decided to perfect the art of saying sod all."

Which is a nice irony now the gamekeeper has turned poacher. These days the former player of a verbal straight bat spends much of his spare time working as a very accomplished journalist, trying to wheedle quotes out of subjects adopting the same tactic he used to.

"Actually I've only done one interview so far, with Steve McClaren, Alex Ferguson's assistant, and he was great, really helpful."

Atherton says he enjoys writing and will make it his career when he retires ("I'm not a footballer, I've not got the money to put my feet up"). But whether it will ever match the buttock-clenching reality of facing Allan Donald or Curtly Ambrose is unlikely. And he is a man who seems to come alive in the most intimidating of circumstances.

"It's a worry for all professional sportsmen, retirement," he says. "My agent told me he had always thought the best people in sport were the ones who were completely obsessed. Now he's not so sure, he thinks being like that leaves you struggling when your time comes to an end. I don't think I've been obsessed enough for it to be a problem. But I'll miss it. No doubt. Clearly the adrenalin rush of facing a fast bowler in front of a big crowd is why you do it. It's not for some freezing April day in front of three men and a dog."

That is one more reason, then, for the best batsman in England to be pleased that the bus for Taunton has just left without him.

fields.headline: Power of Preston means Taylor farewell falls flat
fields.trailText: Defeat against Preston effectively ended Watford's fading hopes of being involved in post-season play while greatly enhancing their hosts' play-off aspirations.
fields.body:
Graham Taylor probably did not envisage his farewell to management being quite like this, but if the Watford manager needed any convincing about his decision to retire this summer, a bitterly cold April afternoon presumably did exactly that.

Defeat against Preston effectively ended Watford's fading hopes of being involved in post-season play while greatly enhancing their hosts' play-off aspirations. But it was the manner of the loss that will have reminded Taylor of precisely how his profession can multiply grey hairs and rapidly reduce life expectancy.

Having received the pre-match fillip of seeing Preston lose their goalkeeper David Lucas to a back injury during the warm-up, Watford might have twice scored past his nervous 17-year-old understudy Andrew Lonergan in the opening two minutes. As it was, having trailed 2-1 at half-time, Watford equalised on the hour thanks to a Lonergan error only to concede the winning goal, Jon Macken's second of the day and 20th of the season, almost immediately after the ensuing kick-off.

Only this week Taylor insisted he can forgive individual defensive lapses as long as his team is winning. In the three games that remain of his career, he may wish to rethink that philosophy.

"I waited for their goalkeeper at the end of the game to congratulate him," said Taylor. "But it is games like this that make you think: 'Thank goodness it's only six weeks to retirement.'"

While Taylor's storied career winds down, that of Preston's David Moyes is just beginning, and looks wholly promising as he leads his side towards a play-off campaign that could see them back in the top flight after a 39-year absence.

Yesterday, Moyes would have been delighted with his young goalkeeper, for Lonergan had only previously made one appearance, a 4-1 Worthington Cup defeat at Coventry in September, and early indications were that his league debut might see him on the receiving end of a similar scoreline.

But he handled well from Watford's first clear shot, Gifton Noel-Williams's long-range 15th-minute effort, to steady his nerves and Macken soon had a hand in steadying them further when he won a 25th-minute penalty. Paul Robinson and Steve Palmer failed to cope with the prolific striker as he chased a through ball and in the resulting melee collided with the goalkeeper Alec Chamberlain for the penalty - a harsh decision punished fully by Graham Alexander's conversion.

Macken continued to pester Watford's defence and soon added Preston's second goal, scoring from an unmarked position six yards out.

However, a Watford reply was always likely in the circumstances and finally arrived in the 36th minute, a powerful, towering header from Noel-Williams, who met Neil Cox's cross and beat Lonergan from just outside the area.

Taylor eventually saw his team equalise on the hour, when Peter Kennedy's corner found Lonergan absent and let Robert Page head in from point-blank range.

But Watford's generosity in defence was highlighted almost immediately afterwards, when Alexander's teasing pass drifted over Cox's head and found the unmarked Macken, who scored the winner from a dozen yards and, in the process, ensured a pulsating final 30 minutes.

Amid the ensuing drama, Tommy Mooney struck the inside of the post but, fittingly, there was also chance for Lonergan to show his stuff, making vital saves from Kennedy, Nordin Wooter and Mooney in the last 12 minutes.

fields.headline: No resolution at Yeovil summit
fields.standfirst: Conference title in balance after big guns draw a blank
fields.trailText: Yeovil's draw with their fellow contenders for the Football League, Rushden left the situation anything but black and white.
fields.body:
"Badgers!" exclaims a road sign on the approaches to Yeovil, promising a new charm to the League map if the Glovers go up. But the draw with their fellow contenders left the situation anything but black and white. Rushden are three points clear; Yeovil have a game in hand. Rushden have the better goal difference; Yeovil have four to play. Neither have irresistible form. Both play tomorrow.

This is the third year running the fixture list has thrown up a Conference summit in April and the first one Rushden have not lost. Cheltenham scored two in the last minute in 1999 to turn 0-1 into 2-1. Kidderminster beat them 2-0 last year. This time Rushden have emerged with their fate in their own hands.

Their manager Brian Talbot said: "There's still a lot to do and no one lays down for us." No one does as the feeling persists that the £20m backing of Max Griggs, the man behind Dr Marten's, has tilted the playing field as Mohamed Al Fayed has at Fulham. Opponents try that bit harder.

"All I keep hearing is what a waste of money," said Talbot and the Yeovil fans had their chanting say after a rendering of Drink Up Thy Cider. But this season Rushden have spent nothing on transfers, reinforcing their ranks with "frees" and the youth system. They have a set-up fit for the League and, as Yeovil's Colin Addison said, "they're three years down the road on us. If we don't do it now, it won't be failure."

Yeovil, who also breed their own, got into the Conference only in 1998 and are still completing their ground after moving from the old Huish in 1990. They are not ones to talk of level playing fields. But the slope was well remembered in a minute's silence for Alec Stock, manager of the club's most romantic moments. They may be hard to match in the new trading estate.

The mass of green and white, which helped lift the ground's crowd record to 8,868, willed a reprise of Celtic celebrations but it was not to be. On a cherry-blossom day there was little polish. The prize was greater than the poise. Anxiety ruled.

The first half was played largely in the air. Much of the second took in the whole estate. Everyone buzzed with energy, few with purpose. Last week scientists revealed that bees can think. They might look into footballers next. But neither side needed to prove their credentials.

Yeovil extended a history of Cup glories at Blackpool this year. At one time they were nine points clear of Rushden, who lost the next two games after Yeovil beat them in November but have since lost one in 19. Diamonds are forever coming. They should arrive on May 5.

Each manager praised his own positive approach. Yeovil's Darren Way and Rushden's Andrew Burgess stood out in midfield. Tony Pennock tipped over Duane Darby's point-blank header and, in a final siege by Yeovil, with the centre- back Terry Skiverton thrown forward, Tom White saw his bullet blocked by Billy Turley.

The old ground is a supermarket now - no doubt with all the grapefruits down in one corner. The climax would have been even better there - a breathless close at the Huish.

fields.headline: Moravcik's party piece
fields.trailText: Celtic rang the changes yesterday before being presented with the SPL trophy at Parkhead.
fields.body:
As hosts should, Celtic raked through their wardrobe to dress appropriately for the formal handing over the Scottish Premier League trophy yesterday. A couple of new numbers were tried, donned in the spirit of experimentation.

Comfortable combinations were also rejigged in the hope of creating a more dramatic impression but, in the end, there was no disguising the fact that Celtic looked best in their most familiar garb.

When Lubomir Moravcik came on as a 62nd-minute substitute to score five minutes later, converting a diagonal pass from Henrik Larsson who had been sent on his way by a clever flick from Tommy Johnson, not only was the SPL trophy poised to be handed over to the champions in the appropriate circumstance of victory, it was further proof that Celtic are at their most complete when their look is as it has been for most of the season.

The absence of Chris Sutton and Neil Lennon could not be entirely ignored but all it did was provide Paul Lambert with the stage to do what everyone knows he can by way of calm authority.

Celtic's manager Martin O'Neill had intimated last week that, with the title wrapped up and a place in the Scottish Cup final to prepare for, fringe players would be given their chance to impress. Colin Healy and Jackie McNamara were the lucky recipients. Whereas Lennon was attending the funeral of his grandmother, Sutton was not even on the bench, fuelling much idle speculation.

His reasoning thus posted in advance, O'Neill put Didier Agathe on the left, the wide player's cut inside and 22-yard thundering shot off Antti Niemi's bar in the fifth minute telling him one thing: Agathe is more comfortable on the right.

When he deployed the same ruse 20 minutes later, this time from just within the Hearts box, Niemi needed to use both fists to clear to safety. The expected switch of flanks came in the 55th minute as Celtic reverted to type.

The change ignited immediate improvement. Unshackled, Agathe started blazing a trail and Celtic were more at ease with themselves. A few minutes later Moravcik's arrival would provide further proof of Celtic's best formation.

Hearts, of course, had reason to be less than compliant guests at the party. Harbouring hopes of qualifying for the Uefa Cup in fourth place, they set out to frustrate. Determination and the occasional breakaway could never, however, amount to a fail-safe protection.

Good fortune provided the insurance that allowed the visitors to survive as long as they did. But, in party mood, Celtic could afford to be generous. A cacophony of sound was soon to burst forth as the trophy was held aloft.
