fields.headline: Holloway lacks security
fields.trailText: Eight years ago QPR finished fifth in the Premiership. Next season they will be scrapping in the Second Division after their worst league campaign in 34 years ended in inevitable relegation.
fields.byline: Christopher Stocks  at the McAlpine stadium
fields.body:
Eight years ago QPR finished fifth in the Premiership ahead of Arsenal, Liverpool and Leeds. Next season they will be scrapping with the likes of Brentford, Brighton and Bury after their worst league campaign in 34 years.

But it is not just the humiliation of dropping down to English football's third tier that will hurt QPR. Financially, especially for a club in administration and losing £570,000 a month, the cost of relegation will be huge.

From next season the Football League's £350m three-year television deal with ONdigital and ITV to screen Nationwide football begins. That will bring each First Division club £3m a season, but by contrast QPR will pick up £750,000 in the Second Division. With other revenues estimated to fall by £1.8m as a result of dropping into the Second Division, the total cost of relegation is estimated at £4m.

To compound these problems QPR are still looking for a new owner, 22 players are out of contract at the end of the season and their sponsors, the troubled mobile phone company Ericsson, look likely to abandon them after this campaign.

For QPR's distraught manager Ian Holloway the situation is clearly a big worry. "I've got a one-year contract but that is not security in this game," he said. "I came here with a long-term plan and wanted to put certain things in place, so I'll have to do that in the Second Division now.

"What you want is stability and there has got to be some sort of plan, but I'm disappointed that the people I had an interview with aren't going to be here next season."

Although QPR's demise has been on the cards for some time, the manner of their defeat on Saturday was unkind. A rip-roaring first half saw Huddersfield take the lead through a deflected Dean Gorre shot. But the visitors stuck manfully to their task and were rewarded two minutes before the interval when the deadline-day signing Andy Thomson lobbed Nico Vaesen to score his fourth goal in four games.

However, a second period of numbing tedium was brought to a dramatic conclusion in the third minute of injury-time when Delroy Facey slotted home Lee Harper's save from an Andy Booth shot to condemn QPR.

That goal could prove to be priceless for Huddersfield, who now sit three points clear of third-from-bottom Crystal Palace.

Their manager Lou Macari believes that three points from the last three games should secure safety. But with testing fixtures against West Bromwich Albion, Wimbledon and Birmingham ahead, Huddersfield could yet join QPR in the Second Division.

fields.headline: Gritty Wolves feed on scraps
fields.trailText: Blackburn had been sitting pretty in the race for automatic promotion until Wolves pricked a hole in their three-point cushion and now anything less than victory in their game in hand at Grimsby tomorrow will leave them severely deflated.
fields.body:
Blackburn had been sitting pretty in the race for automatic promotion until Wolves pricked a hole in their three-point cushion and now anything less than victory in their game in hand at Grimsby tomorrow will leave them severely deflated.

Rovers lead Bolton, victors on Saturday, by only one point after this bout of Thunder in Wolverhampton. Fights broke out on the pitch, David Dunn's challenge on Andy Sinton left the victim hobbling off and Eyal Berkovic flipped after a midfield tangle with the Wolves midfielder Carl Robinson. Marcus Bent manfully restrained him as he tried to wriggle free and square up to Robinson, but the pair clashed again in open play soon after.

The poisonous air that hung over Molineux's vast pastures had much to do with the erratic refereeing of Paul Danson, who reached for his yellow card eight times without ever taking full control of a tense game.

Danson, removed from the Premier League list in 1997, suffered the ignominy of being engulfed by stewards at the end of each half and leaving the pitch to venomous boos.

"What can I say without getting into trouble?" sighed Blackburn's manager Graeme Souness. Wolves' Dave Jones permitted himself a wry smile and said: "Me and Graeme said at half-time we were going to make a comeback. If we could get away with those tackles we would be all right."

A fearsome spell of Blackburn pressure early in the second half seemed to be sowing the seeds for an away win, but from little acorns did mighty Oakes grow. Wolves' goalkeeper Michael was inspired, leaping to push Dunn's shot round the post, rising to tip Matt Jansen's header over the bar and skidding along his goalline with a leg outstretched to nudge Gary Flitcroft's effort on to the post and away to safety.

Oakes also denied Dunn a wonder goal after a mazy run late on, but by then the masses of blue-and-white support knew it was not their day.

It was for Souness two points lost rather than a point gained. "I hope we don't come to regret not taking our chances," he conceded. "It was a game we should have won."

fields.headline: Derby dicing with doom
fields.trailText: Some of Jim Smith's famed durability may need to rub off on his players if their sudden air of vulnerability is not to prove fatal.
fields.body:
If it is true that the character of a football side is reflected by the manager's personality, Derby County should survive with something to spare. Even so, some of Jim Smith's famed durability may need to rub off on his players if their sudden air of vulnerability is not to prove fatal.

Smith made it clear on Saturday that, for all the conjecture about his future, he had no intentions of relinquishing his position and, from the way he was talking, clearly believes next season will be spent in the high-brow company of the Premiership rather than the hoi polloi of the First Division.

Yet, while there may still be a five-point buffer between Derby and Coventry, there is still the potential for everything to go belly-up.

Their final matches of a tempestuous season will pit them against the Premiership's top three teams: at home to Arsenal and Ipswich with a trip to Manchester United in between. If Derby's season is now a game of three-card brag, the dealer has been most unkind.

One certainty is that if they perform as listlessly as at Valley Parade their fate will be reliant on how potent Coventry's powers of escapology are these days.

Smith was positively claret, although whether through anger or embarrassment was unclear. Most of his ire was directed towards Neale Barry, which was harsh on the referee who missed two penalties for Bradford and correctly refused three for Derby when, after a pallid first-half display, it finally seemed to dawn on the visitors that they were playing the Premiership's worst team.

There could certainly be no disputing that Barry was right to send off Seth Johnson just before the hour for a vicious, lunge on Stuart McCall. "He will be fined, make no mistake about that," said Smith. "It was a total brainstorm."

For Bradford their first back-to-back wins of the season may have earned nothing more than a stay of execution but, with relegation all but a formality, a weight of pressure has been lifted and suddenly they are playing with something close to self-belief.

It is somewhat typical of their campaign that Ashley Ward's two goals meant he had trebled his league tally for the season in one afternoon. Next April should see Bradford challenging for the First Division play-offs. Whether they will meet Derby on the way remains to be seen.

fields.headline: Capitulation compounds Bates' new fight for control
fields.trailText: Following this defeat by Charlton, Chelsea's players could have their summer holiday cut short by the Intertoto Cup at the same time as their chairman, Ken Bates may be fighting off a hostile takeover bid.
fields.body:
Alan Curbishley is a demanding manager. He recited the number of injuries that have dogged his team's return to the Premiership and still declared that Charlton had "underachieved" this season. Surely the charge should be levelled at Chelsea, blessed with the resources that tempted many to tip them as champions.

No one appears, after this demoralising defeat, to know where Chelsea are headed. Their head coach Claudio Ranieri has ruled out the Champions League: "It needs a miracle and I don't really believe in miracles." That leaves the Uefa Cup or the Intertoto Cup. The chairman Ken Bates knows which one the team would prefer: "The players want the full holiday . . . what better incentive for them?"

Indeed this summer could be a long, challenging one for both the team and the master of Stamford Bridge. Bates faces another threat to his control with Matthew Harding's widow reportedly about to join a hostile takeover bid for Chelsea.

Ruth Gist, who has remarried since the charismatic Chelsea director's death in 1996, is ready to talk to the telecommunications mogul Peter Harrison, reputedly worth £270m, who claims he is putting together a consortium to remove the chairman. Needless to say, Bates, who once said he would be at Chelsea until he is 100 or dies - whichever is the sooner - will fight this battle with inimitable doggedness.

How Chelsea could have done with some of their chairman's pugnacity as they failed again to dispatch a so-called lesser team. They could have done with some of Bates's straight talking too. Ranieri's debriefing shed little light on his side's puzzling performance and his own questionable changes, most strikingly the replacement of Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink and Gianfranco Zola for the second half.

There was "no logical explanation" for this display, said Ranieri. "After five minutes I could see it wasn't the same side that came out at Tottenham. Gianfranco and Jimmy were a little more tired than the other players." While "not wanting to take anything away from Charlton's skill and determination", he suggested that Chelsea had been dragged down a level.

Charlton kept the ball in play, minimising error while encouraging Chelsea to make mistakes. The emerging Scott Parker and Claus Jensen, both committed and skilful, dominated midfield. Ranieri responded by ringing the changes up front in the second period: first Gustavo Poyet and Eidur Gudjohnsen, then Gudjohnsen and Mario Stanic and, finally, a full-frontal four of Poyet, Gudjohnsen, Stanic and Dennis Wise.

For all this, Sasa Ilic had one shot to save, from a Hasselbaink free-kick back in the 13th minute. Ilic spilled that effort and got away with it. Carlo Cudicini did not 22 minutes later when Jensen was allowed to deliver a long, low shot that Chelsea's goalkeeper should have held but diverted to Shaun Bartlett. The South African's response was as efficient as his side's performance.

Bartlett, on loan from FC Zurich, is about to become a permanent member of Charlton's squad which, said Curbishley, "is the biggest and strongest we have ever had". But like Chelsea, they have travelled poorly. "We should have won at least four or five away games," Curbishley insisted.

Man of the match: Claus Jensen (Charlton).

fields.headline: Burley chases Gunners' tail
fields.trailText: They were 2-1 on to be relegated at the start of the season, but this victory against Coventry has effectively qualified Ipswich for the Uefa Cup at the very least.
fields.body:
It took them four consecutive play-off attempts to get promotion, they were 2-1 on to be relegated at the start of the season, but Ipswich have delighted in proving that you do not have to be a giant of the game to produce a successful side and this victory against Coventry City not only kept them in third place in the league but also effectively qualified them for the Uefa Cup.

In fact, so well are Ipswich playing that a place in the lesser of Europe's club competitions is the last thing on their minds. "To be honest we're looking for more now, because we're still in the race for the Champions League, and if we win all our three remaining games then we are there," said Martijn Reuser, the scorer of their first goal on Saturday.

Ipswich must play Charlton away, Manchester City at home and Derby County away, and as they are only a point behind Arsenal, who are in second place, it is not inconceivable that they could end the season as Premiership runners-up. It would be an incredible feat for a side built from unsung players who have "been through the mill", as Mark Lawrenson put it on Match of the Day. So much for the yo-yo effect.

"It's an unbelievable achievement for a team that's just got promoted," said their manager George Burley. "We're not a club that can spend big money, but we're a fantastic club with great enthusiasm, a tremendous board, and the whole set-up over the last five or six years has grown. We've come into the Premiership, worked very hard with the squad we've got and been able to compete on the field with other clubs who have got maybe four or five times more money to spend."

Since losing to Aston Villa on March 10, Ipswich have won five and drawn one, and Coventry, despite their own good run of form, were never able to withstand such an impetus. The contest was as good as settled in one second-half minute. After 55 minutes John Hartson played Craig Bellamy in on goal but the £5m forward, who has always looked like a panic buy after the loss of Robbie Keane, could only shoot across the face of goal. When Ipswich moved the ball to the opposite end Gary Breen presented the ball to Jermaine Wright and his fearsome shot gave them a cushion they were never going to relinquish.

Reuser's excellent strike had put Ipswich ahead in the 20th minute and after that the Coventry who beat Sunderland on Easter Monday, pushed Manchester United to the limit at Old Trafford and vanquished Derby and Leicester before that, gradually faded into anonymity.

Gordon Strachan was at a loss to explain their ineffectual display. "If we play like that we might as well pack it in and go down and save the supporters any money, any travelling, any enthusiasm they've got, because if we do that again we're not staying up, it's a simple as that," said the Coventry manager.

With only three games to save themselves, Coventry are staring relegation in the face. That they are five points behind Derby, Everton and Middlesbrough, who are tied on 38, means they are reliant on others slipping up, and it is possible that their fate will hinge on thelast game, at home to Bradford on May 19. What that will do to Strachan's nerves hardly bears thinking about.

For Coventry's fans there is at least one consolation. They have been voted 10th best-dressed in the country in a survey by Burtons menswear, up from 72nd last season. If only their team were as on the ball.

Man of the match: Matt Holland (Ipswich).
